fields.bodyText: Poor Nick Brown. The agriculture minister must be dropping on his hooves. He has always resembled a sheep, ambling up to the fence to peer myopically at visitors, but now he looks as if his legs are about to buckle under him. Even Tim Yeo, the Tory spokesman, had a kind word yesterday. "May I offer my sympathy for the substantial burden he is carrying?" he asked. No Tory ever said that to Peter Mandelson. The great panic continues and gets more hysterical by the day. Foot and mouth disease is a non-fatal illness which can't harm humans and used to be cured by slapping tarry rags on to beasts which caught it. So it's now been decided that hundreds of thousands of animals must die and large parts of Britain closed down. It's as if you got a call from your child's teacher explaining that he had cold sores, so that all the children would need to be locked permanently into the school. He himself would have to be put down in case any of his classmates caught the infection. You might consider this an overreaction. Anyhow, this is the route the government has gone down, and like Mr Yeo, one can only sympathise with the poor sod who has to put it into action, with no certainty that it will ever work. fields.headline: Work, work, work
fields.standfirst:
Unemployment has fallen below a million, which is a good reason for Labour to celebrate. But the economic outlook is bleak

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: So Labour  is working again. Of all the social and economic advances made in the past four years, none has greater symbolic significance for the party than this week's news that unemployment has fallen below 1m.
fields.body:
So Labour is working again. Of all the social and economic advances made in the past four years, none has greater symbolic significance for the party than this week's news that unemployment has fallen below 1m.

It was the rise above 1m for the first time since the war in July 1975 that helped to cement Labour's defeat at the 1979 general election. Now that ghost of the party's past has finally been laid to rest.

It hardly came as a surprise, therefore, that the government should choose to celebrate the moment with a high-profile press conference attended by Tony Blair, Gordon Brown and two other cabinet heavy-hitters, David Blunkett and Alistair Darling. The low level of unemployment, together with the low level of inflation, is a key factor in the feel-good factor which places Labour is far ahead of the Tories in the polls. With a general election approaching, you could hardly blame Labour for wanting to exploit the moment to the full.

But are the figures as good as they look? How much credit does Labour deserve for the decline in the jobless total? Is the fall sustainable?

While clearly an important milestone, the 1m figure should not be taken too seriously because it excludes up to 3m people who are disqualified from receiving benefits but are nevertheless looking for work or are not currently active in the labour market for various reasons. These can include family re sponsibilities. The headline figures also mask a structural shift away from manufacturing to service sector employment, which is often, though not always, poorly paid.

Despite the caveats, the trend in the labour market is in the right direction. Since coming to power the claimant count has fallen by 667,000, a 40% cut, the International Labour Organisation definition is down 556,000, a fall of 27%, and employment is up by more than 1m.

The government likes to give the impression that this extremely favourable environment is entirely due to the success of its policies; but thanks to successful macro-economic management by Mr Brown's predecessor, Kenneth Clarke, and structural reform of the labour market begun by Mrs Thatcher in the 80s, unemployment was already on a sharp downward trend well before Labour came to power. The best that can be said for the government is that it has cemented those gains by making the Bank of England independent and making no major policy errors, although Conservatives say the extra employment regulation introduced by Labour, including the minimum wage and working time directive, has actually slowed the downward trend in unemployment.

The impact of the new deal, the government's flagship programme for getting people off welfare and into work, is still hotly disputed. Mr Brown said it had helped to get 270,000 young people into work but research by the National Institute of Economic and Social Research, a leading economic think tank, suggests its influence has been marginal. The much more important factor has been the buoyancy of demand for labour. The new deal is, however, widely regarded as qualitatively better than any previous government jobs scheme, offering tailored rather than blanket advice to benefit recipients and helping to instil positive attitudes to work.

The question of whether the fall in unemployment is sustainable is the most difficult question to answer of all. Subdued average earnings growth suggests that it can continue to go lower without stoking inflationary pressure despite the existence of severe skills shortages in some parts of the country. The bigger worry is not so much whether the jobless total can continue falling, as whether it will soon begin to rise.

Understandably, the prime minister did not mention this week's wild gyrations on the markets when he stood at the podium at the Industrial Society on Wednesday, but they could herald a severe deterioration in the global economy which could have serious consequences for the UK labour market.

Already, the job cuts in the IT sector which have been a feature of the US economic scene for some time are beginning to be repeated here. Motorola and Cable & Wireless both said this week that they will shed staff as a result of the global downturn in demand for their products. So far the numbers of people losing their jobs are being more than offset by the num ber of new ones created but for how long will net job gains continue?

Hi-tech companies which over-invested in the upswing will undoubtedly have to retrench further to remain profitable even if in the long-term they will remain an important source of jobs growth. The grave danger is that the malaise infecting the hi-tech sector begins to spread. While few should care if inflated hi-tech share prices come back down to earth, there are concerns among central bankers that the loss of wealth associated with these declines could trigger a collapse of consumer spending in the United States.

If America goes into recession, Britain is likely to be one of the main casualties. Apart from the direct trade links, the two countries invest heavily in each other and Britain also happens to be home to one of the major global financial centres. The economy's dependence on the City for wealth creation means that Britain will suffer disproportionately from a bear market in financial assets.

Thanks to strong growth in household disposable income this year, domestic demand should remain robust even if the internationally exposed parts of the economy suffer. The weakness of inflation means that the Bank of England's monetary policy committee has ample room to cut interest rates if consumer spending begins to flag. However, the economic outlook now seems more uncertain than at any time in the past four years and is more likely than not to deteriorate in the months ahead. No wonder Mr Blair is anxious not to let foot and mouth get in the way of a May election.

Mark Atkinson is the Guardian's economics correspondent.

fields.headline: Letters add to pressure on Vaz
fields.standfirst:
Publication of letters new blow for Vaz


Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: The reputation of the foreign office minister, Keith Vaz, is expected to suffer a new blow today with the detailed publication of 20 letters between him, his solicitors and Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary standards watchdog, showing how the embattled minister prevaricated and refused to answer questions about his affairs.
fields.body:
The reputation of the foreign office minister, Keith Vaz, is expected to suffer a new blow today with the detailed publication of 20 letters between him, his solicitors and Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary standards watchdog, showing how the embattled minister prevaricated and refused to answer questions about his affairs.

At the same time, he accused those giving evidence to her inquiry of malice, memory loss and introducing irrelevancies.

The saga of the letters ends with his solicitor, Geoffrey Bindman, saying Mr Vaz would refuse to answer any more questions from her and would only talk to the committee. The letters will form part of a huge tranche of documents and include detailed evidence from all the main participants in the eight-month inquiry.

Mrs Filkin complained that Mr Vaz's refusal to answer questions had prevented her from reaching conclusions on eight of the 18 allegations against him, and the committee was critical of his failure to cooperate with her. Mr Vaz was cleared of nine allegations of accepting thousands of pounds to his office and charities. He was found to have breached one rule - not declaring that he had received two small donations from a City solicitor he recommneded for an honour.

The committee decided not to uphold another eight allegations - mainly due to the fact that they could not get hard evidence because Mr Vaz would not hand over documents and because other documents, such as bank state ments, had been lost or destroyed.

Some documents will not be published. They include two damning letters from Labour MP Claire Ward to national party officers accusing the minister of "disgraceful, initimidatory and contemptous behaviour " during a previous internal Labour inquiry, which were leaked to the Guardian yesterday. But it will contain details of three meetings between the Watford MP and Mrs Filkin about her concerns over Mr Vaz.

Yesterday Mr Vaz spoke for the first time about the inquiry's findings. He told BBC Radio Cambridgeshire: "I was cleared by the privileges committee, I was cleared by Mrs Filkin and no action is to be taken. The simple reason is that those who put forward maliciously false complaints have had their evidence turned over by Mrs Filkin."

He had decided to stop answering the commissioner's questions last December because he wished to bring the inquiry to an end, in order to quash allegations that he did not want it completed, he said.

"It reached a stage where it had to go to the committee so that those making allegations had to give evidence in front of the committee.

"What was vital was that we had a conclusion and the conclusion was put before the committee and they rejected all the allegations - all but a very minor allegation, and they accepted that nothing had been wrong in terms of the way in which matters were conducted on that."

Asked if one such charge upheld would be "mortally damaging" for a cabinet minister, he said: "Well, it would, but I'm not in the cabinet".

Mr Vaz's explanation however did not satisfy members of the standards and privileges committee or Lord Neill's committee on standards in public life.

Tory committee member Peter Bottomley said Mr Vaz's claim that he had been cleared was "hopeful" and that his summary of the report's findings was "pretty selective". "I think the report basically speaks for itself," he said. "He and his solicitor flatly refused to go on cooperating with [Mrs Filkin]. That was wrong."

A Liberal Democrat member of the committee on standards in public life added his voice to calls for Mr Vaz to go.

Lord Goodhart said: "I think there is a duty on all MPs, and that includes very much ministers as well, to co-operate with any inquiry. Frankly, Mr Vaz was entirely wrong in failing to do so and should go or be removed.

"If a minister refuses to co-operate with the standards commissioner, it seems to me very difficult to see how the prime minister can continue to have confidence in that minister."

Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, said: "Mr Vaz has at last admitted that the complaint upheld against him is a resigning offence. He should now get on with it and resign. The foreign minister's conduct is unbecoming. His interviews have been a catalogue of evasions and half-truths."

The view from Downing Street was very different. "Mr Vaz has the prime minister's full support. End of story," said a spokesman.

fields.headline: Labour's lead up to 26 points
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText:
Labour's lead over the Conservatives has
extended to 26 points, the biggest lead since
1998, according to a Gallup poll in today's Daily
Telegraph. It puts Labour on 55%, up 6 points from
last month, with the Tories unchanged on 29%.
The Liberal Democrats have slipped to 12%.
fields.body:
Labour's lead over the Conservatives has extended to 26 points, the biggest lead since 1998, according to a Gallup poll in today's Daily Telegraph. It puts Labour on 55%, up 6 points from last month, with the Tories unchanged on 29%. The Liberal Democrats have slipped to 12%.

But support for a May election appears to be ebbing. A poll for Channel 4 News last night showed only a third of voters backed May, down from two-thirds less than a week ago.

English local elections must formally get under way on March 26. To postpone them legislation would have to be rushed through parliament next week. The Home Office insists there are no plans for delay.

The Conservative leader, William Hague, commenting on the Channel 4 poll, said: "It is a sign of how seriously people take this crisis and I think it is quite right that they do so."

fields.headline: TV ads on benefit for old 'an expensive flop'
fields.trailText: A £15m government advertising campaign to promote benefits to pensioners has turned out to be a costly flop, reports Nicholas Watt.
fields.body:
A £15m government advertising campaign to promote benefits to pensioners, which was fronted by actress Dame Thora Hird, has turned out to be a costly flop, according to figures released yesterday.

Out of 2.4m pensioners contacted by the government, a mere 82,000 have been accepted for minimum income guarantee. The minimum income was launched last year to ensure that less well off pensioners receive income support they are entitled to. Dame Thora fronted television ad vertisements to raise awareness of the scheme, described by the government as "central to our strategy for tackling pensioner poverty".

David Willetts, the shadow social security secretary, said that the poor take-up showed that the campaign had been an "expensive flop".

Social security department figures showed that 2.4m letters were sent out to pensioners potentially eligible for the benefit. Of these, 840,000 inquired about the benefit, while 182,000 sent in application forms. A mere 82,000 had their applications accepted. Mr Willetts said: "Ministers have repeatedly dodged our questions on the minimum income guarantee take-up campaign."

Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, said last night: "David Willetts wants to keep pensioners in ignorance of a benefit that will make a huge difference to them - an extra £20 a week on average."

fields.trailText: Good day |  Bad day | Today
fields.body:
Good day

Peter Mandelson. At pains to convince he is happy as a humble backbencher, the former Northern Ireland secretary spoke in the Commons for the first time since he was cleared by the Hammond report. He asked the education secretary, David Blunkett, if he would agree that a 750 jobs boost was "fulfilment of the government's pledge to spread prosperity throughout the regions". Mr Blunkett did.

Bad day

Health minister Lord Hunt blew his chances of a Foreign Office move when he placed the Netherlands in Scandinavia. As he realised his mistake, he continued: "Oh, um, I wasn't allowed to take O-level in geography, my lords. You will understand why."

Today

Commons: Backbench bills. Christmas day (trading) bill, second reading. Transplant of human organs bill, second reading. Private dental practitioners bill, second reading. Lords: Terrorism Act 2000 (proscribed organisations) (amendment) order 2001.

webTitle: Party overrules complaint of Birmingham 'vote rigging'

fields.headline: Party overrules complaint of Birmingham 'vote rigging'
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: The Labour leadership has overruled complaints about grassroots vote rigging in the Birmingham seat of Perry Barr in order to endorse the candidacy of a controversial community development officer who now looks set to become the first Asian MP from Britain's second city.
fields.body:
The Labour leadership has overruled complaints about grassroots vote rigging in the Birmingham seat of Perry Barr in order to endorse the candidacy of a controversial community development officer who now looks set to become the first Asian MP from Britain's second city.

Khalid Mahmood, a 39-year-old Kashmiri Muslim, was this week picked to succeed Jeff Rooker, social security minister and local MP for 27 years, despite two attempts to stall the proceedings - including a failed application for an injunction in the high hourt in London.

The Birmingham party has been the scene of faction fighting and legal actions for many years, aggravated by tensions witin rival ethnic minorities in the city.

Complaints against Mr Mahmood include his sudden disappearance from Birmingham for over a year shortly after first being elected a city coun cillor, and the collapse of the council-backed British Kashmiri Association with huge debts in 1994.

Mr Rooker believes he should not be an MP.

Twenty-four hours after Mr Mahmood won the vacant nomination on Sunday - by a decisive 196 votes to 82 for Sukhvinder Stubbs, the runner-up - Labour's ruling national executive committee endorsed his candidacy and the assurance of its regional officials that no impropriety had occurred.

Ms Stubbs, a high flying Sikh who was the first pupil from the local Broadway comprehensive to go to university - she won an Oxford First - was chief executive of the Runnymede Trust and sits on the of regional development agency, Advantage West Midlands.

Her supporters complain that she was the victim of both ethnic and gender prejudice.

Rival camps have also signed statements complaining that Mr Mahmmod's team ob tained postal votes for party members in Perry Barr, in some cases without their permission, and cast them for their candidate.

Their appeal to a high court judge in London on Friday night was rejected.

Complaints to party HQ at Millbank were also ignored. At the selecton meeting on Sunday appeals for one week's delay were also overturned and Mr Mahmood went on to beat seven rivals.

Critics, including Mr Rooker who backed Ms Stubbs, predict that the decision will prove a long-term embarrassment for Labour, even if it holds the north west Birmingham seat where the 1997 majority was 18,957 over the Tories.

Kashmiri Muslims from Pakistan dominate the constituency organisation - and backed Mr Mahmood - although they are outnumbered by the Sikh and Hindu voters in Perry Bar.

Together they constitute only 35% of voters in the mainly white constituency.

webTitle: BBC governors have outlived their usefulness, says Kaufman

fields.headline: BBC governors have outlived their usefulness, says Kaufman
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The BBC's board of governors yesterday came under a withering attack from Gerald Kaufman, chairman of the commons media select committee.
fields.body:
The BBC's board of governors yesterday came under a withering attack from Gerald Kaufman, chairman of the commons media select committee, who suggested they had "outlived their usefulness".

Launching the committee's report on the communications white paper, Mr Kaufman said the BBC should be brought fully under the remit of Ofcom, the government's proposed regulator for the media and telecoms industries. The report said the regulation of the BBC was "unfinished business".

The committee also recommended that approval of any new BBC services be taken out of the hands of the culture secretary, Chris Smith, and given to Ofcom.

"It seems utterly anomalous that there should be one broadcasting organisation only in the country that does not come under the remit of Ofcom," said Mr Kaufman. "What is being relied upon is that the BBC has its own public accountability through the board of governors.

"But with respect to the excellent individuals who sit on the board, whether in this day and age of ever-advancing technology they are the best people for the job must be open to doubt." The comments endorsed the lobbying of the commercial broadcasting sector which has complained hard that the BBC should be subject to the same regulation.

A BBC spokeswoman said the corporation welcomed debate raised by the report but warned there was a danger that wrapping its regulation into Ofcom could put com mercial needs ahead of the public interest.

The report also recommended the scrapping of Mr Smith's department of culture, media and sport and the establishment of a broader department of communications.

The committee also suggested that complex rules governing cross media ownership should be abandoned and the limits on consolidation in the radio industry be removed.

It criticised the government's handling of the switch-off of the analogue television signal between 2006-2010. The report called for a public information campaign to explain digital TV and a kite-mark to clear up confusion over what sets can receive digital signals.

webTitle: Debate rages over rights of way policy

fields.headline: Debate rages over rights of way policy
fields.standfirst:
Ramblers Access rules differ across the country

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Huge discrepancies in reactions to the crisis by local authorities are emerging as the government's rural recovery taskforce urgently looks at which parts of the countryside need to be closed to the public.
fields.body:
Huge discrepancies in reactions to the crisis by local authorities are emerging as the government's rural recovery taskforce urgently looks at which parts of the countryside need to be closed to the public.

"There is a very big debate going on at the moment about rights of way," said Ewen Cameron, the chairman of the countryside agency and a member of the taskforce.

Many authorities have imposed blanket closures on footpaths in their areas, with devastating effects on rural life. Only 15 of 125 local authorities contacted by the countryside agency said they had taken care to close only rights of way in risk areas.

"People have been confused in the absence of clear advice about what they can and can't do," said a spokesman for the English tourism council.

About 50 local authorities have applied blanket closures to rights of way, many in areas where there are no confirmed outbreaks. Buckinghamshire, East Sussex and Lincolnshire have closed all rights of way, including those in urban areas, although they have no outbreaks."We have done it as a blanket ban, as a precaution," said an East Sussex county council spokesman.

Bedfordshire, Norfolk, and Suffolk, which are also free of foot and mouth so far, have closed rights of way in rural areas but kept urban routes open.

Yet in Northumberland, where the outbreak was first identified, and on Exmoor and Dartmoor in Devon, which has seen several outbreaks, rights of way were closed only where land was or had been grazed by livestock.

The risk of the disease being transmitted by walkers on footpaths is "low but not zero", said Professor Colin Blackstock, the director of the government's institute of animal health. "Is it appropriate to close all footpaths across all of the country? I think it is right to close them where they go over farm land where there might have been contact with susceptible animals."

The ministry of agriculture put in place statutory powers to enable local authorities to close rights of way at the end of February but decisions were delegated to local level.

"Veterinary advice is available to local councils. General guidance is that people should avoid contact with livestock. Maff's role is to manage the outbreak, not to dictate to councils what to do," said a ministry spokesman.

The National Trust and English Heritage, two of Britain's largest rural landlords, have adopted different policies.

The National Trust has closed all but 16 of its 630 properties (the exceptions being those in urban areas), and all its 240,000 hectares of land. But English Heritage, which has 409 properties, has only closed the 180 in or near areas with confirmed outbreaks.

Both organisations said yesterday they believed they were following government guidelines.

webTitle: The danger of being dazzled by wealth

fields.headline: The danger of being dazzled by wealth
fields.standfirst:
Roy Hattersley says there is no way back for a Minister who enjoyed living dangerously - and paid for it

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: March 16: Roy Hattersley says there is no way back for a Minister who enjoyed living dangerously - and paid for it.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson told no lies, attempted no deception and made no overt effort to influence the outcome of the Hinduja brothers' passport application. But he had to go. And no Prime Minister with an instinct for self-preservation will ever bring him back.

Technically his crime was nothing like as serious as David Willetts's attempt to deceive a House of Commons select committee. And Willetts is now back on the Tory front bench and about to draft the Conservative election manifesto. But he was found guilty only once. Mandelson has been in a succession of scrapes, and, innocent or not, the pattern of his conduct had become intolerable. He enjoyed living dangerously, and fell off the high wire far too often.

Although Mandelson was acquitted of all charges, the report exposes a Whitehall machine which is complacent, incompetent and (in a very gentlemanly fashion) institutionally corrupt. The indictment is not that Ministers and civil servants treated the Hindujas in an exceptional way, nor that they helped them by breaking the rules. The report reveals that the rules which are regularly applied - when compounded by a demeaning reverence for wealth - are a disgrace.

Among the working-class black and Asian British, the Home Office is notorious for the unsympathetic way in which it treats run-of-the-mill nationality applications. Yet in 1998 Ministers and civil servants competed with each other to give Strichand Hinduja a swift and easy passage. Shameful, but neither improper nor illegal.

It is possible to relax some of the basic citizenship requirements 'in the special circumstances of any particular case'. So Andrew Walmsley, head of the Nationality Directorate, suggested that Rule D - which requires 450 days' residence in the UK during the five years before application - might be waived. Hinduja had been paying British taxes.

There is no doubt why Hinduja was treated with such deference. In his note to Ministers, Walmsley emphasised a special attribute which he regarded as worthy of 'consideration' when the application for citizenship was considered: 'The family business empire has a corporate wealth of $6-$8 billion and their personal wealth was estimated in 1991 at £500m.'

That wide-eyed description of the brothers' fortune solves the whole Hinduja riddle. It explains why William Hague was photographed with him, Tony Blair accepted invitations to his parties and Peter Mandelson acted as his messenger boy. Sadly, New Labour, no less than the Tories, is hypnotised by big bank balances. Wealth is regarded as synonymous with virtue and success. The mafia of power and money binds Ministers to men who should not be allowed within a mile of No 10.

And the money buys privilege. The Hammond Report is explicit about that. Most people who know how Whitehall works will believe that the Mandelson phone call, whatever its formal purpose, guaranteed Hinduja special consideration. But the evidence proves that he was getting it already. As head of the Nationality Directorate, Walmsley 'tended to deal with high-profile cases himself'. And, partly because of his rank and partly because of his lighter case load, his applications progressed more quickly than those processed by his staff. Ergo, high visibility guaranteed speedy attention. So much for equality before the law.

Walmsley has moved on. We should be grateful for that. He was not sure of the exact number of days Strichand Hinduja had spent in the country immediately before his nationality application, and he did not require him to apply again after his first attempt had failed. References, he said, were useless since they were usually complimentary.

Not all of them. Caroline Elmes of the Foreign Office wrote to say that: 'At the very least, the Hinduja brothers can be said to sail close to the wind.' When he reported to Ministers, Walmsley put it differently. 'At the time of his earlier application there were doubts about the brothers' ability to meet the requirements to be of good character... These were, however, resolved concerning Mr Gopichand Hinduja's application and there is no reason to believe that Mr Strichand Hinduja would not now meet the requirement.' Tell that to the Indian government which will not let him out of the country.

The problem, as so often, is the whole culture. Money talks. My Birmingham constituents had no more chance of having their citizenship application treated in the Hinduja way than they had of Blair accepting an invitation to one of their parties. And, although, the Prime Minister was right to act decisively in the removal of Mandelson, he must take some responsibility for not changing the Whitehall view that to those who have much, more shall be given. It is hard for him to make the Home Office change its ways with so much rich men's money swilling about Labour.

New Labour is right to denounce old-fashioned socialism's antagonism to success. But success is not a virtue. The least we can accept is that, after the election, the Labour will show some discretion in its choice of millionaires. The Hammond Report proves - almost absentmindedly - the danger of being dazzled by wealth.

webTitle: Week 16: Alice Springs to King's Canyon

fields.headline: Toured out
fields.standfirst: At the end of yet another action-packed week in which she and her tour-group visited Alice Springs, Uluru, King's Canyon and the Western Macdonald Ranges, Sue is looking forward to spending some quality time on her own
fields.trailText: Week 16: Alice Springs to King's Canyon At the end of yet another action-packed week in which she and her tour-group visited Alice Springs, Uluru, King's Canyon and the Western Macdonald Ranges, Sue is looking forward to spending some quality time on her own
fields.body:
Here I am in the very heart of this huge land, and I have to admit to feeling absolutely shattered. This week I have spent seven days with NT Adventure Tours: three days down to Alice Springs, three days in the Uluru (Ayres Rock) area, and a day in the Western Macdonald Ranges. I am in amazing-geology overload. This report and the photos, the product of only a week, cannot do justice to the scenery of this remarkable country.

  It started last Friday from Darwin. 23 18-to-30-something international travellers and I began the 1500km journey to the Alice. Our tour-leader was called Meatloaf, due not only to his appearence but also to his love of heavy-metal music, which accompanied us most of the way. It has rained more than usual over the previous few weeks in north and central Australia so we have been rewarded with much more vegetation than is usual; in fact our first stop, Katherine, had been flooded the previous week. All was calm now, and we took a boat trip down the stunning Katherine Gorge with the inevitable (and welcome) swim at a waterfall and swimming hole. We got our second wash when a storm broke on the boat ride back. Already soaked, we sheltered under the narrow eaves of a hut, priority given to trying to keep our packs and cameras dry. Somebody found a box of black bin liners and it became a test of ingenuity and fashion skills to create raincovers. If  I hadn't wanted to keep my camera dry it would have been a great photo - all these black figures with various holes with heads or just noses sticking out.

The camp that evening resembled a scarecrows' convention, with dripping clothes and towels on every branch.  My boots were full of water - I think the housemaid at Kuching had cleaned them so thoroughly that the proofing went, too. Unfortunately, everything was still wet when it had to be packed up again. I will leave to your imagination how everything smelt by the time we reached laundry facilities at Alice.

On Saturday we ate up the miles down the Stuart Highway, a road that goes in an almost straight line right down to Adelaide - empty apart from tour buses and the occasional road-train (three or more trailers attached to lorries). There were stops at the Mataranka Thermal Springs; the Larrimah pub with its interesting railway museum (the railway used to reach there from Darwin, but had long since been abandoned) and at Daly Waters, a 100-year-old pub where travellers leave their cards or photos.

We finally reached our camp at a horse farm outside the mining town of  Tennant Creek. Here we were introduced to the swag-bag, a large canvas bag with a foam matress in which you put your sleeping bag - zip it up and you are safe from all the elements. This was the first night we were to spend under the star-filled Australian sky.  Most people started off outside, safe from everything - apart from the mosquitos. At regular 10-minute intervals, however, there would be a loud series of expletives and another swag-bag would be rolled up and taken into the tent or kitchen area. I suddenly remembered that I had in fact brought a mozzie net, and six of us formed a star with our heads in the middle and draped the net over our heads. Few of us slept; we were all either too hot, bitten to death, or claustrophobic under the net. The expletives and exodus continued until, in the morning, there were only two Geordie girls, a couple of Danes and me left - the things I do for this website!

On Sunday, there were more miles and heavy-metal until we reached the Devil's Marbles: sandstone eroded down to form huge boulders scattered in groups. This is an Aboriginal dream place, where the women and children gather to pass on stories, including tales of children disappearing, taken by the spirits.  It certainly was impressive and atmospheric.

The landscape was changing now, the trees becoming sparser, the speargrass shorter and more red soil and rock appearing.  Unforgiving country for anyone who leaves the highway unprepared or without the necessary knowledge of how to travel across it. We stopped at one roadhouse to say hello to the inseparable camel and donkey that our tour-guide knew. They came bounding over at once, and the camel immediately stuck his head right into the bus and into the apple box. We finally reached Alice Springs, just in time to do the laundry, have a quick shower and send the odd email before the free dinner and party at the hostel - a raucous affair that I left early, in favour of my bed and air conditioning.

We were up again at 5am to head off for phase two, with one or two new faces (including a new tour-leader), and many of the others still semi-drunk or hungover from the night before. We went first to the Watarrka National Park - the King's Canyon. This is a spectacular gorge where we did an 8km walk high on the cliffs, with a lovely swim half-way round in a rock-pool. How did mother nature know to provide these swimming areas in such strategic places, just when you are exhausted and boiling from walking in 35C temperatures? Bless her! Another night under the stars was planned (no mozzies in this area) but the arrival of a scorpion in the kitchen area sent some scurrying into their tents, and several others opting to spend an uncomfortable night on the bus.  I had a blissful sleep outside, cool and refreshing.

Next day started with a trip to the impressive Uluru Cultural Centre, to read about the rock and how the indigenous people regained it in 1984. Then we went to Kata Tjuta, the Olgas, a huge landmass like Ayres Rock, but broken up into enormous boulders. I admit that I had never heard of this area, but the landscape, the atmosphere, and the 9km walk there made it my  favourite part of the whole tour. The cloud that had made walking pleasant cleared in time for us to join the masses for Uluru at sunset. Coaches, many with elaborate picnics and champagne on ice, abounded. We tried to find as quiet a spot as possible  for our champagne (which we drank out of plastic cups) and biscuits as the sun set, casting shadows on the rock.

Everyone was back again for a repeat performance at dawn. Most of my group had decided not to climb the rock in deference to the Aboriginal people's wishes; the few who wanted to couldn't anyway, as it was too windy and the climb was closed. We all did the 10km base walk, romping round in about an hour and a half and waking up the tour-leader, who had been hoping to catch up on at least three hours sleep while we were away.  It was hard to capture any of the atmosphere of this place as it was so busy - even the walk was awash with people, many ignoring the notices which asked you not to take photographs at sites of great significance to the Aborigines. The tourist can be a crass, destructive creature. I don't know if it was because we were all so tired by now, but many of us found the Rock a bit of an anti-climax, and had preferred either King's Canyon or the Olgas.

So it was back to Alice, and goodbye to most of the group. Only Karen from Canada and I took up the free day at the Western Macdonald Ranges.  This was a nice, relaxed day spent visiting  creeks and gorges, with a pleasant walk that included wading through a thigh-high river. A swim at Ellery Creek Big Hole finished off a good day.

So that was the outback and the Red Centre. I have really enjoyed this glimpse of Australia's bush and all the sights, but I am tiring of tours. They are  a relatively cheap way of seeing as much as possible in a short time, and great for youngsters. The tour-leaders are knowledgable, and the facilities usually good. But at times I have craved the less social - even lonelier - days of wandering around on my own. This is not a criticism of the youngsters, who are a great crowd and  inclusive of all who travel with them,  but I wish there was an affordable alternative for those who don't want to hire a car or join  either buses or tours full of  travellers who are mostly in their early 20s. The only Australians I have met have been the tour-leaders. Maybe in such a huge country I am asking the impossible.

I am looking forward to Cairns tomorrow, where I am meeting up with the actual Australians that I met in Baku National Park in Sarawak. I haven't yet decided how to spend my week there, but I reckon that I've got to give snorkelling on the Barrier Reef a go, even though I don't like putting my head underwater. I'll let you know how I get on.

I am going to have a lazy day today. I need to retrieve my big pack from the storage room. I wonder why it's still so full when I haven't needed anything from it for the last eight days - obviously some serious thinning out needed.

Until next Friday when I hope I will be less tired - goodbye.

webTitle: Graham set to sue over Spurs sacking

fields.headline: Graham set to sue over Spurs sacking
fields.trailText: George Graham today threatened to take legal action against Tottenham following what he called the club's "bizarre and inexplicable" decision to sack him.
fields.body:
George Graham today threatened to take legal action against Tottenham following what he called the club's "bizarre and inexplicable" decision to sack him.

Graham insists the club's new owners ENIC had intended to replace him after taking over the club from Sir Alan Sugar.

A statement issued through his legal representatives said: "Mr Graham has already instructed his solicitors to deal with this matter and will be issuing legal proceedings very shortly if the club does not honour his contract."

The statement, issued via his legal advisers through the Press Association, went on: "George Graham was shocked and extremely upset to have been sacked by Tottenham Hotspur today just two weeks before the most important game of the season for the club.

"When David Buchler told him that they were relieving him of his duties because he had told a press conference that the club had only a limited budget for football transfers, Mr Graham was stunned and could not believe that such a flimsy excuse was being given for his dismissal.

"George Graham said: 'I feel intensely sorry for the fans that the money men who now run the club are endangering the club's morale at this time. Anyone who cares for Spurs will see this is a bizarre and inexplicable decision.

"'Every club has a limited budget and to say that I have broken some confidence in revealing this 'secret' just demonstrates how little the new owners understand about the game. The saddest element for me is that the club had started putting together a great run of results and I had managed to build a wonderful team spirit. All of this is now at risk'.

"Mr Graham believes that ENIC always intended to sack him when they came in and for them to say that it was him who had 'his own agenda' was untrue and a complete reversal of the facts."

Graham's Spurs career ended when he was summoned to an emergency meeting with Spurs executive vice-chairman David Buchler and was told the club could no longer work with him.

It follows Graham revealing at a press conference yesterday details of his meeting this week with Tottenham's new owners ENIC.

In an exclusive interview with PA Sport, Buchler said: "I had a private meeting with George Graham and David Pleat this week and then found this morning details of it plastered across the press.

"I called George in for an explanation today. However, no explanation was forthcoming - and he had a defiant attitude.

"I am building from top to bottom a cohesive team, and this is a difficult time for the club with a semi-final coming up and negotiations with players over contracts.

"We agreed we cannot work with each other. I am not prepared to have someone who is not a team player and who is not looking after the club's interests."

Pleat will take charge of the team for tomorrow's home clash against Coventry, with Tottenham's director of football "happy to step into the breach" according to Buchler.

Buchler has no one in mind for Graham's immediate successor, but it is expected the new man will be in place by April 8 when Spurs face Arsenal in their FA Cup semi-final at Old Trafford.

A list of candidates has already surfaced, including Glenn Hoddle, Gianluca Vialli, Joe Kinnear and Terry Venables among others, and Buchler added: "They are all great names.

"But I did not anticipate it would come to this and I have not spoken to any other manager in relation to the job here. I have nobody else lined up.

"There are lots of names that will go into the hat, and that is something I will be thinking about with the club chairman Daniel Levy during the course of the next week or two."

Two former Tottenham greats were stunned by Graham's dismissal, insisting he had done the best he could in difficult circumstances.

They backed the former Arsenal and Leeds boss to bounce back into football management.

Goalscoring ace Clive Allen said: "I think George feels he's done a good job. The club is in a healthy position at the moment, and he would have probably wanted to push the club on another step next season.

"I'm sure George hasn't enjoyed the experience and I would think he will probably just relax for a while, take stock of what health he's in and where he goes from there.

"But George is a great football manager, and I'd be very surprised if there were not a lot of people who were very interested in having him working for them."

Chris Waddle, who called the news "a very, very surprising decision", said: "He's a first-class manager, but it is very difficult to work under those circumstances.

"I think they ENIC want to get their own people in and they might not be George's cup of tea - and unfortunately for George it has cost him his job.

"But we haven't seen the last of him. He's a very good coach, and I wouldn't be surprised if he goes abroad and becomes a big success over there."

webTitle: Charity hopes to guide homeless into higher education

fields.headline: Charity hopes to guide homeless into higher education
fields.trailText: Homeless young people are to be encouraged into higher education through a new step-by-step guide launched by homeless charity the Foyer Federation today.
fields.body:
Homeless young people are to be encouraged into higher education through a new step-by-step guide launched by homeless charity the Foyer Federation today.

The guide, funded by the Nuffield Foundation, provides practical information for young people about how to access higher education. It also seeks to raise awareness within universities.

The chief executive of the Foyer Federation, Carolyn Hayman said "Whilst working with young homeless people, we have become increasingly aware of the gap between potential and achievement.

"What a lot of people - including the universities - fail to realise is that some homeless people's lack of qualifications may only mean that their home life was so disruptive that they were unable to complete their GCSEs or A'levels. It is not an index of their capabilities."

A spokesperson for Universities UK said: "Encouraging non-traditional potential students is a challenge for everyone who offers guidance - from parents, teachers and support organisations like the Foyer Federation to universities themselves."

Owain James, President of the NUS also welcomed the guide, noting that: "The homeless often face further barriers entering higher education because of the means testing of tuition fees and student loans. Contact with the family will in many cases be non-existent, and the students cannot expect contributions from the parental home to cover tuition fees or living cost."

Talking of the need for young homeless people to have the same opportunities as their peers, Ms Hayman added: "We have just initiated a dialogue with government about providing these young people with the same support as those leaving care. We would like to get homeless youth into a situation where they only face the same level of debt as other students do."

A spokesperson for the DfEE said "We welcome the practical advice in this guide. From 2001, opportunity bursaries of £2,000 will be available to bright young people from less well-off families. It's called the Excellence Challenge. The government is keen to see all young people who can benefit from higher education going to university or college. "

The guide is available from the Foyer Federation on 0207 833 8616.

webTitle: Funding group calls for research bids on diagnostic tests

fields.headline: Funding group calls for research bids on diagnostic tests
fields.standfirst: Special report: Research funding
fields.trailText: A UK funding group launched a call today for scientists interested in developing diagnostic test for transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSEs) such as BSE and variant CJD to submit research proposals.
fields.body:
A UK funding group launched a call today for scientists interested in developing diagnostic test for transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSEs) such as BSE and variant CJD to submit research proposals.

The group, which includes the Medical Research Council, amongst others, has stressed a commitment to fund all high quality proposals for research in this area.

A spokesperson for the MRC said: "We don't ringfence money, so we can't provide an exact figure of the amount which is available. But we drove a similar initiative in 1996 and a total of about £8m was awarded to applicants. We really can't estimate how much will be given this time, suffice to say we are committed to finding funds for all good quality proposals."

Ideas and approaches from a broad spectrum will be welcomed, as applicants are encouraged to think 'creatively' about diagnoses that will benefit human and animal health.

The MRC is coordinating the call on behalf of all the funders, and proposals will be submitted to them in the first instance and then be forwarded to the most relevant of the group's member bodies for consideration.

Sir John Pattison, chairman of the joint funders group on TSEs said: "We have made excellent scientific progress in understanding this group of diseases, but much remains unknown. Reliable diagnostics are crucial to animal and human health.

"We need to try as many approaches as possible to develop a range of diagnostics that in turn, will make the prospect of developing effective treatments and suitable programmes of healthcare for patients and veterinary medicine for animals more of a reality".

As well as the MRC, the funding group includes the Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council, the Department of Health, the Food Standards Agency, and the Ministry of Agriculture Fisheries and Food.

Applications must be submitted by 23 April. Successful applicants will be invited to submit full proposals for peer review in the early summer. Funding decisions are expected from autumn 2001 onwards.

webTitle: Women close the US gender gap

fields.headline: Women close the US gender gap
fields.standfirst: Special report: The education gender gap
fields.trailText: Women constitute a higher percentage of the US university population than ever before, according to a new report released yesterday.
fields.body:
Women constitute a higher percentage of the US university population than ever before, according to a new report released yesterday.

The study, by the US census bureau found that 30% of women aged between 25 and 29 now have a bachelor degree compared with 28% of men in the same age group.

Over all age groups, 27.8% of American men have completed a college education, compared with 23.6% of women- a much smaller gap than 30 years ago.

Women also constitute a rising share of people being awarded college and postgraduate degrees. In 1996, they represented 55% of people awarded bachelor's degrees, 56% of masters' degrees, 40% of doctorates, 41% of medical degrees, and 44% of the law degrees.

All this presents a different picture to the 1970 university figures when just 8.2% of all women had received college degrees, compared with 14.1% of men. In 1970, women meanwhile represented 43% of people awarded bachelor's degrees, 40% of masters' degrees, 14% of doctorates, 8% of medical degrees, and only 5% of the law degrees.

The gap may be closing in higher education, but in the world of work women tend to cluster at the lower paid end of the job market: women with a high school degree had a median income of $21,563, about 70% of men's earnings of $30,868 last year

fields.bodyText: Women constitute a higher percentage of the US university population than ever before, according to a new report released yesterday. The study, by the US census bureau found that 30% of women aged between 25 and 29 now have a bachelor degree compared with 28% of men in the same age group. Over all age groups, 27.8% of American men have completed a college education, compared with 23.6% of women- a much smaller gap than 30 years ago. Women also constitute a rising share of people being awarded college and postgraduate degrees. In 1996, they represented 55% of people awarded bachelor's degrees, 56% of masters' degrees, 40% of doctorates, 41% of medical degrees, and 44% of the law degrees. All this presents a different picture to the 1970 university figures when just 8.2% of all women had received college degrees, compared with 14.1% of men. In 1970, women meanwhile represented 43% of people awarded bachelor's degrees, 40% of masters' degrees, 14% of doctorates, 8% of medical degrees, and only 5% of the law degrees. fields.headline: Worldwide
fields.standfirst:
The first in a new series of articles looking at the wider world of higher education, including American SATs, opinionated academics and lobbygate in New Zealand

Guardian Unlimited Higher Education
fields.trailText: The first in a new series of articles in which David Cohen looks at the issues occupying the wider world of higher education, including American SATs, opinionated academics and lobbygate in New Zealand .
fields.body:
The death of SATs?
In any society, observed George Will in an op-ed analysis published on Thursday in the Washington Post, "be it Periclean Athens or Elizabethan England or modern America, the question is not whether elites shall prevail, but which elites shall prevail."

So, concluded the conservative Mr Will, something simply has to perform the predictive function assigned to the Scholastic Aptitude Test, or SAT, the subject of renewed controversy in the United States after Richard Atkinson, the president of the University of California, recently suggested dropping the test as a way of improving the student body's racial and ethnic diversity.

Since the vast majority of America's 2,300 four-year post-secondary schools already have, in Mr Will's view, open admission policies - "if you have a pulse and a high school diploma, you can attend" - the latest controversy "is primarily important only to the minority of high school high achievers seeking admission to the small minority of highly selective institutions."

If not the SAT, then what? The best colleges require "generally accepted means of making millions of annual assessments more objective than those of the family pet, and roughly predictive of ability to perform well in particular colleges."

Opinions and the Harvard presidency
Mr Atkinson received a more sympathetic namecheck this week in an editorial published on Tuesday in the New York Times welcoming the appointment of Harvard University's new president, Lawrence Summers.

"The number of top educators who speak out today seems distressingly small," the leader said, "either because they are swamped raising money and running complex institutions or because they fear offending key constituencies."

Dr Atkinson, however, "showed what can be done by focusing on the inadequacies of SAT exams."

As far the new Harvard president was concerned, the Times approvingly noted that the "precociously brilliant" economist, who served as treasury secretary at the close of the Clinton administration, is willing to express strong opinions to the point "that for years even his supporters fretted that his bluntness and arrogance offended more people than they persuaded. Yet his formidable attributes make him a fitting choice."

The demon world of Sharon and Livnat
In Israel, an op-ed column by Hana Kim in Ha'aretz, sighed over the educational smarts of the Jewish state's new back-to-basics prime minister and education minister, Ariel Sharon and Limor Livnat, both of whom would like the Bible to be better taught in Israeli classrooms.

"If Sharon and Livnat succeed in their mission, students may wave the Israeli flag and sing Hatikva (the national anthem) every morning, they may commit the entire book of Joshua to memory, they may ritually curse all new historians. Then they will continue their day and not really study the Bible, not really study history, and not really study mathematics."

The growth of Israeli orthodoxy?
An editorial in the same newspaper, published Sunday, cocked a snoot at the dramatic increase in the number of yeshiva students registered in Israel - up 20% in the last year and a half.

The increase, said the leader, "raises grave doubts about the accuracy with which attendance figures are reported in modern Orthodox and ultra-Orthodox educational institutions."

According to the article, the inflation of these figures is happening because higher attendance figures at rabbinical institutions translate into "excessively large" allocations of government funding for the schools.

Korean exodus
Broken systems, alas, also featured as an editorial theme in the Korea Times. "An outstanding trend of these days, particularly among those in their 30s and 40s, is the mass exodus in search of a better life, society and education for their children to foreign lands," began a leader headlined Public Education Crisis.

Too many middle-aged wealth-creators, it claimed, "have been compelled to leave the country, fed up with the nation's educational circumstances and political and economic situation."

The leader squarely blamed South Korea's much-vaunted public education system, describing it as the "people's target of criticism and complaint", on whose account public confidence is falling "due to the government's inconsistent policies and the deteriorating educational circumstances".

Lobbygate in New Zealand
In New Zealand, the newspaper commentary on education was much more specific - concentrating on just one man, Peter Davis, a British-born professor of public health at the country's Christchurch Medical School, who also happens to be Prime Minister Helen Clark's husband.

According to documents tabled this week in the New Zealand parliament, Dr Davis had twice used the email address of Ms Clark's private secretary to lobby for his acknowledged friend, the Canadian academic Joel Lexchin, to be flown to New Zealand for a 10-day stint as a consultant involved of an official review of a government health funding agency.

The New Zealand Herald said, "Having been married to a politician for 20 years, Professor Davis should have known much better. More importantly, a clear principle of acceptable behaviour in politics or, indeed, any walk of life is at stake. Nobody should be able to use their spouse to gain advancement or unreasonable advantage.

Professor Davis's efforts, on behalf of his Canadian friend, at the very least ran the risk of being seen as trying to do just that."

webTitle: Interview: Angelique Chrisafis,  feminist and lapdancer

fields.headline: Body of work
fields.standfirst: She is a feminist university lecturer. So why is she stripping off on stage - and leaving academia to become a lapdancer in Florida? Cathy MacGregor talks to Angelique Chrisafis
fields.trailText: She is a feminist university lecturer. So why is she stripping off on stage - and leaving academia to become a lapdancer in Florida? Cathy MacGregor talks to Angelique Chrisafis.
fields.body:
In a white-washed room, there was a naked academic in a pair of ballet shoes, doing a plié. She did a high kick and made eye-contact with her third- year undergraduates across the room. Was it to make sure they were taking notes? They were. Dr Cathy MacGregor, feminist and Andrea Dworkin-follower, did a few more sensual moves while saying in a deadpan, sarcastic and totally depressed voice: "When I do this, it really turns me on. Oh, yes, it really, really makes me come. Oh, yes. Yes, oh."

Cathy MacGregor is a lecturer at Wolverhampton University. She specialises in drama and has written extensively about the portrayal of women in the work of sexist male dramatists. Last year, she felt she would look further at the women's side of entertainment and went to New York to get a job as a lapdancer. She earned around $500 a night and learned a lot about the business, not least that the quick financial gain could be addictive.

She also thought a lot about herself. As well as lecturing in art, she did performance art. As a lecturer, she earned less in a month than she did dancing for 48 hours. The work in New York had already funded her art, while lecturing had left her lacking. This year, she will ditch the lecturing job to go back to Florida to work full-time as a dancer. "The money will let me fund my feminist, intellectual creative work."

Last night, Nottingham council made an exception to its city-wide ban on nude performance to let MacGregor perform her one-woman, nude art, Scarlett's story: Part One at Nottingham Trent University. The show features her video diaries, ballet dance and deconstruction of lapdancing moves to spoken views on the industry. "When the audience comes in, I am naked. I make a point of making eye-contact with all of them. Later, as I am going through the moves of dancing, I speak the mundanity of what is going through my head. I say: 'God, my feet are killing me. I am dying for a cup of tea.'"

The local press in Nottingham has spent the week running headlines on the "naked academic". In person, MacGregor is slight and shy. In crumpled, fitted pinstripe suit and nice boots, she walks with the small steps of a ballet dancer. When she talks about sex, she pushes her red fingernail around the rim of a floral mug. She tells me how tempting lapdancing was, and how she is looking forward to leaving academia and returning.

Last summer, MacGregor, a Catholic from London who had then been lecturing for four years, rang her friend Ralf in New York. Ralf worked in a New Age emporium and was into the more progressive eastern philosophicial ideas about sex. She said she wanted to do some lapdancing and he went to check out some bars. He found one: carpeted, non-nude, 80s decor, and where the men stood round the bar. Wolverhampton University paid the airfare and MacGregor went out to watch the women work and earn some money herself.

"I worked eight- or nine-hour shifts with no breaks, except to sprint back to the dressing- room to retouch my make-up. I had no lunch. I worked the day shift, so there were fewer girls. If there were only four of us, it was very hard work. We worked three or four songs at a time, then we got down off the bar and interacted with the men to get tips. They would tip us $1 a song. We would chat to them to try and persuade them to pay for a private dance. I stress the hard-work aspect. This is a skilled and demanding industry, and we should respect it."

There were rules at the New York bar. Women - "girls" - had to wear a smart cocktail dress and remove it to show a G-string. They danced to chart songs, most often Madonna, and the black women were allowed to do hip hop songs.

MacGregor worked for two months. The friends she made in the business were mostly around her age - late-twenties. Some had come from Argentina or Latin America. One, Gaby, was from Yugoslavia and danced because "she wanted to move to America and the money helped". The women's salaries were unregulated. They paid $40 a night to dance, then took home the flat rate of $20 a song, plus tips. "I saw that the young 22-year-olds were overwhelmed by the earning rate. They found it hard to stop because the money was so attractive. I realised that I could work a three-day week and earn what I earned as a lecturer full-time."

MacGregor went back to the US at Christmas, this time to Florida, and did another month's work at the Florida Diamond topless bar. The money was funding her art. She met her boyfriend in Florida and will now move back there permanently. She says dancing is compatible with feminism. "I had always been interested in the idea of stripping, initially as a naughty fantasy, inspired by the desire, but also by the fear of being looked at as a sexual object," she says.

MacGregor does not tell her dancing friends that she is a feminist academic, in case they think she is intellectually superior. But she says her gender theory is completely compatible with the sex business. "Lapdancing is a logical step from my intellectual, feminist work. You are empowered. You choose where you work. You leave if you don't like it. You never, ever have to put up with crap from a man. You work for yourself, so no one can tell you you're fired if you don't take crap from a punter. You simply act out a parody of female sexuality, under stage names like Demon and Seduction. Then you take the money home. It is like being a female drag queen."

MacGregor feels it has made her stronger. "I am very shy. Before dancing, people used to look at me in the street, and I looked down, feeling uncomfortable. Now, if someone looks, I keep staring until they look away. I feel able to do this."

fields.headline: Liverpool Hope loses university tag
fields.trailText: Liverpool Hope University College will have to remove the word 'university' from its title, judges ruled yesterday.
fields.body:
Liverpool Hope University College will have to remove the word 'university' from its title, judges ruled yesterday.

The college failed in an appeal court bid attacking the government ban on the title being used by HE institutions that have not been granted degree-awarding powers by the Privy Council.

The 150-year-old college believed it had been unfairly treated, but the judges said their decision to ban the use of 'university' in Liverpool Hope's title was justified. They believed it would help to do away with the "continuing mischief and confusion" facing students in the reckless use of institutional titles.

Lord Justice Henry disagreed, flanked by Lord Justice Mantell and Sir Ronald Waterhouse, he said the decision would be a "grave disappointment" to the college that he described as "a quality institution."

But "the writing was on the wall many years ago" that the government was likely to act to do away with the confusion over institutional titles as "the case for change was overwhelming".

The purpose of the ban was to give effect to the Dearing Report that noted the confusion caused by some academic institutions "using names they were not formally entitled to."

Lord Justice Henry believed the government ban had merely reflected the Dearing recommendation that legislation should be brought in to clarify the position "as soon as possible."

Hope's college secretary, Tony Grayson, said after the ruling: "We are considering talking to the DfEE, perhaps making an appeal, but it is early days yet. One thing that did come out was that the courts accept it is not an issue around the quality of the institution, it is just the title. We got 23 out of 24 in our last quality assessment."

"There was no criteria to be met between February 98 and December 1999 to make an application to the Privy Council, we were just unlucky that the gate was shut in front of us. We have applied for approval and have passed the first hurdle. We are doing all we can."

webTitle: Quest to discover how hi-tech is changing Britain

fields.headline: Quest to discover how hi-tech is changing Britain
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: A British research team is to embark on a quest for the definitive answer to "the critical question" of the 21st century: how has new technology really affected the way we live?
fields.body:
A British research team is to embark on a quest for the definitive answer to "the critical question" of the 21st century: how has new technology really affected the way we live?

Amid grandiose claims from the IT industry about the "information revolution", the three year study claims to be the first independent, "forensic" audit of the impact of computers, mobile phones, email, internet and the rest on the way we work, socialise and communicate.

Carried out by the Industrial Society - with the help of undisclosed but "significant" sponsorship from the computing company Microsoft - the society project has already shed new light on the relationship between the British and new technology.

A preliminary survey published today indicates the extent to which technology is influencing everyday life. The most dramatic results were in the social sphere. Almost 50% of respondents believed technology had increased the number of friends they had, while 60% said they communicated more often with family and friends thanks to email, the internet and mobile phones.

A similar number believed computers were unfairly blamed for problems in society, while 20% thought the world would be a better place without computers and mobile phones.

But while 50% thought technology had reduced people's workloads, helped to fight crime and improved healthcare, 40% said it had increased inequality, and 70% blamed it for making life busier.

With the next generation of information and communications gadgetry about to be launched, there are already 10 microprocessors for every person on the planet, while email and mobile phone usage has exploded. In Britain there are around 40m mobiles.

Richard Reeves, the project's coordinator, said: "If email is changing the nature of [people's] relationships with families, friends and work, that is extremely important for society."

The involvement of Microsoft has raised doubts among some observers about the independence of the research.

However, Neil Holloway, managing director of the company's UK operation, said other companies would be brought on board as the project progressed. "To understand the impact of technology, we have to get involved in this kind of project. The research will be available to all IT firms, allowing them to develop and market their products better."

The rapid pace of change and the shifting nature of public attitudes has left question marks over whether the project will ever establish the true impact of technology.

But, Will Hutton, the Industrial Society's chief executive, said: "We have to try. There is no doubt in my mind that the impact of information and communications technology over the next 10 to 15 years is the critical social and economic question of our age."

Most see benefit of innovation

Around 50% said technology had actually increased the number of friends they had, and 60% said email, the internet and mobile phone technology meant they communicated more often with friends and family.

 Almost 90% believed technology had increased opportunities.

 Around50% of respondents said technology had helped fight crime and 50% said it had improved healthcare. But almost 40% said it had increased inequality and less than 30% said it allowed them more free time.

 Only 20% agreed that the world would be a better place without computers and mobiles, but over70% said technology had made life busier and less than 30% said work had become more flexible.

But almost 40% said it had increased inequality and less than 30% said it allowed them more free time.  Only 20% agreed that the world would be a better place without computers and mobiles, but over70% said technology had made life busier and less than 30% said work had become more flexible.

fields.headline: Breast feeding 'link' to heart disease
fields.trailText: Babies who are breast fed for more than four months could be at increased risk of developing heart disease as adults, according to a study published in this week's British Medical Journal.
fields.body:
Babies who are breast fed for more than four months could be at increased risk of developing heart disease as adults, according to a study published in this week's British Medical Journal.

The research by the Childhood Nutrition Research Centre at the Institute of Child Health in London says stiffness of the heart artery walls was not found in 20-year-olds breast fed for less than four months.

The researchers recruited 171 women and 160 men aged between 20 and 28 born in Cambridge maternity hospital. They used sophisticated imaging techniques to measure stiffness of the artery wall, a marker for future heart disease.

The findings fitted with previous research, they say. An editorial in the journal by Ian Booth, professor of paediatrics and child health at the University of Birmingham, says that while nobody doubts the benefits of breast feeding in the first months of life, it may become necessary to reconsider the current wisdom that "breast is best" as long as mother and baby are both happy with it.

Advocates of breast feeding say bottle fed babies are far more likely to suffer from infections, obesity, high blood pressure and - in the developing world - malnourishment.

The researchers acknowledge that the real problem may lie with the western diet that children are given after weaning.

BMJ current issue
Medical research council

fields.headline: Teachers demoted in class structure
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Teachers are no longer top of the class structure, according to a classification issued by the office of national statistics for this year's census on April 29.
fields.body:
Teachers are no longer top of the class structure, according to a classification issued by the office of national statistics for this year's census on April 29.

Teachers, social workers, police constables and branch bank managers have all gone down a grade. In 1998, when the office made what was heralded as the most fundamental reclassification of British society in 90 years, teachers were in the top category, alongside managers in large organisations, judges and architects. Teachers now belong in class 2, lower managerial and professional.

Carol Adams, chief executive of the general teaching council for England, the professional body which begins work this year, said: "This is clearly an unhelpful signal to receive when we're trying to recruit and keep people."

The change is due to reclassifications by the institute of social and economic research at the University of Essex, and the statistics office. The office divided 27,000 occupations into 353 unit groups. Each unit group was placed by the institute in a bracket according to criteria based on the employment contract, including working conditions, prospects and security.

David Rose, a professor at the institute, said the previous divisions, based on work for the 1990 census, had been too crude. "The new classifications allow us to classify occupations into classes 1 and 2 in a way that the theory told us we should do but the old classifications didn't allow us to do."

Academics remain in class 1, because they generally have more freedom and better conditions than teachers. Commenting on the demotion of teachers, Prof Rose said: "If the population as a whole thinks teachers ought to be in class 1, that's telling us the government ought to improve their conditions."

He acknowledged there were anomalies. Headteachers join their rank-and-file colleagues in class 2; police inspectors join chief constables in category 1. "There is always a trade-off between accuracy and cost," he said. Journalists were class 2 and yet "for every John Humphrys [the BBC news presenter], there are 250 journalists slaving away on their local newspaper".

Social workers, like optometrists, have shifted from 1 to 2. Childcare assistants have moved from class 7, routine occupations, to class 6, semi-routine occupations. Landscape gardeners and railway construction workers have moved from class 6 into class 5, lower supervisory and technical.

Lorry and van drivers go from class 6 to class 7. Prof Rose said he had wanted to keep lorry drivers in a higher bracket, but found that terms and conditions were broadly the same whether driving a lorry or van. And a plumber who employs more than 25 is in class 1; a plumber who employs fewer than 25, or is self- employed, is in class 4; and a plumber employed by someone else is in class 5.

Pecking order

Revised socio-economic classification of occupations, with percentage of working population in brackets

1 Higher managerial and professional (11% ) Higher managerial: employers of more than 25 staff, and senior managers. Higher professional: doctors, dentists, lawyers

2 Lower managerial and professional (23.5%)

Junior managers, police sergeants, teachers, social workers, journalists

3 Intermediate (14%) Constables, firefighters, junior prison officers

4 Small employers and own account workers (9.9%)

Non-professionals who employ fewer than 25

5 Lower supervisory and technical (9.8% )

Foremen, supervisors, train drivers

6 Semi-routine (18.6%)

Shop assistants, call centre workers

7 Routine (12.7%)

Drivers, cleaners


Guardian Unlimited Education
