webTitle: School clears head teacher for return to work

fields.headline: School clears head teacher for return to work
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Head teacher Marjorie Evans was today free to go back to work after governors found there was "no credible evidence" to support allegations of pupil mistreatment against her.
fields.body:
Head teacher Marjorie Evans was today free to go back to work after governors found there was "no credible evidence" to support allegations of pupil mistreatment against her.

The decision came after a disciplinary hearing that lasted three days in Cwmbran, south Wales, where evidence was heard from 22 separate witnesses.

The 56-year-old was accused of inappropriate physical abuse of children at St Mary's Junior School in Caldicot.

But, after a 19-hour session ended today, the chairman of the board of governors, Rob Gibbs, said: "I'm making this statement in agreement with all parties.

"The governors have considered all the evidence and have found no credible evidence to support these allegations."

Ms Evans has not been at work since September 1999 when she was accused of slapping a 10-year-old pupil at the school. She was convicted of common assault at Abergavenny magistrates court in July, but was cleared on appeal last September.

Just hours after winning her appeal, the police announced that they were carrying out an investigation into further allegations of pupil mistreatment at the school.

But that investigation was dropped after the Crown Prosecution Service announced that it would not be taking any action. Governors at the school, however, decided to hold an internal disciplinary hearing.

Ms Evans's suspension was lifted last October, but when she said she wanted to go back to the school in December, a threat of resuspension was made.

The three governors who took part in this week's disciplinary hearing will now take their decision to a full governors' meeting at the school this evening.

After the decision, Ms Evans said she was "delighted" with the news. In a statement issued through the National Union of Teachers, she said: "I'm euphoric. I'm lost for words.

"I'm absolutely delighted that the 18 months of stress and pain that I've endured are now over. The whole period has been extraordinarily distressing.

"I've missed being at school, seeing my staff and seeing my children. I can't wait to get back, although it certainly won't be today - I'm very tired."

Ms Evans hoped to be back at school next week, a spokeswoman for the union said.

Last week, the NUT brought a High Court legal action against Monmouthshire County Council and governors at the school, accusing them of not adopting the proper disciplinary rules and procedures.

Mrs Justice Bracewell ruled in their favour and ordered the governors to draw up a new set of rules and procedures that were put in place ahead of the disciplinary hearing.

Ms Evans stood in a show of unity with the three governors on the panel as the head of governors read his statement after the hearing, held at a rented office in Cwmbran.

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the NUT, said after the decision: "This has been an extraordinarily drawn out process. Marjorie was cleared by the High Court.

"She has now been cleared by a disciplinary panel. It should not have taken this long to get a good head teacher back into her own school.

"There has to be a better way of dealing with allegations made against teachers than a process that lasts 18 months and results in the exoneration we knew would always come.

"I'm delighted for Marjorie and for the children at her school."

fields.headline: Stuck  in the  past
fields.standfirst:
Under apartheid, children in South Africa were taught an Afrikaner version of the past, with barely a mention of the black population. Seven years after the republic's first free election, many schools are using the same books. But just how do you go about the awesome task of rewriting a nation's history, asks Chris McGreal

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Under apartheid, children in South Africa were taught an Afrikaner version of the past, with barely a mention of the black population. Seven years after the republic's first free election, many schools are using the same books. But just how do you go about the awesome task of rewriting a nation's history, asks Chris McGreal
fields.body:
It was little more than 20 years ago that a group of men in suits waving a bucket stormed on to the stage of the University of South Africa's lecture hall, pinned down Floors van Jaarsveld, and tarred and feathered him. Van Jaarsveld's crime was to question the myth of Afrikanerdom's holiest day - the Day of Covenant. The prominent historian asked how Afrikaners could claim that divine intervention enabled 471 Boers to defeat 15,000 Zulus at the Battle of Blood River when the whites had been slaughtered at a previous encounter between the two. Did God switch sides, he wondered?

It was too much for Eugene Terre'Blanche and his neo-Nazi Afrikaner Resistance Movement (AWB). Almost no one in South Africa had heard of Terre'Blanche until he led the charge on to the stage to punish Van Jaarsveld's heresy. After that, the AWB's ranks swelled, while the historian was shunned and suddenly dropped from invitations to speak at other universities. White South Africa was far from ready to question the myths about God, race and land that provided the deluded moral and intellectual basis for apartheid.

Two decades later, the Day of the Covenant holiday has been consigned to a very tall scrap heap of discarded fictions once taken as factual history. But South Africa is grappling to decide what to replace them with. "The standard thing here is to unlearn what you've learned in school," says Bill Nasson, head of history at the University of Cape Town. "You have this old history which is that South Africa starts in 1652 with the arrival of Jan van Riebeeck. That's gone. The problem is what you replace that with. You could replace it with the liberation struggle that begins in 1653, but that simply replaces one form of nationalist history with another."

"South Africa has a very complex history. It's the only country in Africa that had slaves imported from other parts of Africa, and when some of those slaves were freed they took slaves themselves. The problem is to address this kind of thing without vilifying one group and making martyrs of another. Nothing is straightforward in our history."

The first stage of officially reassessing South Africa's history has focused on schools, which are still waiting for the government to decide what will be taught, let alone rewrite the text books and print them. The education ministry appointed a committee of prominent historians, anthropologists and archaeologists - including Nasson - to mull over how best to address South Africa's complex past. There was common agreement that history is discredited and therefore in crisis.

"Some schools have even come to regard history as a subject for less able learners or those with a low IQ. It is no great surprise that both at schools and in many universities, students have been deserting the study of history," the report said. "It is a considerable irony that we are having to address a 'crisis in history' when the pressing importance of history continues to be demonstrated daily in South Africa. For we live in a society in which contemporary issues are continually understood and judged within the powerful context of a past which has bequeathed a violent legacy of conquest, colonialism and apartheid."

The result of the crisis is a school system still heavily reliant on the old history books. Revised textbooks are available for those schools that can afford them. Some, such as the pioneering National Education Crisis Committee Peoples' History book, are widely praised. Others are simply the old version of events with a picture of Nelson Mandela on the cover. But there is no common direction or consistency.

The easy bit for the education department was deciding to dump the version of history propagated under what was called "Christian National Education", peppered with white heroes with Dutch surnames. For decades, children of all races learned that the Afrikaner was the real victim of South Africa's perpetual strife. As it was told, the peaceful Boers who settled in the Cape were abused and oppressed by the British in the early 19th century, and so forced to make the Great Trek north. They were attacked and betrayed by the great African chiefs, including the king of the Zulus, and so had to fight for their survival.

And when they had finally established their own countries with the Boer republics, the British made war to get their hands on Johannesburg's gold mines. Tens of thousands of Boer women and children were murdered in the infamous British concentration camps. And when it was over, the Afrikaner was a British subject and a second-class citizen.

Only in 1948, with the election of the National party government, was the Afrikaner liberated. All of this went to justify the imposition of apartheid. It was not a form of oppression, its authors argued, but a survival strategy for a people persecuted on all sides.

In this version of history there was no room for the fate of the Khoikhoi, slaughtered after Van Riebeeck's arrival, or the tens of thousands of black people who also died in the British concentration camps. There was no mention of stolen land or forced removals or the execution of African men for wanting the right to govern. Neither was there recognition of the iron-age settlements in what is now Johannesburg, because that conflicted with the version of history that says the Afrikaners did not steal the land because it was empty.

Much of Afrikaner historical orthodoxy emanated from Stellenbosch University. The last head of the history department was also chairman of the Broederbond, the secretive collection of Afrikaner men who guided apartheid ideology and government policy. Today, the department is led by Albert Grundlingh, the first person to hold the post who is not a former student at Stellenbosch. "History in this country is a congealed set of misunderstandings," he says. "The problemtoday is that after 1994 [and South Africa's first all-race election], history sort of vanished. I would like to suggest that history has served its purpose so far as the liberation movement was concerned. They don't need it to justify being in power. That was not the case of the Afrikaners who used history even after they won power in 1948. It was used to justify everything they did.

"I don't think we want to substitute one set of heroes for another - black for white. But we have to begin somewhere and I'd like to think that there is a hidden history of black and white cooperation. You can ask yourself how it is possible to maintain a system like apartheid over 300 years without cooperation. That is a good basis for exploration."

Thabo Bashe knows only too well the shortcomings of the old version of history. Once a political prisoner, he is now deputy headmaster of Zola secondary school in Khayelitsha, one of the sprawling black townships outside Cape Town. "There's a lot that we weren't taught in school. It was more about the Great Trek and how black people were stealing the cattle from white people and how the whites developed from the Western Cape to the interior," he says.

"We wanted to know more about the struggle against apartheid. At school, nothing would be said about that. As students we wanted to learn about Mandela and how the land was taken from black farmers. I went to a meeting addressed by Steve Biko and that was the first time we heard about our own history. We saw teachers at the time as part of the system. We even stoned the house of our headmaster. I don't know why we did that. It wasn't his fault."

Yet 11 years after Mandela was released from prison, and seven years after he was elected president, Zola secondary school still relies on apartheid-era history books. Some pupils use a 1987 text, History in Action, written specifically for black schools. It has 30 pages on the Great Trek. There are just three on black South African history. "The Great Trek was an independence movement, an act of self-preservation, a protest against British racial policies and a manifestation of the pioneering spirit of the Afrikaner," the book says. The British "racial policies" the trekkers protested against was the abolition of slavery. When the text finally addresses emancipation, it is to paint the Boers as the victims of the end of slavery.

"The Afrikaner farmers were not opposed to the freeing of slaves but they were dissatisfied with the way it was carried out, without a law passed to prevent vagrancy. The freed slaves wandered about and lived by stealing. In this way the farmers' losses were increased," it says.

Bashe despairs. "If you go to class, most teachers are still teaching using the same books and asking the same questions of learners and marking them in the same way," he says. "The sad thing is, the learners don't seem to notice. It takes a long time to get the idea of white superiority out of the system, even among black learners. It's easy for me here because when I talk about apartheid you expect everyone to be against it. But there are learners here who say it was better to have a white government than a black government."

To the disquiet of some teachers, a survey by Johannesburg's Witwatersrand University discovered that a high proportion of black schoolchildren want to know more, not less, about Jan van Riebeeck. But it is not the old Bantu education version they are interested in. What pupils are curious about are the real reasons that whites came at all, and what happened next to the black people who encountered the Dutch settlers. In other words, how did black people find themselves lorded over in their own land?

Bashe says that in many ways it would be easier to leave history out of the curriculum. "History is very difficult. It's very difficult to say these are the facts and these facts are beyond question. If you look at the role of Shaka and his part in building the Zulu nation, he was taking over the smaller ethnic groups and some fled to what is Lesotho now. Zulu students may see him as a hero, but Shaka is not a hero to those he chased out. They regard him as a villain," he says.

"But we have to teach history because these learners must be able to understand why we have Khayelitsha and why there are only black people here and why there are no coloured [mixed-race] or white people. They will understand this is a wrong thing and that is why this must never happen again. So if the government says we are going to oppress the white people who did this to us, they need to understand why that is wrong."

Many whites have already reinterpreted history to suit themselves. So few admit they supported apartheid that it is amazing that the National party remained in power so long. But on the whole they just avoid the subject. "In Afrikaner circles there has been a flight from history because of apartheid. You don't want to be reminded time and again of crimes committed in your name," says Dr Grundlingh. "But there are others who are discovering another false history. Among some coloured [mixed-race] people there's the deliberate invention of a Khoikhoi heritage as a way of saying we were here before the black people. It's one-upping the Africans. It's a joke because I don't think any of them have Khoikhoi blood. This is how myths are made."

Today, the department is led by Albert Grundlingh, the first person to hold the post who is not a former student at Stellenbosch. "History in this country is a congealed set of misunderstandings," he says. "The problemtoday is that after 1994 [and South Africa's first all-race election], history sort of vanished. I would like to suggest that history has served its purpose so far as the liberation movement was concerned. They don't need it to justify being in power. That was not the case of the Afrikaners who used history even after they won power in 1948. It was used to justify everything they did. "I don't think we want to substitute one set of heroes for another - black for white. But we have to begin somewhere and I'd like to think that there is a hidden history of black and white cooperation. You can ask yourself how it is possible to maintain a system like apartheid over 300 years without cooperation. That is a good basis for exploration." Thabo Bashe knows only too well the shortcomings of the old version of history. Once a political prisoner, he is now deputy headmaster of Zola secondary school in Khayelitsha, one of the sprawling black townships outside Cape Town. "There's a lot that we weren't taught in school. It was more about the Great Trek and how black people were stealing the cattle from white people and how the whites developed from the Western Cape to the interior," he says. "We wanted to know more about the struggle against apartheid. At school, nothing would be said about that. As students we wanted to learn about Mandela and how the land was taken from black farmers. I went to a meeting addressed by Steve Biko and that was the first time we heard about our own history. We saw teachers at the time as part of the system. We even stoned the house of our headmaster. I don't know why we did that. It wasn't his fault." Yet 11 years after Mandela was released from prison, and seven years after he was elected president, Zola secondary school still relies on apartheid-era history books. Some pupils use a 1987 text, History in Action, written specifically for black schools. It has 30 pages on the Great Trek. There are just three on black South African history. "The Great Trek was an independence movement, an act of self-preservation, a protest against British racial policies and a manifestation of the pioneering spirit of the Afrikaner," the book says. The British "racial policies" the trekkers protested against was the abolition of slavery. When the text finally addresses emancipation, it is to paint the Boers as the victims of the end of slavery. "The Afrikaner farmers were not opposed to the freeing of slaves but they were dissatisfied with the way it was carried out, without a law passed to prevent vagrancy. The freed slaves wandered about and lived by stealing. In this way the farmers' losses were increased," it says. Bashe despairs. "If you go to class, most teachers are still teaching using the same books and asking the same questions of learners and marking them in the same way," he says. "The sad thing is, the learners don't seem to notice. It takes a long time to get the idea of white superiority out of the system, even among black learners. It's easy for me here because when I talk about apartheid you expect everyone to be against it. But there are learners here who say it was better to have a white government than a black government." To the disquiet of some teachers, a survey by Johannesburg's Witwatersrand University discovered that a high proportion of black schoolchildren want to know more, not less, about Jan van Riebeeck. But it is not the old Bantu education version they are interested in. What pupils are curious about are the real reasons that whites came at all, and what happened next to the black people who encountered the Dutch settlers. In other words, how did black people find themselves lorded over in their own land? Bashe says that in many ways it would be easier to leave history out of the curriculum. "History is very difficult. It's very difficult to say these are the facts and these facts are beyond question. If you look at the role of Shaka and his part in building the Zulu nation, he was taking over the smaller ethnic groups and some fled to what is Lesotho now. Zulu students may see him as a hero, but Shaka is not a hero to those he chased out. They regard him as a villain," he says. "But we have to teach history because these learners must be able to understand why we have Khayelitsha and why there are only black people here and why there are no coloured [mixed-race] or white people. They will understand this is a wrong thing and that is why this must never happen again. So if the government says we are going to oppress the white people who did this to us, they need to understand why that is wrong." Many whites have already reinterpreted history to suit themselves. So few admit they supported apartheid that it is amazing that the National party remained in power so long. But on the whole they just avoid the subject. "In Afrikaner circles there has been a flight from history because of apartheid. You don't want to be reminded time and again of crimes committed in your name," says Dr Grundlingh. "But there are others who are discovering another false history. Among some coloured [mixed-race] people there's the deliberate invention of a Khoikhoi heritage as a way of saying we were here before the black people. It's one-upping the Africans. It's a joke because I don't think any of them have Khoikhoi blood. This is how myths are made."

fields.headline: Charlotte Rampling (II)
fields.trailText: The Guardian/NFT interview
fields.body:
Charlotte Rampling on: Angel Heart | Mickey Rourke | Great Expectations | difficulty of finding roles for older actresses | Paul Newman | He Died With His Eyes Open | directors

Christopher Cook: When the script for Angel Heart arrived, what made you think you really wanted to play Margaret Krusemark in the film? It's a very small, cameo performance on one level.

Charlotte Rampling: First of all because of Alan Parker, who is a friend, I've known him a long time and I admire him enormously, and then it was Mickey Rourke, and then it was the fascinating screenplay and it became irresistible. Even if it was just one big scene, you're always talking about this women, this woman holds tremendous power through the film. The film is quite astounding really.

CC: That's the point, it's her film.

CR: Almost, yeah, although she's hardly ever there.

CC: When you play that scene, you're competing with an astonishing set, crammed with detail. I wonder how easy it is acting with, but against, the décor.

CR: Well, you just don't think about it. You'd very quickly drown otherwise.

CC: It must be quite alarming to have that sort of detail around you.

CR: I don't actually look very much. I think, in a sense, it's a pity, but that's the only way I can protect myself in this business. I just look to the essential of what I have to look at, and the rest I don't see. People will say, "Did you see that?" I will say, "No. I actually didn't." So if you say to me that room was very decorated, I had no idea that it was.

It's also like that with the technicians, and all the movement and the agitation and the razzamatazz that goes around on a day's filming, if I connect into what is really happening then I'll lose what I need to be able to do what I have to do. So I blank out a lot of stuff.

CC: Was it fun to work with Rourke?

CR: Yeah. He was wonderful then too, he was really good, he was well and he was happy and it was a good moment in his life. He became a very good friend, yup.

CC: In terms of performing, what made it good to be with him at that moment?

CR: Because he is a highly instinctive, sensual actor and at that time he was at the peak of all that. He was quite remarkable. He just vibrated. He's not clever like a De Niro, who he was acting with, but he had great gifts. Has great gifts. He hasn't done much now, but then he was at the peak of his power, of his sensuality, of his animal side, of his instinctive side. Alan is a very powerful director, so he was able to keep him there, chain him in there and not let him go from there. Whereas if he's allowed to go on his own, he then gets out of control.

CC: It's an American style of acting that some people call "spit and sawdust." It couldn't be more different than your style. Because it's so overwhelming, Rourke's style, when it works, 200,000 volts in one person, how difficult is it to maintain your presence?

CR: I don't think I do badly

CC: I think you do wonderfully!

CR: In terms of voltageI think I did well there!

CC: It's just a different style, isn't it?

CR: Hmm. Is it? I don't know. I would say Robert De Niro's style is much more different, I wouldn't say Mickey and mine's was so different.

CC: Are you conscious of revealing too much of yourself. Your safety net in the end is based upon things from your own life. Sometimes taking skins off can be a dangerous business.

CR: Yeah. Quite often I didn't do it, for that reason.

CC: Can you sense, as a performer, when you taken one too many skins off.

CR: Yup.

CC: What do you do about it?

CR: You lick your wounds a bit. Stay at home.

CC: Let's talk about your wonderful portrayal of Miss Havisham. The trouble with Miss Havisham is that everybody has in mind David Lean's version of Great Expectations. Did you consciously think what am I going to do in this that isn't going to be David Lean's Miss Havisham? This old, sad, mad woman surrounded by the relics of the marriage that never was.

CR: No, because the screenplay was not that. I met all the people concerned who wanted to make that into something moreI think they wanted to put a bit of sex into Miss Havisham. She might have been dried up, but they did want to make her a bit sexy. That's what they said. "I'm yer girl, then," I said!

CC: That final line in that scene (Miss Havisham is told that she is going to marry after all) I think is wonderful. I can't think of any other way of doing it. You must have planned

CR: "Love"?

CC: Yes.

CR: You don't plan, but you know that certain lines hold immense power and immense depth, and you just hope that you're going to put what is needed behind the words. If words don't have vibration behind them, and a real feeling behind them, then they're just words. Some words are very beautiful and that word is one of the most beautiful, it's been bandied around a million times, but if you can really say it in the context of a character like Miss Havisham then it's very satisfying.

CC: I wonder if you feel that one of the problems for a female actor is that the parts don't come after a certain age. Until you become a character actress

CR: So how long do I have to wait?

CC: I wondered if you were conscious of being offered a lot of things that you really don't want to do because they're not very interesting.

CR: Well, I'm probably lucky because I'm not someone who wants to work very much! So I always feel that there is a role around for me, though I might have to wait around for nine months or a year, but I don't mind that.

CC: And preferably a role with a risk attached?

CR: Yeah. So I suppose if you really wanted to work a lot I suppose I could say yeah, where are the roles for women my age, but they seem to comeThis one in Under The Sand, François Ozon said, "No-one will want to do this role because I want to film you exactly as you are. No French film actor is going to want to do it. They're not going to want to be a) in a bathing costume and b) not very well lit, c) looking pretty terrible and all that. I want to film a woman as a woman is at your age."

CC: He also said he wanted to film "the beauty of wrinkle". So in a sense the romantic in him is there too. There is something romantic about his work.

CR: I think that when a young man of thirty-two wants to film a woman of fifty, there is something very romantic about that. He wants to film something that is not necessarily pleasing all the time, but is certainly fulfilling. So a fulfilled woman sometimes looks beautiful, and sometimes doesn't look so beautiful, but you don't have to worry about that because it's all in a dayIn a day, from the moment you wake up in the morning until the moment you go to bed, all sorts of different faces happen, and that's what he wanted. He wanted very much for the actress not to worry about anything like: "Have I got the right angle?" or "Is my stomach showing?" or "Can you see my double chin?"

CC: And you didn't?

CR: Noof course I didn't

CC: Let's ask the audience.

Question one: I think you were high voltage in Angel Heart. What was it like working with Paul Newman on The Verdict?

CR: He was high voltage. I kind of like this voltage thing we're on. He is somebody so shy and fragile. You have to be very gentle with him, perhaps you wouldn't think it. He's very self-doubting, an immensely humane man. It was the most extraordinary experience working with him, just on a human basis, I find him an exquisite human being.

Question two: You made a film called He Died With His Eyes Open, what was your experience of that?

CR: I thought it was pretty amazing, that film. I really did. As a dark, dark film. It was Robin Cook who wrote the bookdid it get released in England? Yes. It was also working with Michelle Serot, who is one of the finest French actors I think. He started on comedy and became a tremendous dramatic artist. It was one of the darkest films I've made, actually, in terms of the story and in terms of the weight. I saw it recently, I don't really watch my films, but I saw it because it was re-released somewhere.

CC: Was it well received in France?

CR: Yeah. Very well received. Very dark film. One of Jacques Deray's very good films, he's quite an unequal director, Jacques Deray.

Question three: What do you want, as a person, to happen to Marie at the end?

CR: What I feel is that she has come to accept that he husband has died. She has the evidence, the body is there, she knows that. When she sees the watch, she knows that it's her husband because you can't possibly tell from the body. She's not going to be able to stay for very long with the pain of crying and she realises that she has to mourn. When she runs off she maybe invents the fact that it might be her husband, but she knows it's not and she will eventually come to terms with the death of her husband. She will accept it. That's what I feel.

Question four: She won't end up in an asylum like her mother-in-law?

CR: No way, because she's far too proud!

CC: Is she going to marry Vincent?

CR: No. Vincent is still too "leger."

Question five: What did François Ozon need to learn, that he needed two female writers?

CR: I just felt that it needed to have a woman's femininity in it somewhere. I didn't know what at all, or what it would reveal, but when Emmanuel Bernheim came in, something else started to happen, I don't know what it was, but something else happened. I think that collaboration in writing is very important, with male or female writers, but if the subject is uniquely about a woman, I think there's something out of balance if there's not a woman that comes in and collaborates with the writing.

Question six: How important is it for you for a film to be a commercial success?

CR: I'm over the moon, actually, because there are 500,000 people in Paris that have seen Under The Sand. Quite often the films I make are difficult, a certain amount of people have seen them and they've been critically appreciated and respected, but to have a commercial success with a film like this - which is not an easy film, it's a very personal film, people's own story will be revealed a little bit through this film - it's something that makes me feel as if I've been recognised somewhere.

Question seven: You play women with secrets very often. Do you find secrets, and characters with secrets, attractive?

CR: I think what we do best, in the artistic world, are the things where we're handicapped. I'm not very good at talking and being with people, and being gregarious and outgoing. I love people, but I have great difficulty doing it. I think the reason I have secrets is because there are a lot of things I haven't been able to let out and I'm able to let them out through the screen and this medium.

I'm able to let them out in a way that if I'd been able to let them out before in a more easy, normal way it wouldn't be so effective. I think that all us people who perform and are called artists are usually very crippled people, and we use this to uncripple ourselves for a little bit of time. When people want to see your film you're over the moon because you've actually made real contact. That's something very special.

Question eight: Who is the best director that you've worked with?

CR: It's like comparing children. You can't do that. These directors are so much part of me - they've made me and helped me along the way. Some better than othersbut they've all been incredibly kind to me. Maybe they all realised that they wouldn't get anything out of me if they were unkind! I'm not answering your question in the way that you want me to because I find it difficult to be specific in that way.

It's a kind of idealistic love that I have with all these directors. They're figureheads for me. They've been part of such an essential part of my life, just for a short amount of time, but they're mythological gods up there for me. That's the way I like to feel about them, because that's the way I like to feel about my work.

Question nine: Were you nervous about performing for these great directors?

CR: No, because they're all part of my family. I don't think better or worse. The comparison thing for me has never worked in anything. I don't compare things.

Question ten: Why is the film called Under The Sand?

CR: What confuses you?

Question eleven: I don't understand what is under the sand.

CR: Well, he could be, couldn't he? The title was actually going to be the title of a short film Ozon made which was then called Regarde La Mer, but they changed titles. In France they asked about the title too. And it really annoyed François! I'll tell him - there's another one!

Question twelve: What was Robert Mitchum like in Farewell My Lovely?

CR: He was fantastic, yeah. He's the last of the great Hollywood myths. And he really lives up to it.

Question thirteen: What do you think about the look you created in Night Porter becoming so fashionable?

CR: I haven't got my braces on todayWhat do I think about it? I think it's good. No, I do - when things go into fashion it means they're important, doesn't it Christopher?

CC: I'm just imagining you at home trying on the costume

CR: I do wear braces every now and then. Madonna wanted Dirk Bogarde to be in her video

CC: Are you going to tell us what he said?

CR: Umno.

CC: I think that's one of the great lost lines of dialogue. Charlotte Rampling, thank you very much indeed.

CR: Thank you.

webTitle: The links between pop art and fashion

fields.headline: Art on your sleeve
fields.standfirst: As a new exhibition opens, Charlie Porter examines the links between pop art and fashion
fields.trailText: As a new exhibition opens, Charlie Porter examines the links between pop art and fashion.
fields.body:
Bored of the whole trend cycle? Tom Ford is. In an interview in the current edition of Pop magazine, the creative director of Gucci Group says there are people who are "not buying because they know in five minutes they're not going to like it any more, because it won't be new." Andy Warhol's predicted 15 minutes' sell-by date has obviously shrunk by two thirds and it could be that pop art itself has killed fashion. Usually it's seen the other way around, that the miniskirt could only have been born in the time of the screen-prints of Marilyn. But opening this week in Paris, Les Annees Pop, a massive retrospective of the pop years, sponsored by the Gucci Group, shows that pop art may actually be fashion's albatross.

The show, which brings together classic pop pieces of art and design from 1956-68, shows that the turnover of new imagery and ideas in this period was phenomenal. The art world has long since stopped trying to keep up with this rate of mass-audience change. Yet since Yves Saint Laurent, who founded ready-to-wear by opening his Rive Gauche boutique in 1966, was so closely linked to the pop art movement, it became inherent in the industry to feel the need for constant change. And designerscan't keep up.

What we would like is for everything to be as bright, shiny and new as it was in the 60s, when colour, casual cuts and daring designs were a novelty rather than the norm. Back then, because they hadn't seen it all before, a designer could look radical just by doing something different. Now most ideas look retro and shock tactics merely a sign of naivete on the part of a label trying to command headlines.

It's clear why Tom Ford would want his company to be involved in such an exhibition, and not only because being associated with such an excellent show can only be good for business. Ford himself was friends with Andy Warhol. "The very first time I went to Studio 54 was with Andy," says Ford who, as an art history student at New York University, met Warhol in 1978. "I don't think I would have gotten in without him. At that time I was much more impressed with him as a socialite than an artist." Ford's opinion has since changed - he owns eight works by Warhol.

But Ford is also aware of the detrimental affects of pop on fashion. He talks about "the hollowness of my own job and of all of our jobs that sell image and influence taste." Further, he admits: "As much as I love beautiful things, they also become nothing because you realise how short their lifespan is." And so, he says: "Either it'll just keep getting faster, or we'll get fed up and stop buying."

It all comes down to the strength of the links between fashion and pop culture, that wide berth of celebrities and products that pop art left churning in its wake. It can be addictive, especially when slagging off the dresses that will be worn at next weekend's Oscars, or seeing Hear'say stumble through their make-overs on Popstars. But it means that fashion has to have as high a turnaround as the other pop catagories and often it's a shame to force designers on to a new idea when they haven't yet fully concluded a previous train of thought.

This also causes a vast gulf between the pop-friendly and the more serious designers, to the detriment of the latter. During the Paris shows this week, those attending have enjoyed much more overwhelmingly cheeky shows such as Jeremy Scott's, where the models posed with fridges, grand pianos and E-Zee Chairs in an awe-inspiring Price Is Right parody (pop incarnate), than the ponderous examination of the dung beetle shown by Bernard Willhelm (yes, some of the girls did have balls of fake dung attached to their foreheads). Tom Ford wants it all to stop, but our recent history is too tempting, with its mine of bad taste and irony benchmarks. And because pop artists showed us all how gleeful the critic of mass-produced culture can be, no one is going to give up the easy-reference examination now.

As if to assert its dominance in the whole affair, pop art itself has been all-pervasive in fashion for the past two seasons. For spring/summer, Iceberg scored a hit with their blown-up prints by Roy Lichtenstein, on clothes and chic bags. Meanwhile, in the autumn/winter 2001 collections, many designers looked as though they were dressing the people behind the art. Anna Sui's show in New York was like an ID parade at Warhol's factory and the best double-breasted schoolgirl coats, at Miu Miu or Marc Jacobs, had the right air of knowing innocence that would have been necessary to survive pop art's juxtaposition of the seamy and the childlike.

Interestingly, though the exhibition features pieces of design and artefacts from the time, alongside over 200 works of art, there are precious few clothes on display. Perhaps this is because, until it can divert itself from its pop art obsession, fashion will always be playing catch up.

 Les Annees Pop is at the Centre Pompidou, Paris, until June 18.
