fields.headline: Charlotte Rampling (I)
fields.standfirst: Hailed as one of the faces of the 1960s after her breakthrough role in Georgy Girl, Charlotte Rampling has never taken the obvious choices in her subsequent career, which has included startling performances in such celebrated films as The Damned, The Night Porter and The Verdict. To coincide with the release of her latest movie, Under the Sand, the legendary star talked to Christopher Cook about some of her best known films, as well as the actors and directors she has worked with.
fields.trailText: Hailed as one of the faces of the 1960s after her breakthrough role in Georgy Girl, Charlotte Rampling has never taken the obvious choices in her subsequent career, which has included startling performances in such celebrated films as The Damned, The Night Porter and The Verdict. To coincide with the release of her latest movie, Under the Sand, the legendary star talked to Christopher Cook about some of her best known films, as well as the actors and directors she has worked with.
fields.body:
Charlotte Rampling on: Under the sand | early career | Luchino Visconti | Dirk Bogarde | acting technique | Woody Allen and Stardust Memories

Christopher Cook: What was it that you liked about the script of Under the Sand that made you want to take the part of Marie?

Charlotte Rampling: It wasn't a script at all, it was just an idea. François Ozon, whose work I was beginning to discover a few months before, came to me via my agent and said that he had this idea, which was just the first part of the film until the husband disappears, because it was something he himself witnessed when he was a boy of twelve. He was haunted by this idea and it so happens that at the age of thirty-two he was looking for someone who would be able to follow, to find out what happened to this woman that he saw pack her little bag with the towels and the beach ball, and go home and never really know what happened to her husband. So, that's the story. We filmed the first part, up to where the husband disappeared, then we stopped filming and then he wrote the screenplay.

CC: But there must have been something about the story that caught your imagination as an actor?

CR: I think because it was so incredibly difficult to imagine what could possibly happen, and how we could put that across on the screen. How could you actually make interesting what this woman was going through after such an experience? More and more as François Ozon wrote the screenplay, more and more he didn't want anything to happen - he just wanted to film it through the eyes of the woman.

CC: Being there while the screenplay was being written, did you get an opportunity to shape what was happening to Marie?

CR: Yes, because I was his blueprint - the essence of what could happen in this very fragile story because there was no plot particularly, it was just about "a being." Perhaps you feel it when you see this film, this film is more an experience than actually seeing a film, it's a very personal thing for everybody. The people that are affected by the film, and they seemed to be quite affected in France, if you are affected by it then it becomes your story.

CC: Was there a sense in which you felt that the feminine aspect of the character needed a little help that perhaps you could bring in?

CR: Well, there was never a question of me collaborating on the writing, but I very much collaborated with him in terms of ideas. At one moment I said to him that I thought it necessary for him to collaborate with a woman writer and so he worked with two women on the writing at one stage.

CC: When you first see this film it doesn't seem to be a long, strong narrative, it seems to be about a woman trying to come to terms with the inexplicable loss of her husband Jean. But the film plays on your mind and isn't about that at all, it's not about mourning the loss of a husband really, is it?

CR: No, that's the pretext of the story. Quite often in life, when a tragic event arrives it becomes a springboard for mirroring all other things in one's life that one hasn't come to terms with. To grieve is something extremely difficult, we don't even know how to begin to grieve, and I don't know how you can be taught to grieve. But it's how to come to terms with suffering, that's what it's really about - not to resist it, not to deny it, but to accept it - but we don't really want to do that because it's too painful.

CC: Also a woman who is emotionally shipwrecked by an event. She loses all sense of bearing and it's an attempt to recover a sense of identity.

CR: Yeah. I don't know, I sort of feel that, the way we go through life, these moments are necessary in different shapes and forms because they are what will make us understand more about why we're here and what we are doing in life and why we're actually alive. Quite often we're just trundling along and we think, well, it's sort of OK let's hope it stays OK, but it never really does stay OK. When life hits you very hard it's the biggest challenge. So each challenge is how we're going to accept these challenges. So we watch Marie come to terms, or not, with this. We watch how she goes along the way to become, perhaps, to that accepting form at the end of the film.

CC: There's that savage scene towards the end of the film with her mother-in-law, which is I think the most vicious, psychological scene between two women on the screen that I've seen for a long time. Was that tough to do?

CR: Memories of Bette Davis and Joan Crawford

CC: You said it, not me!

CR: I saw it in your eye! Well, it was positive, because it made Marie really resolve and say, "Fuck her,", that body is your son - she didn't know if it was, but she's going to tell that woman it was him in the net, and she says, "Oh. But he never liked fishing! How strange!"

CC: You're competing with an actress in that scene who, like you, knows exactly where to position herself in relation to the camera. So it becomes a great duel between two powerful actors as well as two powerful women.

CR: Yeah, that's what cinema is about. Good cinema can be like that.

CC: I'm curious about the end. Should we suppose that there really is Jean there on the end of the beach or are we deliberately not supposed to make up our minds, and what does Marie think?

CR: Well I think you've got to be as confused as Marie. I'm sorry!

CC: Going back to the beginning of your career, did you always know that you wanted to act?

CR: No, but I knew I wanted to be somewhere in the limelight, I knew I wanted to be up there somewhere. But acting, I didn't really think about it. I thought about singing but that become impossible because my father didn't want that. Acting came, sort of, out of the blue.

CC: Acting was all right with your parents but singing wasn't?

CR: Singing was rather daring because it meant rather short skirts and cabaret, because this was before discotheques you see, so I would have been a cabaret artiste. And I was only sixteen and still at school.

CC: You studied at The Royal Court with William Gaskill and George Devine. What did you learn from these two great men of the British theatre?

CR: Certainly, with George Devine, I learnt stillness, I learnt actually that movement wasn't necessary and you could convey all - we worked a lot with masks - through being still. That was enormous as a lesson, I certainly learnt that through him.

CC: Do you think it's important for a cinema actor to have that sort of stagecraft?

CR: I don't know, because I didn't do it

CC: But the training

CR: I think all training is wonderful and great, it's always useful. I regret not having enough training, I trained for a year at The Royal Court, but I very quickly went off to do films and television. Training is fabulous because it gives you a basis, a strong structure, so that when you're unbelievably nervous and you think that you can't get a word out, you will get the word out. Something is structured within you, that's what the training has given you, and it will come out.

CC: After Georgy Girl you might have spent your career making English pictures, but very quickly you became interesting to European directors - you worked with Visconti on The Damned. Was that something that you'd wanted to do, get into European cinema?

CR: No, but what I wanted to do I was researching psychologically what's the word not disturbed, but psychologically rich people whose inner world could have a voice. The films that were being offered to me in the early sixties in England were very much dollybirds, and girls following plots, and girlfriend of the hero and that sort of thing. So it was through Italy that I found the roles I needed.

CC: Did you find Visconti, or did he find you to play Elizabeth Thallman in The Damned?

CR: He found me. He'd seen me in Georgy girl and he'd seen me in the first Italian picture I did, Sequestro di Persona, called Kidnapped in England. He'd seen those two films.

CC: What was he like as a director?

CR: He became my master. He illustrated all that I imagined cinema could be. I didn't know much about cinema, I didn't have a culture in cinema, I hadn't had theatre training, I wasn't particularly educated in the cinema world and I didn't even know who Visconti was. He showed me a particular type of cinema, which became my matrix, which became the way I wanted to make films. I've never really deviated - they're not all Visconti-type films, but the essence, the quality, the style is what I've always looked for.

CC: When he was on set with you, what would he be asking from you and the other actors?

CR: I said to him, "Look. I can't play this role," when I first met him. She's a woman of thirty and I'm twenty-three and here I am with my hair all over the place in a mini-skirt and I just don't know how this woman suffers. She's got two children and it's an incredible story and I said I didn't know how to do it. He said, "I know that you can do it. Will you trust me?" It was really sweet, and the idea of me turning down Visconti - well, I realised the extent of my youthful madness.

He said, "I know you can do it," and I said, "How?" and he said, "I can see it behind your eyes. Just listen to me. I'm going to make you up, I'm going to change your style, I'm going to make you look like a woman in her thirties, you're going to have beautiful clothes, a beautiful set, you're going to have beautiful people around you. I'm going to put you into this place and you're going to have to do what you have to do. I can't act for you. I can do everything else for you, but I can't act for you. Will you act for me?" I said, "Senor, si! Grazia!" And I did.

CC: What you describe is similar to what other people have said - the absolute fascination with detail. There is a famous story about when he was shooting Ludwig where he sent his favourite designer back to Rome because he didn't like the coachman's buttons. Did you feel that once you were there on the set, that he wasn't going to tell you much about how to do it?

CR: It depends. With Helmut Berger he was an absolute tyrant. He told Helmut every single thing to do. Everything. Every movement. But with the women, he was - I don't know how he was with Ingrid Thulin because we didn't have so many scenes together - certainly with me and Romy Schneider, he just puts you in this most incredible situation where you feel like a princess and you're absolutely loved, and you're dressed and you're made-up and he says, "Just now act for me." And with his women it was like that. With the men it was very different.

CC: That was the first time you worked with Dirk Bogarde. We saw a clip of one of your most notable partnerships, The Night Porter. What were Bogarde's strengths as an actor to work with? What did he bring to the relationship?

CR: Certainly endurance. He never gave up. If ever for a moment I got tired, or looked depressed he would just literally pick me up by the scruff of my neck, sit me down and say, "You never ever admit that you feel tired because you have to be ready for one minute at any time in the fourteen or fifteen hours we're working, because that minute will be the one that is eternally on the screen. You prepare for that constantly'."

He sounded a bit like my father! But he was right, he was absolutely right. You can never go to pieces. It is incredibly strenuous, filming, physically, psychologically, in every way. It's a huge endurance test because you do have to be absolutely there for one minute. That's all it is - three minutes a day, filming. That's all you do. There is a lot of irritation and difficulty and waiting and being uncomfortable in your make-up and costume, and you just want to get out, but you can't. You must be ready for that one moment. He very much taught me about that and helped me in that film and certainly I never forgot that.

CC: Both you and Bogarde are very English in one sense, as actors, but somehow terribly un-English too. It becomes rather dangerous. Am I overstating this, or did you have a sense of that?

CR: Dangerous in what sense?

CC: It doesn't have the neatness and order of most English acting.

CR: After Dirk left the Rank organization and went to live in Italy and then in France, he was in his early forties at that time, he made his break with that. I made my break with that when I was twenty-three and decided that I needed to find characters that weren't in English cinema at that time. In that sense we were on a parallel.

CC: How did you prepare yourself for the part of Lucia Atherton in The Night Porter? Did you think your way into the terrifying history of this woman who had been in the camps during the holocaust?

CR: We started filming the concentration camp sequences in a disinfected TB hospital outside Rome. I'd decided not to think about this story until I started. It was such a violent start I was just propelled into it. I can't describe it.

CC: In approaching a part, do you need to research it and have lots of external things that you know?

CR: No, because I dare to believe that I've got it somewhere in me. I dare to take that risk.

CC: High wire walking, isn't it?

CR: Yeah, but it hasn't proved too bad, has it?

CC: Do you ever worry you might fall?

CR: Of course I do, all the time, but that's the fun! Free-form, no net.

CC: What can you put as a net beneath you?

CR: What can you put? You put things of your life there.

CC: So you've got things to draw on?

CR: Yes. You've got your family, your children, your husband, your home, you put that. That's what holds a lot of stuff so you don't fall off and crash to the ground. There must be a sense of reality, the things you've really created, which is your home and your children.

CC: How much do you want the director to offer you things to hold on to and how much do you want to listen to what you think he or she wants and then do it?

CR: Well, he really is the ringmaster. In a sense I have to be at his command, but not in a submissive way or a puppet-like way, but I must feel that I am going to perform uniquely for him. I have to be sure that he really knows that so that he knows the risk I am taking.

CC: So there is a very important trust from the very beginning?

CR: Yes.

CC: Do you like rehearsals?

CR: No. I don't like rehearsals. That's probably why I don't do theatre. I don't like repeating things.

CC: Is that because in the end there is only one way of doing it?

CR: Gosh, I don't know, that would be terrible to think, wouldn't it? That there's only one way of doing it. But I think I probably think that, yeah. And when I've got it, I don't ever want to do it again. Or I'm too frightened not to be able to get it. Or perhaps I'm not trained enough - had I had a training I think you think differently. I don't think you can think like the way I'm saying, that it can only be once, if you've had a theatrical training because you know you can get it again. But my training is instinctive and it's my training, it's what I've taught myself as I've gone along as to how to get the effect that I want.

CC: Do you think that's a kind of nakedness? The technique that you might have acquired if you'd gone through "great British acting institutions" would have created a superstructure around you, but you don't have that.

CR: No. I have always avoided it, not consciously, except for The Royal Court, which I loved, and the work I did with George Devine. Improvisation work, for example, we did there, and that was wonderful for me. You just had to get up in front of the class and do things. The teacher would say make us laugh, make us cry, make us believe in this. Make us believe in a way that children do. That's very powerful and useful. But anything that's formal, any kind of formal, institutionalised training - and anything institutionalised in life - I always end up avoiding that, and doing something else.

CC: Many people would treasure the film Zardoz most, what was it like working with John Boorman?

CR: Who would treasure most?

CC: Those who'd admired your careerwell, I think that. Alright, I'm speaking for myself

CR: Is he? Is he speaking for himself? That surprises me. Zardoz?

CC: You don't regard that as something special in your career?

CR: I don't know what I regard as special too much, I'm not the best judge. It just made me laugh, I don't know why. It's a funny film, a mixture of all sorts of things.

CC: It just goes to show that critics are always wrong.

CR: I'm certainly not the one who can judge all of that.

CC: It seems to me that you find a completely different style of acting. There you are, with Sean Connery in an all-muscles role, and you cease to be this strange, dark creature and it's another actress altogether.

CR: Hmm.

CC: No? Well, passing lightly over Orca Killer Whale, let's talk about Stardust Memories

CR: Just as well I had Orca Killer Whale, otherwise not a child in the world would know who I was. They couldn't see any of my films. What could my sons see? Well, they saw Orca. And they jolly well enjoyed it, it was a lovely film.

CC: Did Woody Allen casting you in Stardust Memories come out of the blue?<BR

CR: No, he called my agent up. He was in Paris and I saw him and we had a very odd interview. I was sitting there, and he was asking me these rather odd questions and at the end he said, "How do you feel about being my ideal woman?" I said, "Well, I love the idea," and he said, "Well, OK." So I ended up doing the film.

At the time, I had just had a baby and I said to Woody that I couldn't do the film - a pretty agonizing decision but I couldn't leave all my family because he wanted me in New York for five months, because he said it was going to be "an experimental film." I talked to the producer, and the producer said if that was really the case thenWoody got back on the phone and said what can we do? I said, "I don't know," and he said, "Bring the family over." I said, "I can't bring the family over, I've got three children and a husband, I can't bring everybody over to New York and live there for five months." So he said, "Well what can we do?" and I said, "Will you let me come and go?" - in American productions they never let you come and go, especially the studios in Hollywood - so they allowed me to do that. On the Concorde I came and went.

CC: What did he mean when he said my ideal women? Was it just tongue in cheek?

CR: No. No, no it wasn't. His ideal woman is absolutely completely bonkers for twenty-eight days of the month, and fantastic for two or three, but so fantastic you get through the other twenty-eight when she's completely out of her skull.

CC: When he was working on set, did he direct in a way that was quite unusual compared to what you were used to?

CR: He went on and on and on. He said, 'Right. We're going to improvise. You can do what you want.' You could not change a word. So you did things in various ways, but always his way completely.

CC: Was he allowed to improvise?

CR: Well, yeah. He did a lot of improvising, but you weren't allowed to do any improvising at all. But you were bathed in the illusion that you were improvising like mad, but actually you were not changing a word of anything, not even a movement, because he would tell you exactly how he wanted you to move, which was very sweet.

CC: Was the script written so that there was only one way of doing it? You sound like Charlotte Rampling as a Woody Allen leading lady - the lines don't end, there's an upbeat on the end of the line - is that the way it's written or is that the way you find yourself performing for him?

CR: When you work with a director you become like a chameleon. The process of filmmaking is very musical, you get into the rhythm and the rhythmics of how someone is, especially with Woody Allen who is very much into body language and body movement. So it's a kind of mimicry that happens very quickly, you are getting into his rhythm because that's the way he wants you to be in the film. If he wanted you to be very different, you could be very different, but he wanted me to undergo osmosis with him, become the same person. So you just get into that rhythm.

CC: That becomes even more obvious in the sequence where the two of you are in the apartment and the pigeon comes in. When you saw the film, were you surprised at what had happened?

CR: [Laughing] I'm just remembering the sceneWas I surprised? No. I don't know. I suppose I'm always a bit surprised, yeah, when I see the films.

CC: Although he insisted that you kept to the script, quite a lot of things happened when he started to construct the film afterwards, so perhaps what you thought you were doing wasn't what you ended up doing.

CR: Well, he said that it was going to be "an experimental film," and this meant that a few times I came back and we'd do five versions of a scene.

For instance, the scene where Dorrie breaks down, we couldn't get how to show somebody breaking down. We did this scene in a clinic, then we were here, then we were there, then it was me, looking depressed and all this. Every time it didn't work. The final time he called me back and said just sit down, with a black background, and said, "I've got all this text. Just read it, or learn it. Do something with it. Say all these words to the camera." As I was saying them something happened with the camera, I don't know the technical word, but the frame freezes for a minute and so it sort of stops. That became the scene. It was a mistake. He was doing something and it did that. That's how things happen. You find things, and that is the magic of films - so often it's out of your control. The most beautiful things happen.

 To next page.
fields.bodyText: Charlotte Rampling on: Under the sand | early career | Luchino Visconti | Dirk Bogarde | acting technique | Woody Allen and Stardust Memories Christopher Cook: What was it that you liked about the script of Under the Sand that made you want to take the part of Marie? Charlotte Rampling: It wasn't a script at all, it was just an idea. François Ozon, whose work I was beginning to discover a few months before, came to me via my agent and said that he had this idea, which was just the first part of the film until the husband disappears, because it was something he himself witnessed when he was a boy of twelve. He was haunted by this idea and it so happens that at the age of thirty-two he was looking for someone who would be able to follow, to find out what happened to this woman that he saw pack her little bag with the towels and the beach ball, and go home and never really know what happened to her husband. So, that's the story. We filmed the first part, up to where the husband disappeared, then we stopped filming and then he wrote the screenplay. CC: But there must have been something about the story that caught your imagination as an actor? CR: I think because it was so incredibly difficult to imagine what could possibly happen, and how we could put that across on the screen. How could you actually make interesting what this woman was going through after such an experience? More and more as François Ozon wrote the screenplay, more and more he didn't want anything to happen - he just wanted to film it through the eyes of the woman. CC: Being there while the screenplay was being written, did you get an opportunity to shape what was happening to Marie? CR: Yes, because I was his blueprint - the essence of what could happen in this very fragile story because there was no plot particularly, it was just about "a being." Perhaps you feel it when you see this film, this film is more an experience than actually seeing a film, it's a very personal thing for everybody. The people that are affected by the film, and they seemed to be quite affected in France, if you are affected by it then it becomes your story. CC: Was there a sense in which you felt that the feminine aspect of the character needed a little help that perhaps you could bring in? CR: Well, there was never a question of me collaborating on the writing, but I very much collaborated with him in terms of ideas. At one moment I said to him that I thought it necessary for him to collaborate with a woman writer and so he worked with two women on the writing at one stage. CC: When you first see this film it doesn't seem to be a long, strong narrative, it seems to be about a woman trying to come to terms with the inexplicable loss of her husband Jean. But the film plays on your mind and isn't about that at all, it's not about mourning the loss of a husband really, is it? CR: No, that's the pretext of the story. Quite often in life, when a tragic event arrives it becomes a springboard for mirroring all other things in one's life that one hasn't come to terms with. To grieve is something extremely difficult, we don't even know how to begin to grieve, and I don't know how you can be taught to grieve. But it's how to come to terms with suffering, that's what it's really about - not to resist it, not to deny it, but to accept it - but we don't really want to do that because it's too painful. CC: Also a woman who is emotionally shipwrecked by an event. She loses all sense of bearing and it's an attempt to recover a sense of identity. CR: Yeah. I don't know, I sort of feel that, the way we go through life, these moments are necessary in different shapes and forms because they are what will make us understand more about why we're here and what we are doing in life and why we're actually alive. Quite often we're just trundling along and we think, well, it's sort of OK let's hope it stays OK, but it never really does stay OK. When life hits you very hard it's the biggest challenge. So each challenge is how we're going to accept these challenges. So we watch Marie come to terms, or not, with this. We watch how she goes along the way to become, perhaps, to that accepting form at the end of the film. CC: There's that savage scene towards the end of the film with her mother-in-law, which is I think the most vicious, psychological scene between two women on the screen that I've seen for a long time. Was that tough to do? CR: Memories of Bette Davis and Joan Crawford CC: You said it, not me! CR: I saw it in your eye! Well, it was positive, because it made Marie really resolve and say, "Fuck her,", that body is your son - she didn't know if it was, but she's going to tell that woman it was him in the net, and she says, "Oh. But he never liked fishing! How strange!" CC: You're competing with an actress in that scene who, like you, knows exactly where to position herself in relation to the camera. So it becomes a great duel between two powerful actors as well as two powerful women. CR: Yeah, that's what cinema is about. Good cinema can be like that. CC: I'm curious about the end. Should we suppose that there really is Jean there on the end of the beach or are we deliberately not supposed to make up our minds, and what does Marie think? CR: Well I think you've got to be as confused as Marie. I'm sorry! CC: Going back to the beginning of your career, did you always know that you wanted to act? CR: No, but I knew I wanted to be somewhere in the limelight, I knew I wanted to be up there somewhere. But acting, I didn't really think about it. I thought about singing but that become impossible because my father didn't want that. Acting came, sort of, out of the blue. CC: Acting was all right with your parents but singing wasn't? CR: Singing was rather daring because it meant rather short skirts and cabaret, because this was before discotheques you see, so I would have been a cabaret artiste. And I was only sixteen and still at school. CC: You studied at The Royal Court with William Gaskill and George Devine. What did you learn from these two great men of the British theatre? CR: Certainly, with George Devine, I learnt stillness, I learnt actually that movement wasn't necessary and you could convey all - we worked a lot with masks - through being still. That was enormous as a lesson, I certainly learnt that through him. CC: Do you think it's important for a cinema actor to have that sort of stagecraft? CR: I don't know, because I didn't do it CC: But the training CR: I think all training is wonderful and great, it's always useful. I regret not having enough training, I trained for a year at The Royal Court, but I very quickly went off to do films and television. Training is fabulous because it gives you a basis, a strong structure, so that when you're unbelievably nervous and you think that you can't get a word out, you will get the word out. Something is structured within you, that's what the training has given you, and it will come out. CC: After Georgy Girl you might have spent your career making English pictures, but very quickly you became interesting to European directors - you worked with Visconti on The Damned. Was that something that you'd wanted to do, get into European cinema? CR: No, but what I wanted to do I was researching psychologically what's the word not disturbed, but psychologically rich people whose inner world could have a voice. The films that were being offered to me in the early sixties in England were very much dollybirds, and girls following plots, and girlfriend of the hero and that sort of thing. So it was through Italy that I found the roles I needed. CC: Did you find Visconti, or did he find you to play Elizabeth Thallman in The Damned? CR: He found me. He'd seen me in Georgy girl and he'd seen me in the first Italian picture I did, Sequestro di Persona, called Kidnapped in England. He'd seen those two films. CC: What was he like as a director? CR: He became my master. He illustrated all that I imagined cinema could be. I didn't know much about cinema, I didn't have a culture in cinema, I hadn't had theatre training, I wasn't particularly educated in the cinema world and I didn't even know who Visconti was. He showed me a particular type of cinema, which became my matrix, which became the way I wanted to make films. I've never really deviated - they're not all Visconti-type films, but the essence, the quality, the style is what I've always looked for. CC: When he was on set with you, what would he be asking from you and the other actors? CR: I said to him, "Look. I can't play this role," when I first met him. She's a woman of thirty and I'm twenty-three and here I am with my hair all over the place in a mini-skirt and I just don't know how this woman suffers. She's got two children and it's an incredible story and I said I didn't know how to do it. He said, "I know that you can do it. Will you trust me?" It was really sweet, and the idea of me turning down Visconti - well, I realised the extent of my youthful madness. He said, "I know you can do it," and I said, "How?" and he said, "I can see it behind your eyes. Just listen to me. I'm going to make you up, I'm going to change your style, I'm going to make you look like a woman in her thirties, you're going to have beautiful clothes, a beautiful set, you're going to have beautiful people around you. I'm going to put you into this place and you're going to have to do what you have to do. I can't act for you. I can do everything else for you, but I can't act for you. Will you act for me?" I said, "Senor, si! Grazia!" And I did. CC: What you describe is similar to what other people have said - the absolute fascination with detail. There is a famous story about when he was shooting Ludwig where he sent his favourite designer back to Rome because he didn't like the coachman's buttons. Did you feel that once you were there on the set, that he wasn't going to tell you much about how to do it? CR: It depends. With Helmut Berger he was an absolute tyrant. He told Helmut every single thing to do. Everything. Every movement. But with the women, he was - I don't know how he was with Ingrid Thulin because we didn't have so many scenes together - certainly with me and Romy Schneider, he just puts you in this most incredible situation where you feel like a princess and you're absolutely loved, and you're dressed and you're made-up and he says, "Just now act for me." And with his women it was like that. With the men it was very different. CC: That was the first time you worked with Dirk Bogarde. We saw a clip of one of your most notable partnerships, The Night Porter. What were Bogarde's strengths as an actor to work with? What did he bring to the relationship? CR: Certainly endurance. He never gave up. If ever for a moment I got tired, or looked depressed he would just literally pick me up by the scruff of my neck, sit me down and say, "You never ever admit that you feel tired because you have to be ready for one minute at any time in the fourteen or fifteen hours we're working, because that minute will be the one that is eternally on the screen. You prepare for that constantly'." He sounded a bit like my father! But he was right, he was absolutely right. You can never go to pieces. It is incredibly strenuous, filming, physically, psychologically, in every way. It's a huge endurance test because you do have to be absolutely there for one minute. That's all it is - three minutes a day, filming. That's all you do. There is a lot of irritation and difficulty and waiting and being uncomfortable in your make-up and costume, and you just want to get out, but you can't. You must be ready for that one moment. He very much taught me about that and helped me in that film and certainly I never forgot that. CC: Both you and Bogarde are very English in one sense, as actors, but somehow terribly un-English too. It becomes rather dangerous. Am I overstating this, or did you have a sense of that? CR: Dangerous in what sense? CC: It doesn't have the neatness and order of most English acting. CR: After Dirk left the Rank organization and went to live in Italy and then in France, he was in his early forties at that time, he made his break with that. I made my break with that when I was twenty-three and decided that I needed to find characters that weren't in English cinema at that time. In that sense we were on a parallel. CC: How did you prepare yourself for the part of Lucia Atherton in The Night Porter? Did you think your way into the terrifying history of this woman who had been in the camps during the holocaust? CR: We started filming the concentration camp sequences in a disinfected TB hospital outside Rome. I'd decided not to think about this story until I started. It was such a violent start I was just propelled into it. I can't describe it. CC: In approaching a part, do you need to research it and have lots of external things that you know? CR: No, because I dare to believe that I've got it somewhere in me. I dare to take that risk. CC: High wire walking, isn't it? CR: Yeah, but it hasn't proved too bad, has it? CC: Do you ever worry you might fall? CR: Of course I do, all the time, but that's the fun! Free-form, no net. CC: What can you put as a net beneath you? CR: What can you put? You put things of your life there. CC: So you've got things to draw on? CR: Yes. You've got your family, your children, your husband, your home, you put that. That's what holds a lot of stuff so you don't fall off and crash to the ground. There must be a sense of reality, the things you've really created, which is your home and your children. CC: How much do you want the director to offer you things to hold on to and how much do you want to listen to what you think he or she wants and then do it? CR: Well, he really is the ringmaster. In a sense I have to be at his command, but not in a submissive way or a puppet-like way, but I must feel that I am going to perform uniquely for him. I have to be sure that he really knows that so that he knows the risk I am taking. CC: So there is a very important trust from the very beginning? CR: Yes. CC: Do you like rehearsals? CR: No. I don't like rehearsals. That's probably why I don't do theatre. I don't like repeating things. CC: Is that because in the end there is only one way of doing it? CR: Gosh, I don't know, that would be terrible to think, wouldn't it? That there's only one way of doing it. But I think I probably think that, yeah. And when I've got it, I don't ever want to do it again. Or I'm too frightened not to be able to get it. Or perhaps I'm not trained enough - had I had a training I think you think differently. I don't think you can think like the way I'm saying, that it can only be once, if you've had a theatrical training because you know you can get it again. But my training is instinctive and it's my training, it's what I've taught myself as I've gone along as to how to get the effect that I want. CC: Do you think that's a kind of nakedness? The technique that you might have acquired if you'd gone through "great British acting institutions" would have created a superstructure around you, but you don't have that. CR: No. I have always avoided it, not consciously, except for The Royal Court, which I loved, and the work I did with George Devine. Improvisation work, for example, we did there, and that was wonderful for me. You just had to get up in front of the class and do things. The teacher would say make us laugh, make us cry, make us believe in this. Make us believe in a way that children do. That's very powerful and useful. But anything that's formal, any kind of formal, institutionalised training - and anything institutionalised in life - I always end up avoiding that, and doing something else. CC: Many people would treasure the film Zardoz most, what was it like working with John Boorman? CR: Who would treasure most? CC: Those who'd admired your careerwell, I think that. Alright, I'm speaking for myself CR: Is he? Is he speaking for himself? That surprises me. Zardoz? CC: You don't regard that as something special in your career? CR: I don't know what I regard as special too much, I'm not the best judge. It just made me laugh, I don't know why. It's a funny film, a mixture of all sorts of things. CC: It just goes to show that critics are always wrong. CR: I'm certainly not the one who can judge all of that. CC: It seems to me that you find a completely different style of acting. There you are, with Sean Connery in an all-muscles role, and you cease to be this strange, dark creature and it's another actress altogether. CR: Hmm. CC: No? Well, passing lightly over Orca Killer Whale, let's talk about Stardust Memories CR: Just as well I had Orca Killer Whale, otherwise not a child in the world would know who I was. They couldn't see any of my films. What could my sons see? Well, they saw Orca. And they jolly well enjoyed it, it was a lovely film. CC: Did Woody Allen casting you in Stardust Memories come out of the blue?

fields.headline: Race equality: the basics
fields.trailText: • Minority ethnic groups now account for 10% of Britain's population.
fields.body:
 Minority ethnic groups now account for 10% of Britain's population.

 The failure to convict anyone for the murder of Stephen Lawrence acts as a symbol for the racial discrimination and injustice still prevalent in Britain today. It has also served as the catalyst to address the particular problem of institutional racism.

 The new Race Relations Amendment Act comes into force in April 2001.

 The act attempts to stop racism and discrimination in the public sector.

 Britain's five leading political parties have pledged to act against candidates and campaigners who stir up racial prejudice in the forthcoming general election.

fields.headline: 'Defiant' Graham sacked by Tottenham
fields.trailText: George Graham has parted company with Tottenham Hotspur.
fields.body:
George Graham has parted company with Tottenham Hotspur.

He was summoned to an emergency meeting with Spurs executive vice-chairman David Buchler and was told that the club could no longer work with him.

It follows Graham revealing at a press conference yesterday details of his meeting this week with Tottenham's new owners ENIC. Graham had told fans not to expect "big outlays" on new players.

Buchler said: "I had a private meeting with George Graham and David Pleat this week and then found this morning details of it plastered across the press.

"I called George in for an explanation today and asked for an explanation. However no explanation was forthcoming and he had a defiant attitude.

"I am building from top to bottom a cohesive team and this is a difficult time for the club with a semi-final coming up and negotiations with players over contracts.

"We agreed we cannot work with each other. I am not prepared to have someone who is not a team player and who is not looking after the club's interests."

Buchler went on to say that no contacts had been made toward finding a replacement for Graham, and that David Pleat, "who has stepped into the breach successfully in the past", would be taking over the running of the team.

However, he did say that the club would be looking "at all options, both in this country and abroad" to find a new manager.

Buchler angrily denied that Tottenham's new owners did not have ambitions for the club. "We're talking about investing an eight-figure sum in the club's playing squad, and we've made an offer for one player in the last 24 hours," he said. "There is no lack of ambition here."

Expressing regret for the timing of the decision, Buchler insisted that "this club is bigger than any individual."

fields.headline: Black policewoman wins race claim
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: An industrial tribunal yesterday called on the chief constable of Merseyside police to apologise to a black woman officer, who was intimidated by colleagues' racist comments.
fields.body:
An industrial tribunal yesterday called on the chief constable of Merseyside police to apologise to a black woman officer, who was intimidated by colleagues' racist comments.

PC Dawn Devanna, 31, was awarded £5,000 for hurt feelings by the tribunal in Liverpool, where two white officers were also given verbal and written disciplinary warnings.

The tribunal unanimously recommended that Norman Bettison, chief constable of Merseyside, make a formal apology to PC Devanna, who broke down in tears at the hearing. She is still a serving officer with the force which issued a statement after the verdict, saying that "inappropriate behaviour" by its officers would not be tolerated.

The four-day tribunal had been told that references to "Toxteth buckesses" were intended only as harmless banter, but the chairman dismissed that as an unacceptable excuse. Elaine Donnelly, giving the verdict, said: "For many years, both women and non-white people have had to accept such banter with good grace. The world has changed, particularly since the Macpherson Report."

The tribunal had been told that Ms Devanna, who was brought up in the Toxteth area which was scarred by rioting in 1981, had been left "bewildered, bullied, initimidated and angry" by comments from Alan Richards and Anne Baker, at Huyton police station. They had referred to the riots in a stream of what they claimed were "office jokes".

fields.headline: The Black arts leave writers riled
fields.standfirst: Letter to Spectator accuses pro-Israeli tycoon of stifling debate on Middle East throughout his Telegraph Group
fields.trailText: Three writers have accused Telegraph chief Conrad Black of abusing his responsibilities as a proprietor, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
An intellectual pillow fight between Conrad Black and a clutch of distinguished writers from his prestigious publications has exploded into a titanic battle of egos. After accusing the Spectator columnist Taki Theodoracopoulos of anti-semitism for criticising Israel's role in the Middle East conflict, the press baron is in the dock himself - accused of stifling reasoned debate.

Three prominent writers - all of them past contributors to Mr Black's Telegraph group - have signed a letter to the Spectator accusing him of abusing his responsibilities as a proprietor. Such is the vehemence with which Mr Black has expounded his pro-Israel views, they say, no editor or reporter would dare write frankly about the Palestinian perspective.

"Readers have been warned. There may be many good things in Black's newspapers, but for balanced reporting from the Middle East, they must now, sadly, turn elsewhere."

With characteristic bombast, Black dismisses them as "whingers and simperers", arguing that he has just as much right as the next man to write to his own publications and insisting that his editors are free to print a range of opinions without proprietorial interference.

Caught in the middle is the Spectator editor, Boris Johnson, fielding at once the ire of his boss and the irritation of his contributors.

The anger of pro-Palestinian writers was provoked last November when the commentator Barbara Amiel, wife of Mr Black, wrote in a 5,300-word article in the Daily Telegraph that, despite Palestinian claims to the contrary, no serious attacks on Islamic holy sites would ever be tolerated by the Israelis.

Taki later incensed Mr Black in a Spectator column when he said that the US had intended to force down the aeroplane of the fugitive financier Marc Rich. He said that Rich only escaped because he was tipped off by the Israeli secret service Mossad - a payback for the "moola" that Rich had given Israel. (In an unfortunate passage, Taki labelled himself an anti-Semite by confusing the term "soi disant" - thinking it meant "so-called" when in fact it translates as "self-styled".)

For Mr Black, Taki's claims about Rich were "lies worthy of Goebbels". In a trenchant piece the following week, he said Taki's piece was unworthy of the Spectator and went on to lambast sections of the media- including the BBC, the Indepen dent and the Guardian - for allegedly being biased in favour of the Palestinians.

A boisterous correspondence ensued in the letters pages of the Spectator: this week, Mr Black returned to print with another scathing attack on his critics. "Fair comment and non-venomous ethnic reflections that might offend the politically correct are perfectly acceptable from contributors. However, our publications will not be used for incitements to racial or religious bigotry," he thundered.

In the same issue, three prominent writers took issue with Mr Black's line. His original article would scare his editors from printing opposing views, argued William Dalrymple, Piers Paul Read and AN Wilson. "It makes explicit what has long been apparent to those of us who have written about the Middle East in the Spectator: that under Black's proprietorship, serious, critical reporting of Israel is no longer tolerated in the Telegraph Group, however much Arab land Israel seizes, however many settlements it constructs in violation of international law and the Geneva conventions, however many Palestinians it expels or tortures and however many unarmed children it shoots."

Mr Black dismissed the charges as "complete nonsense". He said: "I'm happy to exchange fire with these people, but when I score a series of direct hits on them, I don't see why they should whinge and simper that I don't have the right to write to my own publications."

He said that while he might exchange views with his editors, they were free to publish articles expressing views that opposed his own, so long as they were clearly labelled as comment. "The allegation that I bully and intimidate our editors is nonsense," he said.

Mr Johnson was equally scathing, claiming that the writers wanted to withdraw their letter when it emerged that they had praised the independence of a Jerusalem-based publication without realising it was now controlled by Mr Black. "It's all very well them casting aspersions, but if they are going to get their facts wrong, they had better get up earlier in the morning," he said.

The three writers claim Mr Johnson and Mr Black colluded to retain the inaccuracy, thereby giving the proprietor more ammunition with which to attack them. Mr Johnson said: "It must be the first time in history that people are complaining that we ran their letter."

Who's who in The Spectator spat

Conrad Black Age 56. Canadian publisher. Chairman of Hollinger, owner of the Telegraph group. Military historian. Has passionate and strongly-held views on the Middle East conflict. Former Tory minister Lord Gilmour accused him of dispensing "virulent Israeli propaganda"; Black retorted that Gilmour was "an almost pathological Americanophobic myth-maker".

Boris Johnson Age 36. Young fogey editor of the Spectator and regular on the punditry circuit - currently seen sparring on BBC News 24 with the Guardian's Polly Toynbee. Selected as Tory candidate for Michael Heseltine's seat, Henley, for the next election. Speculation continues about whether he will continue a role at the magazine if he is elected.

AN Wilson Age 50. Full name Andrew Wilson. Former literary editor at the Spectator. Now writes column for the Evening Standard, edited by former Daily Telegraph editor Max Hastings. Revealed recently that Field Marshall Montgomery, on a visit to Rugby school, had "allowed his fingers very delicately to stroke mine".

Taki Theodoracopoulos Age 63. Outspoken socialite and columnist, writes column for the Spectator. Vocal supporter of General Pinochet and one-time backer of disgraced former Tory MP Neil Hamilton. Once described New York Puerto Ricans as "fat, squat, ugly, dusky, dirty and unbelievably loud. They turned Manhattan into Palermo faster than you can say spic." Then, he was defended by Black.

Barbara Amiel Age 60. Wife of Mr Black and occasional Telegraph contributer. Appears to have set off the current spat with a legendary article in the Daily Telegraph last November, in which she claimed Israel would never desecrate an Islamic holy site. Described by a former editor of the Tatler, Lucy Yeomans, as a woman who can"sit in the front row of the couture and then whip up 5,000 words on the Middle East crisis".

William Dalrymple Age 35. Travel writer and author. Has had run-ins with Black over the Middle East question before: Black claims Dalrymple was dropped as a Telegraph contributor after "inventing" a story of Israeli desecration of Christian sites in Palestine; Dalrymple says his claims, in the award-winning book From the Holy Mountain, have never seriously been challenged.

Caught in the middle is the Spectator editor, Boris Johnson, fielding at once the ire of his boss and the irritation of his contributors. The anger of pro-Palestinian writers was provoked last November when the commentator Barbara Amiel, wife of Mr Black, wrote in a 5,300-word article in the Daily Telegraph that, despite Palestinian claims to the contrary, no serious attacks on Islamic holy sites would ever be tolerated by the Israelis. Taki later incensed Mr Black in a Spectator column when he said that the US had intended to force down the aeroplane of the fugitive financier Marc Rich. He said that Rich only escaped because he was tipped off by the Israeli secret service Mossad - a payback for the "moola" that Rich had given Israel. (In an unfortunate passage, Taki labelled himself an anti-Semite by confusing the term "soi disant" - thinking it meant "so-called" when in fact it translates as "self-styled".) For Mr Black, Taki's claims about Rich were "lies worthy of Goebbels". In a trenchant piece the following week, he said Taki's piece was unworthy of the Spectator and went on to lambast sections of the media- including the BBC, the Indepen dent and the Guardian - for allegedly being biased in favour of the Palestinians. A boisterous correspondence ensued in the letters pages of the Spectator: this week, Mr Black returned to print with another scathing attack on his critics. "Fair comment and non-venomous ethnic reflections that might offend the politically correct are perfectly acceptable from contributors. However, our publications will not be used for incitements to racial or religious bigotry," he thundered. In the same issue, three prominent writers took issue with Mr Black's line. His original article would scare his editors from printing opposing views, argued William Dalrymple, Piers Paul Read and AN Wilson. "It makes explicit what has long been apparent to those of us who have written about the Middle East in the Spectator: that under Black's proprietorship, serious, critical reporting of Israel is no longer tolerated in the Telegraph Group, however much Arab land Israel seizes, however many settlements it constructs in violation of international law and the Geneva conventions, however many Palestinians it expels or tortures and however many unarmed children it shoots." Mr Black dismissed the charges as "complete nonsense". He said: "I'm happy to exchange fire with these people, but when I score a series of direct hits on them, I don't see why they should whinge and simper that I don't have the right to write to my own publications." He said that while he might exchange views with his editors, they were free to publish articles expressing views that opposed his own, so long as they were clearly labelled as comment. "The allegation that I bully and intimidate our editors is nonsense," he said. Mr Johnson was equally scathing, claiming that the writers wanted to withdraw their letter when it emerged that they had praised the independence of a Jerusalem-based publication without realising it was now controlled by Mr Black. "It's all very well them casting aspersions, but if they are going to get their facts wrong, they had better get up earlier in the morning," he said. The three writers claim Mr Johnson and Mr Black colluded to retain the inaccuracy, thereby giving the proprietor more ammunition with which to attack them. Mr Johnson said: "It must be the first time in history that people are complaining that we ran their letter." Who's who in The Spectator spat Conrad Black Age 56. Canadian publisher. Chairman of Hollinger, owner of the Telegraph group. Military historian. Has passionate and strongly-held views on the Middle East conflict. Former Tory minister Lord Gilmour accused him of dispensing "virulent Israeli propaganda"; Black retorted that Gilmour was "an almost pathological Americanophobic myth-maker". Boris Johnson Age 36. Young fogey editor of the Spectator and regular on the punditry circuit - currently seen sparring on BBC News 24 with the Guardian's Polly Toynbee. Selected as Tory candidate for Michael Heseltine's seat, Henley, for the next election. Speculation continues about whether he will continue a role at the magazine if he is elected. AN Wilson Age 50. Full name Andrew Wilson. Former literary editor at the Spectator. Now writes column for the Evening Standard, edited by former Daily Telegraph editor Max Hastings. Revealed recently that Field Marshall Montgomery, on a visit to Rugby school, had "allowed his fingers very delicately to stroke mine". Taki Theodoracopoulos Age 63. Outspoken socialite and columnist, writes column for the Spectator. Vocal supporter of General Pinochet and one-time backer of disgraced former Tory MP Neil Hamilton. Once described New York Puerto Ricans as "fat, squat, ugly, dusky, dirty and unbelievably loud. They turned Manhattan into Palermo faster than you can say spic." Then, he was defended by Black. Barbara Amiel Age 60. Wife of Mr Black and occasional Telegraph contributer. Appears to have set off the current spat with a legendary article in the Daily Telegraph last November, in which she claimed Israel would never desecrate an Islamic holy site. Described by a former editor of the Tatler, Lucy Yeomans, as a woman who can"sit in the front row of the couture and then whip up 5,000 words on the Middle East crisis". William Dalrymple Age 35. Travel writer and author. Has had run-ins with Black over the Middle East question before: Black claims Dalrymple was dropped as a Telegraph contributor after "inventing" a story of Israeli desecration of Christian sites in Palestine; Dalrymple says his claims, in the award-winning book From the Holy Mountain, have never seriously been challenged.

fields.headline: Downturn has worldwide impact
fields.standfirst:
Jane Martinson reports from New York on how the US markets are not alone in their downward slide

Special report: Japan
Special report: Bush's America
fields.trailText: Jane Martinson reports from New York on how the US markets are not alone in their downward slide.
fields.body:
It has been an awful week for US stock markets and today provided little relief.

Early morning optimism based on economic data that was somewhat less than terrible caused forecasters to predict a happy start to the last trading day of the week. In the event, few traders had cause to thank God it was Friday as both the benchmark Dow industrial average and technology-dominated Nasdaq composite index fell as soon as the opening bell had rung. Within an hour, they had plummeted.

Sentiment was so far that few traders believed that a bottom had been reached in spite of having suffered one of the worse weeks so far this year. Art Hogan, chief market analyst at Jefferies and Co, said wearily: "I don't think anybody really feels like the worst is over."

The Nasdaq composite index, which tracks most of the world's best known high technology companies, sank below the psychologically important 2,000 level for the first time in more than two years on Monday. This is 62% below a high reached just last March, when the bubble of enthusiasm for dot.com shares was at its most bloated. The decline reflects trillions of dollars of value erased from portfolios around the world.

This week underlined the fact that once high flying wannabes are not the only ones suffering from the downturn in the US economy and enthusiasm, however. The Dow, a blue-chip index of 30 of the biggest and most established companies in the US, fell below 10,000 this week after falling more than 6% since last Friday.

The travails of the US markets have had a dramatic impact on those in rest of the world. The FTSE stock market index in the UK also reached two-year lows this week as investors worried about the exposure of British companies to the world's biggest economy.

In the UK, the direct correlation between share prices and consumer sentiment is not as high as the US, where more than half of the population are equity owners. However, the negative sentiment still has an impact on corporate confidence and behaviour.

In the US, economists believe that consumers are so terrified about their obliteration of their stock market wealth that they will stop spending on all but essentials, exacerbating the fears of a full-blown recession. These fears were heightened by weak consumer confidence figures yesterday.

The fear has become so great that George Bush, who has repeatedly talked about the bleak state of his country's economy since being sworn in as president, finally decided to stop talking it down. As the Dow was falling on Wednesday, he said, "I've got great faith in our economy."

Traders were pleased. Mr Hogan said: "The leader of the country should not be saying that the sky is falling in."

The president's comment admittedly did little to cheer the markets. Most traders were too busy trying to predict what an even more important man will say next Tuesday, when Alan Greenspan, US central banker, is expected to cut the cost of borrowing in the US for the third time this year.

Lawrence Kudlow, chief economist at ING Barings, is one of several who believe the Fed is unlikely to take a tough enough stance on cutting interest rates. He has accused Mr Greenspan of doing "too little, too late".

webTitle: Huge shock, Big Cup, and Reasonably sized Vase

fields.headline: Huge shock, Big Cup, and Reasonably sized Vase
fields.trailText: SPURS SHOCK SACKING SUPER SPECIAL!
fields.body:
SPURS SHOCK SACKING SUPER SPECIAL!

If you thought that Spurs executive vice-chairman David Buchler was angry yesterday when he was firing salvos at well-known buck-toothed train franchise owners, you ain't seen nothin' yet. This afternoon, the perpetually cross ENIC executive summoned manager George Graham to his parlour and demanded to know why details of a "private meeting" were splattered all over the papers. Nanoseconds later, he sacked him.

[pause while 86% of White Hart Lane faithful cheer wildly and race off to pub]

"I had a private meeting with George Graham and David Pleat this week and then found this morning details of it plastered across the press," Buchler explained, referring to an interview Graham gave telling fans not to expect any "big outlays" on new players. "I called George in for an explanation today. However, no explanation was forthcoming and he had a defiant attitude," the Spurs exec seethed, simmered, salivated and stewed.

"I am building from top to bottom a cohesive team, and this is a difficult time for the club, with a semi-final coming up and negotiations with players over contracts," babbled the bubbling board member. "We agreed we cannot work with each other. I am not prepared to have someone who is not a team player and who is not looking after the club's interests," he put the boot in, before installing David Pleat as caretaker manager.

But who will take over full time? Well, there's Southampton boss Glenn Hoddle, of course, although they'll want to get their FA Cup run out of the way first, as Hod is plainly a managerial liability in that particular tournament. Another former player, Gary Mabbutt, has been mentioned in dispatches, seemingly on the grounds that he's a bit of a nice bloke. And, of course, there's Terry Venables. The Middlesbrough supremo may have had enough of picking Bryan Robson up when he needs burping, and with nemesis Alan Sugar out of the way, he'd be free to return.

Inevitably, other names will enter the frame as well, so if you've heard any wild rumours - or perhaps made one up yourself - send them to the.boss@theguardian.com. And if Spurs haven't cleared this mess up over the weekend, we may be able to get some mileage out of them next week.

TOUGH DRAW FOR UNITED (BUT EUROPE ISN'T JUST ABOUT LEEDS, YOU KNOW)

ITV commentator Clive Tyldesley finds it impossible to string more than a few words together without mentioning Manchester United's 1999 Big Cup victory over Bayern Munich. The other night, barely seven minutes of a game involving Arsenal had elapsed before he was waxing lyrical about Ole Gunnar Solksjaer's late Nou Camp contribution. This, to be fair, was his most restrained effort for some time, but as the Fiver doubts whether the man can order a cup of tea in the staff canteen without mentioning a Teddy Sheringham near-post flick, we're sure this morning's draw for the Big Cup quarter-finals has blown his sense of perspective to pieces once and for all.

Yes, the most hated team in England have drawn the most hated team in Germany in Big Cup. "Bayern will be looking for revenge but obviously we've got great memories of that night," United secretary Ken Merrett said as the Old Trafford PR machine wheeled the big guns out. "We see them as the toughest opponent in the draw," uberface of Bayern, Franz Beckenbauer, smarmed in unison. Sadly, the romantic trills of the United-Bayern love-in were soon drowned out by raucous laughter across Europe, when it was realised that the winners of this tie will probably be knocked out in the semis: they'll face either Real Madrid or Galatasaray (ie Real Madrid).

Meanwhile, the other half of the draw looks a bit healthier for the two teams Clive barely mentions on ITV's superb and in no way base Big Cup coverage. Leeds will play Deportivo, while Arsenal will struggle against Valencia, and it wasn't long before big nobs from both teams were wheeling out meaningless soundbites. "We've just got to win!" said Arsenal vice-chairman David Dein, while shy Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale mumbled, "It doesn't matter who we got!" And if both English teams win their ties - first leg April 3/4, second leg April 17/18 - they'll face each other in the semis. That should be enough to grab Clive's attention. Won't it?

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"It's another challenge. It's not a challenge that I would have liked - I'd rather have had the challenge of getting into Europe - but it's another challenge and it's a challenge that I relish. It's a challenge and I'm up for that challenge" - Middlesbrough midfielder Paul Ince on the challenge of the relegation challenge.

NOT BIG CUP

It may be the competition nobody takes seriously, but there are advantages to playing in Euro Vase, you know. Unlike the teams playing with the Big Cup big boys, you get a whole section in the Fiver to yourself for a start. Actually, that's about it, to tell the truth. But plucky little Alaves, who will play Kaiserslautern in the semi-finals to be held on April 5 and April 19, aren't going to turn down some much-needed exposure, are they?

Liverpool, meanwhile, have drawn Barcelona in the other semi. So that's that, then. "It would be a great final but you've got to play the best teams sooner or later and in many ways I think we would rather have them over the two legs," grimaced Anfield money-man Rick Parry. "And we also have the opportunity of that visit to the Nou Camp," he bravely chirped, desperately grabbing at the few straws poking out of the pile of rubble that represents his club's hopes and dreams.

At least one man is happy to be facing Barcelona's multitude of famous names including Rivaldo, Patrick Kluivert and, erm, um, that Dutch bloke who has a brother. "I am sure this is the tie every Liverpool fan wanted," smiled tricky winger and hopeless crosser Vladimir Smicer. "After all, Barcelona is a great city and I know that I am not the only person on Merseyside who wants to experience their magnificent stadium. It has always been my dream to play in the Nou Camp stadium and this gives me the opportunity to do that." Hmm, close your eyes and that could almost be Jari Litmanen talking, couldn't it?

THE RUMOUR MILL

Coventry, Derby and Wimbledon are all chasing 24-year-old Mechelen striker Joris van Hout.

Huddersfield are interested in Southampton midfielder Chris Marsden.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Middlesbrough today confirmed that Dean Windass' move to the Riverside from Bradford has been completed. The deal, which could eventually be worth up to £1m, was sealed ahead of the noon deadline which means he is available for selection for tomorrow's derby clash with Newcastle. No details of the agreement have been revealed after a week of renegotiations, during which it emerged the original plan - £600,000 down with £400,000 to come if Boro avoid relegation - was extremely unlikely to be approved.

England Under-21 coach Howard Wilkinson has included Newcastle striker Shola Ameobi in his squad for next Friday's European Championship qualifier with Finland at Oakwell. Wilkinson is keen for the 19-year-old Ameobi to pledge his international future to England after news that Nigeria are keen on securing his services.

Wycombe manager Lawrie Sanchez has been charged with misconduct by the FA. Sanchez allegedly used abusive behaviour towards a match official during the second half of last weekend's FA Cup quarter-final win over Leicester at Filbert Street.

Tony Cottee has left his post of player-manager at Barnet after just four months in charge. He said: "This has been a fantastic learning curve for me and my experience with Barnet will stand me in good stead for the future. With the current precarious situation, the chairman and I agree that it is best that the team is placed in the hands of a man with more experience in Third Division football." John Still, who was installed as director of football following Cottee's appointment, will resume his former role of manager for the remainder of the season.

Confusion surrounds former Liverpool manager Roy Evans' plans to join Stockport County. The Hatters released a statement this morning saying Evans, who has been out of football since leaving Anfield in 1998, would be linking up with manager Andy Kilner on Monday to act as an advisor. But now BBC reports suggest Evans has turned down the invitation, saying that he does not want to interfere with Kilner's position.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: World Football (2.25am)

"I work in the programme development department of a small-to-middling independent television production company," writes Lucas.

Sky Sports 2: Futbol Mundial (5.30pm)

"We make several light-entertainment reality shows [remember Jailbreak?] for Channel 5, and last January I was responsible for trying to purchase the rights to the original US version of Touch the Truck."

Sky Sports 3: Sports Centre Football Hour (10pm, 1.30am SS2)

"Instead of securing a money-spinning deal, I spent my time reading the Fiver and missed out on this golden opportunity. This cost my company a contract worth over £100,000."

Hold the Back Page (11pm, 2.30am SS2)

"However, this lucky escape has almost certainly safeguarded our company's reputation and respect amongst commissioning editors, which is likely to guarantee at least two other shows. I therefore suggest that a net total of minus £100,000 be added to the Totaliser."

Radio 5 Live: Sport on 5 with Ian Payne (7pm)

Pesky meddling independent television production company programme developer! You've jiggered our Totaliser! It now stands at a pitiful £230,353,356.02, so we need a big push to keep it ticking along. Emailing the.boss@theguardian.com might help.

fields.trailText: Chuck & Buck | Dirty Pictures | Liberty Heights
fields.body:
Chuck & Buck
Rental and DVD (£19.99) Metrodome Cert 15
****

Most of us have had that weird experience of meeting a childhood best friend and not having much in common. But what if you've grown up and the ex-best friend still sucks lollipops and plays kids' records? And what if he just wants to hang out with you and do what you used to do? And what if that was "Chuck & Buck, Suck & Fuck", as Buck reminds Chuck? This is a funny, disarmingly simple film dominated by the permanent, bland smile of Mike White, whose emotionally stunted protagonist sets off to LA to be near his best buddy (now a successful record executive) and takes his disappointments out by writing an autobiographical play, Hank & Frank. White, who also wrote the film, and Chris Weitz (a bit of a Tom Cruise lookalike, which makes it funnier) don't put a foot wrong, and Miguel Arteta's film is not like anything you've seen: imagine Fatal Attraction rewritten by a benign gay 12-year-old. I haven't been this exquisitely embarrassed since Happiness.

Dirty Pictures
Rental MGM Cert 18
****

Perfect timing for this intelligently argued TV movie about the trial of a Cincinnati art centre director for obscenity following the 1990 exhibition of Robert Mapplethorpe's photos. The arguments closely mirror those of the current Saatchi exhibition hoo-ha. This is no dry discussion programme on obscenity v art, but an intelligently written and argued reconstruction with James Woods in top form as the gallery owner forced unhappily into the role of defender of art and free speech amid threats, intimidation and bribery. He is no straight-arrow hero figure, but a flawed and self-doubting character which, like Russell Crowe's whistleblower in The Insider, makes him an unusually lifelike kind of hero: this, you feel, is the best you might do in an awful situation, muddling through and getting it right some of the time. Craig T Nelson is equally uncaricatured as the sheriff taking the expected stance in an election year. You get to see the photos and the usual rightwing suspects - Jesse Helms, Pat Buchanan and George Bush - appear in TV footage while Salman Rushdie is interviewed on the side of freedom of expression. Dirty Pictures won the Golden Globe for best TV movie. Many of Woods's finest performances never make it to the cinema - if you spot Citizen Cohn (tautly directed, like this, by Frank Pierson) or Promise in the racks, do yourself a favour.

Liberty Heights
Rental Warner Cert 15
***

This is writer-director Barry Levinson back in Baltimore, a positive recommendation for fans of Diner, Tin Men and Avalon. Levinson goes back to 1954 (five years before Diner) - "No Jews, dogs or coloreds" is the sign on the local swimming pool. "Burlesk" is dying but Joe Mantegna's head of the family is still eking out a living from presenting it, augmented by running an illegal numbers racket. His sons are getting interested in girls outside the tight little Jewish community that gives the film its title. This lets Levinson compare black life with the Wasp well-to-do. Even if it's all a little too schematic for its own good and the dialogue doesn't quite have the snap of his best work, it's still an enjoyable, bittersweet experience that never drags at two hours. Mantegna is typically unfussy and authoritative.

fields.standfirst: Publication date: March 16
fields.trailText: March 16: 145 jobs have been axed by Express newspapers boss Richard Desmond.
fields.body:
145 jobs have been axed by Express newspapers boss Richard Desmond. Most of the jobs cut are expected to be journalists.

Formula One legend Niki Lauda has resigned as editor-in-chief of new motor racing magazine F1 after only one issue, although he will continue to write as a columnist

Cumulous Business Media is on the verge of a deal to buy 10 business magazines from Reed Business Information.

The NUJ is submitting a formal bid for re-recognition at the Independent and Independent on Sunday.

The launch of new teen magazine Elle Girl has been delayed by Emap until September in the hope of better market conditions.

The new fortnightly glossy Project Helena from H Bauer has signed up several high-profile journalists including Julie Burchill, Toby Young and Trudi Wallace.

webTitle: CD of the week: Manic Street Preachers: Know Your Enemy

fields.headline: Condemned to rock'n'roll
fields.standfirst: The Manics are back with a derivative mess - but  Garry Mulholland  still loves them
fields.trailText: The Manics are back with a derivative mess - but Garry Mulholland still loves them
fields.body:
Manic Street Preachers Know Your Enemy (Epic) *** £14.99

The real clue to What the Manics Did Next had nothing to do with launching their sixth album in Cuba, nor their much-hyped return to a revolutionary punk-rock agenda. Nope, the real clue was tucked away on the B-side of last year's limited-edition, back-to-basics, number one single Masses Against the Classes, where James Dean Bradfield, Nicky Wire and Sean Moore treated the fans to an exuberant cover of Chuck Berry's Rock and Roll Music. It was an enthusiastically pointless pub-rock joy, and sounded like a band desperately trying to shake off their increasingly humourless, flabby-arsed, Brit-friendly AOR, even if it meant being retro and corny. And so it proves from the outset of Know Your Enemy, as Bradfield recklessly unleashes a bunch of old Johnny Thunders geetar licks on Found that Soul, followed by Ocean Spray, a clean, sweet, acoustic stroll reminiscing on the death of Bradfield's mother. Those who only check in for the band's post-Richey angst-with-orchestras might like to leave about now.

Because Know Your Enemy, produced with an ear for invention, spontaneity and grungy din by Dave Eringa, Mike Hedges and David Holmes, is all over the place and so blatantly derivative of so many bands that it occasionally resembles one of those old Top of the Pops compilations. Indeed, the album features your fave Welsh rockers performing in the style of the Beach Boys (So Why So Sad), Sonic Youth (Intravenous Agnostic), Joy Division (Dead Martyrs), New Order (Baby Elian), Jesus and Mary Chain (the coda of My Guernica) and, on The Year of Purification and His Last Painting, good old REM - which might surprise those who remember Wire's "I hope Michael Stipe gets Aids" pronouncement onstage at the Kilburn National a few years ago. Unoriginal? Well, yes. But it does make Know Your Enemy more fun to listen to than anything since their Generation Terrorists debut.

This scattershot approach has its shortcomings, though. Wattsville Blues features Wire's first lead vocals on a Manics LP. Pitched entirely on one note, he manages to make Mark E Smith sound like Mariah Carey. This lurching, sweary, sneery thing tries, and fails, to be very New York, 1976. Which, in a very different way, is what the next track would like to sound like too. Miss Europa Disco Dancer is their much-discussed first stab at disco, featuring Wire and drummer Moore struggling miserably to master the rudiments of a basic disco beat. By the time Wire starts chanting "Braindead motherfuckers" repeatedly to fade, your smile has congealed into an embarrassed wince.

Of course, their being the Manics, it's not all Studio 54 and glittery slingbacks. The preacher part of the name is more appropriate here than at any time since the early days. Sadly, Wire continues to be lousy at it. The Small Faces-esque Let Robeson Sing pays tribute to the great Afro-American baritone and left-wing activist Paul Robeson, with Wire (via Bradfield's tonsils) asking: "Can anyone make a difference any more?/ Can anyone write a protest song?" Well, yes, probably. Tell you what - why don't you get on and give it a try? What is this, Who Wants To Be a Guilt-Ridden Millionaire? Elsewhere, and in keeping with the central theme of "America - Crap or What?", Baby Elian bigs up Cuba and informs us that "You don't sit in a rocking chair/ When you build a revolution" - which perhaps explains why Val Doonican never worked with Public Enemy.

So ignore the words, because My Guernica, His Last Painting and The Convalescent are magnificently dark, marching and charging post-punk anthems. Freedom of Speech Won't Feed My Children, apart from possessing the definitive Manics song title, is swaggering, driving drone-rock that sums up everything great about this band. Furious, unreasonable (the Dalai Lama and the US celebs who support him come in for serious stick), confusing (freedom of speech "just brings heart disease", apparently) and cantankerously dumb, it reminds you that the Manics are, essentially, all the misguided and muddled bits of the Clash without a London Calling or White Riot to make it all right. Which, in a world of Coldplays and David Grays, remains surprisingly lovable.

Nevertheless, this record is the most directionless and baffling Manics album thus far. It's tempting to conclude that its true nature will only be revealed in the fullness of time. But I suspect that Know Your Enemy will remain what it is - a well-meaning and charismatic mess, much like the band who made it.
