fields.headline: Siren calls
fields.standfirst: Tim Buckley is haphazard, Terris are enraged and Aerosmith are confused - what a messy week for pop releases
fields.trailText: Tim Buckley is haphazard, Terris are enraged and Aerosmith are confused - what a messy week for pop releases
fields.byline: Reviews by John Aizlewood, Robin Denselow and Caroline Sullivan
fields.body:
Tim Buckley Morning Glory: The Anthology
(Warners, 2 CDs)
***
£21.99

By 1975, when heroin took him, Tim Buckley's career had long been in creative and commercial freefall, but he has been posthumously lucky. His most accessible track, Song to the Siren, the narcotic generation's Unchained Melody, was resurrected by This Mortal Coil; while the success of his son Jeff, who made similarly complex, jazz-inflected music, excited further interest in the father. His original albums veer wildly in quality, but this 34-track retrospective is a judiciously selected précis, featuring six tracks from the inspired and beautiful Goodbye & Hello and just one from the unfocused Look at the Fool. Buckley avoided taut verses and whistlable choruses; not, as the pretty It Happens Every Time confirms, because he couldn't master them, but because he had other goals. Phantasmagoria In Two is more typical: tearfully sung, structurally haphazard, but possessed of emotive dignity. For the uninitiated, this is the place to discover Tim Buckley. (JA)

Kristin Hersh Sunny Border Blue
(4AD)
****
£12.99

Pop music tends to recoil in embarrassed horror when confronted by genuine mental illness. With commendable bravery, however, American singer-songwriter Kristin Hersh has spoken candidly about her bipolar disorder: in medical terms, a sibling of cyclothymia; in lay terms, manic depression. It has long been her contention that her condition makes her a conduit for, rather than a pro-active participant in, the dark songs that hurtle out of her. Sunny Border Blue takes time to settle, but the songs are a hive of activity that yield more charms with each play. Hersh drums, fiercely strums guitars, tootles on brass and, especially on Ruby, wafts over some divine backing vocals. And when she starts to sing, potential chaff becomes wheat. She delivers all these songs in emotional extremis, her voice cracking during Tearful on Trouble, then vulnerably sneering on White Suckers. She is utterly convincing: that, allied to her keening intelligence, is why she is special. Her lyrics pick over emotional debris, from marital discord to self-awareness and self-delusion ("It's not my fault you don't love me when I'm drunk" on Your Dirty Answer). The album is not for the faint of heart, but its effect becomes increasingly uplifting the more familiar songs such as 37 Hours and the sprightly Flipside become. (JA) Radio Tarifa Cruzando El Rio
(World Circuit)
**
£13.99

The Spanish band Radio Tarifa have specialised in mixing Arabic influences with flamenco and medieval Spanish styles. Performing live with their stirring flamenco dancer, they are one of the most exhilarating world-music bands in Europe, but here they sound decidedly less adventurous. Band leader Fain S Duenas has mysteriously decided to add electric guitar (played by himself) to his band's eclectic instrumental mix, and the opening piece sounds like an awkward mix of flamenco and Moroccan styles with an odd Caribbean edge. Other tracks range from an unremarkable percussive work-out to some gentle, delicate songs that blend African and medieval influences. But they lack the exuberance of either the best North African pop or flamenco, and many are just fragments: pleasant enough, but a bit thin. (RD)

Terris Learning To Let Go
(WEA)
***
£9.99

Prematurely touted as best new band at last year's NME awards, Terris took the next 12 months off to get over the shock of their elevation from morose Welsh garage band to Radioheads-in-waiting. Their first album finally arrives to a distinct sense of anticlimax. Their thunder has been stolen by the return of the real Radiohead and the repunked Manic Street Preachers, who make Terris's guitar/drums rawness feel redundant. What they do have going for them is Gavin Goodwin, a peroxided torrent of rage who hates most things with a passion and does so in tune. He rasps the embittered sentiments of Shapeshifter and Beneath the Belt ("I'm gonna get over you, I've learned to deal with you") as if choking on his own bile. But deeply felt as it clearly is, the incessant clawing at his wounds is hard to sustain, and harder to listen to. (CS)

Aerosmith Just Push Play
(Columbia)
***
£15.99

Strange to remember that Aerosmith (well, singer Steve Tyler and guitarist Joe Perry) were the first rockers to bridge the rock-rap divide when they teamed up with Run-DMC in 1986 on Walk This Way. That aberration aside, Boston's finest have spent their 30-year career heeding the maxim "If it ain't broke . . . " It could be time for a rethink. With the formerly wild-living Tyler and Perry now apparently clean and serene, they're no longer the band they were. Calling their first album in four years Just Push Play might be a sly dig at their own entrenched ways, although considering that the thundering title track is about deflowering virgins, it's probably not. Then again, on the titanic weepie Fly Away From Here, Tyler busts a gut exploring the subject of changing and moving on. Confused? They certainly are. But they sustain the energy to the last gasp of Face - spurred on, no doubt, by fantasies of girls in a school gym locker. (CS)

webTitle: Live CD of the week:  Bob Dylan: Live 1961-2000

fields.headline: Just passing time
fields.standfirst: How can collections of Dylan's live recordings keep missing his magic, asks  Richard Williams
fields.trailText: How can collections of Dylan's live recordings keep missing his magic, asks Richard Williams
fields.body:
Bob Dylan Live 1961-2000
(SME/Sony)
***
£18.99

By now it should be clear that Bob Dylan doesn't care much about records. Not, at any rate, to the same degree as most people in his position. The endless touring - this month, for example, he is to be found in Australia - can be seen as an expression of his abiding belief that music is best performed in front of an audience and has its real existence in the moment of creation. It is understood that studio recordings of his songs are early snapshots, which partially explains why his subsequent live reworkings are often so radically different. It seems curious, then, that with the exception of the 1966 Manchester Free Trade Hall concert, released a couple of years ago, his live albums have only sporadically captured Dylan's magic. This latest effort is no exception.

You might have thought that the imminence of his 60th birthday - on May 24 - would have provided the opportunity for a celebratory release commensurate in scale with the artist's standing. Instead, we get a "limited edition" Japanese import, subtitled "Thirty-nine years of great concert performances", which sounds promising until you notice that only six of the 16 tracks have never been released before, while five are permanently available in Dylan's back catalogue. This lazy piece of work will cost you around £20.

The "new" items are a 1961 version of the gospel song Wade in the Water, from the much-bootlegged Minneapolis hotel tape; a fine Handsome Molly from the Gaslight Café in Greenwich Village the following year, also familiar from unofficial issues; a poised To Ramona from Sheffield City Hall in 1965 (the concert captured in D A Pennebaker's Don't Look Back); and three enjoyable but hardly revelatory performances - Somebody Touched Me, Country Pie and Things Have Changed - from a concert at Portsmouth Guildhall six months ago.

The appearance of the five already available tracks (including I Don't Believe You from Manchester '66, Knockin' on Heaven's Door from 1974's Before the Flood, and Dignity from 1994's MTV Unplugged) is inexplicable. Why not something from the 1966 Liverpool or Albert Hallconcerts, which were also recorded? More acceptable are a rollicking Grand Coulee Dam, from a 1968 Woody Guthrie memorial concert with the Band, and a nimble-fingered It Ain't Me, Babe from Renaldo and Clara, with the Rolling Thunder combo, briefly circulated on a promo disc 25 years ago.

The remainder of the CD consists of Dead Man, Dead Man from New Orleans in 1981 (once the B-side of a cassette single), and two tracks issued on EPs, Cold Irons Bound from Los Angeles in 1997 and Born in Time from New Jersey in 1998. Each is decent but not half as good, for example, as the version of Boots of Spanish Leather of similar vintage, released on a Japanese EP.

Goodness knows what this weird cross-section is supposed to demonstrate. If it is intended simply as an entertaining potpourri, then the selection of material is desperately unimaginative, and a step back from the intelligence on display in the archly titled Bootleg Series, which Sony began to release, somewhat haltingly, in the mid-1990s.

It would be perfection, of course, to have Dylan's complete works, released and previously unreleased, studio and live, in a sort of Pléiade edition, with exhaustive annotation. Once he is dead, no doubt that will come soon enough. In the meantime, why not let us have the 1963 New York concerts at Town Hall and Carnegie Hall, which show him on the cusp of fame, and which were originally packaged for official release until Dylan and Albert Grossman thought better of it? Or the exceptional Sheffield City Hall performance, which represented a farewell to his old persona? Or the Newport Folk Festival and Hollywood Bowl concerts of 1965, when he attacked the citadel of rock music? Or the controversial 1970 Isle of Wight Festival set with the Band? Others will have their own ideas, but some of those would be a start. This release, while bringing a special glow to the people present in Portsmouth last October, merely marks time.
fields.bodyText: Bob Dylan Live 1961-2000 (SME/Sony) *** £18.99 By now it should be clear that Bob Dylan doesn't care much about records. Not, at any rate, to the same degree as most people in his position. The endless touring - this month, for example, he is to be found in Australia - can be seen as an expression of his abiding belief that music is best performed in front of an audience and has its real existence in the moment of creation. It is understood that studio recordings of his songs are early snapshots, which partially explains why his subsequent live reworkings are often so radically different. It seems curious, then, that with the exception of the 1966 Manchester Free Trade Hall concert, released a couple of years ago, his live albums have only sporadically captured Dylan's magic. This latest effort is no exception. You might have thought that the imminence of his 60th birthday - on May 24 - would have provided the opportunity for a celebratory release commensurate in scale with the artist's standing. Instead, we get a "limited edition" Japanese import, subtitled "Thirty-nine years of great concert performances", which sounds promising until you notice that only six of the 16 tracks have never been released before, while five are permanently available in Dylan's back catalogue. This lazy piece of work will cost you around £20. The "new" items are a 1961 version of the gospel song Wade in the Water, from the much-bootlegged Minneapolis hotel tape; a fine Handsome Molly from the Gaslight Café in Greenwich Village the following year, also familiar from unofficial issues; a poised To Ramona from Sheffield City Hall in 1965 (the concert captured in D A Pennebaker's Don't Look Back); and three enjoyable but hardly revelatory performances - Somebody Touched Me, Country Pie and Things Have Changed - from a concert at Portsmouth Guildhall six months ago. The appearance of the five already available tracks (including I Don't Believe You from Manchester '66, Knockin' on Heaven's Door from 1974's Before the Flood, and Dignity from 1994's MTV Unplugged) is inexplicable. Why not something from the 1966 Liverpool or Albert Hallconcerts, which were also recorded? More acceptable are a rollicking Grand Coulee Dam, from a 1968 Woody Guthrie memorial concert with the Band, and a nimble-fingered It Ain't Me, Babe from Renaldo and Clara, with the Rolling Thunder combo, briefly circulated on a promo disc 25 years ago. The remainder of the CD consists of Dead Man, Dead Man from New Orleans in 1981 (once the B-side of a cassette single), and two tracks issued on EPs, Cold Irons Bound from Los Angeles in 1997 and Born in Time from New Jersey in 1998. Each is decent but not half as good, for example, as the version of Boots of Spanish Leather of similar vintage, released on a Japanese EP. Goodness knows what this weird cross-section is supposed to demonstrate. If it is intended simply as an entertaining potpourri, then the selection of material is desperately unimaginative, and a step back from the intelligence on display in the archly titled Bootleg Series, which Sony began to release, somewhat haltingly, in the mid-1990s. It would be perfection, of course, to have Dylan's complete works, released and previously unreleased, studio and live, in a sort of Pléiade edition, with exhaustive annotation. Once he is dead, no doubt that will come soon enough. In the meantime, why not let us have the 1963 New York concerts at Town Hall and Carnegie Hall, which show him on the cusp of fame, and which were originally packaged for official release until Dylan and Albert Grossman thought better of it? Or the exceptional Sheffield City Hall performance, which represented a farewell to his old persona? Or the Newport Folk Festival and Hollywood Bowl concerts of 1965, when he attacked the citadel of rock music? Or the controversial 1970 Isle of Wight Festival set with the Band? Others will have their own ideas, but some of those would be a start. This release, while bringing a special glow to the people present in Portsmouth last October, merely marks time.

webTitle: Classical CD of the week: Verdi: Falstaff

fields.headline: Knight of passion
fields.standfirst: Andrew Clements  salutes a terrific new Falstaff
fields.trailText: Andrew Clements salutes a terrific new Falstaff
fields.body:
Verdi: Falstaff
Lafont/Martinpelto/Evans/Mingardo/James/Michaels-Moore/Palombi/Orchestre Révolutionnaire et Romantique/Gardiner
(Philips, 2 CDs)
*****
£28.99

For one of the supreme masterpieces of the operatic repertory, Falstaff has been surprisingly ill-served on record since the advent of CD. The current top choices date well back into the pre-digital age: there is Georg Solti's first version, recorded by Decca in 1963, with Geraint Evans as the fat knight, and Herbert von Karajan's from 1956 with Tito Gobbi peerless in the title role.

But now those two have a genuine rival. John Eliot Gardiner's performance, made in the studio after a semi-staged tour in 1998, won't appeal to everyone, but it is so fresh and imaginatively conceived that the occasional weaknesses hardly matter.

This is the first recording of Falstaff that qualifies as a period performance - the Orchestre Révolutionnaire et Romantique use instruments from around the time of the premiere in 1893, and there are huge gains in transparency and cleaner articulation.

The detail Gardiner brings to every texture is astonishing - in the chattering woodwind of the opening scene; the swelling string lines of the third act as Falstaff recovers from his dunking in the Thames; all of the needlepoint punctuations with which Verdi embroiders every morsel of the text. The playing is exuberantly alive, and the performance zips along with irresistible relish, surrounding the singers with kaleidoscopic changes of colour.

Vocally, it is very much a team effort. Even the Falstaff of Jean Pierre Lafont is smaller-scale than usual. Some might want a heavier, fruitier tone - Lafont is very much a baritone rather than a bass-baritone - and he does not always dominate proceedings as dramatically perhaps he should, but all the humanity is there, as well as enough of the swagger.

Similarly, the Ford of Anthony Michaels-Moore lacks the steely edge that his outburst of jealousy in the second act really needs, though everywhere else he fits perfectly into the ensembles.

Hillevi Martinpelto is an Alice Ford with a ravishing sense of line and perfectly focused tone, while Sara Mingardo is a Mistress Quickly of elegance and sly wit. Rebecca Evans is the Nannetta, rapturous in her duets with the Fenton of Antonella Palombi. Like everyone in this exceptional achievement, they know exactly how their characters should fit into this inexhaustibly rich musical tapestry.

webTitle: Leeds's tempo should set the tone for English success

fields.headline: Leeds's tempo should set the tone for English success
fields.trailText: With six of the Champions League quarter-finalists coming from the Premiership or La Liga, today's draw could throw up three Anglo-Spanish ties. And if that is the case I fancy our clubs to win at least two of them.
fields.body:
With six of the Champions League quarter-finalists coming from the Premiership or La Liga, today's draw could throw up three Anglo-Spanish ties. And if that is the case I fancy our clubs to win at least two of them.

If, for instance, Manchester United get Real Madrid, Arsenal are paired with Deportivo La Coruna and Leeds meet Valencia, I think a maximum of one English team will go out and it might even be a clean sweep.

I've looked at Spanish football and I like it but it is a myth to say it's stronger overall than the Premiership. The middle of our league is considerably better than the middle of theirs and that extra competitiveness brings a greater mental toughness.

Of course the Spanish are dangerous. Real Madrid are most people's favourites to retain their crown, Valencia were last season's runners-up and Deportivo have been a top side domestically for several seasons. Any of those three - in fact any of the remaining eight teams - could win the competition.

But if the English clubs approach whoever they meet with the right tempo I would give them more than half a chance. That means playing the sort of quick, aggressive, driving game which can terrorise European sides.

Leeds's strength lies in that and in many ways Manchester United's best European displays have been when they've more or less said: "Forget the opposition, we'll go out and impose ourselves at our pace and our tempo."

What they've done is wear down a lot of top-quality sides who favour a steadier, pattern game. I'm not advocating a return to the bad old route-one days but when English teams sit off and try to protect their goal and be patient they tend to hand over the initiative.

The fact that three English clubs have made it into the last eight for the first time is very positive. Psychologically it helps everyone. Arsenal have learned from experience and benefited from playing at Highbury, and Leeds's success has been a brilliant achievement. It also means the Premiership has an excellent chance of getting a fourth team in the Champions League the season after next.

Spain already have that and it is interesting to see two countries who have underachieved at international level flourishing on the club scene. Contrast that with the fact that not one of the four nations who reached the semi-finals of Euro 2000 - France, Italy, Portugal and Holland - has a single Champions League representative left.

Of course foreign talent has had a big bearing on the success of the Spanish and English clubs. The Spanish, for instance, have a lot of good South Americans and the absence of French sides is not a surprise because nearly all the France team who won Euro 2000 and the World Cup play abroad, with several in England.

The same goes for many of Portugal and Holland 's stars but the failure of the Serie A sides is a puzzle and will be making waves in Italy.

There is no doubt English clubs have caught up after being out of Europe for a while but I genuinely think the Italian collapse is just one of those things. Milan will feel the disappointment most, with the final to be played at the San Siro.

Because no side are head and shoulders above the rest, predicting the last two is tricky. It is a sign of how tight the tournament is that Lazio, the massive pre-tournament favourites, have been found wanting.

In any event performances in the group stages can be misleading. Nobody fancied Real Madrid much this time last year but they started to emerge in the knockout competition.

That's why I wouldn't bet against Arsenal, even though they will know how lucky they have been to survive. And I think we'll see a more tigerish and effective Manchester United. I fancy they'll produce performances more in tune with those against Juventus and Internazionale in 1998-99 when the chips were down.

The little dip David Beckham has had should help them because I expect he'll reassess and start to zip about again. On top of that Roy Keane's hunger will be a real force because he didn't play in the 1999 final. Although he got a Champions League winner's medal I think he wants to be the one who lifts the cup this year.

As for Leeds, after their tremendous performances so far I hope Dave O'Leary doesn't restrict his team at all. If they play with the same lack of fear and stick to their natural game they could be the surprise package, as Valencia were last season.

That run by Valencia produced an all-Spanish final. An all-English version this time would be nice.

fields.headline: Classical CD releases
fields.trailText: Schoenberg | Brahms | Shostakovich | Schmidt
fields.body:
Schoenberg: Piano Concerto; Klavierstücke Op 11 & 19; Webern: Variations; Berg: Piano Sonata
Uchida/Cleveland Orchestra/Boulez
(Philips)
*****
£14.99

This is the recording that Schoenberg's Piano Concerto has been waiting for. Easily the best yet to appear, it demonstrates that the concerto, far from being the grey and featureless essay in neoclassical serialism that its detractors have often claimed, is actually a work of tremendous rhythmic and textural variety, passionately argued. Mitsuko Uchida and Pierre Boulez make a wonderfully complementary partnership: her playing is by turns intensely febrile and delicately introspective; his conducting relishes every colour and nuance in the orchestral score. Together they shape the four-movements-in-one structure with total conviction. If that were not enough, Uchida's performances of two of Schoenberg's sets of piano pieces, together with Webern's Variations and Berg's single-movement Sonata, are a model of clarity, control and spontaneous fantasy. An outstanding disc.

Brahms: Piano Sonata Op 5; Ballades Op 10
Lars Vogt
(EMI)
****
£14.99

There is a great deal to admire in the 30-year-old Vogt's playing of a composer who suits his temperament perfectly. He has the measure of the sweeping drama in the first movement of the F minor Sonata, yet balances its tragic intensity with moments of genuine delicacy. It is clear from the start that this is much more than wham-bam Brahms, as his careful voicing of the slow movement and punctilious articulation of the rhythms in the scherzo confirm. Each of the four Ballades has the same sense of proportion: Vogt is well aware of their programmatic origins, yet presents all the incidental details just as deftly as he apprehends the larger issues. Very classy piano playing altogether.

Shostakovich: Symphonies Nos 2 & 3; Suite - The Bolt
Gothenburg Symphony Orchestra and Chorus/Jarvi
(Deutsche Grammophon)
***
£14.99

The least well-known and the most problematic of all Shostakovich's symphonies (the composer as good as disowned them later in his life) make an obvious coupling. They were written in 1927 and 1929 - the Second to mark the 10th anniversary of the October Revolution, the Third to celebrate May Day - and are the most extreme examples of Shostakovich's agit-prop style. Each begins with a display of modernist gestures, with a bit of everything from neoclassicism to expressionism, and ends with a hymn to Soviet progress. Neeme Jarvi and the excellent Gothenburg forces realise the effects well enough, though they never quite screw up the tension as tightly as they could. The coupling is the suite from equally bombastic ballet The Bolt, withdrawn after one performance in 1931; by then the political tide had turned, and Shostakovich realised very quickly that he had to reorientate his style to survive.

Schmidt: The Book with Seven Seals
Streit/Roschmann/Lipovsek/Lippert/Hawlata/Vienna Singverein/Vienna Philharmonic/Harnoncourt
(Teldec, 2 CDs)
*****
£28.99

Nikolaus Harnoncourt's onward march through the Austro-German tradition began in the baroque and has now reached the 20th century. The majestic world of Franz Schmidt's apocalyptic masterpiece is a natural progression from Bruckner, whom Harnoncourt now conducts regularly with passionate conviction. This is the second outstanding set of The Book with Seven Seals to appear in recent years, and it would be hard to choose between this live account, by turns blazingly theatrical and exquisitely intimate, and the studio version by Franz Welser-Most on EMI. If Harnoncourt just wins out, it is because he is willing to take more risks, to go for extremes rather than adopt a pragmatic middle way, and all his gambles pay off. He also has the bonus of the Vienna Philharmonic on top form, a distinguished line-up of soloists, and a recording with a tingling sense of immediacy.

fields.headline: Fiona Mactaggart
fields.standfirst:
Slough (1997- )

Ask Aristotle about Fiona Mactaggart
fields.trailText: No one was more surprised than new Labour MP Fiona Mactaggart to find herself described as "disabled" in newspaper headlines when she disclosed in a Commons debate she was infertile and suffered from MS. Looking in her full length mirror she saw the person newsmen see striding around Westminster or battling in the chamber: a tall, strapping, garrulous extrovert, happy to trade verbal punches with political adversaries.
fields.body:
No one was more surprised than new Labour MP Fiona Mactaggart to find herself described as "disabled" in newspaper headlines when she disclosed in a Commons debate she was infertile and suffered from MS. Looking in her full length mirror she saw the person newsmen see striding around Westminster or battling in the chamber: a tall, strapping, garrulous extrovert, happy to trade verbal punches with political adversaries.

Fiona Mactaggart stands out among Labour's new women: her frequent contributions display a high intelligence, independence of mind and special sensitivity to the needs of the many immigrants in her Slough constituency.

She can only be embarrassed by the repeated reminders of the far-right Tory MP Gerald Howarth about how close he was to her father, the late Sir Ian Mactaggart Bt, the multimillionaire Glasgow property developer, Tory candidate and Europhobe. Her mother Rosemary was the daughter of Sir Herbert Williams Bt, a Tory MP for 27 years. But her politics owes more to Sir John Mactaggart, her great-grandfather, who was the first treasurer of the first ever branch of Keir Hardie's Labour party.

Although her inheritance makes her probably the second richest Labour MP after Geoffrey Robinson - her father left her a fifth of his estate of £6.5m - she has never considered it a reason for failing to make her own contribution.

After Cheltenham ladies college, King's College, London for her BA, the Institute of Education for her MA and Goldsmith's College (PGCE), she became a lecturer on education, having been a primary school teacher: "I have a voice that children can hear at the other end of the playground."

Her entry into politics initially was as a student leader. As secretary of the NUS 1978-81, she was involved in the 1978 youth festival in Cuba, along with Peter Mandelson and Charles Clarke.

Her extramural activities tended to revolve around helping immigrants - having acted as the director of the joint council for the welfare of immigrants (1982-86) - and extending civil liberties through being chairman of the executive of Liberty (1992-96).

From 1986 she served as a Labour councillor in Wandsworth. She won the nomination as Labour's candidate for Slough on an all women shortlist, defeating a local councillor, Brenda Lopez, the wife of the previous Labour candidate who had just failed to take the seat by 514 votes, and she took the seat by 13,071 votes in 1997 on a 13.7% swing.

Since entering parliament, she has concentrated on her key causes: immigration - she has urged a speedier reduction in the backlog of immigration and asylum appeals and an easier process by which the Pakistani relatives of her constituents would be allowed to visit Britain - and education - her maiden speech backed the winding up of the assisted places scheme and the channelling of the saved money towards cutting class sizes, and she has urged an end to the bar on primary school teaching candidates with the "wrong" degrees. In December 1997 she was named parliamentary private secretary to Chris Smith.

fields.headline: Chris Mullin
fields.standfirst:
Sunderland South (1987-)

Ask Aristotle about Chris Mullin
fields.trailText: A double change of identity can ultimately lead to boredom, as Chris Mullin, once the Robespierre of the Bennite revolution has proved. First he transformed himself into a Labour MP, pressing the establishment to take notice of miscarriages of justice such as the Birmingham Six.
fields.body:
A double change of identity can ultimately lead to boredom, as Chris Mullin, once the Robespierre of the Bennite revolution has proved. First he transformed himself into a Labour MP, pressing the establishment to take notice of miscarriages of justice such as the Birmingham Six.

Then, after becoming a respected chairman of the home affairs select committee, he again transformed himself in 1999 into an obscure, boring under secretary for environment before moving to the Department for International Development in the mini-reshuffle which followed Peter Mandelson's hasty departure in January 2001.

He still looks something akin to a scholarly Irish priest, with his domed forehead and steel specs - hardly the face of a leftwing firebrand.

He was much more provocative in 1982 when he captured the leftwing weekly magazine Tribune as part of Tony Benn's effort to revolutionise Labour politics, pushing many Labour MPs into the SDP. He was much more productive, too, as Sunderland South's MP from 1987. Uncovering the country's worst legal scandals, he earned the Sun headline, "Loony MP backs bomb gang".

He is the product of a mixed marriage: his father was a Scottish Protestant electrical engineer working for Marconi, his mother an Irish Catholic secretary there. His own wife is Vietnamese. After St Joseph's, his Roman Catholic private boarding school near Ipswich, he did a law degree at Hull University, where he read the Daily Telegraph and dressed like a young fogey.

It was the Vietnam war which switched him to the Labour party and made him a key activist in the upsurge of Bennite leftwing factions, demanding a purge of moderates among Labour MPs and trade union leaders.

Then, in the wake of the takeover of Tribune, he became its editor, against the wishes of its shareholders. He transformed Tribune into a friendly society, with shares distributed among fellow activists - a structure found by the high court to be illegal. Almost as consolation, safe Sunderland South's Labour party chose him as their candidate and the voters then elected him their MP.

His journey toward a more pragmatic left position began in March 1988, when he warned Tony Benn against challenging Neil Kinnock once more for the leadership.

Changing his approach to politics, he then became the scourge of the legal establishment - criticising them through the press, in the Commons and through his book, An Error of Judgment, for miscarriages of justice. He also became a political novelist with his A Very British Coup, which was subsequently turned into a TV drama.

He became a probing chairman of the home affairs select committee in 1997; an MP with credibility who proved it was possible to thrive outside the New Labour net.

But not for long. In 1999 he became a junior minister, shuffled upwards not just for his talent but to silence his dissident voice. The irony of a former firebrand of the left being charged with the privatisation of British skies was not lost on commentators.

The metamorphosis was complete when, after the fall of Peter Mandelson, he became No 2 at the Department of International Development, under fellow reinvented leftwinger Clare Short.

fields.headline: Alan Howarth
fields.standfirst:
(Newport East, 1997- )

Ask Aristotle about Alan Howarth
fields.trailText: Alan Howarth, once a rightwing Conservative MP and later a New Labour arts minister, is not like all the other ex-Tories romanced by Tony Blair. Fellow converts Peter Temple-Morris and Shaun Woodward left their old party in revulsion at its europhobia and homophobia. Mr Howarth's pilgrimage, on the other hand, has been long, tortured and considered. When he abandoned his safe Tory seat of Stratford-on-Avon for the solidly Labour Newport East seat, where he was returned in 1997, he became the first politician since Sir Oswald Mosley to make such a move.
fields.body:
Alan Howarth, once a rightwing Conservative MP and later a New Labour arts minister, is not like all the other ex-Tories romanced by Tony Blair. Fellow converts Peter Temple-Morris and Shaun Woodward left their old party in revulsion at its europhobia and homophobia. Mr Howarth's pilgrimage, on the other hand, has been long, tortured and considered. When he abandoned his safe Tory seat of Stratford-on-Avon for the solidly Labour Newport East seat, where he was returned in 1997, he became the first politician since Sir Oswald Mosley to make such a move.

In fact, he did it in two stages, morphing from a rightwinger into a one nation Tory, and then moving across to Labour in autumn 1995 at a time calculated to provide maximum embarrassment to the Conservative party whose conference was about to begin.

After standing as a Conservative candidate and winning Stratford-on-Avon in 1983 he served as a minister at the Department for Education, where his rightwing platform included the support of student loans and local self-management of schools.

But it was the inadequate assistance offered to his palsied son Charles and other disabled persons that provoked Mr Howarth's change of heart and he then went on to agitate for increased funds for higher education and the disabled.

Even then he did not rush things - as his columns in the Guardian made clear. The break appeared sudden, coming in response to a joking invitation to cross the floor from a Labour MP, but those closest to him insisted it was not. "He's been considering this [defection] for three years," his son James said at the time.

It was not easy for Labour to find him a safe new seat, even though they knew many unhappy Tories might follow him if they succeeded. After losing out on safe Wentworth and then Wythenshawe, he was selected and elected for Newport East in south Wales. Arthur Scargill stood against him to emphasise the left's charge that he had backed the closure of the mines but Mr Scargill barely cause a ripple in Howarth's majority.

After Labour's 1997 victory, Mr Howarth was named under secretary for education and employment and then, in 1998, he became minister for the arts, replacing the rebellious old Etonian Mark Fisher. In this post, the cultured Mr Howarth has shone - not least in opposing the decision of the Oxford University press to stop publishing poetry. He also secured free entry to museums and galleries, against stiff resistance from the Treasury.

In the Commons he seems, as ever, a suave, serious, cerebral man, infinitely calm, emollient and persuasive, but lonely, with a tortured conscience. As with other ex-Tories now in Labour, the question of how many old dogmas he still harbours hangs over him. He undoubtedly still believes in discipline in public finances.

More than most junior ministers, Mr Howarth has security of tenure. After all, can Tony Blair sack the man holding aloft the flag inscribed, "All one nation Tories are welcome in Labour's ranks"?

fields.headline: Glenda Jackson
fields.standfirst:
Hampstead and Highgate (1992-)

Ask Aristotle about Glenda Jackson
fields.trailText: The key to Glenda Jackson's character is that she is completely work-orientated, throwing herself into any part for which she is cast. Meeting her just after she was selected for Hampstead, I was astounded at the political knowledge accumulated over her 20 years of support for Labour. Formerly a famous actress, she saw politics as "exchanging one extremely demanding disciplined area of work for another".
fields.body:
The key to Glenda Jackson's character is that she is completely work-orientated, throwing herself into any part for which she is cast. Meeting her just after she was selected for Hampstead, I was astounded at the political knowledge accumulated over her 20 years of support for Labour. Formerly a famous actress, she saw politics as "exchanging one extremely demanding disciplined area of work for another".

Born in 1936 to a charlady and a Birkenhead bricklayer who served on a minesweeper for most of her childhood, Ms Jackson's first jobs after leaving her local grammar school at 16 were behind the counter at Boots and the bar at a local Butlin's. It was only when she won entry into RADA at 18 that her career began to take off as an actress, culminating in two Oscars, for Women in Love and A Touch of Class. She has since worked in journalism and radio.

Openly admitting to being "difficult to live with" she has not had a completely happy personal life, and after her marriage to Roy Hodges, she had a six-year affair with lighting man Andy Philips. Her son, Dan, worked with her in opposition and he is now a senior spin doctor for the GMB Unions.

Ms Jackson seems uncertain about her political roles or how to dress for them. After she captured the seat in 1992 she strode about the Commons without makeup and wore clothes drab enough for an East German production of Mother Courage.

In the Tory dominated Commons she actively resisted their bill privatising the railways, becoming a junior transport spokesman (1996-97). Once Labour won in 1997, this was translated into minister for transport in London. She worked hard, scowled too much, but won popularity with Londoners - ranking second to Ken Livingstone in newspaper polls - if not with her senior civil servants.

Her greatest role change was in 1999 when she left office and topped Tony Blair's list as a "Stop Ken" candidate. She launched her fight against Mr Livingstone for the London mayoralty before Mr Blair finally decided to hand the poisoned chalice to neighbouring MP Frank Dobson.

Once Mr Livingstone had triumphed, she had no hesitation in winding up as a bit player in his cast, offering her transport knowledge, without pushing her support for John Prescott's public-private partnership.

She was later appointed by the newly elected Mayor as his adviser on homelessness in the Greater London assembly. She will continue to pursue these causes from the backbenchers and undoubtedly use her well rehearsed communications skills on the broadcast media.

fields.headline: Andrew MacKinlay
fields.standfirst:
Thurrock (1992-)

Ask Aristotle about Andrew Mackinlay
fields.trailText: Andrew MacKinlay insists that it is Tony Blair's swing to the right that has seen him labelled a "leftwing rebel". The engagingly honest Labour MP for Thurrock has shone in the 1997 parliament for being anything but an identikit clone - he even asks the prime minister difficult questions in the Commons.
fields.body:
Andrew MacKinlay insists that it is Tony Blair's swing to the right that has seen him labelled a "leftwing rebel". The engagingly honest Labour MP for Thurrock has shone in the 1997 parliament for being anything but an identikit clone - he even asks the prime minister difficult questions in the Commons.

Not that he always likes the attention. He insisted recently that "for 29 of my 33 years in the Labour party I was traduced as a rightwinger by people I now see in government who have rapidly moved on a fast track to the right."

"It took five general elections to get me here," the trade union veteran said after winning his seat in 1992. "I did not go through all that disappointment of defeat after defeat to become a cipher."

Far from it. As an MP he has been assiduous in holding the executive to account, evoking Tory cheers and the votes of fellow Labour MPs who tried unsuccessfully to elect him chairman of the parliamentary Labour party.

Mr Mackinlay is a fiftysomething, Wembley-born leftover from old Labour, and a former trade union organiser in Surrey. Catholic-educated, he admits to being culturally backward: "I saw my first ballet in Bratislava when I was 46 years old." But he challenges anyone to dispute his adherence to the Labour ideals, imbibed since he decided to become a Labour MP at the age of 12.

In pursuit of that goal he fought hopeless seats such as Surbiton, Croydon Central and Peterborough. After defeating the extreme rightwinger Tim Janman in 1992, he made his name as an assiduous MP and tough inquisitor of John Major.

But it has been his behaviour under Tony Blair since 1997 which has marked him out from the Blairite sycophants and the usual "awkward squad" of leftwing rebels. In June 1998 he was widely applauded when he told the prime minister to stop scaring off his MPs from their duty to hold the government to account by encouraging "fawning, obsequious" and "softball" questions just as the Tories had done.

He asked equally legitimate hardball questions of Labour ministers Robin Cook and Tony Lloyd as a member of the foreign affairs select committee, to the dismay of the whips. On the committee he has shown his commonsense shrewdness, without either subservience or disloyalty.

He helped his reputation, too, with a longstanding crusade to secure belated pardons for first world war soldiers, shot for cowardice when most were suffering from shellshock and other mental breakdowns due to the horrors of trench warfare.

In November 1998 he was also the first MP to introduce a freedom of information bill into the House of Commons, under the 10-minute rule.

Without being disloyal to his party, he has sought to diminish the power of its whips and the power of its government, while strengthening the power of parliament.

webTitle: On the Edge CD of the week: David Rothenberg & Douglas Quin: Before the War

fields.headline: Blowin' in the wind
fields.standfirst: John L Walters  on a clarinettist who combines urban jams with the sampled sounds of nature
fields.trailText: John L Walters on a clarinettist who combines urban jams with the sampled sounds of nature
fields.body:
David Rothenberg & Douglas Quin Before the War
(EarthEar)
****

David Rothenberg is a clarinet player and composer who has made a number of jazz-inflected collaborations and solo albums, including the superb Unamuno (New Tone). He is also a writer and editor, and once put together a CD compilation entitled Music from Nature (an adjunct to the journal Terra Nova for MIT Press). That was an entertaining collection that included a Beethoven piano sonata (No 30), Chris Hughes's Steve Reich-inspired Slow Motion Blackbird, and field recordings of Pygmy women gathering mushrooms. It was pure Late Junction, well before Late Junction was even a twinkle in a Radio 3 controller's eye.

Before the War features a studio ensemble of Rothenberg, bassist Bill Douglas, drummer Russ Gold and Douglas Quin, a guitarist who has collected a large number of field recordings from Alaska, Kenya, Madagascar and so on. Quin's samples of birds, wind and water fill out the texture and work in easy dialogue with the percussion. This is not a particularly new concept: composer Basil Kirchin made a couple of extraordinary albums in the early 1970s (Worlds Within Worlds) that featured improvisers such as Evan Parker alongside animal and insect sounds. What is significant about Rothenberg and Quin's ensemble is that technology now permits them to improvise in real time with the natural sounds in Quin's library: perhaps this is the airy rural equivalent of the way super-hip musicians like Julien Lourau use samples and programming as part of a more urban jamming band.

The inclusion of a live track, Crabs Who Fall from Tree into the Sea, makes it clear that the group doesn't need studio trickery to generate the forest ambience that underpins the piece. Another piece, Orchid Angels, builds slowly from the sounds of distant birds, a shaker, a low drone and some tentative bass clarinet before easing into a more definite rhythm. Karelian Midnight features the bowed Jouhikko and voice of Mari Jarvinen. Three of the 12 tracks, including Murder in the World and the title track, feature Rothenberg's spoken voice. The sleevenotes quote Woody Guthrie, John Cage (who said that music should imitate nature by its manner of operation) and Evan Eisenberg, whose "earth jazz" concept means players should "relax their rigid beat and learn to follow nature's rhythms - in other words, to swing". Whether you trace that idea back to Aristotle or Disney's Jungle Book, it is not a bad way to get in touch with your inner loon. EarthEar's mail-order catalogue includes many recordings that take the idea of "environmental sound art" in many different directions, with discs by Chris Watson, Bernie Krause and Annea Lockwood and "urban soundscapes" by Michael Rusenberg and Hans Ulrich Werner.

Whatever the ecological implications of this vast area of recording and documentation, the Rothenberg/Quin ensemble sound, weaving together understated drums, bass, guitar and environmental samples, provides a new and entirely appropriate setting for jazz clarinet, an instrument that at one time evoked 20th-century city life in all its modernist glory. But that was two generations ago, before the war. This feels like genuinely 21st-century music: I think we'll be hearing a lot more from Rothenberg.

fields.headline: Baroness Jay of Paddington
fields.standfirst: Created a peer in 1992
fields.trailText: Broad shouldered, tall and tough, the leader of the House of Lords is nothing if not formidable: she's James Callaghan's daughter, she was married to the British ambassador to the United States and was a producer at the BBC's Panorama. Labour's Baroness Margaret Jay's life (and of late, political career) is a heady mix of heritage and exertion.
fields.body:
Broad shouldered, tall and tough, the leader of the House of Lords is nothing if not formidable: she's James Callaghan's daughter, she was married to the British ambassador to the United States and was a producer at the BBC's Panorama. Labour's Baroness Margaret Jay's life (and of late, political career) is a heady mix of heritage and exertion.

As Baroness Jay glides imperiously along the corridors of the Lords , her Labour colleagues wonder how she can so often put her foot in her mouth. Her best gaffe was when she tried to pass off the direct grant school she attended as "a pretty standard grammar school". She also tried to assure John Mortimer over lunch that "nobody who lives outside the M25 cares about juries."

If leader of the Lords was a post elected by Labour peers, Baroness Jay would never have had a chance. She was foisted on her colleagues in 1998 by the prime minister. She became unpopular with her Tory opponents when, as Tony Blair's instrument, she got rid of most of the hereditary peers. She compounded this by backing Lord Neill's proposal for a tough register of Lords' outside interests. The outspoken Tory peer, the Earl of Onslow, described Lady Jay as "an ungracious, ungenerous woman, fit only for grazing."

Although she is now married to Professor Michael Adler, an Aids specialist, she has retained the surname of former husband, BBC economics editor Peter Jay, whom her father made ambassador to Washington. In Washington, competing affairs (and her luring away the married Watergate journalist Carl Bernstein from his wife) destroyed her marriage and made her the villain of a thinly-disguised novel by dumped Bernstein spouse Nora Ephron.

Margaret Callaghan was born in 1939. While studying at Somerville College, Oxford, she met Peter Jay and married him at 21. The young couple often stayed at 11 Downing Street. As Margaret Jay, she was later made "co-ambassador" of the British embassy in Washington. On her return, she became a BBC producer on Panorama. A programme about Aids led her to become director of the national Aids trust. Through this work she met her future husband, Dr Adler, becoming his wife when he dissolved his then marriage.

Created a life peer in 1992, she became Labour's health spokesperson in the Lords in 1995 and deputy leader there in 1997 when Labour won power. Trusted by Tony Blair, she was a natural for promotion a year later. At the prime minister's behest, she is likely to halve the number of hereditary peers, although the debate about the final number and nature of members of the House of Lords rages unabated. Also in 1998, she was created minister for women, sharing the portfolio with Tessa Jowell - a position from which she has pushed for changes in government policy, such as the introduction of the minimum wage, working families tax credit and record increases in child benefit.

Although she is now married to Professor Michael Adler, an Aids specialist, she has retained the surname of former husband, BBC economics editor Peter Jay, whom her father made ambassador to Washington. In Washington, competing affairs (and her luring away the married Watergate journalist Carl Bernstein from his wife) destroyed her marriage and made her the villain of a thinly-disguised novel by dumped Bernstein spouse Nora Ephron. Margaret Callaghan was born in 1939. While studying at Somerville College, Oxford, she met Peter Jay and married him at 21. The young couple often stayed at 11 Downing Street. As Margaret Jay, she was later made "co-ambassador" of the British embassy in Washington. On her return, she became a BBC producer on Panorama. A programme about Aids led her to become director of the national Aids trust. Through this work she met her future husband, Dr Adler, becoming his wife when he dissolved his then marriage. Created a life peer in 1992, she became Labour's health spokesperson in the Lords in 1995 and deputy leader there in 1997 when Labour won power. Trusted by Tony Blair, she was a natural for promotion a year later. At the prime minister's behest, she is likely to halve the number of hereditary peers, although the debate about the final number and nature of members of the House of Lords rages unabated. Also in 1998, she was created minister for women, sharing the portfolio with Tessa Jowell - a position from which she has pushed for changes in government policy, such as the introduction of the minimum wage, working families tax credit and record increases in child benefit.

fields.headline: Overexposed
fields.trailText: We know we're in France because the croissants on our continental breakfast are, for once, fresh. So we don't need any other reminders of our location on the fashion schedule.
fields.body: We know we're in France because the croissants on our continental breakfast are, for once, fresh. So we don't need any other reminders of our location on the fashion schedule. Yet at the weirdly raunchy Comme des Garçons show on Sunday, Rei Kawakubo started playing Je T'Aime, the classic ode to sex by Parisian cliché hero Serge Gainsbourg (above). Later in the week at Ungaro, the soundtrack was a souped-up remix of some of Serge's greatest hits. It was as if designers on the London schedule sent out their assymetric skirts to the theme tune from EastEnders. Or, for his first couture show at Givenchy in July, Julien Macdonald opens with Tom Jones - Serge in Paris is just too obvious. Mind you, anything was better than the music at Yves Saint Laurent Rive Gauche. Can someone please tell Tom Ford that the Stereophonics are the least fashionable band in the world?

fields.headline: The insider
fields.trailText: As the fashion crowd entered the fifth week in their punishing schedule of sitting on chairs and looking at clothes, the night-time text messaging stopped being about parties and became limited to "wot u dng?" and "gng 2 bed".
fields.body:
As the fashion crowd entered the fifth week in their punishing schedule of sitting on chairs and looking at clothes, the night-time text messaging stopped being about parties and became limited to "wot u dng?" and "gng 2 bed". The timetable didn't help either, with the last shows of the day never starting before 10pm. But if needs must, the crowd can always summon the courage for another glass of champagne, so on Monday night, between shows by Dries Van Noten and Givenchy reject Olivier Theyskens, the pack nipped into Listen To This Picture, a photo exhibition by Pierre Bailly. Bailly is a close friend of Marc Jacobs, who was there waving at the lucky few who got sent as a present a Stephen Sprouse-ified Louis Vuitton bag (which won equal-first best gift prize alongside the Christian Dior Fender).

The next night, between Martin Margiela and Veronique Branquinho, Tom Ford threw a party for Les Annees Pop, where guest-watching was as popular as looking at the exhibits. While Anna Sui ambled slowly, and Alexander McQueen went round the wrong way with his husband George, American Vogue editor Anna Wintour displayed the true power method to work a gallery. From the door of each room, quickly head in a diagonal line to the corner, turn around and walk out. Obviously, do all the above wearing shades.

By this point, the fashionistas had got back their taste for champagne, which was a shame since at the party for Celine at the Ritz later that night, the drink ran dry. But isn't Celine owned by LVMH and doesn't the M stand for Moet?

fields.headline: On the edge releases
fields.trailText: Klucevsek/Bern: Accordance | Peter Blegvad: Choices Under Pressure: An Acoustic Retrospective
fields.body:
Klucevsek/Bern Accordance
(Winter & Winter)
****
£14.99

If you don't have much accordion music in your collection, then this CD will be a quiet revelation - it is extraordinary to hear how much can be done by two virtuosos. Positioned left and right in the mix, Guy Klucevsek and Alan Bern generate dense harmonies, jazzy rhythms, atmospheric soundscapes and long, graceful melodies with the aplomb of magicians pulling silk scarves, rabbits and unicorns out of a battered old hat.

Klucevsek is something of a new-music hero, moving and squeezing between the worlds of jazz and contemporary music with ease. He was the pivotal player in Bill Frisell's Have a Little Faith (Nonesuch). On that album, he added an orchestral element that enabled the guitarist's quintet to tackle Charles Ives, Aaron Copland and John Philip Sousa with a fresh ear and sound palette, kicking off with an ambitious version of Copland's Billy the Kid. A few years later, trumpeter Dave Douglas built his Charms of the Night Sky band (with violin and bass) around Klucevsek's accordion. Douglas is a hyperactive performer/ composer, but no one who caught his UK tour last September could fail to have been impressed by Klucevsek's cool strength in the eye of the hurricane.

Accordance is made up of original compositions by both performers that range from the wilfully lightweight (Happy), through the finger-twistingly virtuosic (Scarlatti Fever), to more angst-ridden, post-minimalist tango workouts (Astor Place). Bern is a good composer, with pieces such as the moving, nine-minute Starting Over and the sure-footed Angel Blue. He also throws in a bit of fortepiano and melodica as sonic seasoning. They include a duo version of a jazzy Klucevsek suite featured on Douglas's first Charms of the Night Sky album (also on Winter & Winter). Mug Shots is a fleet-footed, dancing trio of pieces, evoking polkas (Klucevsek comes from a Slovenian-American background) and plaintive refrains shot through with melancholy.

Randy Newman chose his words carefully at the end of his song Love Story, anticipating a modest wedding banquet, accompanied by "a violin, an accordion, and a tenor who can sing". There is something sad and mysterious about these instruments, whether they are playing long, swollen chords (Pauline Oliveros-style) for Bern's composition Hegel's Fantasy, or negotiating the tricky articulations of Klucevsek's opening song Life, Liberty And the Prosciutto Happiness. Accordion players can be the life and soul of the party, but they have to keep playing. However nimble or wildly chromatic, the accordion can never be as sexy or as selfish as a lead guitar or sax, and therein lies its appeal.

Peter Blegvad Choices Under Pressure: An Acoustic Retrospective
(Resurgence)
****
The Book of Leviathan
(Sort of Books, £12.99)
*****

"That's my daughter in the water, everything she knows I taught her," sings Peter Blegvad at the close of his song Daughter. Bass, drums, guitar and a little splash cymbal hustle along behind in neat folk-rock style while the composer wails his sentimental but affecting words over the top. We could be in the LA Troubadour, or the one in the Old Brompton Road, listening to the man deliver well-crafted balladry such as the songs Gold or Waste of Time, in a Dylanesque drawl. Sometimes the surprise in Blegvad's work is how straightforward he sounds. Given his CV, which encompasses Faust, the Golden Palominos, Slapp Happy (his influential trio with Anthony Moore and Dagmar Krause), and ongoing work with Chris Cutler and other ex-Henry Cow musicians on ReR albums such as Just Woke Up and Hangman's Hill, you might expect something less FM-friendly than his easy-on-the-ear dad-rock. Yet the oddness is revealed in subtle twists and turns and the Lewis Carroll-like wordplay of songs such as The Unborn Byron ("She calls him and he answers back, from the amniotic sac"), or the funky Haiku, with its fabulous pumping chorus: "Systole, diastole, dealing with the parts but feeling with the whole".

In fact to get the whole picture, you really have to buy more than one Blegvad product, and Choices Under Pressure serves as a neat promotional device for his magnum opus The Book of Leviathan (Sort of Books, £12.99), drawn from the comic strip that ran for years in the Independent on Sunday. Combining anecdotes, puns, wry social comment, wild fantasy and unsentimental affection with a masterful and eclectic drawing style, Blegvad's Leviathan achieves a level of rich and surreal complexity his songs can only hint at. Blegvad the graphic artist has some fans in high places, including Matt Groening and Ben Katchor. The CD's title comes from a Leviathan strip whose first panel reads: "Q: what defines 'character'? A: The choices a person makes under pressure." On the cover, the lightbulb outline of baby Leviathan can be glimpsed within a diving bell, while a thinks bubble reads: "Eenie, meenie, minie, mo . . ." The guy's a genius. Give him a TV series. No, give him a whole channel.

fields.headline: Express journalists consider work-to-rule
fields.trailText:
4.30pm: Express journalists are preparing a ballot for industrial action following the job cuts announced yesterday, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Mar 15: Sports writers under threat
Mar 15: Dot.gone from Express
Mar 15: NUJ fears for future of Express
Mar 15: Union warns of cuts
fields.body:
Journalists at the Express have today decided to prepare a ballot for industrial action following the brutal job cuts announced yesterday.

They have been instructed by the union to examine their contracts this weekend to examine the possibility of a work-to-rule as an initial protest against the 145 redundancies being planned by the newspaper group.

An estimated 200 journalists gathered at a packed NUJ meeting in the Express canteen at 3pm today to discuss what action to take.

The atmosphere was calm but determined and peppered with jokes at the expense of proprietor Richard Desmond and his management team.

Staff came to the brink of instructing the NUJ to go ahead with a ballot for a strike action.

Instead NUJ national newspaper organiser Jeremy Dear told journalists to "go away and look at their contracts and see about the possibility of a work-to-rule."

A motion was also proposed about the possibility of journalists refusing to work on other titles.

However, this was not put to the vote because it was approaching press deadlines and journalists were going back to their desks.

The proceedings were not all doom and gloom, however.

Mr Dear raised a hollow laugh when he claimed that the editorial board assembled by Richard Desmond shortly after he took over had never actually convened.

Mr Desmond put the board together to head off fears that the editorial quality of the paper would plunge under his stewardship.

Journalists also wondered if jobs could be saved if they come up with alternative means of saving money.

One journalists shot up with one novel suggestion, asking: "Why don't the get rid of Vanessa Feltz?". Feltz is paid an estimated £100,000 a year for her new column in the OK! magazine weekly supplement in the Express.

fields.headline: When Harry met Larry
fields.standfirst: Harry Potter publisher fights back against plagiarism allegations
fields.trailText:
Legal document: Stouffer's complaint

N K Stouffer's real muggles.com home page
fields.body:
Legal document: Stouffer's complaint

N K Stouffer's real muggles.com home page

An American author who has accused Harry Potter creator JK Rowling of plagiarism is steeling herself for a counter lawsuit from Rowling's publishers, Scholastic, and the film giant, Time Warner.

Nancy Stouffer claims that Rowling stole ideas from a series of books she wrote between 1984 and 1988, in which the protagonist was one Larry Potter. Rowling, who has already appeared in court to defend herself against these charges, has flatly denied lifting any characters or plots from Stouffer's books.

Stouffer has taken particular exception to Rowling's use of the word "muggles", which feature prominently in one of Stouffer's books, The Legend of Rah and the Muggles. However, Stouffer's hairless creatures have magical powers, unlike the human non-wizards in Rowling's books. Stouffer has also pointed out that her Larry Potter is identified as "Keeper of the Gardens", while a character in Rowling's books is known as "Keeper of the Keys".

Stouffer also claims that Rowling has used similar illustrations. Like his more famous counterpart, Larry Potter wears oversized round glasses and has wavy black hair.

Rowling and her publishers have strongly denied the charges set out by Stouffer. Rowling, whose books have sold more than 75m copies worldwide, told the New York judge during the original court hearing in January that she came up with the word muggles after hearing people call each other "mugs".

Scholastic and Time Warner, which owns the film rights to the Harry Potter books, are countersuing, claiming that they do not violate Stouffer's trademark and copyright. Meanwhile, spotting a potential market for Larry Potter, US publishers Thurman House have been quick to reprint Stouffer's entire series and are now thought to be looking for a British publisher.

webTitle: Business: Shell and Toyata, more jobs

fields.headline: Oil industry fires up 4,000 jobs
fields.standfirst:
Shell and Toyota plan to create more than 4,250 jobs

Shell
Toyota
fields.trailText: Shell and Toyota yesterday announced plans that will create more than 4,250 jobs, many in the north east and Wales.
fields.body:
Shell and Toyota yesterday announced plans that will create more than 4,250 jobs, many in the north east and Wales.

Shell has placed a ground-breaking offshore export contract with construction group AMEC while Toyota is to start building diesel engines in Britain.

The jobs announcements arrived 24 hours after news that unemployment had fallen below 1m. This encouraged the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, to declare the Shell deal "an important step towards achieving full employment in all regions of the UK".

More than 4,000 of the new positions will be created with AMEC which has won the £300m contract to build a floating production system for the use in the Bonga field in Nigeria. The deal is the largest export contract of its kind and was won against ferocious competition from engineering group ABB which planned to use low cost Korean construction yards.

Britain has found it difficult to land big deals outside the UK North Sea but Shell said AMEC had put together the best all-round package.

Some industry experts suggested the oil group might have come under pressure from British politicians to place the contract in Britain but Shell insiders dismissed this.

About 1,000 jobs will be created at AMEC's Wallsend yard on Tyneside with a further 1,100 going to subcontractors in the north east including 750 at Heerema's yard at Hartlepool.

Other jobs will be spread around the country. Mr Byers said: "It will put the UK in an excellent position when it comes to winning future contracts in the country [Nigeria] as well as other deep water projects."

Shell officials agreed that if the contract was performed well it should provide a springboard for AMEC and others to win contracts in other burgeoning offshore areas in west Africa and South America.

Japanese car maker Toyota said it would start making diesel engines at its Deeside plant from 2003 with the creation of 250 jobs.

The north Wales plant produces petrol engines and plans to export engine components to other Toyota plants in South Africa and South America.

Toyota's news follows recently announced car investment in Britain including Nissan's decision to produce the new Primera and Micra models in Sunderland, safeguarding 4,000 jobs.

It was not all good news from the industrial sector yesterday. European Telecom, the mobile phone distributor based in Slough, Berkshire, said it would make "significant" redundancies from its 600 staff.

The company said it would record a substantial loss this financial year because of worsening conditions in the mobile phones sector.

fields.headline: Seamus Mallon
fields.standfirst:
Newry and Armagh (1986- )

Ask Aristotle about Seamus Mallon
fields.trailText: One of the oldest hands in Irish politics and a central figure in the peace process, Seamus Mallon has been on the political scene for more than 25 years. Mr Mallon has offered more criticism of the IRA than many republican figures. But, he's equally willing to lay into the unionists, particularly in 1999 when he brought the peace process to a temporary halt by resigning as deputy first minister of Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
One of the oldest hands in Irish politics and a central figure in the peace process, Seamus Mallon has been on the political scene for more than 25 years. Mr Mallon has offered more criticism of the IRA than many republican figures. But, he's equally willing to lay into the unionists, particularly in 1999 when he brought the peace process to a temporary halt by resigning as deputy first minister of Northern Ireland.

'Always the deputy and never the leader' will line the tombstone of bespectacled, white-haired Mr Mallon. Not only is he Ulster's deputy first minister, under David Trimble, he is also deputy leader of the SDLP, under John Hume. Mr Hume is easing the burden on his own indifferent health by giving up his job in the Northern Ireland assembly, while retaining his posts in Westminster and Brussels. This does not help Mr Mallon, who has not had a day off for years and was close to collapse several years ago. Admittedly, chain smoking does not help his health.

Mr Mallon worked so hard to achieve 1998's Good Friday agreement that Mr Hume stepped aside to let him become deputy first minister to carry it out but Mr Mallon stepped down in 1999 when he felt Mr Trimble was violating the agreement by insisting on decommissioning, but was allowed to "de-resign" in November 1999.

Mr Mallon is caught between the IRA, whose "mindless violence" he deplores, and the unionist Protestants who use decommissioning as an excuse to slow or reverse steps toward peace. A brave man, he has always refused police protection: "I won't accept protection because I know those protecting me would be killed."

Although he looks older, Mr Mallon was born in 1936 in Markethill, Armagh, the son of a headmaster and a nurse. He followed in his father's footsteps by entering teaching and becoming a headmaster. Mr Mallon has worked extremely hard for Irish unity and to reverse Ulster's tradition of discrimination against its Catholic minority. This is not from religious conviction because he himself is an agnostic: "I was really brought into politics when the family of one of my pupils was trying to get out of a horribly dilapidated home and into a council house. At that time councillors had the power of allocation. That family was turned down by a [unionist] councillor who said: 'No Catholic pig and his litter will ever get a home in Markethill while I am here!'"

After becoming involved in the civil rights movement, Mr Mallon helped form the SDLP. By 1973 he had taken that unionist councillor's seat and within five years he was the SDLP's deputy leader.

He was also the first politician to be elected to both the Irish senate (in 1981) and the old Northern Ireland assembly (in 1982). He occupies a middle ground which he will have to hold onto and work at, if he is to maintain peace in Northern Ireland.

fields.headline: Mo Mowlam
fields.standfirst:
Redcar (1983- )

Ask Aristotle about Mo Mowlam
fields.trailText: The news that Mo Mowlam, after leaving Westminster, will set up an educational peace trust in Northern Ireland shows how fully Ulster captured her heart and mind - even after the brutal shock of being replaced as Northern Ireland secretary when the peace process had nearly delivered a legislative assembly.
fields.body:
The news that Mo Mowlam, after leaving Westminster, will set up an educational peace trust in Northern Ireland shows how fully Ulster captured her heart and mind - even after the brutal shock of being replaced as Northern Ireland secretary when the peace process had nearly delivered a legislative assembly.

She was brought up in a family where her drunken postal worker father had often shamed her, but she rose to become head girl at Coventry's Coundon Cross comprehensive. She then went to Durham University, but was forced to live out of college accommodation because her room displayed a half-naked picture of Jimi Hendrix.

As a young woman, she had followed her boyfriend to Iowa University where both of them won PhDs. On returning to the UK, she sought a seat until she won last-minute selection for Redcar in 1983, and was elected to the shadow cabinet (1992-1997).

One of the first declared supporters of Tony Blair, she threw herself completely into mastering Ulster from 1994, when he named her Northern Ireland spokesman in place of pro-republican Kevin McNamara. Despite battling against a brain tumour, she got to grips with the ropes from the start, and understood that while prodding the Unionists into accepting a partnership, the key was convincing the men of Sinn Fein and the IRA to fight verbal battles instead of continuing with the destructive urban guerrilla war, which Gerry Adams had long recognised as unwinable.

Ms Mowlam knew that she was not the pinup of the chauvinist Unionist leaders, who disliked her huggy-kissy style and "unladylike" language. But she had made great progress toward peace by frogmarching the Unionists and Gerry Adams into partnership.

She knew her strengths and weaknesses and was much better at cajoling people than in memorising the nitty-gritty of legal agreements - the 71% vote for the Good Friday agreement during her role as Northern Ireland secretary (1997-1999) showed she had won the hearts of the Irish people.

But what hurt her most was Mr Blair's willingness to accept Unionist requests to have Peter Mandelson replace her. After Northern Ireland, consignment in October 1999 to the shadowy committee work of the Cabinet Office as a bureaucratic "enforcer" was the worst form of political miscasting. Her subsequent announcement that she would stand down at the next election showed the depth of her hurt. She had survived a brain tumour, but not political betrayal.

fields.headline: Rhodri Morgan
fields.standfirst:
Cardiff West (1987- )

Ask Aristotle about Rhodri Morgan
fields.trailText: It takes a lot for a lifelong agnostic to want to urge a sainthood for a politician. Yet that that was my reaction to Rhodri Morgan's powerful loyalist speech at the 2000 last Labour conference after more than a year of brutal Blairite sidelining.
fields.body:
It takes a lot for a lifelong agnostic to want to urge a sainthood for a politician. Yet that that was my reaction to Rhodri Morgan's powerful loyalist speech at the 2000 last Labour conference after more than a year of brutal Blairite sidelining.

But Mr Morgan always insisted that he was not "the Welsh Ken Livingstone", loyally becoming No 2 to the more pliant Alun Michael after Downing Street used the Welsh party apparatus and its union vote to block him. Only after Labour voters massively abstained from the 1999 Welsh assembly elections was he allowed his rightful place.

Having spent 30 years rebuilding a Welsh cottage, I long ago became a fan of his brilliant Commons speeches analysing the peculiarities of Wales, with its reviving linguistic nationalism, its mixture of indigenous folk with essential "incomers" and its un-Scottish dependence on the English economy. His enthusiasm for soundly based devolution was well rooted.

"My great-great-grandfather, Morgan Morgan, at the height of the Rebecca Riots, shot... Colonel Napier, the head of the Glamorgan Yeomanry, aided by his mother, who struck with a frying pan one of the sergeants sent to arrest him."

A brilliant scholar at Cardiff's Whitchurch grammar and St John's, Oxford, he took his MA at Harvard. He moved into the Welsh civil service, becoming the highest paid civil servant in Wales, before winning back Cardiff West for Labour in 1987.

From his maiden speech his brilliance was not in doubt. But he was seen as a maverick, a "loose cannon" who tended to strike out wittily. He accused the CEGB of converting the Severn basin into the "largest nuclear flush lavatory in the world" because it used river waters to cool eight nuclear reactors. He made fun of Margaret Thatcher's anti-litter campaign by altering president Kennedy's famous phrase to "ich bin ein binliner".

He quickly became a spokesman on energy under Frank Dobson, accusing energy secretary John Wakeham of privatising generators, "our major national assets, at junk bond prices". He also became a leading opponent to the Cardiff Barrage, backed by the Tory government and some Welsh Labour MPs, because he feared it would waterlog his constituency. But his main worry now, and one of the reasons why he is stepping down from Westminster at the next election, is to prevent Plaid Cymru from eroding the massive Labour vote in Wales, as they did in the Welsh assembly elections.

fields.headline: John Hume
fields.standfirst:
Foyle (1983- )

Ask Aristotle about John Hume
fields.trailText: It was a telling irony that an ailing John Hume should have to give up his most recent job first - his seat in the new Northern Ireland assembly ought to have been the pinnacle of the achievement which earned him the 1998 Nobel Peace Prize. But his poor health has seen this job go while he retains his better paid but less demanding posts at Westminster and in the European parliament.
fields.body:
It was a telling irony that an ailing John Hume should have to give up his most recent job first - his seat in the new Northern Ireland assembly ought to have been the pinnacle of the achievement which earned him the 1998 Nobel Peace Prize. But his poor health has seen this job go while he retains his better paid but less demanding posts at Westminster and in the European parliament.

Even before his health sagged, Mr Hume had always wielded a broad brush, like a Renaissance painter leaving the filling in of details to his apprentices. In his case this has been his overworked deputy, Seamus Mallon, who was also saddled with the job of deputy leader of the assembly, having to work with its chilly unionist leader, David Trimble.

Mr Hume has always enjoyed taking the applause for being the non-violent voice of Ulster's Catholics, particularly in Brussels, Strasbourg, Stockholm and Washington, more than in Westminster, where he has been less appreciated. Across the Atlantic, he is the top Irish hero of the Democrats' Kennedy-led "Murphia".

This is because, for almost 20 years, he has been repeating the same message: that peace can only come to Northern Ireland if the dominant Protestant unionists take into partnership the catholic minority and make it unnecessary for their armed wing, the Provisional IRA, to battle as urban guerillas for a united Ireland. To do this, he linked up secretly with Gerry Adams, the former IRA man who was among its first to recognise that the British could not be thrown out by force and the ballot box could eventually bring about a united Ireland sooner than the armed struggle. From time to time Mr Hume's message also got through to the British and Irish governments, resulting in the 1985 Anglo-Irish agreement and the 1998 Good Friday agreement. This brought him - and David Trimble - the Nobel Peace Prize and £286,000, which Mr Hume donated to charity.

Warned off politics by his father, he entered teaching until he became involved in the first civil rights parade of Londonderry's Bogside in 1968, becoming leader of the local civil rights protests. Elected to Stormont for the Londonderry seat of Foyle in 1969, he was arrested by British troops in 1970.

By 1979 he succeeded Gerry Fitt as leader of the SDLP (Social Democratic Labour party), which had become the party of moderate Catholics in Northern Ireland. By 1983 he was elected for Foyle to Westminster, the first Catholic to achieve this in 100 years.

The final irony of his situation is that, having helped convert Sinn Fein-IRA to politics, they may now outstrip his own SDLP in the looming race for Catholic voters.
