fields.headline: Henry McLeish
fields.standfirst:
Fife Central (1987-)

Ask Aristotle about Henry McLeish
fields.trailText: Henry McLeish is determined that devolution will mean that Scotland can decide for itself on issues like university fees and personal care for the elderly. He will argue fiercely with the UK Treasury, not least because he'll need to show the SNP that he's capable of standing up to Westminster.
fields.body:
Henry McLeish is determined that devolution will mean that Scotland can decide for itself on issues like university fees and personal care for the elderly. He will argue fiercely with the UK Treasury, not least because he'll need to show the SNP that he's capable of standing up to Westminster.

He took in Scottish Labourism from his birth in central Fife in June 1948. "My grandmother [was] a member of the Labour party for 70 years and a member of the Co-op party. My grandfather was a miner in a private coal company and in later life he turned to Christianity, so there was a strong Christian socialist influence as well," he recalled. His father was a miner for 30 years.

Mr McLeish left Buckhaven high school aged 15 to become a schoolboy professional at Leeds United football club. After six weeks homesickness struck and he moved back to Scotland to join East Fife football club. Resuming his education at Herriot-Watt University, he went on to work as a planning officer for Dunfermline district council and Fife county council, while also lecturing part time at Herriot-Watt.

He joined the Labour party in 1970. Two years later he was a Kirkcaldy district councillor at 24, becoming chairman of its planning committee. In 1978 he was elected to Fife county council, becoming its leader in 1982 and enacting a "municipal socialist" package with free bus passes and TV licences for pensioners.

In 1981 he began challenging the rightwing Labour MP Willie Hamilton, known nationally for his anti-monarchy campaigns, for Central Fife. Mr Hamilton gave up the struggle in 1985, enabling Henry McLeish to be elected in 1987.

As a strong devolutionist, he was one of the original signatories of the claim of right at the inaugural meeting of the 1989 Scottish constitutional convention which paved the way for devolution.

After Labour's 1992 defeat, he contested the shadow cabinet, emerging as deputy spokesman on Scotland. When Tony Blair became leader (1994), Mr McLeish became deputy spokesman on transport (1994-95). He described rail privatisation as "the most monumentally stupid piece of public policy since the war". He then switched over to become deputy spokesman on health (1995-96).

He showed his loyalty to the leader by not standing for the shadow cabinet in 1996 when Mr Blair wanted to increase the chances of Harriet Harman's survival. He was rewarded by being made election campaigns director for Scotland in 1997.

When Scotland emerged Tory-free from the May 1997 election, he was made minister of state in the Scotland Office under Donald Dewar. After weeks of negotiations he persuaded the SNP to back Labour's devolution plans. He showed his patience not only by carrying much of the burden of devolutionary legislation but in answering the 14th adjournment debate by Tam Dalyell on the Lockerbie plane crash.

Having announced he would not again contest for the Westminster parliament, he won his Central Fife seat in the Scottish parliament and initially became its minister for enterprise and lifelong learning (1999-2000), with the deputy first minister's title going to Liberal Democrat Jim Wallace. A year later Mr McLeish finally stepped into Donald Dewar's vacated shoes as the top man (2000-).

He has grown into his job as first minister in the period since the much mourned death of Mr Dewar, the father of Scottish devolution, and his defeat by 44 to 36 of his leadership rival, Jack McConnell, in October 2000. He has shown a new authority and dynamism and an ability to take on Mr Dewar's commitments - like the visit to the Pope - without Mr Dewar's fondly recalled awkwardness.

There is no doubt about his commitment to devolution, or his contributions to the legislation which set it up. Donald Dewar was undoubtedly its presiding genius, but the main task of carrying through the complex bill was shouldered by his lieutenant, Mr McLeish, who spent more hours on the frontbench than Mr Dewar.

Having lost its founding father Mr McLeish will have to use all his political acumen to ensure that the new parliament becomes part of Scottish life outside the Edinburgh elite.

fields.headline: Peter Lilley
fields.standfirst:
Hitchin and Harpenden (1997- )
St Albans (1983-1997)

Ask Aristotle about Peter Lilley
fields.trailText: A search party has not yet been sent out, but the politician formerly known as Peter Lilley, Tory deputy leader from 1998-99 and social security secretary in 1992-97, who used to convulse Tory conferences with cringe-making doggerel, has disappeared.
fields.body:
A search party has not yet been sent out, but the politician formerly known as Peter Lilley, Tory deputy leader from 1998-99 and social security secretary in 1992-97, who used to convulse Tory conferences with cringe-making doggerel, has disappeared.

All that remains is a silent wraith of that name, making rare appearances on the backbenches. And all because he tried sensibly to water down their Thatcherite inheritance, as requested, and to depict the Tories as "generous and caring", opposed to privatising the NHS and education.

Historians may judge that his was the last serious effort before Michael Portillo tried to move the depleted Tories toward a more winnable centre ground. Peter Lilley had already demonstrated in office his almost Butler-like ability to give Toryism a human face. In 1995 he had fought off Treasury attempts to end payments to lone parents, not his only display of humanity.

Despite his house in Normandy, he is Eurosceptic enough to have been called a "bastard" by John Major. He is also Thatcherite in his economics. But he opposes capital punishment and disdains demagoguery. His only concessions to rightwing populism were his stormily applauded annual party conference verses.

Mr Lilley was clearly better in the cabinet doing deft things behind his concealing civil servants. Even ex-communist Sue Slipman, speaking as director of the national council for one parent families, admitted he never did anything "actively harmful to lone parents and has actually been helpful".

Once he was in opposition, he lacked the killer instinct to attack chancellor Gordon Brown without scruple as the shadow chancellor in 1997-98 and had to make way for Francis Maude, who did no better.

Kicked upstairs by William Hague to develop longterm policies as deputy leader, he only lasted a year when he unveiled them. He became a non-person as if dispatched to a Siberian gulag. He emerged, briefly, from oblivion in January 2000 when he displayed a degree of favour for the legalisation of cannabis. "It's very difficult to argue for the present situation," he said. "If somebody can find something better, I would certainly consider it." After Ann Widdecombe wrenched open the pandora's box which is the cannabis issue at the party conference it was thought that Mr Lilley considered publishing a pamphlet setting out the case for legalising cannabis.

Yet despite his brief reappearances, it was an unexpected oblivion for a stockbroker turned politician. Born in Hayes, Kent, in 1943, he was educated at Dulwich college and Clare College, Cambridge. An oil expert with stockbrokers Greenwell Montague, he blew the money he received when bought out as a partner on his manor in Normandy.

Although he came from a Liberal family, he became a Tory quite young, but was "too shy" to express his views at Cambridge. But as national chairman of the Bow Group in 1973-1975 he helped push the group to the right and urged Tories to re-embrace the Friedman economic principles which had been abandoned by prime minister Ted Heath. Elected for St Albans in 1983, he made his name initially as a rightwinger by co-authoring "No Turning Back" from which the hardline Thatcherite group took its name - a far cry from his new life on the backbenches.

In the runup to the London mayoral election in 2000 his flirtation with heresy had not gone unnoticed. He was even approached to chair "Tories for Livingstone" and confessed to the Cambridge Forum: "I was tempted but will probably vote for Steven Norris."

He has had to learn anew that other Tory rightwingers will not allow you to turn back.

Once he was in opposition, he lacked the killer instinct to attack chancellor Gordon Brown without scruple as the shadow chancellor in 1997-98 and had to make way for Francis Maude, who did no better. Kicked upstairs by William Hague to develop longterm policies as deputy leader, he only lasted a year when he unveiled them. He became a non-person as if dispatched to a Siberian gulag. He emerged, briefly, from oblivion in January 2000 when he displayed a degree of favour for the legalisation of cannabis. "It's very difficult to argue for the present situation," he said. "If somebody can find something better, I would certainly consider it." After Ann Widdecombe wrenched open the pandora's box which is the cannabis issue at the party conference it was thought that Mr Lilley considered publishing a pamphlet setting out the case for legalising cannabis. Yet despite his brief reappearances, it was an unexpected oblivion for a stockbroker turned politician. Born in Hayes, Kent, in 1943, he was educated at Dulwich college and Clare College, Cambridge. An oil expert with stockbrokers Greenwell Montague, he blew the money he received when bought out as a partner on his manor in Normandy. Although he came from a Liberal family, he became a Tory quite young, but was "too shy" to express his views at Cambridge. But as national chairman of the Bow Group in 1973-1975 he helped push the group to the right and urged Tories to re-embrace the Friedman economic principles which had been abandoned by prime minister Ted Heath. Elected for St Albans in 1983, he made his name initially as a rightwinger by co-authoring "No Turning Back" from which the hardline Thatcherite group took its name - a far cry from his new life on the backbenches. In the runup to the London mayoral election in 2000 his flirtation with heresy had not gone unnoticed. He was even approached to chair "Tories for Livingstone" and confessed to the Cambridge Forum: "I was tempted but will probably vote for Steven Norris." He has had to learn anew that other Tory rightwingers will not allow you to turn back. Ask Aristotle about Peter Lilley

fields.headline: John Major
fields.standfirst:
Huntingdon (1983-)
Huntingdonshire (1979-83)

Ask Aristotle about John Major
fields.trailText: No postwar former prime minister has made the transition from power to backbench impotence as gracefully as John Major. In office he was troubled, angry and constantly under fire. But with his party's 1997 defeat behind him, he has spoken regularly from the backbenches with authority and assurance, and been received with the warmth his personality demands.
fields.body:
No postwar former prime minister has made the transition from power to backbench impotence as gracefully as John Major. In office he was troubled, angry and constantly under fire. But with his party's 1997 defeat behind him, he has spoken regularly from the backbenches with authority and assurance, and been received with the warmth his personality demands.

And that is not the only oddity about Mr Major. He is not unique in reaching high office from a humble background, but he is certainly rare in combining the feat with a troubled childhood and basic education. Born into a south London family and trapped in debt, he went to Rutlish grammar school in a secondhand blazer when his former trapeze artist father lost his garden ornament business.

He left at 15, with the complex of an underdog but local politics provided an escape route. Elected to Lambeth council in 1968, he eventually reached the Commons in 1979 as MP for Huntingdonshire.

Once there his rise was quiet but unmistakable. He was made a parliamentary private secretary at the Home Office in 1981, and became a minister at the Department of Health in 1986.

From there he was a favourite of Margaret Thatcher, becoming first chief secretary to the Treasury after the 1987 election, and replaced Sir Geoffrey Howe as foreign secretary in a shock promotion by a prime minister in trouble. By the end of the year he achieved his life's dream, becoming the chancellor of the exchequer in the wake of Nigel Lawson's resignation.

In November 1990 he won the Conservative party leadership after Mrs Thatcher's fall. Initial success, in the Gulf war and the 1992 general election, gave way to decline in the face of economic troubles - especially Black Wednesday - and growing hostility to Europe within his party and cabinet. Slipping behind in the polls, the election defeat in 1997 was inevitable.

Heavily criticised for his inept leadership, he left office on May 2 1997, with his party's reputation for probity in tatters. But he, at least, retained some of his famed decency.

His personal popularity was also intact, shown by the unexpected sale of more than 150,000 copies of his autobiography, the £25,000 he commands for lectures, and his comfortable selection of boardroom jobs.

Although his speeches since the election have often offered sensible advice, they are not always heeded - certainly not his warning to William Hague that moving further to the right spelled Tory "ruin". But as a good party man, most of his warnings are directed at Labour. He has opposed the provision of Commons facilities to Sinn Fein MPs (who refuse to take the oath of allegiance to the Queen), and is only mildly supportive of Tony Blair's initiatives in Northern Ireland, insisting that the IRA should decommission more rapidly than they have done.

From his 1999 autobiography comes the impression that John Major is finally at ease with himself, having concluded that he played as good a hand as possible with the cards dealt to him. Gone are the nightmares of trying to run a government around party splits and with the constant threats of revolts from both inside and outside of the cabinet.

He no longer seems to feel the long-evident insecurity he revealed when, on his appointment as foreign secretary by Mrs Thatcher, he said: "The only people [at the Foreign Office] without a degree were the porter and me."

Out of government his confidence has grown while the hostility in the Tory party towards him diminished. Even his support for Europe has been met with an ambivalent attitude from his colleagues - he certainly does not evoke the sort of hostility generated by Sir Edward Heath's always-europhile speeches. His only contemporary equal is Kenneth Clarke, the punchy former chancellor, who is still seen as a "big hitter" in the battle against Blair, and a possible future contender for the Tory leadership.

As Mr Major surveys a life after parliament he can expect to be judged more fairly than he was in office, with plenty of respect for his decency, if not his political courage.

fields.headline: Michael Howard
fields.standfirst:
Folkestone and Hythe (1983-)

Ask Aristotle about Michael Howard
fields.trailText: Michael Howard, the former Tory home secretary, is one of those half-ghosts from Tory cabinets who materialise on the backbenches to indicate that they are not quite dead to do a spot of Labour-bashing.
fields.body:
Michael Howard, the former Tory home secretary, is one of those half-ghosts from Tory cabinets who materialise on the backbenches to indicate that they are not quite dead to do a spot of Labour-bashing.

In his case one can almost see the dagger in his back, inscribed "something of the night". Piquantly, Ann Widdecombe, his former junior who thus maligned him, has surged into popularity as the more rightwing alternative to Michael Portillo and potential successor to William Hague.

Mr Howard was the last of the Tory "Cambridge Mafia" of the 60s - which included Kenneth Clarke, John Gummer, Norman Fowler and Leon Brittan - to retire to the back benches.

He came up via Llanelli grammar school in Gorseinon, near Swansea, where his Romanian Jewish shopkeeper father had settled. At school he was one of only two Jewish pupils. The family name of Hecht was anglicised to Howard.

In 1966 and 1970 he contested two parliamentary elections for the Conservative party at Edge Hill, Liverpool, before finding a safe seat 13 years later in Folkestone and Hythe. The delay was partly because of his desire to make his way as a successful barrister in planning and employment law, but also provided a chance to cement his marriage to ex-model Saundra Paul - her fourth, his first.

Once in the Commons, Mr Howard established his rightwing views. In his maiden speech he urged legal protection for strike breakers, and endorsed the restoration of the death penalty and US intervention in Grenada. Within two years he had begun his climb up the greasy pole of politics.

A populist home secretary, from 1993 to John Major's 1997 election defeat, he fought crime by locking people up - to the dismay of top judges and his more centrist predecessors like Douglas Hurd. His tough line saw crime drop by 15% and made him the darling of the tabloids but he was seriously undermined by his handling of the resignation of the Derek Lewis, the director of prisons, in 1996.

Mr Lewis fell on his sword when a report into the escape of prisoners from Whitemoor prison highlighted serious deficiencies in the system. Mr Howard almost suffered the same fate when he was asked about whether he had made Mr Lewis a scapegoat 14 times by Jeremy Paxman on Newsnight.

Despite this public relations disaster, Mr Howard managed to maintain widespread support in the press due to his Europhobia. As the senior Eurosceptic in John Major's cabinet he pursued many battles with Europhile Ken Clarke and seemed well placed to succeed Mr Major.

This hope was destroyed in the first round of the Tory leadership battle following their May 1997 defeat. After William Hague reneged on a deal to run as Mr Howard's deputy, Mr Howard came fifth with 23 votes. He then backed the much younger man and was rewarded with the post of shadow foreign secretary. He spent the next two years doing little else other than demanding Robin Cook's resignation.

Although still very pro-American and against a federal Europe, Mr Howard no longer fitted in with Hague's "Little England" Europhobes, who criticised him for supporting Nato's attack on Serbia as a "just war". After Mr Hague announced plans for "kitchen table Conservatism" in March 1999, Mr Howard retired from frontbench politics to the relative comfort of his well-cushioned boardrooms.

There he can exhibit his QC's mind, expressed with a slight Welsh accent in his smoothly courteous personal manner.

The departure of Derek Lewis made an enemy of Ann Widdecombe and probably ended Mr Howard's chances of becoming leader. He must often think what might have been if those convicts had not gone over the wall in Whitemoor.

fields.headline: Stephen Byers
fields.standfirst:
North Tyneside (1997- )
Wallsend (1992-97)

Ask Aristotle about Stephen Byers
fields.trailText: An ambitious New Labour cabinet minister who can paper his toilet with press coverage about himself on an average Friday might be pleased with his public profile. Unless it's all bad publicity. Stephen Byers, Labour MP for North Tyneside and chief of the Department of Trade and Industry, is an ambitious politician but with a heavy slate of bad publicity on his balance sheet. Two of his biggest advents onto the national agenda hardly attracted accolades: he failed to prevent the closure of both the Rover and Vauxhall car plants.
fields.body:
An ambitious New Labour cabinet minister who can paper his toilet with press coverage about himself on an average Friday might be pleased with his public profile. Unless it's all bad publicity. Stephen Byers, Labour MP for North Tyneside and chief of the Department of Trade and Industry, is an ambitious politician but with a heavy slate of bad publicity on his balance sheet. Two of his biggest advents onto the national agenda hardly attracted accolades: he failed to prevent the closure of both the Rover and Vauxhall car plants.

The Rover and Vauxhall closures were a weird comeuppance for an able, ambitious politician who learned his protesting cadences while agitating for the teachers' unions in the north-east. During both the closures and the modernisation of the Labour party, Mr Byers' image morphed from union campaigner to the "enemy of the unions", a frontbencher who worried about big business and left jobs to rot.

In fact, he has never really recovered from his 1996 briefing of four journalists, when he was assistant education spokesman, where he said New Labour was about to "break the links with the unions altogether" and perhaps end their voting rights to avoid another "winter of discontent" fiasco. He was given a dressing down by David Blunkett but his offer to resign was refused as only making matters worse.

Born in Wolverhampton in 1953, the son of an RAF radar technician, Mr Byers was educated at Chester City grammar, Chester College of further education and Liverpool Polytechnic, where he earned his law degree. This enabled him to become a senior lecturer in law at Newcastle University 1975-92.

It was on the North Tyneside council that he made his initial reputation as a backer of the activist democracy which almost made the Labour party unelectable. By 1985 he was deputy leader. By 1990 he was more moderate as leader of the council of local education authorities, a job that left him trying to pry more pay for teachers out of John Major's education ministers.

After two previous failures against union-backed candidates in Blyth and Newcastle North, he made it into the Commons for Wallsend (now Tyneside North) in 1992. He showed himself a remorseless questioner, his first success being to show that of the £2bn the Tories pumped into Michael Heseltine's 10 urban development corporations, six had lost £67m on land purchases largely for commercial rather than industrial development.

With Alan Milburn, he is a leading example of the kind of ambitious able young politician who, while climbing Labour's ladder, has managed to move from its left side to the "modernising" right without batting an eyelid. As long as they are able and moving into his camp, Tony Blair does not mind helping them up the ladder. Mr Byers became president of the board of trade in 1998 after reaching the cabinet earlier that year as chief secretary to the Treasury under the chancellor, Gordon Brown. If he is not beloved of trade union leaders, despite representing the heavily industrial Tyneside, Mr Byers has certainly kept other political fences well mended. He is as acceptable to Mr Brown's affiliates as he is to Mr Blair's.

fields.headline: Harriet Harman
fields.standfirst:
Camberwell and Peckham (1997-)
Peckham (1982-1997)

Ask Aristotle about Harriet Harman
fields.trailText: Harriet Harman was once the chilly beautiful face of New Labour, a middle class moderniser. Mr Blair consistently protected her until a series of blunders, including cutting lone parent benefits in 1997, led to her fall from grace in July 1998 when she was sacked from the cabinet as social security secretary after just 14 months.
fields.body:
Harriet Harman was once the chilly beautiful face of New Labour, a middle class moderniser. Mr Blair consistently protected her until a series of blunders, including cutting lone parent benefits in 1997, led to her fall from grace in July 1998 when she was sacked from the cabinet as social security secretary after just 14 months.

Born into a professional background, she followed her mother's footsteps and trained as a solicitor. She was a crusader for civil liberties as the legal officer for the national council for civil liberties (1978-82), now called Liberty. She married into the Labour establishment when she walked down the aisle with Jack Dromey, a senior official at the T&G.

When she first entered the Commons as the MP for Peckham in 1982 she had the reputation of being a hard-leftist and endorsed "extra-parliamentary action". She claimed that Mrs Thatcher's mass unemployment was designed to drive down wages.

She was later to be seen as a "slavish Blairite" who was close to Gordon Brown after having served as his deputy in the shadow Treasury team from 1992-1994.

The aura of that early left reputation still hung over her when she joined the Blair camp in 1994, enabling her to be elected both to Labour's NEC and the shadow cabinet where she became health spokesperson.

Upon entering the cabinet in 1997 she turned her back on her leftist roots and while secretary of state for social security pushed through cuts in benefits for lone parents, insisting they "wanted to work", whether their children were under five or over 10. She had shown this same lack of political touch in sending her children to distant selective secondary schools rather than local Southwark comprehensives, without clearing it with Blair.

Her outspoken colleague Gwyneth Dunwoody said Ms Harman was one of those "women who were of the opinion that they had a God-given right to be amongst the chosen".

Since the shock of her sacking she has returned to her roots campaigning for women and children. She was thrown into the spotlight following the murder in her constituency of Nigerian 10-year-old Damilola Taylor in November 2000. She handled the situation with dignity and avoided the opportunity to exploit his death for an attempted political comeback. Although Ms Harman remains ambitious, she is not tasteless.

fields.headline: Kate Hoey
fields.standfirst:
Vauxhall (1989- )

Ask Aristotle about Kate Hoey
fields.trailText: The harsh nasal accents of a woman who was once a Belfast games mistress have become the decisive tones in all British sports. Irish born Kate Hoey, MP for Vauxhall and the first woman sports minister, has proven herself willing to challenge the government's line on more than one occasion.
fields.body:
The harsh nasal accents of a woman who was once a Belfast games mistress have become the decisive tones in all British sports. Irish born Kate Hoey, MP for Vauxhall and the first woman sports minister, has proven herself willing to challenge the government's line on more than one occasion.

Tony Blair isn't laughing at his maverick sports minister, whom Neil Kinnock tagged "Ho Ho Hoey". A popular football fanatic and once Ulster's high jump champion, Kate Hoey seems to be tempting fate and the ultimate red card by ignoring all the rules of ministerial responsibility.

Ms Hoey has stood out against Labour's agreed line on handguns, terracing in football stadiums and fox hunting.

In January 2001, she spoke out in a shooting magazine against the post-Dunblane 1997 law banning the use of handguns. She insisted her Labour colleagues had taken a "very unfair attitude" toward legitimate shooting, which she argued young children should learn, as she had on her family's farm in Ulster.

That rebellion came shortly after she called for a return to terracing at Premiership football grounds. Since the Taylor report into the Hillsborough disaster of 1989, terracing has been effectively banned, with government approval.

In addition to both of these revolts, Ms Hoey made herself the darling of the Countryside Alliance by defending fox hunting. She is credited with telling the Daily Mail: "A ban on hunting is not going to help us save a [single] fox. In fact, there will be very few foxes left in the country if hunting is abolished."

Politicians who rattle the bars of a ministerial cell can have many reasons for doing so. Ms Hoey may want promotion above her technical status as a parliamentary secretary of state at the Department of Culture. She may want more Treasury funds for sports. But the revolts could always be one too many, and can always carry risks for future promotion (if not relegation to the second division).

Ms Hoey was given her belated promotion in 1998 in recognition of her efforts to shore up Northern Ireland's protestant support for the Good Friday Agreement. She is the only protestant Ulsterwoman on Labour's benches. In fact, even her election as an MP had a maverick quality. After its sitting MP, Stuart Holland, deserted Vauxhall, she was shortlisted for the seat against the wishes of its hard-left activists who wanted Nigerian-born leftist Martha Osamor. Ms Hoey won the byelection by 9,766 votes. Prior to winning Vauxhall, she had tried for Dulwich without any success.

She had a rough ride initially, because she fiercely attacked the corrupt loony-left group running Lambeth, of which Vauxhall is a part. She urged Labour to field candidates in Ulster, which destabilised Labour's relationship with its sister party, the SDLP. Her outspoken support for field sports has also angered her colleagues.

But, she can be happy with her lot. As she once said: "My aim is to be the first woman minister for sport."

Ms Hoey was given her belated promotion in 1998 in recognition of her efforts to shore up Northern Ireland's protestant support for the Good Friday Agreement. She is the only protestant Ulsterwoman on Labour's benches. In fact, even her election as an MP had a maverick quality. After its sitting MP, Stuart Holland, deserted Vauxhall, she was shortlisted for the seat against the wishes of its hard-left activists who wanted Nigerian-born leftist Martha Osamor. Ms Hoey won the byelection by 9,766 votes. Prior to winning Vauxhall, she had tried for Dulwich without any success. She had a rough ride initially, because she fiercely attacked the corrupt loony-left group running Lambeth, of which Vauxhall is a part. She urged Labour to field candidates in Ulster, which destabilised Labour's relationship with its sister party, the SDLP. Her outspoken support for field sports has also angered her colleagues. But, she can be happy with her lot. As she once said: "My aim is to be the first woman minister for sport." Ask Aristotle about Kate Hoey

fields.headline: Patricia Hewitt
fields.standfirst:
Leicester West (1997- )

Ask Aristotle about Patricia Hewitt
fields.trailText: Designer clothed and well coiffured, Patricia Hewitt, the Labour MP for Leicester West and the Department of Trade and Industry's e-commerce minister is the fastest rising woman of the 1997 intake (and so tagged as one of "Blair's babes"). She is also central to New Labour's thinking on social welfare.
fields.body:
Designer clothed and well coiffured, Patricia Hewitt, the Labour MP for Leicester West and the Department of Trade and Industry's e-commerce minister is the fastest rising woman of the 1997 intake (and so tagged as one of "Blair's babes"). She is also central to New Labour's thinking on social welfare.

All this is a far cry from her earliest frontline political incarnation in the mid-1980s, as Neil Kinnock's press secretary. Then, she co-wrote Mr Kinnock's dramatic 1985 conference speech attacking the Liverpudlian militant Derek Hatton. The speech helped to define Labour's long road back to electability.

Petite and birdlike, Ms Hewitt has only recently secured elected office. She arrived in parliament in 1997, a long time after her network of metropolitan women contemporaries had secured seats in the Commons. Harriet Harman had become an MP in 1982 - her partner in the so-called "Hattie and Pattie show" when the pair ran the national council for civil liberties in the early 80s.

Even from the fringe, however, she was influential. As vice-chairman of the social justice commission, established at the request of then Labour leader John Smith and run by the IPPR, she contributed to the thinking which led to welfare-to-work and the social exclusion unit. Ken Follett credited her with realising Labour's need for the excalibur rapid reaction computer, which so effectively armed Labour propagandists during the 1997 election.

Ms Hewitt is given less than full credit because her drive, intelligence, energy and lack of easy charm can be read as needlessly abrasive, evoking bitchiness among her detractors (who generally lack her quickness of mind). A lot of envious noses were put out of joint when she was named economic secretary to the Treasury in 1998, then minister for small business and e-commerce at the DTI in 1999..

Perhaps it is her Australian origins which make her an outsider. Born in Canberra she followed her mother's family to Cambridge University, graduating from Newnham College. Only then did she join the Labour party, standing out early for her hostility to then prime minister James Callaghan and many of his MPs. At Labour's 1980 conference, she insisted from the podium in the hall that the rank and file should determine future policies, not "a handful of cabinet ministers and civil servants".

After failing to win the marginal seat of Leicester East in 1983, she went to work as Neil Kinnock's press secretary and adviser on re-establishing links with Labour's grass roots. She remained a politician of the centre ground, attacking both Roy Hattersley on the right and loony left councils parading their support for minority rights ahead of running essential services.

When the Kinnock crusade crashed in 1992, she went into well paid internal exile as head of research in Andersen Consulting. This did not stop her thinking about how to make Labour more popular and get herself elected, achieving both aims. "She was New Labour long before the party," according to a colleague of the time. Having drifted from the left in the early 1980s to the centre under Mr Kinnock and now the right with Mr Blair she is well placed to enter the cabinet after the election.

fields.headline: Nick Harvey
fields.standfirst:
North Devon (1992- )

Ask Aristotle about Nick Harvey
fields.trailText: Nick Harvey, the balding 39-year-old Liberal Democrat spokesman on health, is Charles Kennedy's secret weapon. The Lib Dems' Alastair Campbell, the MP for North Devon was chairman of campaigns and communications for the 1997 election before being rewarded with his frontbench role for supporting Mr Kennedy's leadership bid.
fields.body:
Nick Harvey, the balding 39-year-old Liberal Democrat spokesman on health, is Charles Kennedy's secret weapon. The Lib Dems' Alastair Campbell, the MP for North Devon was chairman of campaigns and communications for the 1997 election before being rewarded with his frontbench role for supporting Mr Kennedy's leadership bid.

A former marketing man, Mr Harvey challenged (and lost to) Michael Portillo in Enfield Southgate in the 1987 general election before winning North Devon in 1992. When he decided to back Mr Kennedy and not contest the Lib Dem leadership he earned himself a return to the frontbench and assured that Mr Kennedy, the darling of the chat shows, would receive shrewd and sound advice.

Speaking persuasively on health, Mr Harvey seldom makes headlines, unlike his impulsive predecessor Simon Hughes. He treats the subject too seriously to reduce it to soundbites. But Commons listeners take him seriously, unlike the Tory spokesman who normally precedes him in debates. In his speeches, he shows little of the genial humour that characterised him in the decade before he won North Devon, when he was well known to me as a lobbyist.

Nick Harvey's support for the Liberal Democrats was an early allegiance. At 18 he was the Liberal candidate in the mock election at Queen's College, Taunton. By 22 he was the Liberal agent in Mrs Thatcher's Finchley seat and backed Liberal leader David Steel against the Liberal assembly's attempt to foist a deputy on him. By 25 he had switched sides within the party to oppose the Steel-Owen proposal for a joint Anglo-French nuclear missile.

He came into his own when, at 29, he was selected as the Liberal Democrat candidate for North Devon, previously held by Jeremy Thorpe before his disgrace and defeat by Tory Tony Spellar in 1979. Mr Harvey moved into the constituency and backed its demands for cheaper petrol. In 1992 he recaptured the seat for the Liberal Democrats by 794 votes and was instantly named Liberal Democrat transport spokesman.

Mr Harvey has opposed arms exports to the Indonesian regime and attacked the Tories' "shambolic" rail privatisation. He was the conduit through whom Emma Nicholson crossed from the Tories to the Liberal Democrats. But Nick Harvey's greatest contribution to his party was as its campaigns and communications chief. He held the reins when the Liberal Democrats won 46 of their targeted seats in May 1997. Although now a spokesman on health, his role in planning the Liberal Democrats' strategy and his influence on Mr Kennedy remain undiminished.

fields.headline: Margaret Beckett
fields.standfirst:
Derby South (1983-)
Lincoln (1974-1979)

Ask Aristotle about Margaret Beckett
fields.trailText: Margaret Beckett's logical, analytical, steeltrap mind, linked with her strong party loyalty is perfect for politics - but it is not warmed by her personality. She suffers from being seen as an apparatchik, a successful manager, but not a political visionary.
fields.body:
Margaret Beckett's logical, analytical, steeltrap mind, linked with her strong party loyalty is perfect for politics - but it is not warmed by her personality. She suffers from being seen as an apparatchik, a successful manager, but not a political visionary.

Born in 1943 in Ashton-under-Lyne into the family of an invalid Congregationalist carpenter father and an Irish Catholic teacher mother. Her father died early, precipitating family poverty.

Educated at mainly Catholic schools, she qualified as a metallurgist from the Manchester College of Science and Technology. As such she began her working life with AEI in Manchester, then worked at Manchester University, until she became a research officer for the Labour party, and subsequently for Granada TV.

Joining the Labour party in 1964, she broke into the public eye a decade later as Margaret Jackson. She contested Lincoln in February 1974 against defector Dick Taverne and despite losing she went on to win the seat from him in October 1974. She lost the seat in 1979, but won a place on Labour's NEC in 1980.

Attention turned to her again in 1981 when, at a Tribune conference fringe rally, she sharply attacked Neil Kinnock and other soft-left MPs for having abstained from supporting Tony Benn against Denis Healey.

She re-entered the Commons for Derby South in 1983 as Margaret Beckett, having married her husband, Leo. She then joined both the soft-left Tribune group and the hard-left Campaign group. She left the Campaign group in 1988, with Clare Short, when it again backed Tony Benn's challenge to Neil Kinnock.

Partly because of her slightly chilly, uptight manner, as leader of the Commons Mrs Beckett has never received adequate appreciation for her role in holding both wings of the Labour party together. Having herself moved from the semi-hard left to the centre, she considers herself an inclusive "servant of the party". Her loyalty is all the more remarkable because of her thinly-concealed hurt that she's not recognised as a former Labour leader having carried out the role between John Smith's death and Tony Blair's election.

She's been a success in the party because the inclusive position, which she has reached after almost 40 years in Labour politics, cuts across usual group loyalties. Her roots are on the left, but she opposes reckless spending. She is a moderniser, but believes in retaining union links. As a working woman, she has sympathies with those who want more modern practices. But she recognises the need for harassing the executive.

fields.headline: Michael Ancram
fields.standfirst:
Devizes (1992-)
Edinburgh South (1979-1987)
Berwick and East Lothian (Feb-Oct 1974)

Ask Aristotle about Michael Ancram
fields.trailText: Not since Patty Hearst, the female scion of the wealthy Californian newspaper family, turned up in a leftwing terrorist gang have so many been so surprised at the survival of Michael Ancram as a leading member of William Hague's band of Eurosceptics. Ancram, or more accurately, the Earl of Ancram, has been chairman of Mr Hague's Conservative party since 1998.
fields.body:
Not since Patty Hearst, the female scion of the wealthy Californian newspaper family, turned up in a leftwing terrorist gang have so many been so surprised at the survival of Michael Ancram as a leading member of William Hague's band of Eurosceptics. Ancram, or more accurately, the Earl of Ancram, has been chairman of Mr Hague's Conservative party since 1998.

Nobody who has known the witty, guitar playing, folk singing, level headed heir to the 12th Marquess of Lothian, can think this Swiss educated, multilingual, razor sharp barrister to be as obsessively anti-European as many of his colleagues. The alternative to his being seen as a "hostage" is to think of him - along with Michael Trend, the son of former cabinet secretary Baron Trend - as an establishment "balance wheel". As such he can help keep the party from tipping over into Europhobic lunacy, thus saving it for the future.

It is probably easier for him because, although born into a aristocratic Scots Catholic family, he has always been something of an outsider. Born in London he was initially educated in a French speaking Swiss school before attending Ampleforth and Edinburgh University.

An Edinburgh advocate since 1970, he has been an active company director, not least in his wealthy family's agricultural firms, one of which holds 1,500 acres. He is married to Lady Jane Fitzalan-Howard, daughter of the 16th RC Duke of Norfolk.

Michael Ancram was the first Scottish Catholic to take a seat in Scotland when he won Berwick and East Lothian in 1974, then Edinburgh South (1979-87). But the Scottish anti-Tory tide forced him to seek asylum in Devizes from 1992. His talents were soon recognised in his post of under secretary, then minister of state for Northern Ireland (1993-97) and he was recommended by Sir Patrick Mayhew as his successor, but that was blocked by Labour's 1997 landslide.

A close friend of Mr Hague, Mr Ancram backed him for the leadership from the outset. Mr Hague named him spokesman on constitutional affairs, in which role he battled forcefully against devolution, even for Scotland. When he lost the devolution argument, he became deputy chairman and then chairman of the Conservative party, succeeding Lord Parkinson. In this post, he has played the unseen role of a buffer for the relentless pressure from Europhobes on their more moderate leader. Because of the continuing shift to these Europhobes, this does not always work.

fields.headline: Yvette Cooper
fields.standfirst:
Pontefract and Castleford (1997- )

Ask Aristotle about Yvette Cooper
fields.trailText: Yvette Cooper is a 'golden girl', both as Labour's youngest minister and for her connections. Married to Gordon Brown's top adviser-confidante, Ed Balls, she had worked for Bill Clinton and John Smith and was seen as so talented that Sir Geoffrey Lofthouse was prised out of safe Pontefract and Castleford to give her an easy entry to the Commons.
fields.body:
Yvette Cooper is a 'golden girl', both as Labour's youngest minister and for her connections. Married to Gordon Brown's top adviser-confidante, Ed Balls, she had worked for Bill Clinton and John Smith and was seen as so talented that Sir Geoffrey Lofthouse was prised out of safe Pontefract and Castleford to give her an easy entry to the Commons.

In Labour terms, she has the advantage of a grandfather who was a miner and a father, Tony Cooper, who has been the general secretary of the engineers and managers association. Born in Inverness in 1969, she went from Eggars comprehensive and Alton sixth form college in Hampshire, to Balliol College, Oxford, where she tried cannabis and collected a first class degree in PPE. She then went on to Harvard University as a Kennedy scholar and the London School of Economics where she collared a masters in economics.

Elected in 1997 at the age of 28, she went on to the select committees on education and employment as well as intelligence and security (1997-1999). She turned down the offer to become a parliamentary private secretary and, in 1999, was named under secretary for public health at 30, the youngest in ministerial office.

She juggles her ministerial role and the family demands of a Treasury-based husband and a two-year-old daughter, Ellie, by spending midweek at her Kennington flat with weekends in her Yorkshire constituency - she lives up to her "highly-organised" reputation.

Her main problem has been to live up to her high promise as a junior minister, when the main decisions and publicity radiate from its top man, health secretary Alan Milburn. In her Commons sessions replies, her elfin little girl appearance and high pitched voice do not lend weight, and her earnest intensity is not often softened by humour. As a former journalist at the Independent, she does better in articles than in the Commons in urging better diets for the nation's children.

She can be over eager, and caused Sir John Krebs to tell her, "Get your tanks off my lawn" after she had twice revealed details from his food standards agency without his permission. She made her biggest impact in July 2000 by launching a report showing Labour had failed to ease persistent class inequalities.

She said: "Daughters of unskilled men born in 1970 were an astonishing nine times more likely to become a teenage mother than girls whose fathers were more highly qualified".

She also made headlines after disclosing that more HIV infections come from heterosexuals (45%) than homosexuals (41%).

Other 'Blair babes', envious of her early promotion, think she doesn't dress well enough for the job, tagging her 'Miss Selfridge' - but she and her husband are still rated to become the next Labour generation's golden couple.

fields.headline: Brown apologises to farmers
fields.trailText: The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, has apologised for a statement he made yesterday to the Commons that led hundreds of farmers to believe their cattle would be slaughtered.
fields.body:
The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, has apologised for a statement he made yesterday to the Commons that led hundreds of farmers to believe their cattle would be slaughtered.

Mr Brown said he accepted the statement was ambiguous and reassured farmers that the policy of three-kilometre wide slaughter zones around outbreak in Cumbria and Dumfries and Galloway would only apply automatically to pigs and sheep.

Speaking at the ministry of agriculture, fisheries and food in central London, he said: "I want to apologise on my own behalf and behalf of the ministry for any hurt this has caused farmers."

The number of infected farms and abattoirs today rose to 260, but some farmers warned of a "rural revolt" if the killings go ahead.

A farmers' lobby group announced it would mount a legal challenge to the government over its handling of the outbreak.

Farmers For Action said it was "all out war" after the government announced the mass slaughter.

A spokesman for the group described the cull as "nothing more than a sinister way of ethnically cleansing the British countryside".

He said it was "absolutely ludicrous" that just two days ago Britain was importing meat from countries affected by foot and mouth, such as Argentina and Zimbabwe.

"They do not want British agriculture and this is their way of doing it."

Guns were today confiscated at the home of a farmer from Penrith, Cumbria, who allegedly threatened Maff officials about to cull his herd.

A spokesman for Cumbria police confirmed the incident had happened but would not specify the type or number of weapons. No other legal action was being taken against the farmer.

Mr Brown urged everyone involved in the livestock industry to support the government in its bid to stamp out the virus.

"The war we should be fighting is against the virus. To be fighting each other is a ridiculous thing to do," he said.

"I appeal to everyone to work with the government and to work together to defeat this virus."

The National Farmer's Union president, Ben Gill, said that Britain's farming industry faces months of torture as the toll from the disease continues to rise.

He said the key objective for farmers was to wipe out the disease, but he warned that parts of the countryside would be "idle" for the next six months.

About 90 countries, including the United States and Australia, have now banned EU live animal imports, meat and dairy products, after the disease spread to mainland Europe earlier in the week.

Already 205,000 of Britain's pig, cattle and sheep population have been condemned, 75% of which have been slaughtered.

Speaking at the ministry of agriculture, fisheries and food in central London, he said: "I want to apologise on my own behalf and behalf of the ministry for any hurt this has caused farmers." The number of infected farms and abattoirs today rose to 260, but some farmers warned of a "rural revolt" if the killings go ahead. A farmers' lobby group announced it would mount a legal challenge to the government over its handling of the outbreak. Farmers For Action said it was "all out war" after the government announced the mass slaughter. A spokesman for the group described the cull as "nothing more than a sinister way of ethnically cleansing the British countryside". He said it was "absolutely ludicrous" that just two days ago Britain was importing meat from countries affected by foot and mouth, such as Argentina and Zimbabwe. "They do not want British agriculture and this is their way of doing it." Guns were today confiscated at the home of a farmer from Penrith, Cumbria, who allegedly threatened Maff officials about to cull his herd. A spokesman for Cumbria police confirmed the incident had happened but would not specify the type or number of weapons. No other legal action was being taken against the farmer. Mr Brown urged everyone involved in the livestock industry to support the government in its bid to stamp out the virus. "The war we should be fighting is against the virus. To be fighting each other is a ridiculous thing to do," he said. "I appeal to everyone to work with the government and to work together to defeat this virus." The National Farmer's Union president, Ben Gill, said that Britain's farming industry faces months of torture as the toll from the disease continues to rise. He said the key objective for farmers was to wipe out the disease, but he warned that parts of the countryside would be "idle" for the next six months. About 90 countries, including the United States and Australia, have now banned EU live animal imports, meat and dairy products, after the disease spread to mainland Europe earlier in the week. Already 205,000 of Britain's pig, cattle and sheep population have been condemned, 75% of which have been slaughtered. fields.headline: Coke kicks off orange juice wars
fields.trailText:
3.45pm: Coca-Cola is to go to war with arch-rival PepsiCo, but this time over orange juice, reports Julia Day
Mar 1: Coke and Disney plan drinks range
Feb 21: Coke and P&G form joint marketing company
fields.body:
Coca-Cola is to go to war with arch-rival PepsiCo, but this time over orange juice.

Coke is launching a not-from-concentrate orange juice drink called Simply Orange to take on PepsiCo's leading Tropicana Pure Premium brand.

The brand will be positioned as an affordable alternative to fresh-squeezed orange and will be packaged in clear plastic bottles.

A massive marketing push will launch Simply Orange in the US this May with TV, print, internet and PR campaigns supported by money-off vouchers.

The drinks giant has hired US advertising agency Donor rather than Minute Maid's agency of record Leo Burnett to handle the account.

The intention is for Donor to portray the Simply Orange Juice Co, a new division being set up produce the brand, as a small, entrepreneurial company.

The media account will be handled by Bcom3's Starcom, with Sharpe Partners, New York handling internet promotions and Vorhaus & Co, New York doing PR.

fields.headline: BT's Comic Relief riches
fields.trailText: BT is raking in massive revenues from Comic Relief phone-ins.
fields.body:
BT is raking in massive revenues from Comic Relief phone-ins.

Telephone votes for Celebrity Big Brother will generate around £450,000 for the charity but also about £280,000, excluding VAT, for BT.

Each eviction phone vote costs 25p, of which 15.5p goes to Comic Relief. The remaining 9.5p is split between BT and the taxman, who takes a slice through VAT.

Celebrity Big Brother has been a phenomenal TV ratings success with up to 10m viewers a night hooked on the strife at the east London house.

And viewers have been phoning in eviction votes in their droves.

An astonishing 742,885 calls were made the night Chris Eubank was evicted. This raised £115,147 for Comic Relief and £70,574 for BT.

The eviction of Vanessa Feltz raised £108,857 for the charity and £66,719 for BT and Anthea Turner's raised £112,651 for the charity and £69,044 for BT, all excluding VAT.

It is estimated that at least as many viewers will be phoning in today for the final vote which will decide who wins out of Jack Dee, Boyzone's Keith Duffy or Brookside's Claire Sweeney.

This will generate at least £100,000 but if the nation's interest in the show is reflected in the phone vote the final figure could be closer to £150,000 or even £200,000.

Celebrity Big Brother is just one of many premium rate phone-ins for Comic Relief.

Radio 4's The Funniest Thing I Ever Heard phone vote costs callers £1, of which 66p goes to Comic Relief and BT keeps between 15p and 23p to cover network running costs.

BT is prevented from offering the charity a discount on premium rate numbers by the telecoms regulator Oftel.

Because of BT's monopoly it must treat all users the same and exceptions cannot be made for good causes, according to an Oftel spokeswoman.

A BT spokeswoman said: "We are not allowed to give a free service or a discount. But we do give a very considerable amount in different ways."

This year the company has made a £65,000 donation to Comic Relief, purchased £25,000-worth of vehicle red noses and has donated volunteers to set up and run telephone lines.

A spokeswoman for Comic Relief said the charity was aware of the cost involved in running the premium rate lines.

"Comic Relief recognises the disruption such a major appeal has to BT's network and that significant resource and expense is incurred by BT in managing the network," she said.

"BT has been supporting Comic Relief since the very first Red Nose Day; without their support, advice and assistance, Red Nose Day simply could not happen," she said.

webTitle: Three killed as Saudi forces storm hijacked Russian jet

fields.headline: Three killed as Saudi forces storm hijacked Russian jet
fields.standfirst: Special report: Chechnya
fields.trailText: Saudi security forces stormed a hijacked Russian plane today, ending a hostage drama that left three people dead.
fields.body:
Saudi security forces stormed a hijacked Russian plane today, ending a hostage drama that left three people dead.

Chechen men armed with knives had commandeered the Moscow-bound plane after takeoff from Istanbul. Two men and a woman were killed and several others were injured, paramedics at Medina airport said.

Two men and a woman were killed in the operation, which lasted a few minutes. The standoff between Saudi authorities and hijackers, who were armed with knives, had lasted several hours.

Paramedics said a woman was stabbed to death and two men were gunned down. "As soon as the woman opened the door, she was both stabbed and shot to death," a paramedic, who wished to remain anonymous, said.

There were conflicting reports over the identity of those killed. The number of hijackers was not immediately clear either. Earlier reports put the number between two and four men.

In Moscow, aides to Kremlin envoy Sergei Yastrzhembsky said one Turkish passenger, one hijacker - "apparently the younger one" - and one stewardess were killed.

One man was handcuffed and led away by Saudi security forces, said the paramedics.

A statement from the Saudi interior ministry statement said that "an anti-terrorism force from the special forces was able to storm the Russian plane ... and was able to free all the passengers in a swift operation and controlled the hijackers".

A surgeon who boarded the plane after the rescue operation said seven people were injured, and most of them were being treated for minor cuts and bruises.

Earlier, as many as 46 of the 174 people aboard the plane were freed or escaped from the plane.

The hostage drama began yesterday afternoon shortly after the plane took off from Istanbul.

Minutes before the plane was stormed, more than 30 members of the Saudi army's special forces unit in full battle gear, armed with semiautomatic rifles and wearing helmets and bullet proof vests, were loaded into an army bus.

About six ambulances and fire engines surrounded the plane, which was parked in an isolated area on the tarmac while Medina airport remained open to commercial flights. Two Saudi air force cargo planes were parked a few hundred meters away.

Other members of the special forces unit were huddled in tents in the services area of the airport, out of sight of the plane. Four army vehicles and four armored personnel carriers were parked behind the tents.

A passenger with bloody trousers was seen being carried away from the plane. Paramedics were on hand to offer first aid and medical assistance to other passengers.

Topa Bilgetin Toker, general director of Turkish civilian aviation, said Saudi forces had stormed the plane after the pilots managed to escape from the aircraft.

He said the decision came after the hijackers failed to establish further contact with the Saudis.

Russia's Interfax news agency quoted Mr Yastrzhembsky as saying the storming had received the approval of Russian authorities.

Aftayeva Fariza, a representative of the breakaway Chechen republic, who is based in Amman, Jordan, identified the hijackers as Aslambek Artsayev, the former Chechen interior minister, and his brother, Sufian. She said the information comes from a third brother, Adam, who was not among the hijackers.

She said the reason for the hijacking was not terrorism or money, but to attract world attention to the situation in Chechnya.

"Adam Arsayev, the brother of Aslambek, told me over the phone that he urges the Saudi authorities not to extradite the hijackers to Moscow," Ms Aftayeva said.

She also said the hijacker's brother felt sorry that people had lost their lives in the operation. That was "not the aim of the hijackers".

An official at Medina airport, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the hijackers had earlier asked authorities to refuel the plane and prepare it for a long flight, but later changed their minds. He did not say where the hijackers had wanted to go.

Russia's president, Vladimir Putin, returned from his ski vacation in Siberia today because of the hijacking. Mr Putin had planned to stay through the weekend in the republic of Khakasia, but left for Moscow as Saudi Arabian officials prepared to storm the plane in Medina.

fields.headline: 'Naive' Anthea hits back over Snowflake wedding pics
fields.trailText: 2pm: Anthea Turner has revealed how she naively walked into the PR disaster surrounding her 'chocolate bar' wedding photos. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Anthea Turner has told how OK! magazine cruelly stitched her up after signing away photographic rights to her wedding.

Just hours before she was evicted from the Big Brother house, she revealed how somebody from the magazine had innocently asked her to try a Cadbury's Snowflake.

The picture turned into a PR disaster for the former Breakfast TV presenter.

Ms Turner was accused of being so money-grabbing as to make even her own wedding into a cash-making venture after cheesy shots of her munching the Cadbury's chocolate bar were splashed over the front page of the tabloids.

Her career has since taken a downward turn.

But on last night's Comic Relief Celebrity Big Brother, Turner was given the chance to vindicate herself.

Asked about the famous incident by fellow contestant Jack Dee, Ms Turner protested her innocence, claiming she had known nothing about planned promotion when she allowed herself to be photographed by OK! magazine, which had exclusive rights to the wedding, eating the Snowflake bar.

"Someone from OK! asked if they could bring the chocolate along and we had a sweet stall at the wedding with jelly babies and things so we said yes, put them on there," said Ms Turner.

"Then at 1.30am. Someone asked us to taste one."

Ms Turner said she had no idea that OK! would go on to release the photo as their publicity shot for OK!'s wedding special on the couple.

"We didn't have copy approval of the picture OK! released to the press. Grant and I just assumed they would pick a nice photo," she said, adding that she had been naive.

The Sun newspaper ran a highly critical piece about Ms Turner on its front page the day after the photo was released.

Under the headline "Sickener. Anthea's wedding photo is so, so sad", the paper said: "This is the most sickening wedding photo ever - showing Anthea Turner and Grant Bovey plugging a new chocolate bar.

The picture is the only one released to newspapers by the greedy newlyweds."

But Ms Turner last night got her own back on the promoters of the chocolate bar, who she claims duped her into the publicity shot.

Asked by Mr Dee whether she liked the Snowflake she turned up her nose and said it was "a bit sickly".

Keith Duffy then asked whether she had at least got "a few bob" out of it.

When she replied that she had not, Mr Duffy joked: "Jaysus, isn't that terrible when that happens and you don't even get a few bob for it?".

Ms Turner also talked about how she and husband Grant Bovey had "wrestled" with the fact they both had committed adultery with their respective spouses.

She married Mr Bovey after she divorced her husband Peter Powell and he divorced his wife Della.

Telephone votes for Celebrity Big Brother will generate around £450,000 for the charity but also about £280,000, excluding VAT, for BT.

Celebrity Big Brother has been a phenomenal TV ratings success with up to 10m viewers a night hooked on the strife at the east London house.

And viewers have been phoning in eviction votes in their droves.

The eviction of Vanessa Feltz raised £108,857 for the charity and £66,719 for BT and Anthea Turner's raised £112,651 for the charity and £69,044 for BT, all excluding VAT.

This will generate at least £100,000 but if the nation's interest in the show is reflected in the phone vote the final figure could be closer to £150,000 or even £200,000.

fields.headline: Emap suffers valuation slump
fields.trailText: 3.15pm: Analysts have has lowered Emap's core valuation to less than its share price, reports Wale Azeez.
fields.body:
The uncertainty surrounding Emap's troubled US operations has prompted broker Commerzbank to lower the publisher's core valuation to significantly lower than its share price.

The bank has cut Emap's valuation to within 9% of its share price to 724p.

This is 75p below this morning's share price of 799p.

The bank has urged the publishing and radio group to carry out "corporate liposuction".

Commerzbank is concerned about Emap's retention of the loss-making Petersen division, which it acquired in 1999 for £900m.

Recent industry speculation has estimated Petersen's disposal value at £450m.

"Since its acquisition, profit expectations have virtually halved," Commerzbank analysts noted in a report on Emap.

"Not only has Petersen been a significant drag on the company's earnings - missing all nine of the market's forecasts - but it has also been a major drain on the management's time.

"We are particularly concerned about the fundamental lack of top-line growth in the core magazine businesses.

"Margins have been squeezed and the launch culture has been eroded," the analysts added.

Commerzbank has also questioned Emap's short-term prospects.

It is seeking clarification as to "the extent to which the current slowdown in growth is a cyclical [advertising] issue and therefore temporary, or whether the group's current woes are predominantly a structural problem".

fields.bodyText: The uncertainty surrounding Emap's troubled US operations has prompted broker Commerzbank to lower the publisher's core valuation to significantly lower than its share price. The bank has cut Emap's valuation to within 9% of its share price to 724p. This is 75p below this morning's share price of 799p. The bank has urged the publishing and radio group to carry out "corporate liposuction". Commerzbank is concerned about Emap's retention of the loss-making Petersen division, which it acquired in 1999 for £900m. Recent industry speculation has estimated Petersen's disposal value at £450m. "Since its acquisition, profit expectations have virtually halved," Commerzbank analysts noted in a report on Emap. "Not only has Petersen been a significant drag on the company's earnings - missing all nine of the market's forecasts - but it has also been a major drain on the management's time. "We are particularly concerned about the fundamental lack of top-line growth in the core magazine businesses. "Margins have been squeezed and the launch culture has been eroded," the analysts added. webTitle: The interview which cost Graham his job

fields.headline: The interview which cost Graham his job
fields.trailText: "I had a long meeting with the vice-chairman this week and gave him my recommendations, mainly on two topics.
fields.body:
"I had a long meeting with the vice-chairman this week and gave him my recommendations, mainly on two topics.

"The first is new contracts for Sol, Darren and Les, and I left him in no doubt that I feel we should do our utmost to keep the three of them.

"Secondly, we need to strengthen the squad, so we don't get into another situation like this year where we have had to sling in the youngsters. I want to put them in when they are ready, rather than being forced into it.

"He has taken on board my recommendations and I am sure that hopefully he will act on them.

"I hope to get players in to add to the squad, and hopefully I can do it before next Thursday's transfer deadline. But I have been told there is a limited budget.

"I cannot reveal how much is available, but I don't think there will be big outlays. There is a budget and it is a limited budget, and I have been led to believe that is the case for next season, so it will be the same in the summer.

"Only time will tell how things will work out in the future. Actions are a lot more difficult than words and once we see a bit of action, that will give me a lot of encouragement and I hope it will encourage the whole situation about the club and the fans.

"Everybody wants the same at Tottenham, which is success, and only time will answer whether or not there will be some action. All I can do is recommend players, and I'll soon find out if I am going to get those players. I won't know until my recommendations are maybe taken on board.

"The new owners want success from me, and they are probably hoping that with my CV I can do it again. But my own contract situation never arose, and it is not up until the end of next season."

fields.headline: 12m witness Turner's humiliation
fields.trailText:
2.30pm TV overnights: A record audience watched Anthea Turner's eviction on last night's Celebrity Big Brother, writes Jessica Hodgson.
9.30am: Dee odds-on favourite
The story in pictures
Special report: Big Brother
Who should be next? Talk about it

fields.body:
A record 12m people tuned in to watch the eviction of Anthea Turner on last night's triple-headed Celebrity Big Brother.

As the hype surrounding the show escalated, Channel 4 broadcast a whole hour of Big Brother in two half-hour segments last night.

This was followed by a late-night broadcast on BBC1.

The first episode, in which Anthea left the Big Brother house to be reunited with her husband Grant Bovey, hooked in 5.2m viewers to give Channel 4 21 % share of the audience, according to unofficial overnight figures.

A second edition of the programme on Channel 4, at 10.30pm was watched by 4.8m viewers - a 31% audience share.

The BBC programme pulled in 2m viewers, 28% of audience share.

However, Big Brother's first showing on Channel 4 at 9pm had fewer viewers than the previous night's instalment, which took 6.9m and 27% of the audience.

But last night's early edition was not helped by aggressive scheduling from the BBC and ITV.

Peak Practice gained 7.2m viewers and a 30% audience share on ITV.

Meanwhile, the tail-end of Match of the Day Live's coverage of Liverpool v Porto in the UEFA cup on BBC1 pulled in 7.3m viewers and 30% of the audience.

Elsewhere, 800,000 viewers tuned in to see the final of Touching the Truck on Channel 5.

The endurance show gained a 3% audience share - a drop of 200,000 from the programme's first-night high of 1m viewers.

fields.headline: George Graham factfile
fields.trailText: 1944: Born Bargeddie, Scotland, November 30.
fields.body:
1944: Born Bargeddie, Scotland, November 30.

1962: Signs for Aston Villa in June after offers from other top clubs, including Newcastle.

1963: Collects League Cup runners-up medal as Villa lose to city rivals Birmingham.

1964: Transferred to Chelsea for £6,000.

1965: Collects League Cup winners' medal after victory over Leicester.

1966: Joins Arsenal for £50,000, collecting League Cup runners-up medals in 1968 (beaten by Leeds) and 1969 (Swindon).

1970: Helps Arsenal win Inter-Cities Fairs Cup, beating Belgium's Anderlecht in the final.

1971: Is a key member of Arsenal's League and FA Cup double-winning side. Liverpool are beaten in Cup final at Wembley while Arsenal clinch the title with victory at rivals Tottenham.

1972: Leaves Highbury to join Manchester United after collecting FA Cup runners-up medal (Arsenal are beaten by Leeds) and the first of 12 Scotland international caps.

1974: Transferred to Portsmouth.

1976: Moves to Crystal Palace, helping them earn promotion to division two.

1977: Retires from playing and works part-time as a barman before taking coaching job at Queens Park Rangers. Moves to Crystal Palace as coach.

1982: Joins Millwall as manager, steering them clear of relegation from Division Three.

1985: Guides Millwall to promotion from Third Division.

1986: Becomes Arsenal manager in May.

1987: Wins Littlewoods (League) Cup in his first season as Liverpool are beaten at Wembley.

1988: Takes Arsenal to another Littlewoods Cup final but suffers surprise Wembley defeat by Luton.

1989: Guides Arsenal to their first League title for 18 years thanks to dramatic injury-time decider by Michael Thomas in the final match of the season at Liverpool.

1991: Arsenal, who lose only one League match all season, are champions again, even though they are deducted two points after an on-pitch brawl at Manchester United while captain Tony Adams is jailed for 56 days after a drink-driving conviction.

1992: Graham's men suffer FA Cup humiliation at Wrexham, the League's bottom club, after a European Cup exit against Benfica three months earlier.

1993: Graham presides over historic FA Cup and Coca-Cola (League) Cup double-triumph, as Sheffield Wednesday are beaten in both finals.

1994: Crowns a brilliant European Cup Winners' Cup campaign with 1-0 tactical triumph over crack Italians Parma in Copenhagen.

But by November Arsenal are languishing in mid-table when Paul Merson's drink and drugs confessions rock the club. In December Graham is accused of taking a £285,000 'bung' in the John Jensen transfer.

He is reported to have tendered his resignation, but Arsenal issue a statement declaring: "He is and remains the manager of the club for the foreseeable future."

After being interviewed by a special Premier League commission over the charges, Graham emerges to say: "I am comfortable with my situation, and so are the club."

1995: Arsenal fail to publicly back Graham after former PFA chairman Garth Crooks claims on Greater London Radio that the match against Leicester on February 11 would be his last as manager.

Arsenal terminate his contract on February 21 after Premier League inquiry concluded he did not act in the best interests of the club. Ordered to face FA inquiry.

Found guilty of misconduct by FA disciplinary commission and faces the prospect of a heavy fine and/or a ban from the game.

1996: Graham's world-wide soccer ban ends on June 30, but he admits: "There is nothing immediately on the horizon. I'm itching to get back to work with an ambitious club, but it looks like I'll have to be patient. Sadly, in this business, you only get a job when somebody else loses theirs."

Graham turns down offer to become new manager of Manchester City after earlier expressing an interest in the job. Becomes new manager of Leeds on September 10, 24 hours after Howard Wilkinson is sacked at Elland Road.

1997: Ensures Leeds retain their Premiership status as the club finish 11th.

With the club up to fourth by early December, Graham signs a new long-term contract, believed to be worth £1million-a-year.

1998: Takes Leeds into the Uefa Cup after the club finish fifth in the Premier League.

Leaves Elland Road to become new manager of Tottenham Hotspur two days after leading Leeds into the second round of the Uefa Cup.

1999: Guides Tottenham into the final of the League Cup, their first Wembley appearance for 12 years. Spurs beat Leicester 1-0 to win the trophy.

2000: Spurs' lack of league success continues as they remain stuck in the Premiership mid-table.

2001: Following the ENIC takeover of the club from chairman Alan Sugar, Spurs win through to a glamour FA Cup semi-final against London rivals and Graham's former club Arsenal.

March 16: Parts company with Tottenham.

fields.headline: The original persuader
fields.standfirst: Harvey Smith examines the life and influence of the 'father of public relations', Edward Bernays, who was born on November 22 1891 and died on March 8 1995
fields.trailText: 24 Mar 1995: Edward Bernays , public relations expert, born November 22, 1891, died March 8, 1995. Obituary by Harvey Smith.
fields.body:
When Edward Bernays, who has died aged 103, ran the first course in public relations at New York University in 1923, he spoke on "the technique and method of reaching the public, with particular emphasis on the newspaper, the periodic press, the pulpit, the motion picture, and other avenues of approach to the public".

The same year, Bernays wrote the first book on public relations, Crystallising Public Opinion. In counselling clients on their public relations he left behind the one-way ideas of propaganda or publicity. He took into account "all the relations you had with all of your publics". He moved rapidly from mass communication to targeting specific audiences: he added the "s" to public.

By 1965, he was writing in his autobiography, Biography Of An Idea: "From a one-way street of information and persuasion from client to public, it became a two-way street, with the element of adjustment added... Counsel on public relations was based on dealing with interaction between client and public." He wrote 14 books in all, one called The Engineering Of Consent raising the problem of who adapts - client or public.

Bernays was born in Vienna but was taken to New York as a small child. He married Doris Fleischman, whom he met when he was 16, in 1922, having formed his business with her three years earlier. A feminist, she kept her maiden name and was the first American woman to use it on her passport. They were in business together until she died in 1980.

Bernays linked public relations studies closely to social science, and to the importance of influencing "group leaders" or "opinion formers". Thus he persuaded a nomadic labour force of Indians to eat a new type of corn by having the shaman of the tribe bless it - solving a company's labour problem. And he persuaded Americans to eat more (of his client's) bacon by publishing a survey of 5,000 doctors who confirmed the need for a more substantial breakfast than coffee and rolls.

The nephew of Sigmund Freud, he was aware of psychology. "Never attack the ego of your superior by stating that he is wrong and you are right... it is much easier to gain acceptance by quoting authority, giving reasons for your point of view or referring to tradition, than telling someone that he is wrong.'

His creative imagination in countering poor images became legend at the highest levels. "(President) Coolidge looks as though he had been weaned on a pickle," said Alice Roosevelt Longworth. So Bernays got Al Jolsen, the "sexy, spirited" Dolly sisters, and assorted actors to have breakfast with him. Headlines included: "President nearly laughs."

He advised Eisenhower, Thomas Edison, Henry Ford, Enrico Caruso ("He called me Bernaysie"), Jan Masaryk, Nijinsky, Samuel Goldwyn and Eleanor Roosevelt. He is said to have turned down Hitler and Franco, and to have had some 350 clients, from government departments to labour unions, educational institutions to large corporations. In the 1980s he advised the US Departments of State, Health and Commerce.

The British Institute of Public Relations honoured him with their President's Medal in 1981 and with an honorary fellowship on his 100th birthday in 1991 (an event at which he gave a stand-up 40-minute speech without notes). Life magazine named him one of the 100 most important Americans of the 20th century.

Death he felt about "as philosophically as I feel about winter and summer" and he enjoyed many seasons. He died knowing that the future of PR would be rapidly bound up in a convergence of electronic communication undreamt of when he, its acknowledged father, first articulated the new profession. What multimedia connections he might have made.

This obituary was first published in the Guardian, 24 March 1995.
