webTitle: New documents show how Vaz obstructed inquiry

fields.headline: New documents show how Vaz obstructed inquiry
fields.standfirst: Full text of the report
fields.trailText: Europe minister Keith Vaz was clinging on to his political career by his fingertips today after the publication of document detailing how he obstructed a Commons inquiry into his constituency.
fields.body:
Europe minister Keith Vaz was clinging on to his political career by his fingertips today after the publication of document detailing how he obstructed a Commons inquiry into his constituency.

Earlier this week, the Commons standards commissioner, Elizabeth Filkin, was forced to clear the Leicester East MP over allegations into election donations due to a lack of evidence.

Today she published the appendix to her report laying out correspondence between her committee and the minister.

The 291-page report publishes 20 letters between Mr Vaz and the inquiry, plus a transcript of oral evidence given to the investigation.

The document reveals that in evidence given to the committee behind closed doors, Mr Vaz suggested that Ms Filkin may have had a conflict of interest in the investigation because of her personal acquaintance with the former Leicester city council leader, Sir Peter Soulsby.

Mr Vaz said: "It is a matter of fact that he is the only witness that she knows personally. One should just bear this fact in mind on the issue of conflict of interest."

Mr Vaz also told the committee he believed that the investigations into him were at least in part motivated by his race.

"I think that people do not understand the Asian community and the way in which they operate. This is a new community that wants the status, it wants the recognition, it wants to feel part of the mainstream. I think we are under scrutiny because I am there," he added.

Mr Vaz's solicitor claimed Ms Filkin's persistent questioning was an "interrogation" which conflicted with "natural justice and with article 6 of the European human rights convention."

He said Mr Vaz was aware that declining to answer certain points could leave him open to accusations of failing to co-operate but added that his client had helped the inquiry in a manner which was "far beyond the call of duty". He also said in doing this Mr Vaz had undergone great stress and legal expenses.

Officially, Mr Vaz still has the backing of the prime minister. Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's official spokesman, said last night: "He has the complete support of the prime minister - end of story."

However, most Westminster opinion now sees it as only a question of time before Mr Vaz is shunted towards the backbenches.

The Tories - scenting blood - have renewed their calls for the minister to resign.

Today the Conservative party chairman, Michael Ancram, said: "He is saying he has been cleared because he hasn't been found guilty.

"But all the evidence we have heard so far, particularly from Ms Filkin, suggests that the reason he hasn't been found guilty is because he wasn't prepared to cooperate with the committee and give sufficient information."

At this week's prime minister's questions, William Hague taunted Tony Blair: "You can keep your reputation, or you can keep your minister - but you cannot do both."

The original report from the standards and privileges committee cleared the MP of all but one of the allegations made against him - but criticised his reluctance to cooperate with Ms Filkin's investigation.

Her own inquiry had concluded that she could not fully investigate eight of the charges because of problems getting evidence from Mr Vaz and other witnesses.

One complaint - that he should have declared a financial link to a constituent he nominated for an honour - was upheld.

Mr Ancram went on to say that it was not just Mr Vaz's judgment at stake but the prime minister's. "We have seen him turning his back on accusations against his foreign secretary for misleading parliament," he said.

"We now see him supporting Mr Vaz. The more this goes on, the more I feel there is a stench at the heart of government and it starts at Downing Street."

Mr Vaz is now back in his Leicester constituency - where a party meeting tonight is expected to see calls for the resignation of the constituency chairman, Colin Hall.

Mr Hall was criticised by the standard and priviliges committee for trying to intimidate a witness.

Last night Mr Vaz threatened to storm out of a BBC radio interview when asked about the allegations. He blasted: "I will not have this. I thought I was dealing with professionals."

The news that Labour MP Claire Ward criticised his behaviour in a 1994 inquiry as "disgraceful and contemptuous" will not endear Mr Vaz to the party leadership, despite Labour's 26-point lead in the latest poll.

The Tories - scenting blood - have renewed their calls for the minister to resign. Today the Conservative party chairman, Michael Ancram, said: "He is saying he has been cleared because he hasn't been found guilty. "But all the evidence we have heard so far, particularly from Ms Filkin, suggests that the reason he hasn't been found guilty is because he wasn't prepared to cooperate with the committee and give sufficient information." At this week's prime minister's questions, William Hague taunted Tony Blair: "You can keep your reputation, or you can keep your minister - but you cannot do both." The original report from the standards and privileges committee cleared the MP of all but one of the allegations made against him - but criticised his reluctance to cooperate with Ms Filkin's investigation. Her own inquiry had concluded that she could not fully investigate eight of the charges because of problems getting evidence from Mr Vaz and other witnesses. One complaint - that he should have declared a financial link to a constituent he nominated for an honour - was upheld. Mr Ancram went on to say that it was not just Mr Vaz's judgment at stake but the prime minister's. "We have seen him turning his back on accusations against his foreign secretary for misleading parliament," he said. "We now see him supporting Mr Vaz. The more this goes on, the more I feel there is a stench at the heart of government and it starts at Downing Street." Mr Vaz is now back in his Leicester constituency - where a party meeting tonight is expected to see calls for the resignation of the constituency chairman, Colin Hall. Mr Hall was criticised by the standard and priviliges committee for trying to intimidate a witness. Last night Mr Vaz threatened to storm out of a BBC radio interview when asked about the allegations. He blasted: "I will not have this. I thought I was dealing with professionals." The news that Labour MP Claire Ward criticised his behaviour in a 1994 inquiry as "disgraceful and contemptuous" will not endear Mr Vaz to the party leadership, despite Labour's 26-point lead in the latest poll. webTitle: Business: Trinity Mirror net spending cuts

fields.headline: Trinity Mirror cuts back net spend
fields.standfirst:
60 job loses at Trinity Mirror due to internet cut backs

MediaGuardian.co.uk
More net news</A
fields.trailText: Trinity Mirror is closing several of its websites with the loss of 60 jobs, reports David Teather.
fields.body:
Trinity Mirror yesterday became the latest traditional media firm to scale back its investment in the internet when it announced the closure of several websites and the loss of 60 jobs.

The company, owner of the Mirror newspapers and the largest publisher of regional titles in Britain, has reduced its online spend from the £150m flagged 12 months ago to £90m in the next three years.

It is closing the icShowbiz and icSport websites and has abandoned the launch of lifestyle site icChoice. Trinity Mirror confirmed that talks have opened for the sale of its internet service provider, ic24, which has 240,000 active users.

The shake-up is part of a wider review of the group formed from the merger of Trinity and Mirror Group more than 18 months ago. The review began in November and will see the sale of the magazines and exhibitions division which includes specialist medical and housebuilding titles. PA Sporting Life which comprises Sportinglife.com and Totalbet will also be sold.

Analysts estimate the magazines will fetch around £50m, Sportinglife another £25m and ic24 about £12m.

Philip Graf, the chief executive, said Trinity Mirror had learned a lot from its experiences with the internet and underlined the group's commitment to a network of regional websites using the "ic" brand.

He said: "Some of the early predictions of the shift of revenues from newspapers to the internet were clearly overdone. We had thought it would be enough to be a top five player but with the advertising market online not as big as some had anticipated you really need to be top three."

Mr Graf added: "We are still very confident of the opportunity provided by the internet where we have a distinctive capability, like the regional network."

The online division, which employs around 400 people, is forecast to record revenues of around £25m this year and will have 12 regional sites up by the end of the month.

Despite the retrenchment, Trinity Mirror pleased investors with a strong set of full year results for 2000. Pretax profits before internet losses of £42m were 12.2% higher at £196m. Revenues were 5.3% better and just exceeded £1bn.

The company also provided positive news of the present trading environment. Mr Graf said advertising revenues across the national titles were 9% higher in the first two months of the year, while the regional titles were 7% higher.

The shares climbed 27.5p to 486p.

webTitle: Brussels struggles with language of integration

fields.headline: Brussels struggles with language of integration
fields.standfirst: As the EU prepares to incorporate a dozen new languages, vital translators and interpreters are thin on the ground, reports Ian Black
fields.trailText: As the EU prepares to incorporate a dozen new languages, vital translators and interpreters are thin on the ground, reports Ian Black from Brussels.
fields.body:
It was just another routine European Union meeting: five men in suits - the interior ministers of Britain, France, Spain, Germany and Italy - sitting on a podium, waiting to deliver their message, about Basque terrorism, to the journalists in the auditorium.

But there was a sudden hitch: the glass interpretation booths were inexplicably empty - apparently because of scheduling problems the council of ministers staff had overlooked.

The result: embarrassing, throat-clearing delay and patchy, time-lagged - and distinctly amateur - interpretation by harassed diplomats, not the professional, multilingual voiceover that is the norm.

Europe cannot function without its interpreters and translators, so, in the Babel that is Brussels, feverish attempts are now under way to prepare for the biggest enlargement the EU has ever seen - and the dozen new languages that will come with it.

With 15 members now and 12 official languages already in use (though Irish is used only for written texts), plans to take in up to 12 new candidate countries in the coming years are imposing a huge strain.

From Latvian to Bulgarian and Lithuanian to Czech, the search is on for the linguists who can do this vital job. The only bright spot is that Malta, the smallest candidate, has agreed to forgo the use of its own tongue - an obscure mixture of Arabic and Italian - just as Luxembourg did when it joined back in 1957.

None of this is optional: the European community's first ever regulation stipulated that all official documents have to be available in all languages: current output is a staggering one million pages a year or the equivalent of a 100 metre high tower. Full interpretation has to be provided.

It is highly sensitive stuff, with issues of cultural diversity, national pride and democratic legitimacy always coming up against hardheaded officials worrying about budgets, efficiency and logistics.

And they are on a awesome scale: every candidate country has to have 80,000 pages of the EU's official journal rigorously translated - a basic requirement of bringing national legislation into line with the body of community law, and sometimes compared to climbing Mount Everest without oxygen.

Yet there is no choice. Globalisation and the practice of multinational companies have created expectations that cannot be ignored: if Microsoft can publish its manuals even in minority languages like Catalan, Europe's institutions cannot afford to lag behind.

And there is a powerful democratic incentive too for an EU which worries - quite rightly - about the distance between Brussels and ordinary Europeans.

"A Spanish farmer doesn't care about the Greek or Danish version of some commission publication," says one veteran of its translation service. "For him the EU isn't multilingual at all. It just speaks to him in his language."

Interpretation is technically more complicated. With 11,000 meetings a year and 50 to 60 every day, there are already 110 possible combinations when working with the current 11 languages.

With 25 languages the figure will rise to 600 and the chances of finding someone who can turn Greek or Portuguese into Slovak or Hungarian are virtually nil - even though there are some weird and wonderful combinations of expertise.

Much routine business is done in English and French (spoken by 31% and 10% respectively of the EU's 375m people) and thus the two official working languages. But ministers meeting in the council have to have their own interpreters - thus that awkward silence over the Basque problem.

The solution is the so-called "relay" system, in which a more obscure language - say Slovene or Romanian - will be rendered into French or English, and thence into Danish, German and Spanish and so on.

It's not perfect: "Every filter that you go through, you lose something, however small, from the original," says one expert. And there is always the possibility of what one minister called "Kafkaesque misunderstandings". But overall it is a tried and tested method.

Relay interpretation creates practical problems too, not least of finding the physical space for all those booths. But modern electronics allows for creative if expensive solutions: for example with delegates in Tahiti and interpreters in Brussels working via a satellite link.

The commission already has 1,900 in-house translators and interpreters - 12.5% of total staff - and uses outside freelancers at an annual cost of £180m. When all other EU institutions are included, it rises to £415m.

Even so, it still only costs 2 euros (£1.25) per citizen per year or 0.8% of the total EU budget. "It enables all European citizens and their governments to play a part in the building of Europe, in their own mother tongue," the commission says.

Currently, some 120 commission translators in Brussels and Luxembourg are doing in-house courses in Hungarian, Polish, Estonian, Slovene and Czech - roughly reflecting the order in which the candidate countries are likely to join from about 2005.

Courses in Romanian, Latvian, Lithuanian, Bulgarian and Slovak will be started later this year.

The European parliament, with 626 MEPs (and 840 translators and interpreters), is a special case, because democratic fairness mean that elected representatives cannot be expected to have the linguistic abilities of diplomats and civil servants.

So, despite the costs, arrangements will have to be made for a post-enlargement situation where the increase in language combinations becomes a problem more complex than a Rubik cube.

Interpretation and translation issues include a well stocked bank of jokes and anecdotes, throwing the drier aspects of EU life into uncharacteristically humorous relief. There's the one about how "shooting the rapids" became a disconcerting "shooting the rabbits". Or how "frozen semen" in an agricultural working group became, in French, "matelot congelé" (frozen seaman).

Much, inevitably, is lost in translation. Wit, especially irony, historical or literary allusions, and vivid metaphors, do not often work. Memorable European speeches are thus few and far between.

Yet even the driest of eurocrats relishes the one about the interpreter, who struggled with the leaden speech of a German minister - who had compared the pace of a negotiating session to a hedgehog - and translated it as: "This meeting is slow, ponderous and full of pricks."

fields.headline: Liverpool land Barca test
fields.trailText: Barcelona and Liverpool will meet in the semi-finals of the Uefa Cup.
fields.body:
Barcelona and Liverpool will meet in the semi-finals of the Uefa Cup.

Spain's Alaves, playing in Europe for the first time, were drawn against Germany's Kaiserslautern in the other semi.

Despite both clubs' illustrious European histories, Liverpool and Barcelona have met only once before, when the English side won the two-legged semi-final of the Uefa Cup in 1976 en route to winning the competition.

Liverpool are on course for a cup treble having already won the Worthington Cup and reached the semi-finals of the FA Cup, where they play Wycombe. Barcelona, who will host the first leg on April 5, qualified for the Uefa Cup after being knocked out of the early stages of the Champions League.

Barcelona's last European success was the 1997 Cup Winners' Cup but they have not won the Uefa Cup since it was in its Fairs Cup guise in 1966.

Liverpool chief executive Rick Parry said the game would be worthy of the final.

"It would be a great final but you've got to play the best teams sooner or later and in many ways I think we would rather have them over the two legs," he said.

"And we also have the opportunity of that visit to the Nou Camp."

Liverpool's Czech midfielder Vladimir Smicer said: "I am sure this is the tie every Liverpool fan wanted. After all, Barcelona is a great city and I know that I am not the only person on Merseyside who wants to experience their magnificent stadium.

"It has always been my dream to play in the Nou Camp stadium and this gives me the opportunity to do that."

While Barcelona and Liverpool have won 14 European trophies between them, neither Alaves nor Kaiserslautern have even reached a final.

Alaves are in Europe for the first time while Kaiserslautern's best previous performance was reaching the Uefa Cup semis in 1982 where they lost to eventual winners Gothenburg.

Alaves, who beat fellow Spaniards Rayo Vallecano in the quarter-finals, will host the first leg of their semi.

The final will be in Dortmund on May 16.

THE DRAW

Barcelona v Liverpool

Alaves v Kaiserslautern

First legs to be played on April 5, second legs April 19.

Final in Dortmund, Germany on May 16

fields.headline: BBC to examine Freud family history
fields.trailText:
11.30am: The Freud family, and the links between psychology and PR, are to be the subject of a BBC series, writes Jason Deans.
Picture gallery: Freud family tree

Profile: Matthew Freud
Obituary: Edward Bernays 'the original persuader'
fields.body:
The Freud family history, from Sigmund to Matthew, and the links between psychology and modern public relations techniques are to be the subject of a BBC series.

Bafta-winning programme-maker Adam Curtis is working on the BBC2 documentary about the famous dynasty which also spans fashion, fine art and cookery.

"The story of the Freuds is a way of looking at how psychology has been used to control the mob, the crowd, in the past 100 years," said Mr Curtis.

"It's not really a biography, but about the way Sigmund Freud's original ideas about human nature were taken up and used by his family."

Mr Curtis said he had approached Matthew Freud, the great-grandson of Sigmund and founder of Freud Communications, about an interview for one episode of the four-part series.

The documentary, which is as yet untitled, will also focus on Sigmund's nephew Edward Bernays, who is regarded as the founder of modern PR.

Mr Bernays took Sigmund's concepts to New York in the 1920s and applied them to PR and communications.

"He set out to use Freud's idea that people are basically irrational and used it to sell people products," said Mr Curtis.

"Bernays was the first person to latch onto the idea that you could have an emotional attachment to a product.

"He was the first guy to suggest that cars may be sexual symbols."

Mr Curtis is working with independent producer RDF Television on the four 60-minute documentaries, which are due to go out on BBC2 in the autumn.

He is producing and directing the series, with RDF director of programmes Stephen Lambert executive producing.

Mr Curtis won the best documentary series Bafta for his last project, BBC2 show the Mayfair Set, which focused on the impact the likes of James Goldsmith and Tiny Roland had on British business and politics.

fields.headline: Mr PR
fields.standfirst: Freud Coummunications founder; Lis Murdoch's former partner; dot.com loser; and now attempting to revive his fortunes with Soho's Groucho Club - Jason Deans profiles Matthew Freud
fields.trailText: Matthew Freud made his name as the founder of media and showbiz PR firm Freud Communications, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Matthew Freud, 37-year old great-grandson of Sigmund, made his name as the founder of media and showbiz PR firm Freud Communications.

But in the past couple of years he has become even better known for his relationship with Lis Murdoch, which ended earlier this year shortly after the birth of their child.

Mr Freud has provided endless tabloid story fodder with a client list that has included Chris Evans, Geri Halliwell and Zoe Ball.

His company's less high-profile but more lucrative corporate business has featured names including Planet Hollywood, Pepsi, BT, Kentucky Fried Chicken, Unilever and BSkyB.

Freud Communications was set up in 1985. Nine years later, Mr Freud sold it to Abbott Mead Vickers for £10m.

fields.headline: Internet revolution for deprived areas
fields.trailText: A scheme aimed at preventing the emergence of a "digital underclass" is to provide internet and digital access to 12,000 homes in six deprived communities across England.
fields.body:
A scheme aimed at preventing the emergence of a "digital underclass" is to provide internet and digital access to 12,000 homes in six deprived communities across England.

The Department for Education and Employment today revealed which areas would benefit over the next year from part of the £10m wired up communities programme.

Announcing the successful schemes Michael Wills, learning and technology minister, said: "There is a gulf emerging between those who have access to new technologies and those who do not - and it's a gap that must be narrowed if we are to create a fair and prosperous society."

He added: "We know that only one in five members of the poorer social groups have used the internet compared with two thirds of professionals - and this is a digital divide that must be overcome."

Four of the poorest urban areas and two deprived rural areas will benefit. They are:
 The Carpenters estate, Newham, where all 750 homes on the estate and the local primary school will be wired up.
 Whitebirk estate, Blackburn, where five schools and 2,500 homes will benefit.
 As part of the East Manchester New Deal for Communities project, 4,500 homes will get either recycled PCs, set to boxes, or laptops.
 Brampton upon Dearne, a former pit village in South Yorkshire, which will get 1,500 Ondigital set top boxes.
 Framlingham, Suffolk an area of low population density and poor communications where half of the 3,000 homes will be connected and a school intranet scheme for home based students will be funded.
 Alston in Cumbria, one of the areas worst hit areas in the foot and mouth outbreak, will get internet access for more than 90% of the homes including several isolated farms.

Daniel Heery, development officer for Voluntary Action Cumbria, who has coordinated Alston's bid said: "There is a real problem for rural communities getting broad band access to the internet, because if you do not have the market, firms like BT won't bother putting in the infrastructure. Without this, rural communities will get left behind."

He added: "It's an hour's bus trip from Alston to Carlisle college, this will provide a way of getting training courses down the line."

Steve Mather, director of employment, training and business development for East Manchester New Deal for Communities, said: "In a short time this area will go from limited exposure to information and communication technology to above the national average. It's a massive massive boost."

He explained that as part of the scheme a website has been set up. It provides residents with a link to the local police to report crime, and links to the local housing office to report repairs, as well as access to local jobs information with software to calculate the benefit implications of taking up a job.

fields.headline: Ministers gamble on mass cull
fields.standfirst:
Gamble on mass slaughter

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: A massive slaughter scheme that could kill up to a million healthy animals in the next month was announced yesterday by Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, in a bid to prevent the foot and mouth outbreak dragging on for months.
fields.body:
A massive slaughter scheme that could kill up to a million healthy animals in the next month was announced yesterday by Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, in a bid to prevent the foot and mouth outbreak dragging on for months.

Although he is acting on advice from Jim Scudamore, the government's chief veterinary officer, the dramatic clearing of all farm animals from large areas of countryside is also Tony Blair's last chance of running for election on May 3 without the campaign being overshadowed by foot and mouth.

The decision to move into a new gear was taken in the last few days as it became clear existing measures were not working fast enough and that the outbreak had reached epidemic proportions as it moved uncontrolled from farm to farm.

The total number of outbreaks yesterday reached 251, and some vets in the Ministry of Agriculture calculated the crisis might last until Christmas.

With large areas of the country already virtually no-go areas for normal life, this was not politically acceptable. Although these areas are sparsely populated they are vital for the tourist industry and this is the biggest clamp down on movement since the war. The economic life of large areas is being severely squeezed, creating potential disaster zones, not least for a prime minister anxious to call an election.

With less than two weeks in which to decide whether to take the plunge on May 3 Mr Blair is believed to be happy that veterinary advice to take draconian action to kill the epidemic coincided with his own plans.

The NFU president, Ben Gill, said: "There will be many tears around the British countryside today. Our farms should be starting to jump with life with new-born lambs and calves. Instead many will feel that spring has been cancelled and their farms are simply 'dead'."

"These are tough but terrible measures which I regret to say are undoubtedly needed. We will do whatever we can to get ahead of this scourge on our countryside.

"These measures will leave farmers feeling desperate and appalled at the implications for our industry. But not to act in this way would be even more disastrous for Britain's livestock farmers. If we do not try to cull ahead of the disease then even more animals will be affected."

The most dramatic measures are being taken in the worst centres of the disease in Cumbria and across the Scottish border in Dumfries and Galloway. The disease is spreading from farm to farm and to stop it "fire breaks" will be created 3km around each outbreak where all animals will be killed. Outbreaks are already so frequent that the exclusion zones overlap. Whole swaths of countryside currently dotted with sheep and cattle will have all animals removed.

Elsewhere all sheep which have been through Longtown in Cumbria, Welshpool in mid-Wales and Northampton markets from mid-February will be killed, and thousands of animals handled by the two main sheep dealers, Willy Cleave, of Burdon Farm, Highampton in Devon, and Kevin Feakins, of Llancloudy, Ross-on-Wye, will be destroyed. Both men have already lost all their own animals.

All animals taken into the current disease-free areas of mid and northern Scotland, west Wales and East Anglia since mid-February will be traced and slaughtered as a precaution. The idea is to save the tourist industry in those areas and prevent further spread of the infection.

With the disease still spreading yesterday the number of animals to be killed under existing measures rose to more than 219,000. This is already half the total number killed in the six months of the 1967 epidemic. Mr Brown, in a statement to the House of Commons, did not mention the vast numbers of animals involved in the new cull - about 2% of the 55m farm animals in the country - partly because precise figures are hard to obtain.

In Scotland, the rural affairs minister, Ross Finnie, put the figure in Dumfries and Galloway at 200,000 sheep in 500 farms, with a smaller number of cattle, probably 20,000. Cumbria is expected to lose at least as many sheep.

The restrictions on movement elsewhere have trapped up to half a million animals, mostly sheep in winter pastures. They need to be moved to summer pastures but have been forced to stay put because of movement restrictions. A licence scheme to move some of them will be in operation over the weekend but many will not qualify because they are trapped in exclusion zones and farmers who decide to have sheep and their lambs put down on welfare grounds will get compensation.

Mr Brown said: "I want to express my deepest sympathy for those farmers who have lost their herds and their flocks, and to wider farming communities who are going through a terrible time of uncertainty and distress. If the whole country works together and works constructively then we will get through this."

William Hague welcomed the new measures, saying they were "sensible".

More support came from James Black, chairman of the National Pig Association, whose members are still recovering from the classical swine fever outbreak last autumn. He said: "The trauma experienced by our members, both financial and emotional, is too hard to contemplate, and this epidemic will have an incalculable effect upon British agriculture.

"We support the difficult veterinary judgments that have to be made and we shall continue to work and support all those who are working to bring this disease under control."

webTitle: Voters cool over plan for May poll

fields.headline: Voters cool over plan for May poll
fields.standfirst:
Election: Labour risks 'arrogant' tag if it pushes for early date

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Voters are rapidly cooling towards the government's determination to hold the general election in May despite the foot and mouth crisis. A poll last night for Channel 4 News showed only a third of voters (36%) thought it should go ahead, while 47% thought it should be delayed. Less than a week ago 63% supported a May election.
fields.body:
Voters are rapidly cooling towards the government's determination to hold the general election in May despite the foot and mouth crisis. A poll last night for Channel 4 News showed only a third of voters (36%) thought it should go ahead, while 47% thought it should be delayed. Less than a week ago 63% supported a May election.

Downing Street's dilemma grows by the day: a Gallup survey for today's Daily Telegraph puts Labour's lead at 27 points, but there are fears that lead could crumble if voters perceive the government's decision to stick to May 3 as arrogant and out of touch.

Yesterday's dramatic escalation of the cull was an unspoken acknowledgement that in Cumbria at least the disease was out of control. Yet the agriculture minister Nick Brown was backpedalling on his plea to the public to stay away from the countryside, in order to breathe some life into the near moribund tourist industry. Privately, Tories - and some Labour MPs - see the fate of the tourist industry as a surrogate for the debate about an election: if tourists should not travel then nor should politicians hit the campaign trail.

Around Westminster there has been anxious canvassing of opinion as backbenchers with rural constituencies hit by the foot and mouth outbreak warned the government of the danger of pushing on with its plans. Clive Soley, chairman of the Parliamentary Labour party, insisted that it was right to push ahead. "Unless the position dramatically worsens," he said last night, "we should go ahead even though we have to be very sensitive about it. But to cancel the local elections, or indeed the general election, would send an appalling message to the world and damage our tourist trade."

Any decision to cancel now has to be made within days. The formal starting date for the local elections in England, which are due on May 3 - is March 26. Emergency legislation would be needed to cancel them, and that would have to go through parliament next week. It would also be necessary to set a new election date, the leader of the house, Margaret Beckett, confirmed in the Commons yesterday, ensuring a long and voter-alienating election campaign. Although a June election is possible, much of the countryside would still be crippled by foot and mouth restrictions. A delay until the autumn, perhaps October 4 would be more likely.

But the government has almost nothing to do in parliament, where the mood is already excited. Meanwhile the bill to outlaw hunting is due for more debate in the Lords who are expected to overturn the massive Commons majority in favour of a ban. With no election, the legislation could be back in the Commons before the summer recess.

Hotels, shops, pubs and restaurants are reeling from the public's decision not to risk spreading the disease by travelling to the country. Yesterday Mr Brown appealed to tourists not to change their plans and assured them it was safe to visit market towns and villages.

fields.headline: St Patrick's Day
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about Ireland's national day on the web
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about Ireland's national day on the web
fields.body:
1. An early top of the morning to you from Guardian Unlimited. Tomorrow's St Patrick's Day when Irishmen remember the man who drove the snakes out of the emerald isle.

2. From north to south, from Dublin to Galway, the Irish raise a glass to their patron saint. And in New Orleans, they throw cabbages, carrots and onions.

3. New Orleans? Yes, over 100 cities hold St Patrick's Day parades in America. In New York, there is a parade through Fifth Avenue and in Chicago the river's dyed green. Elsewhere the beer's drunk green.

4. St Patrick's Day is the one national holiday celebrated in more countries across the world than any other: it's the day when more people claim to be Irish than, perhaps, is possible.

5. The Americans have more reason than most: the first St Patrick's Day parade was held in Boston, Massachusetts, in 1737 and many (such as the Kennedy family) can claim an Irish ancestor from the millions who emigrated in the years after the potato famine.

6. Between 1815 and 1845, almost a third of North America's immigrants were Irish. Groups such as the Ancient Order of Hiberians (formed in New York in 1836) strived to preserve the culture of the old country.

7. But it would be naive to think the celebrations don't have something to do with beer. Especially the popular Welsh drink Guinness.

8. St Patrick himself was born in 373AD in Roman Britain (or somewhere north of Hadrian's Wall). Kidnapped by pirates at the age of 16, he was sold into slavery in Ireland.

9. After six years, he escaped to France and became a priest. At the age of 60, he returned to Ireland, converted the resident Celts to Christianity (using a shamrock to explain the Holy Trinity) and drove all the snakes into the sea.

10. Thirsty work, no doubt, which is why many mark the day by piling into Irish pubs around the world and drinking until they see leprechauns.

fields.headline: Jobs may go as Mail cuts budgets
fields.trailText:
12.30pm: Department heads at Associated Newspapers are slashing 10% from their budgets, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Feb 21: Mail dismisses Express threat
fields.body:
Department heads at the Daily Mail and the Mail on Sunday have been asked to trim 10% from their budgets over the course of the next financial year - and some editorial staff may face redundancy.

For news and features reporters, the cuts so far have only meant a tightening of the expenses purse strings.

Staff have been asked to be more frugal with hospitality and the use of taxis.

But the subs desk has already felt the cuts.

At least one senior sub-editor has been made redundant in the past week and insiders say further cuts are possible.

Sources say the department has been asked to scale back the use of freelances and more redundancies have not been ruled out.

Associated Newspapers was unavailable for comment.

News of cuts at Associated - a cash-rich business with a reputation for being one of the industry's best-resourced newspaper publishers - is likely to be received with some surprise.

The move by the Mail and Mail on Sunday, which are known to spend more on editorial than most of their rivals, suggests newspapers across the board are bracing themselves for a downturn.

Rising paper costs and an advertising slowdown are curtailing some of the spending excesses of the past few years.

At least two newspapers have imposed a recruitment freeze.

webTitle: Council tax to rise above targets

fields.headline: Council tax to rise above targets
fields.trailText: Council tax bills in England and Wales are set to rise by more than twice the rate of inflation, busting government targets designed to keep increases low in the run up to the general election. Simon Parker reports
fields.body:
Council tax bills in England and Wales are set to rise by more than twice the rate of inflation, busting government targets designed to keep increases low in the run up to the general election.

Local government minister Hilary Armstrong told councils in January that she expected most of them to keep tax rises below last year's average band D increase of 6.1%.

Today, however, research from the Chartered Institute of Public Finance and Accountancy (Cipfa) reveals that local authorities in England and Wales have missed that target, and predicts average band D increases of 6.4%, bringing the average band D bill to £891.

Council tax bills will hit the nation's doormats at the height of campaigning for the expected May general election, and ministers have been keen to ensure large increases do not damage Labour's prospects. In January, they unveiled nearly £190m in targeted funding to help local authorities dampen their tax rises.

The figure is doubly embarrassing for ministers because it bucks an overall downward trend in increases, which have been falling since Labour came to power. It comes despite an overall increase of more than 7% in this year's local government finance settlement.

The government is currently refusing to accept that Cipfa's figures are definitive, saying that the Department of the Environment does not yet have budget information from all authorities, and so will not comment in depth on what the final figures might be.

A government spokesman did say: "With inflation low and stable and with the big increase in central government grant this year, ministers will be disappointed if the overall downward trend has not continued."

Ministers still have powers to cap council tax increases, and the spokesman said they would look carefully at whether any individual authority had set an excessive figure.

The Conservatives, who had predicted that tax increases could reach as high as 9%, leapt on the figures as proof that Labour was hiking up so-called "stealth taxes".

Shadow environment secretary Archie Norman said: "Under Labour, council tax has become the ultimate stealth tax, piled onto taxpayers without any improvement in services. Their fuel taxes, pension taxes, extra regulations and bureaucracy have all pushed up the costs of local councils."

London topped the increases, posting an average band D rise of 8.5%, a figure that has been inflated by the precept increase imposed by the Greater London Authority, which put nearly £30 on band D bills.

The traditionally high taxing metropolitan authorities posted the lowest increases, averaging 5.4%, but their bills remain the highest in the country at an average £968.

Four out five of those authorities which bill for council tax responded to the survey, and Cipfa says it does not expect the final outcome to be significantly different from today's figures.

webTitle: Bribery claim forces out Indian defence minister

fields.headline: Bribery claim forces out Indian defence minister
fields.trailText: The Indian coalition government descended further into further crisis last night when the defence minister, George Fernandes, was forced by a deepening arms bribery scandal to resign.
fields.body:
The Indian coalition government descended further into further crisis last night when the defence minister, George Fernandes, was forced by a deepening arms bribery scandal to resign.

Three days ago an internet site claimed that he presided over a ministry riddled with corruption. His resignation came after a key member left the coalition in protest. Three other ministers from his Samata party also resigned.

In a halting speech broadcast last night on state television, Mr Fernandes said he was innocent and resigning only to preserve the morale of the armed forces.

The president of Samata, Jaya Jaitly, also quit yesterday after being secretly filmed accepting more than £3,000 at Mr Fernandes's residence from journalists posing as representatives of a fictitious London arms company, West End.

They also obtained video footage of generals, politicians and senior officials accepting large amounts of cash to help secure an arms contract.

It was not clear last night whether the government can ride out the storm.

Most worrying to the prime minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, is the fact that the videotapes appear to implicate both his private office and his most trusted aide, the national security adviser Brajesh Mishra, in the defence scandal.

The website which carried out the exposé, www.tehelka.com, continued to pile on the pressure yesterday. It released a tape of Bangara Laxman, president of Mr Vajpayee's party, the Bharatiya Janata party, saying that Mr Mishra played a crucial role in "defence issues", and adding: "We normally turn to him." Mr Laxman resigned on Tuesday after being filmed putting a £1,500 bribe in his desk drawer.

Last night observers were speculating whether Mr Fernandes would reveal further offences at the heart of government.

Hours before Mr Fernandes left, the leader of the Trinamool Congress party, Mamata Banerjee - who had demanded a corruption inquiry - announced that she and her nine MPs were leaving the coalition.

The government still has a majority of 19 in the 545-seat lower house. Both houses were adjourned in uproar for a second day yesterday.

The normally divided opposition, led by the Congress party, has called on the government to quit.

The defence ministry has suspended four officials featured in the documentary.

fields.headline: Waiting and watching and hoping
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited is regularly interviewing a small panel of people whose lives and livelihoods have been directly affected by the foot and mouth crisis. Here is our latest dispatch from Derek Brown in Chipping Norton, Oxfordshire, on the front line.

Meet the panel
fields.trailText: Guardian Unlimited is regularly interviewing a small panel of people whose lives and livelihoods have been directly affected by the foot and mouth crisis. Here is our latest dispatch from Derek Brown in Chipping Norton, Oxfordshire, on the front line.
fields.body:
Still no outbreaks of the foul disease in our immediate area, thank goodness, and there is even something good to look forward to, the shape of the next month's resurrected Cheltenham Festival.

If it really does come off, it will at least bring some cheer to the gloomstricken tourist trade. The meat business has also stabilised, with stocks plentiful and prices, if anything, easing back towards pre-crisis levels.

It would be tempting to fall back on the old saw, that no news is good news. But the foot and mouth news, even if it is not being generated in our West Oxfordshire backyard, is as grim as it could be.

The farmers

The farmer Marilyn Ivings, even in the midst of the crisis, is unfailingly cheerful. But today her voice breaks, as she tells of watching a Cumbrian farmer friend on the television news last night.

"I was very upset. I'm afraid I had to cry. Oh dear, I think I'm going to cry again now, it was so awful," she said. Les Armstrong, her friend, had just seen his sheep and cattle slaughtered.

"He's a big man, very strong, a natural leader," Marilyn went on. "But when I saw him last night, he looked bent, doubled up. He looked grey..." Her voice tails off.

The 'what if it happened here?' factor is a inescapable part of farming these days. For non-farmers, it's an unimaginable anxiety. "Even for me - and I am a farmer - it' impossible to think what it must be like," said Marilyn.

"They asked the man's wife at Chesterton [where the disease has been confirmed, in the south of the county] what it was like after the animals had all been killed, and she said the thing she noticed most was the silence."

Marilyn paused. "No more animal noises. No, I can't imagine that."

For the moment, happily, the 35 suckler cows Marilyn and husband Ted look after at Mill Farm, Church Enstone, are perfectly healthy.

No thanks, though, to the walkers who still insist on using the footpaths and bridleways in the area.

Marilyn saw two women this morning, walking their dog along the footpath that runs through their farmhouse yard. Fortunately, the cattle are kept some distance away, and the only animals in the yard - chickens, ducks, dogs and cats - are non-susceptible to foot and mouth.

Still, it seems incredible that there are still countryside users who believe their 'rights' are more important than the deadly risk of spreading the disease.

The caterers

Most people are aware of the risks, and are keeping away. That's bad news for Brian Galbraith and partner Jan Blackburn, who run the smart bar-restaurant, Stones, in the heart of Chipping Norton.

The pattern of business has altered completely in the past two weeks, with lunchtime deadly quiet and predominantly local trade in the evening.

"We have done a little better this week than last, and we are keeping our heads above water," said Brian. "But in financial terms, the point is that we had a good December, and January was okay - but it is now that we are having to pay our December and January bills."

Jan, more used to producing home-cooked meals for a steady stream of lunchtime customers, now has time to talk in the pleasant restaurant.

"It's the lunchtimes I can't stand. I like to be busy, but this" - she nods at the handful of customers - "it's just dreadful."

The Cheltenham Festival, if it goes ahead, should bring back some cheer to the local tourist trade, and provide a fillip for Brian's other business, a chauffeur service.

But looking ahead to Easter, when a rising tide of tourists normally comes through the town on its way to the Cotswolds, the outlook remains clouded with uncertainty.

The butcher

Businesses geared to the tourist trade are clearly feeling the pinch, but others have weathered the immediate crisis. After a difficult first week, in which supplies were tricky and prices under pressure, butcher John Kench is noticing some interesting new trends.

"I can't be certain of course, but I am fairly sure we are getting some customers in who normally go to the supermarkets. People are becoming ever more aware of things like food hygiene and quality and above all, traceability - ie is it British produced?

"I have certificates in my window about my Orkney beef and a lot of people are stopping and reading them. They want to know where the goods are from," he said.

Early fears about panic buying have ebbed, and there is certainly no sign of it on John's well-stocked counters. Nor is there any evidence that consumers are turning away from meat.

"My sales have been strong. I'm probably doing better than this time last year, but it's difficult to say why exactly because the business is building up anyway," he said.

On prices, most lines are stable and there could even be a slackening of bacon and pork prices, which rose sharply in the early days of the crisis.

The Co-op

It's much the same story at the Chipping Norton Co-op supermarket, where shelves are healthily stocked with most kinds of meat, fresh and frozen.

"Prices haven't changed at all, although we have cut back on some of our promotions. Where we used to offer chicken fillets on a buy one get one free basis, now we are saying buy one, get another one at half price," said duty manager Mark Corbett.

The Co-op's buy-British policy is under pressure, though Mark says most of the meat on display is still UK-produced. "It's very frustrating for the buyers.

"The company is trying to keep British, but if it comes to it, we will have to look elsewhere to keep the customers supplied."

fields.headline: C5 goes ahead with Oprah internet twins specials
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Channel 5 is to show two Oprah Winfrey specials featuring the couples at the centre of the internet adoption row, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 5 is to broadcast the two Oprah Winfrey Show specials featuring the couples at the centre of the internet adoption row next week, after taking legal advice.

The two 45-minute programmes will go out in Channel 5's regular Oprah 1pm slot on Monday and Tuesday.

The shows brought the two couples involved in the internet baby adoption row, the Kilshaws and the Allens, face to face for the first time.

The US couple, the Allens, originally adopted the twin girls at the centre of the row, but they were then brought to England by the Kilshaws.

The eight-month-old twins are now in foster care in the UK, while the adoption issue is settled in the US courts.

The Oprah shows on the affair went out in the US at the beginning of February.

Channel 5's lawyers have been looking at the shows and have now decided they can be transmitted in the UK, according to a spokesman.

"We have decided to broadcast the show because we feel it is a matter of interest to the public," he said.

"It shows the dangers of adopting babies from abroad and over the internet," he added. "People all over the world have seen the programme, so should people in the UK.

"We are confident the programmes can in no way harm the young babies involved or the proper administration of the court proceedings in the US."

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week twenty-nine
fields.standfirst: God of gambling, let these bets come in
fields.trailText: God of gambling, let these bets come in.
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £165.54
The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £24.08
Paul MacInnes = £20.01
Sean Ingle = £19.82

Scott Murray: Chelsea v Sunderland - Sunderland to lead at half-time, Chelsea to lead at full-time £5 @ 28/1

Sometimes I feel so very, very tired. And at the end of a miserable week, the last thing I want to do is toil away in a bookies on a search for value when it's much easier to fritter all my money away on a long-priced hunch instead. OK, so it's going to make me upset and unhappy, but here goes!

Two of Chelsea's last three home games have followed this pattern: home side clank around hopelessly, visitors take unlikely lead, home side get it together and thrash visitors out of sight. (The other match was against Manchester United, so I'm ignoring it.)

Now, I wouldn't actually recommend joining me on this bet: it simply isn't good value. Also, my logic is skewed - the aforementioned deficits (against Newcastle and Ipswich) were cancelled out before the break. But if you had the opportunity to gamble with someone else's money, wouldn't you occasionally be very reckless indeed?

Charlotte Freemantle of the Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective: Newcastle v Middlesbrough, Boro to win - £5 @ 3/1

Boro's record at St. James' Park isn't that impressive, but their away record this year isn't too bad and Newcastle are riddled with injuries.

Terry Venables will be looking over his shoulder at Manchester City, who'll be going for three points at Bradford, and I'm sure he'd love to get one over his old England predecessor in his first north-eastern derby.

The Prince of Punts: CIS Cup final, Kilmarnock to beat Celtic at half-time - £5 @ 6/1

Glurrgle. The Prince of Punts writes today from his chaise longue, unable to complete the most basic of gambling actions. You see, dear reader, the Prince has been wounded, perhaps even mortally, in a duel with his most hated rival the Baron of Bets (or was it the Viscount of Wagers? I cannot remember). The incident occurred in the most sneaky of fashions, a ball of lead flying into the Prince's chest as he checked out the special prices on offer at Ladbrokes on the total number of incinerated animal carcasses by the end of March. I couldn't believe i. oh, the pain.

So while the nurse applies the laudanum, here is my bet. Celtic, runaway leaders of the Scottish Premier League, could claim the first part of a Scottish treble this Sunday if they beat Kilmarnock. But the Bhoys have been making hard work of opponents recently, and will be without Stilian Petrov, Didier Agathe, Robert Douglas, Jackie McNamara and Chris Sutton. I'd still back Martin O'Neill's men to win, but a good start for Killie is not beyond the realms of possibility.

Take that punt and run with it, I've got a suppurating wound to attend to.

Sean Ingle is on holiday, off to watch some Serie A match or other, the great big gadabout

Terry Venables will be looking over his shoulder at Manchester City, who'll be going for three points at Bradford, and I'm sure he'd love to get one over his old England predecessor in his first north-eastern derby. The Prince of Punts: CIS Cup final, Kilmarnock to beat Celtic at half-time - £5 @ 6/1 Glurrgle. The Prince of Punts writes today from his chaise longue, unable to complete the most basic of gambling actions. You see, dear reader, the Prince has been wounded, perhaps even mortally, in a duel with his most hated rival the Baron of Bets (or was it the Viscount of Wagers? I cannot remember). The incident occurred in the most sneaky of fashions, a ball of lead flying into the Prince's chest as he checked out the special prices on offer at Ladbrokes on the total number of incinerated animal carcasses by the end of March. fields.headline: TBWA confirms Greenlees departure
fields.trailText:
11.30am: TBWA Worldwide's president Mike Greenlees is to take up a post at Omnicom, writes Claire Cozens.
Mar 14: Greenlees rumoured to be leaving TBWA
fields.body:
TBWA Worldwide has confirmed its president and chief executive Mike Greenlees is leaving to take up a post with Omnicom, the advertising agency's parent company.

In a statement released last night, the company said Mr Greenlees would be replaced by Jean-Marie Dru, the Paris-based head of TBWA's international operations.

Omnicom said Mr Greenlees would take up a "new leadership position" at the company, where his remit will be to "advance [Omnicom's] e-business strategy".

Further details of his new role, which he will take up on April 1, will be released "in the very near future", the company said.

Mr Dru will move to New York and will work with Lee Clow, the chairman and worldwide creative director of TBWA.

"In Jean-Marie and Lee, TBWA has two of the most talented and visionary leaders in the industry," said Omnicom chief executive John Wren.

"Under their leadership, TBWA is perfectly positioned to continue to build upon the outstanding progress it has been made in the past three years," he added.

Related story

webTitle: In brief: Rachel Weisz too beautiful for Bridget Jones

fields.headline: Rachel Weisz too beautiful for Bridget Jones
fields.standfirst: Plus: King Lear heads out to the wild west; Norwegian farmers want to disinfect Depardieu
fields.trailText: Plus: King Lear heads out to the wild west; Norwegian farmers want to disinfect Depardieu
fields.body:
 Rachel Weisz was apparently turned down for the lead role in Bridget Jones's Diary because she was too gorgeous. According to today's Mirror, Sharon Maguire, the director of the film, says that Weisz was "very funny" and of course, beautiful. However, she adds that she was "too beautiful for the part in fact."

 TNT is to spend $11m (£7.65m) on an epic western which transplants King Lear to 1840s Texas. According to Variety, King of Texas is to star Patrick Stewart as the Lear character, with Oscar nominee Marcia Gay Harden and Lauren Holly as the equivalents of Regan and Goneril. The two hour film, which will be filmed in various Mexican locations, is the latest in a string of updated Shakespeare movies including Ethan Hawke's Hamlet and Baz Luhrmann's Romeo + Juliet.

 Farmers in Norway want to disinfect Gerard Depardieu. Mr Showbiz reports that the farmers, who are terrified of an outbreak of foot and mouth disease, want the French star and other actors and crew working on I Am Dina to be disinfected. The film is currently being shot in a rural area of northern Norway.

fields.headline: Hijackers stifle mental health facilities
fields.standfirst: A campaign led from the top is needed to prevent prejudice controlling local planning
fields.trailText: Geoff Martin: A campaign led from the top is needed to prevent prejudice controlling local planning.
fields.body:
There are ominous signs that old-fashioned "Nimbyism" has taken a nasty turn for the worse and is being entangled with sheer prejudice and misinformation into local campaigns that could make it almost impossible to develop new mental health facilities in many parts of the country.

The Unison branch at the south London and Maudsley mental health trust (Slam) has recently been caught up in a particularly vicious "not in my back yard" battle. The trust planned to expand the services on the Cane Hill hospital site near Croydon to include a new medium secure unit (MSU).

Slam has seen huge holes blown through its budgets because of the costs of outplacements into beds in the private sector, and Unison has been campaigning for years for an expansion of in-house provision to cut costs and improve the quality of care. Unison, then, was 100% behind the plan to expand the services on the neglected Cane Hill site to create 200 new beds, including the MSU.

In these circumstances, you expect some public fears to surface and the trust worked flat out to deal with them and to offer the safeguards and reassurances people needed. But it's impossible to engage in a rational debate when the opposition campaign pitches itself along the lines of "Gangs of paedophiles set to descend on local schools" - which is what the Cane Hill proposal found itself up against.

The climate was not a million miles away from the vigilantism in Portsmouth and other towns last year surrounding the anti-paedophile campaign.

Pictures of managers from the trust were posted on the anti-Cane Hill campaign's website alongside torrents of personal abuse. Caught in the middle of the battle was staff. At least one nurse was assaulted by local youths who mistook him for a patient and kids took to driving up to the isolated hospital buildings and hurling stones before speeding off into the night.

The whole episode proved just how easily genuine fears and concerns can be hijacked by mob rule, and just before Christmas the council threw out the planning application for the new unit. At least one Labour councillor received anonymous threats of physical violence as the ugly mood was whipped up to fever pitch.

So what next? Slam may appeal against the decision but it still leaves it in limbo. Meanwhile, the trust's budget is being bled dry by private outplacements and many managers are wondering whether they would have any prospect of getting a similar proposal approved elsewhere if a mirror-image campaign were to spring into life.

The nonsense is that the same people who will fight dirty to stop a new unit being built in their area would be the first to demand that people with severe mental health problems be swept from the streets as long as it isn't into their back yard. The growth of the internet, and the anonymity that goes with it, means opposition campaigns can set the pace and whip up fear with virtual impunity.

The only solution is a campaign led from the top to break down the prejudice that can so easily be ignited against people with mental health problems and the services they so desperately need. Until that happens, and at a level that can have a real impact, the Nimby's and the vigilantes will continue to control the local planning agenda.

webTitle: United meet Bayern as Spain awaits Arsenal and Leeds

fields.headline: United meet Bayern as Spain awaits Arsenal and Leeds
fields.trailText: Manchester United were drawn to face Bayern Munich in the quarter-finals of the Champions League on Friday in a repeat of the 1999 final won in injury time by United.
fields.body:
Manchester United were drawn to face Bayern Munich in the quarter-finals of the Champions League on Friday in a repeat of the 1999 final won in injury time by United.

Deportivo Coruna face Leeds United while last year's runners-up Valencia clash with Arsenal in two England v Spain encounters.

Favourites and holders Real Madrid will play Turkey's Galatasaray as the Spaniards seek their ninth title.

The quarter-final first legs will be played on April 3 and 4. The second legs take place a fortnight later.

The semifinal draw was also made with the winners of the United-Bayern game playing the winners of Real Madrid-Galatasaray and the same applying to the Deportivo-Leeds and Valencia-Arsenal games.

United have played Bayern three times in Europe, drawing twice in Champions League group action in the 1998-99 season and then the following year winning one of the most dramatic games in soccer history 2-1 with the last kick of the match.

"Bayern will be looking for revenge but obviously we've got great memories of that night," United secretary Ken Merrett said following the draw.

"But it adds to the glamour and the excitement of the game.

"We have a good relationship with Bayern but there is also a great rivalry.

"But it's good to meet them. They are a great club with great traditions - as we believe we are."

Arsenal's only previous European game against Valencia was another dramatic encounter as the Spanish club won the 1980 Cup Winners' Cup on penalties after a 0-0 draw.

"We've just got to win," said Arsenal vice-chairman David Dein.

"You have got to beat the best to get to the final so it doesn't matter who we got."

Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale said of his team's pairing with Spanish champions Deportivo: "After finishing second in our group we always knew it was going to be a difficult draw.

"But we are just grateful to be in the last eight."

Speaking about the presence of three English teams in the last eight for the first time he added: "It's putting England back on the map which I'm very pleased about."

Mete Rizklin, sporting director of Galatasaray, promised Real Madrid a fight. "We are honoured to be in the quarter-finals against such an opponent," he said. "We will fight to the end."

THE DRAW

Leeds v Deportivo

will play the winners of

Arsenal v Valencia

Galatasaray v Real Madrid

will play the winners of

Manchester United v Bayern Munich

First leg ties to be played 3/4 April, second leg ties to be played 17/18 April.

fields.headline: BBC nets England World Cup match
fields.trailText:
12pm: The BBC is understood to have paid £3m for exclusive live TV and radio rights to England's World Cup qualifier against Greece in June, writes Jason Deans.

Mar 16: Salmon unveils sports strategy

Mar 15: TV bosses fear World Cup defeat
fields.body:
The BBC is understood to have paid around £3m for exclusive live TV and radio rights to England's World Cup football qualifier against Greece in June.

The match will go out on BBC1 on June 6, although the kick-off time has not yet been finalised. Gary Lineker will be the presenter.

The BBC has already signed up the live TV rights to the following England World Cup qualifier, against Germany on September 1.

The corporation will also have live coverage of all England's home internationals from next season, following the deal signed last summer with the FA.

Channel 5 will carry live coverage of England's next World Cup qualifier, which is against Albania later this month.

fields.headline: MediaCom wins £416m GlaxoSmithKline brief
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Media agency MediaCom has landed the global media buying account for drug giant GlaxoSmithKline, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The media buying giant MediaCom has landed the £416m global media buying account for drug company GlaxoSmithKline.

The New York office of MediaCom, part of the Grey Global Group, has been appointed to handle the consolidated account.

The appointment is the result of a two-month review process that followed the merger of Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham.

Three other New York agencies pitched for the account.

These were Young & Rubicam's the Media Edge, part of the WPP network; Initiative Media Worldwide's Media Direct Partners, part of the Interpublic network; and Media Planning Group, part of Havas Advertising.

All four of the agencies handled media buying for Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham.

Before the merger, MediaCom handled SmithKline's media buying in the UK while MindShare and Universal McCann looked after the Glaxo brands.

webTitle: Bloody Sunday to be subject of film

fields.headline: Bloody Sunday to be subject of film
fields.trailText: A new film will look at one of the most controversial incidents in recent Northern Irish history which left 13 civilians dead
fields.body:
The Film Council is to invest £250,000 into a film about the Bloody Sunday shootings which left 13 civilians dead. Bloody Sunday will star James Nesbitt, Tim Pigott-Smith and Nicholas Farrell.

According to Reuters, the project, which promises to "piece together the tragic and complex events" of January 1972, is one of seven films to receive backing from the recently formed New Cinema Fund.

According to its makers, it will be "non-partisan, dispassionate and humane." "We see the events of Bloody Sunday as encapsulating the whole tragic and violent history of relations between out two islands," writer and director Paul Greengrass told the BBC.

Greengrass, who made the Bafta-winning drama, The Murder of Stephen Lawrence, added: "The prospect of lasting peace and the passage of time give us the opportunity to look back and examine the dynamics of the conflict."

Almost 30 years after Bloody Sunday, the events leading up to the shootings remain contested and a government inquiry is currently investigating the incident.

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapskate | Quick bites | On the menu | On the net | Just out
fields.body:
 Cheapskate... Where to eat out for under £15

Willows Wine Bar, 81 Denmark Hill, Camberwell, SE5, Tel: 020-7701 0188
Mention of the words "wine bar" may dredge up uncomfortable memories of harooshing City wide boys, knocking back the vino after a hard day's wheeler-dealing. Thankfully, Willows is an altogether mellower sort of place, with heavy wooden tables and long glass windows lending a proto-Parisian air. The wine is the thing, but devoted guzzlers need a solid as well as liquid diet. Starters are around the £4 mark, and main dishes stretch from about £7 to £10.95. The menu is hardly radical, but the food itself - penne with salmon, pine nuts and a mushroom sauce; warm goat's cheese salad, potato skins with cheese and salsa; pitta with humus and taramasalata - is pretty spot on. More than enough to soak up the Chardonnay.

 Quick bites... Where to eat out in 15 minutes

4 Grove Lane, Camberwell, London, SE5, Tel: 020-7701 4944
Tucked snugly off the main road, away from Camberwell's fried chicken joints and greasy spoons, 4 Grove Lane is a sandwich shop plying the sort of ciabatta rolls that come plumply stuffed like hamsters' cheeks. At 6.30pm, the place is magicked, Bugsy Malone-style, into a pizzeria. May not be authentic enough to please pizza snobs, but the bases are whippet-thin, and the toppings toothsome, all sinewy cheese and crisp, buckled edges. The menu is a glorious inventory of Mediterranean feelgood goodies: feta, olives, anchovies and the like. And the staff are snake-hipped funksters who serve with a swagger.

 On the menu: Nagiri Bocho

Sounds delicious. What is it? You can't eat it. You can't smell it. You can't hear it.

Cut it out. What can I do with it? Cut it out. Literally.

Cut to the quick? Exactly. It's a knife.

Any old knife? A Japanese knife that is used by the kitchen samurai in that country for cutting vegetables.

What's so special about a nagiri bocho? Western knives are forged from steel. Japanese knives are made by forge-welding steel and iron together to give strength without brittleness and long-lasting sharpness.

I'll rush out and get one right away.Don't get a deba bocho (for poultry and fish), unagisaki bocho (eel), or a sashimi bocho by mistake.

 On the net: www.vegweb.com

Meat-eaters might be feeling a little edgy at the moment, so now might very well be the time to start improving your vegetarian culinary know-how - and vegweb gives you a wealth of meat-free recipes at your fingertips. True, I'm not too sure about the Congo Tofu, or even the Pina Colada Tofu Shake, but the Bean and Pumpkin Curry has a certain allure. Vegweb has a dozen recipes for French toast, and a culinary dictionary telling us all about the nutritional merits of dandelions (high in iron and vitamin A, apparently) and explaining precisely what spatzles are (noodles, as if you didn't know). And yes, fret not, there's even a recipe for vegan bacon.

 Just out: Duchy Originals Organic Creamy Mature Stilton

Form: chunky wedge; good creamy colour; decent bluing; a little wet

Flavour: lovely texture; very strong; blue predominates; verges on ammoniac; creaminess lost completely.

Verdict: "Made with the milk from the rare breed of shorthorn cows." Ah, yes, well. The milk may be great, and the cheese, potentially, is very good (though not unpasteurised, as one might wish), but the marketing rather does for it. Classy packaging, as ever, but plastic wrap around the cheese itself means the cheese can't breathe properly, so it tastes more acidic and pungent than it should.

Cost: £11.56 per kg or £2.96 for 256g.

 The taste test: dark chocolate

Or plain, as we might call it. The kind that sorts out chocoholics from mere choccieluvvies. We're looking for a refinement-and-purity high, so those with less than 65% cocoa solids got relegated to the bin (after tasting).

£0.79p/100g

Green & Blacks

£1.35/100g

Tesco Belgian

£0.79p/100g

Waitrose Organic

£0.89p/100g

We're looking for a refinement-and-purity high, so those with less than 65% cocoa solids got relegated to the bin (after tasting). fields.headline: Choosing shrubs?
fields.standfirst: Go for the big performers, not the big yawners, say Christopher Lloyd
fields.trailText: Go for the big performers, not the big yawners, say Christopher Lloyd
fields.body:
In a recent article about making the best use of the space in a small garden, three shrubs were recommended: pyracantha, viburnum and garrya. These shrubs can, indeed, be reduced in size without their objecting. But let's take a look at them in greater detail. After all, they may prove more of a disappointment than an asset.

The main appeal of pyracanthas is their showy crops of orange or yellow berries in the autumn. White blossom in spring is a pleasant extra. When I see pyracanthas at their best, I wonder why I don't grow any. But, considered year-round, I find them a bit sordid. They are evergreen, but their leaves are without character and their way of growing has little attraction - a point that is of small importance once they have to be clipped back, generally to a wall, on a regular basis. But, in the course of time, clipping back makes them a lumpy feature, and is also apt to reduce their berry production. They are tolerant of shade, which is an advantage, but our huge one used to get scab on its fruit. I was greatly relieved when we got rid of it, but don't let me put you off. If you have the space, a free-standing pyracantha that needs no pruning can look splendid. They are not 100% hardy, but with global warming I suppose it will be of less notice.

When viburnum was mentioned, I imagine the writer had the ubiquitous Viburnum tinus in mind, popularly known as laurustinus. This is an incredibly generous shrub, often flowering abundantly both in autumn and spring; sometimes in winter, too, if that is mild. The evergreen foliage is sombre but pleasing. If you need to clip it to fit into a space, do this in spring when it has finished flowering.

'Eve Price' is a popular clone, reasonably dwarf and very pink in the bud, though the flowers are always white. 'Gwenllian' is another good one, larger growing but again a good pink in the bud. It also fruits freely, these being blue. The fruits are even more conspicuous in V. davidii, which is a lower-growing shrub, almost a ground-coverer (you can cut it back when it gets too big). Its leathery leaves with deeply grooved parallel veining are its main point. Most nurseries sell it unsexed but some do specify and it is certainly worth having a male among your females, the fruit being a definite bonus. This is what I should describe as a thoroughly worthy, good-tempered shrub, but if, after many years, you become bored with it, you have my sympathy. An end to the relationship is far cheaper and less messy than divorce. I admired Garrya elliptica for many years, and it thrived on a sunless wall. You can cut it back quite severely in spring and it will flower abundantly the next winter on its young shoots. January is its season and its long, grey-green catkins make a great display (if not frosted) for a few weeks. But for the rest of the year it is a big yawn, with leathery, evergreen foliage of no character. Even in January you may feel that there are enough grey skies without a garrya to emphasise them.

What you really should be growing, to flower from late February well into April, is Daphne odora, generally marketed in the 'Aureomarginata' clone. It is highly lime-tolerant. Its evergreen leaves are generally a rather sickly yellowish-green colour, but don't let that worry you, because its flowering is prodigious - clusters of blossom that are rosy purple on the outside, near-white within - and the powerful, airborne scent is incredible. It's great for picking, too. The shrub is only 0.5m high, as a rule, but more spreading. In southern counties, it will flower well in shade, but in the north, even in sunshine, it may not flower at all.

An evergreen ceanothus is such an exciting feature that it should not be passed over without an effort. Generally, it will flower in May-June, though some species are earlier, and its blossom, in globe-shaped pouffes, is genuinely blue (in the best kinds) and totally different from anything else you can flower at that time. Hardiness is a little dubious, but it is an admirable wall shrub on any reasonably sunny aspect (east, south, west). It can (should, indeed) be kept into the wall, first by tying in growths to cover the area, then on a regular basis by clipping it over immediately after flowering. Branches that jut inconveniently forwards should be removed but anticipate later trouble and do this regularly. Ceanothus of this kind does not enjoy being pruned into old wood.

I would choose a small and neat-leaved variety such as 'Puget Blue' or 'Cynthia Postan'. These really are show-stoppers, and you'll have the public gawping over your gate in unbelieving admiration. Sudden death is only to be expected, sooner or later, in such a paragon, but don't be put off by that. Plant another. And this is the time to be planting, as it is for all slightly dubiously hardy shrubs.

This type of ceanothus is not to be confused with the much hardier, deciduous, summer- flowering kinds, which are of looser growth and less pure or intense colouring. They are a lot easier to manage - 'Gloire de Versailles' is the best known of them - but less rewarding. Such is life
