fields.headline: Yelland's heavens
fields.standfirst: David Yelland's editorship since 1998 marks a cautious move towards a more informed political stance but, asks Maggie Hyde, has he got the style and personality to make the Sun shine?
fields.trailText: 6pm: Has David Yelland got the style and personality to make the Sun shine, asks Maggie Hyde.
fields.body:
The downmarket pitch of the British tabloids is world (in)famous, and the Sun remains leader of the pack with a house style set by ex-editor Higgins and the good ladies of Page 3. David Yelland's editorship since 1998 marks a cautious move towards a more informed political stance and circulation is holding, but has Yelland got the style and personality to make the Sun shine?

Yelland is a Taurean bull and his birth date (May 14 1963) shows a hard horoscope for a hard man. Tight and closed, giving little away, it has the Sun square to self-disciplined Saturn, making Yelland a heavyweight when it comes to work and responsibility. Things don't come easy with a horoscope like this, and life can feel like an uphill struggle.

"Everything is earned the hard way; nothing comes freely... this aspect builds character; but it can also lead to a sour disposition, expressed in a Spartan outlook. It can also be manifested in rigidity, and the natives may be too traditional in their approach to problems. They must cultivate the virtues of optimism and cheerfulness. " (Sackoian & Acker, The Astrologer's Handbook)

Yelland's birthday is almost exactly six months in the year away from the tabloid's Murdoch relaunch (November 17 1969), and this puts his own slow and deliberate Taurus Sun in opposition to the paper's Sun in Scorpio. It's not the best connection for an editor's ability to stay tuned to what a Scorpio readership wants - a paper that's sexy, provocative, full of human interest and above all, visual.

Both horoscopes have a passive and reactive streak, and claiming credit for Major's victory in the 1992 election - "it was the Sun wot won it" - has always been something of an illusion. The Sun's watery, Scorpio horoscope, with a fickle, Pisces Moon, isn't a leader of opinion. Like water, and like fishy Pisces Murdoch, it goes with the flow and swims along in the winning stream.

Right now, revolutionary Uranus is putting the spotlight on Yelland's Saturn, demanding that he doesn't straitjacket himself with a rigid or narrow approach. He has had to put his own politically conservative tendencies to one side to back New Labour for the coming election, and for much of this year he may not feel in control of the agenda.

June and July are turbulent months when events triggered by underworld Pluto could pull the rug from under his feet. Despite election support for New Labour, Yelland can expect little thanks afterwards from Tony Blair if the Sun keeps up its anti-Euro stance. Blair is also a Taurean and if these two bulls clash, we can expect a savage locking of horns. Yet despite his Taurus stickability, by spring 2003, Yelland could decide he's had enough. His Uranus mid-life crisis kicks in then, and he may seek a different, more political role.

Although he is probably not comfortable at the paper, he does share with it a striking planetary line-up of Mars and Saturn. The tabloid has a brutal square aspect of Saturn to its red-top Mars, and as astrologer Alan Leo says, this " encounters hostility, opposition and criticism, even from friends... (it is) indifferent to the feelings of others ...hard, cruel, spiteful, and revengeful".

Yelland's own Mars-Saturn benefits from Mars in fiery, leadership Leo, so although he can sometimes be over-competitive, this saves the aspect from the pits. According to Charles Carter, when Saturn and mars work well, people with this contact are "excellent explorers, rulers of savage tribes, or organisers of men needing firm control". Just wot an editor needs to survive at Wapping.

webTitle: Leader: A bad prison gets worse

fields.headline: A bad prison gets worse
fields.standfirst: The shameful squalor of Winson Green
fields.trailText: Suppose you were a prisoner in the "hell hole" - to use the prison director general's description - of Winson Green, Birmingham, in 1998. How would you feel about the system today?
fields.body:
Suppose you were a prisoner in the "hell hole" - to use the prison director general's description - of Winson Green, Birmingham, in 1998. How would you feel about the system today? In 1998 the chief inspector of prisons produced one of his most scathing reports. Similar reports in that year were filed on Wandsworth, Wormwood Scrubs and Feltham, which led to taskforces and action plans that earned the respect of the chief inspector. But at Winson Green, a bad prison has got even worse, as yesterday's report makes abundantly clear.

It is no longer just failing but "sick". The report documents a catalogue of appalling conditions: filth, overcrowding, the least amount of association of any prison (less than an hour a day) and low numbers in education and work, with half the prison idle every day. One mentally ill prisoner had not washed or changed his clothes for weeks. Now think of the 730 days spent by an inmate in the two years between the chief inspector's visits. Is it any wonder prisons generate such anger among their inmates?

Why is it the chief inspector uncovers conditions that area managers have failed to expose? Lord Laming was supposed to have answered this question, but failed lamentably. Who was it who sent in management consultants who proposed cuts - in already the cheapest prison - of almost £1m? And why have ministers failed to resolve the conflict between the chief inspector and director general? Both agree on the appalling conditions, but disagree about solutions. The inspector wants identified individuals to be responsible for conditions which different categories of inmates face. Paul Boateng, the prison minister, is notorious for his knee-jerk condemnations of public service failings. Why is he not facing the sack? There can be no excuse for his failure to resolve the dispute - or his failure to insist on the chief inspector's reappointment. The protection of prisoners makes this imperative.

fields.headline: Oversubscribed
fields.standfirst: Foldaway aviators
fields.trailText: Foldaway aviators
fields.body:
So many trends, only so much space in the wardrobe. If it isn't military, it's babydoll chic; if it's not sexy strong female, it's retro 80s babe. So what is the fashion fan to do? Well, thank heavens for Stella McCartney, who can always be relied upon to whip up the accessory of the season for her label Chloe, magically encompassing all possible trends into two little frames.

The influence of Chloe's first big sunglasses success (you remember - aviators, diamanté heart in corner) can still be spotted on high streets across the land, two years on - practically immortality in fashion land. Last summer's heart frames decorated all the important faces (All Saints, TP-T) and now McCartney gives us the foldaway aviators, which manage to be military (in their fold- up efficiency), vintage (oversized frames), cute (note the diamanté case) and sexy (well, they're sunglasses, aren't they?).

Best of all, they are marvellous fun to play with. Get ready to spot many a party picture of It girls twiddling with their fiddlesome frames.

 Foldaway aviators, £135, enquiries 01635 529 997.

webTitle: Bush pulls out troops as Balkans crisis deepens

fields.headline: Bush pulls out troops as Balkans crisis deepens
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: The US is pressing ahead with plans to reduce its military presence in Bosnia, Pentagon officials said yesterday, despite signs that the Nato-enforced peace in the Balkans is beginning to unravel.
fields.body:
The US is pressing ahead with plans to reduce its military presence in Bosnia, Pentagon officials said yesterday, despite signs that the Nato-enforced peace in the Balkans is beginning to unravel.

The US is reducing by 900 to 3,500 its troop contribution to Nato's stabilisation force (S-for) in Bosnia. It is also removing its 16 Apache gunship helicopters and some tanks and armoured cars, a Pentagon spokesman said yesterday. Their withdrawal had already begun.

Rear Admiral Craig Quigley did not deny a report that the Bush administration intended to reduce the US force in Bosnia by 80% over two years. But he did say no final decision had been taken. Future reductions would depend on conditions on the ground and consultations with allies.

Adm Quigley said the troop reduction was a product of the success of the peacekeeping mission. But Nato officials were stunned by the plan, which comes as instability in the Balkans is worsening. There is tension along Kosovo's borders with Macedonia and Serbia, and in Bosnia, where the five-year-old Dayton peace agreement is fraying. Bosnian Croat forces have refused to continue participating in a joint army with Muslims and yesterday signalled that they were preparing to set up a separatist administration in the south.

Campaigning last year, Mr Bush said he would reduce US military obligations abroad, and pointed particularly to the Balkans. But when the Nato secretary-general, Lord Robertson, visited Washington recently, the president assured him the US would stick to its Nato obligations and was not planning drastic cuts.

"Nato didn't get a hint of any further reductions during the secretary-general's visit. There was no indication of this," said a Nato official yesterday.

The removal of the Apaches, tanks, armoured cars and their crews had been agreed between Nato and the Clinton administration in December as part of a six-monthly review.

But many strategists in the Bush administration favour a switch from a "presence mission" in Bosnia - large enough to control any outbreak in hostilities - to a "deterrence mission" - a much smaller presence made up mainly of police with military forces ready to move in in the event of trouble.

Such a switch has been discussed for some time by Nato planners, but many in the Bush team, including the national security advisor, Condoleezza Rice, want it to take place almost immediately.

"For the US to float this idea that we can now pull out is just wrong," said Ivo Daalder, an expert on Nato and the Balkans at the Brookings Institution. "These problems in Presevo [in Serbia] and in Macedonia are in part because people there don't believe the US is going to stay. And when the federation (between Bosnian Muslims and Croats) is hitting difficulties is just the wrong time."

Adm Quigley said the situation in Macedonia was being "watched very carefully" and that a Nato rapid reaction force was standing by for "a localised beefing up of forces".

A British official said London's understanding was that most of the troops being withdrawn were in Bosnia as "force protection" (to protect other US troops) and could be removed without harming the capacity of the US contingent.

According to a report on the CBS television network, the Bush plan involves cutting the US troop presence to 1,000 within two years. The job of conducting routine foot patrols would be handed over to civilian police.

A White House official refused to comment on the report, saying only "there are a number of concepts under review, but all decisions will be taken according to the normal Nato consultation report. There will be no withdrawal."

Special report: George Bush's America

Questioned on last week's school disaster in Jiangxi province which killed several dozen children, Mr Zhu, 72, took ultimate responsibility for the government's failure to improve national safety standards. "The state council has not fulfilled its responsibility," he admitted. "I feel very sad and I carry a very heavy heart. I want to apologise and reflect on my own work."

In apologising, he regained some of the ground he had lost by previously supporting the official claim that the blast was caused by a lone "madman." Parents of the children allege that they were being forced to make fireworks in school.

Mr Zhu said yesterday that after his statement last week was challenged by foreign and domestic media, he sent a special team of investigators to the scene. They discovered that in 1999 the school made its pupils assemble fireworks under the guise of "work experience", but the practice was allegedly stopped last year.

He said there was still no evidence of fireworks being made at the time of the blast, but promised to continue investigations "until we really get the full picture". In future, he warned, local officials would be punished and sacked - including the governor of the province where a disaster occurred.

On foreign policy, he refused to show any sign of irritation with the conflicting signals towards Beijing from the Bush administration.

In a lengthy statement of China's commitment to a lasting partnership with the US, Mr Zu said that "it takes time for two sides to get to know each other". But he insisted that "the channels of exchange of views" between Presidents George Bush and Jiang Zemin were "open and unimpeded". He said Mr Bush would pay a state visit to China in October.

Significantly, he avoided polemics over the Taiwan issue, and American plans for a national missile defence (NMD) system. On Wednesday, China's chief disarmament spokesman, Sha Kukang, also took a moderate line, saying that Beijing was willing to have a "candid dialogue" with Washington on NMD.

In answer to other questions, Mr Zhu spoke of his concern for the widening income gap between China's rich and poor and the excessive taxation of peasants. He promised to enforce personal income taxes on overpaid staff in protected sectors. The maximum theoretical rate of 45% tax is widely evaded. Mr Zhu also reiterated his commitment to tax reform in the countryside, raising the official rate from 5% to 8.4% but removing local levies which can treble the farmers' burden.

He defended his "proactive" fiscal policy in running up a large budget deficit to finance infrastructure projects aimed at stimulating consumption and cutting unemployment.

This year, as in recent years, the parliament which used to be routinely dismissed as an empty "talking shop" by most foreign observers has become harder to label. Even its chairman, Li Peng - best known for his role in suppressing the 1989 student movement - said "we should do more concrete, necessary things [for the people] and give less empty and useless speeches".

Delegates yesterday showed dissatisfaction with the national budget which includes an almost 18% rise in defence spending. One in four of them voted against or abstained.

fields.headline: French evolution
fields.standfirst: Forget sudden, sweeping trends: the Paris shows signal a gradual shift in the way we wear. Jess Cartner-Morley reports
fields.trailText: Forget sudden, sweeping trends: the Paris shows signal a gradual shift in the way we wear. Jess Cartner-Morley reports.
fields.body:
Extrapolating trends from fashion shows is an imprecise science. Sometimes it works: if nine out of 10 designers show miniskirts, we can safely assume that miniskirts are In. At other times, however, it can feel like trying to read social trends from soap operas: "bullying is the new bulimia", you might deduce, or "murder is so last season". In real life, it doesn't work like that. This season has no pithy, wipe-the-slate-clean New Look. There are some items that are likely to translate on to the high street - boots to just over the knee, for instance - but which will not deliver a new image singlehandedly.

That's not to say it's been a dull week. Far from it: Paris has been full of ideas. But these shows have not been about sudden, sweeping trends; rather they have been about the more gradual shifts in fashion, the ones that mould and shape your wardrobe over seasons. For instance, reading between the headline pieces, it becomes clear that one of the major shifts of the past year has been to a new dressing-up formula: the pretty, draped blouse in a luxurious fabric, worn with trousers either skintight or straight.

As a "modern evening" look, this is taking over from the beaded-skirt-and-cashmere-cardigan combination that swept the board a few years ago. It is a way of dealing with increasingly relaxed sartorial rules. As Celine designer Michael Kors put it this week: "The time of day is disappearing."

At Chloe, Stella McCartney has a sure eye for outfits that are a little too chichi and glossy for day but not quite proper enough for night - and therefore always look cool. Using the motifs of Paris fashion but with a light touch, she added pearls as dangling epaulettes on off-the-shoulder blouses, worn with slouchy trousers.

Emanuel Ungaro went a similar route. This label has bounced back from naffness, bringing up to date the prettiness with which it has always been associated: butterfly appliqués are beautiful and feminine but always asym metrically placed, always a little outsized, so look modern rather than prissy. The dresses were gorgeous - black silk chiffon, bare at one shoulder, bias-cut to the knee, decorated with branches and buds in ivory and scarlet velvet - but for more relaxed glamour there was a red silk chiffon blouse with silk crepe trousers, or a black asymmetric top with softly tailored jade silk trousers.

Valentino is never a designer who pays attention to trends, so this was a perfect season for him. His customers know what suits them and are not about to be distracted by bumblebee stripes or distressed fabrics, however fashionable they might be. The eveningwear inspires awe as to these women's lifestyles (to what event exactly would one wear a black tulle sequined dress coat with double layer in lace?) and the daywear is dressier than most designers' evening gowns. Mink-trimmed ivory lace blouses with satin trousers gave a moneyed look to the blouse-and-trouser idea.

Dries van Noten's was a strong collection: clean-lined, light, wearable, never frumpy. Colour combinations centred on white with peach, cream with sky blue. Elegant trousers and printed silks were teamed with pale, luxurious boots and coats. At Celine, lingerie-esque garments were worn with outdoorsy fabrics: a lace-trim satin camisole with tight jeans, a tartan jacket, fur collar and tiny, shiny handbag. The look was Lumberjack Luxe: Kors' favourite all-American staples of denim, knits and leather given an uptown gloss.

At Yves Saint Laurent, Tom Ford combined a diplomatic reverence for the YSL heritage with his own keen eye for what works now. Using a moody black and purple palette, he took elements from Saint Laurent's bohemian-ethnic era but made them sleek rather than folky.

Sculptured, elegant tailoring abounded this week. Jackets featured curving hems, cutaway at the front to make the silhouette barer. Coats were streamlined and striking, with funnel necklines and sleek, straight shapes: high-necked and military at Vuitton, cosy in cream at Dries van Noten and Chloe. There were excellent dresses, from Dries van Noten's 30s print silks, which wrap around the neck like a silk scarf, to Chloe's asymmetric, curvy lacquered satin. Asymmetry was everywhere, in fact: knee-length has been usurped by knee-length with a bit trailing down the calf.

Cacharel's teenage take on French dressing - "cari-couture" - featured delicious wrapped and draped dresses as well as witty trompe l'oeil-effect separates. With Chloe becoming more grown up every season, perhaps Cacharel will take over the old-style Chloe mantle of London-in-Paris cheekiness. As Cacharel designer Inacio Ribeiro put it: "If Cacharel is going to have a relevance on the calendar, it will be for being high-spirited and fun, cutesy but still cool."

The idea of clothes gradually changing shape, rather than being unceremoniously dumped and replaced, was reflected in the work of Hussein Chalayan. With no show this season, the collection was available to view in the showroom and was described by the designer as "a journey in clothing": one black wool coat had a sliver of denim, almost hidden under the collar; the next a slice of denim; the next a whole section. Exquisitely thought-out and made, each piece stood on its own. There was also a theme of outfits cut and spliced: a "shirt dress" with cotton shirt blending into crepe mini; a pair of trousers with shirt-tails attached.

Jean Paul Gaultier had a very similar idea: jackets had their arms cut off and hung from silver threads; a coat was cut in two to make a voluminous cropped jacket and a wrapped, buttoned skirt. A strange look, but pedestrian compared with those at Christian Dior, where John Galliano experimented with sharp, slightly sleazy trouser suits and ethnic bohemian embroidery. This was a feast for the eyes: a kimono-print silk coat with mink trim was combined with a huge Peruvian-style hat and sheer beaded tulle skirt.

Renowned oddball Oliver Theyskens left his experimental image behind and sent out glamorous dresses in flowing chiffon. Issey Miyake, however, can be relied on never to switch to nice dresses. His sculptured coat of puckered, gathered fabric, with red daubed face and floor-length Medusa wig of glittering red flowers, was catwalk theatre pure and simple, no trend intended.

fields.headline: Taking to the piste
fields.standfirst: Chanel for ladies who ski as well as lunch
fields.trailText: Who says you have to suffer for fashion? At Chanel you can wrap up warm and still be the height of fashion next winter.
fields.body:
Who says you have to suffer for fashion? At Chanel you can wrap up warm and still be the height of fashion next winter.

First on the catwalk was a classic patch-pocketed skirt suit, in peach and white check with pipe trim - but worn with over-high patent boots instead of court shoes, and with a huge white fur muff and earmuffs emblazoned with the label's "double C" logo.

This was a collection for ladies who ski as well as lunch. No conceivable element of the perfect Chamonix wardrobe was left uncatered for: there was even a bride in a white quilted wedding dress, clutching a muff instead of a bouquet, accompanied by a groom in snowsuit and goggles holding a Chanel logo-ed snowboard. They were followed by bridesmaids and attendants wearing ski jumpers and gloves, and bobble hats appliqued with the Chanel camellia.

Off-piste wear was equally young and unstuffy: a snowflake-patterned micro sweaterdress came with matching snood. There were even jeans and denim jackets.

There were also plenty of the skirt suits and coats the label is renowned for: a double breasted cropped jacket in red and white fleck boucle was worn with a matching pleated miniskirt; and a swingy, glitter-woven cream tweed and fur coat. The irreverent mood held sway, with hemlines at mid-thigh and suits scattered with cute reindeer badges.

Chanel's designer, Karl Lagerfeld, is a fashion grand master, and well understands that the right accessories are crucial not only to image but to profits. Metallic silver boots plastered with the Chanel logo replaced traditional court shoes. Instead of pearl chokers were diamante gun necklaces and pearls shifted to the ankle as the ankle strap of spike heeled shoes.

webTitle: Macedonia tries to smoke out insurgents

fields.headline: Macedonia tries to smoke out insurgents
fields.standfirst:
Crisis in the Balkans Shells set fire to mountain oak woods as rebel gunmen attack city

Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Macedonian artillery set a mountain ablaze yesterday to flush out ethnic Albanian guerrillas who carried their insurgency into the city of Tetovo, stoking fears of a new Balkan conflagration.
fields.byline: Rory Carroll and  Nicholas Wood  in Tetovo
fields.body:
Macedonian artillery set a mountain ablaze yesterday to flush out ethnic Albanian guerrillas who carried their insurgency into the city of Tetovo, stoking fears of a new Balkan conflagration.

Incendiary shells blasted Mt Baltepe as police and army units traded gunfire with rebels overlooking the city's northern suburbs, in a second day of fighting which turned Macedonian Slavs against their ethnic Albanian neighbours.

Smoke from at least a dozen fires plumed above Tetovo as Slav residents evacuated the Koltuk neighbourhood, vowing revenge on the guerrillas and their supporters.

Ethnic Albanians cowering in the streets blamed years of Macedonian discrimination for triggering the insurgency, which started in remote mountain villages two weeks ago. Troops were accused of targeting civilians.

Russia joined Nato and the EU in condemning the self-styled National Liberation Army (NLA), but the rebels, hidden in the mountain's oak forests, are expected to resume their assault today.

Security forces used 120mm mortars and anti-aircraft guns mounted on armoured personnel carriers to pound the unseen gunmen, who responded with Kalashnikovs and - according to police - rocket launchers.

Fears that the guerrillas may succeed in igniting civil war appeared justified as Macedonian civilians grew enraged as the bullets whined overhead. Streets emptied as the bombardment intensified.

"We want guns from the government to fight these Albanians. They want our land, our homes, and we need to repel them. Give me a machine gun and I'll go into the woods to fight them," said Dragan Brkic. "Macedonians cannot wait any longer. This is real war here. I have Albanian friends but now we must strike back. I'd say 85% of Albanians support these guys."

A crowd surged around a policeman to demand arms. A bus of Albanians returning from Mecca was stoned by children on Wednesday.

Ministers met in the capital Skopje to discuss putting up a security buffer against mountain borders and declaring a state of emergency. Nato officials are sceptical that Macedonia's tiny army, which has no combat experience, can snuff out the insurgency. Its airforce is three helicopters.

Ministers said the rebels' aim was to annex western and northern Macedonia, which have Albanian majorities, into a greater Kosovo. Other Albanian militants with links to the NLA has been waging a guerrilla war against Yugoslav troops in southern Serbia.

Two civilians were injured in yesterday's clashes, but it was not known if the rebels had suffered casualties. Fifteen Macedonian police officers were injured on Wednesday.

Daja Ali, an NLA representative, said Macedonian forces had shelled his group's positions in mountains further west in the morning. "There are no injured on our side. We are waiting for the right moment to teach them a lesson," he said

In Tetovo one elderly man, who abandoned his mountain villa as rebels approached, wept as his vines disappeared into smoke.

Just 40 yards down the street, three Albanian neighbours sheltered behind a wall as army snipers took up positions. War was not desirable but the rebels were justified in seeking to redress discrimination, they said, echoing other Albanian interviewees.

Pointing to an elderly Macedonian couple sheltering behind a soldier, a 34-year-old Albanian named Dani said: "I don't want people to die, but I can't deny pleasure in having the boot on the other foot."

"We have nothing - no jobs, no prospects. They've had it well for too long," a 22-year-old said. Albanian flags - a black eagle on a red background - sprouted from houses.

Outside No 20 Qarshia e Eperme, a three-storey house, a martyr was declared. Sulejman Ramadani, 42, a married teacher with two young sons, was shot dead outside his front door on Wednesday night. Mourners inspecting the bloodstained sand were adamant that he was killed by Macedonians, though this was impossible to confirm.

In the living room, women in white headscarves washed his body and wrapped it in the Albanian flag. The cracks of gunfire and whooshes of artillery punctuated a Muslim cleric's prayers in the court yard below, where about 100 men were gathered.

Halim Halimi, 50, a professor of Albanian and the dead man's brother-in-law, said Albanians would no longer tolerate being second-class citizens. "It's not just one year, it's been over a century of discrimination," he said.

Macedonia's president, Boris Trajkovski, said his government would crush the guerrillas: "The fight against them will not stop and we will not give up. We will isolate them politically and militarily."

As the fighting wore on, shots could be heard targeting a police post on the edge of the Albanian-dominated area. Police responded with heavy calibre machine gun-fire.

The government admitted it was struggling to contain the rebels. "They have equal quality and quantity of weapons [as Macedonian forces]," said a spokesman for the interior ministry. "We have rocket launchers, they have them as well. They are fully equipped and very mobile, and have support from local inhabitants."

fields.headline: Rebellious kinsmen upset mainstream Albanian politicians
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: The sudden outburst of fighting by Albanian gunmen near Macedonia's second city, Tetovo, has caught Balkan politicians by surprise, not least the main Albanian political leaders in Macedonia and nearby Kosovo.
fields.body:
The sudden outburst of fighting by Albanian gunmen near Macedonia's second city, Tetovo, has caught Balkan politicians by surprise, not least the main Albanian political leaders in Macedonia and nearby Kosovo.

Macedonia has until now been the most peaceful of the former Yugoslav republics which became independent in the early 1990s. It has an Albanian minority of 22.9%, according to a 1994 census, though the true current figure could be up to one-third. The Macedonian majority is Slav.

Since Macedonia's independence, Albanian political demands have largely centred on language and cultural rights. They want the Macedonian constitution to be changed to drop the preamble that Macedonia is "the national state of the Macedonian people" and recognise that it is multiracial, with equal rights for all peoples, including Albanians, Turks, and Roma.

Unusually for a Balkan state, Macedonia has a bi-ethnic coalition government. In an act of ethnic tolerance and political wisdom, the more radical of the two Albanian political parties, the Democratic Party of Albanians (DPA), was invited into government after the 1998 election. It has engineered some key changes. The Macedonian government has agreed to recognise the private Albanian-language EU-funded university in Tetovo, which has a large Albanian majority. An Albanian was appointed to be chief of police for the first time in Tetovo.

All this makes the current crisis doubly unexpected. It suggests that the fighting is the work of a handful of marginal men. It is not part of a general upsurge in favour of changing Balkan borders and creating a so-called greater Albania. The Albanian government is as alarmed as western politicians and Ilir Meta, its prime minister, yesterday condemned the gunmen and urged restraint.

Although ethnic feelings are close to the surface in Macedonia, where Albanians and Macedonians tend to lead separate lives, this does not mean that every Albanian wants independence or secession, or to join Kosovo or Albania.

The fighting is not connected to the trouble in the Presevo valley of southern Serbia, where Albanian gunmen took control of the buffer zone imposed when Nato forced Yugoslav troops to leave Kosovo in 1999. "Unlike the commanders in Presevo, who have come forward and are well known, no one here is sure who the commander of the extremists in Macedonia is," an editor at Koha Ditore, a leading Albanian newspaper in Pristina said.

One of their political masterminds is thought to be Emrush Xhemaili, the leader of the People's Movement of Kosovo (LPK). The LPK is a tiny party which won less than 1% of the vote in last autumn's elections in Kosovo. Its motive in supporting the fighting in Macedonia could be a mistaken belief that it will win more backing than at the ballot box.

The US Balkans envoy, James Pardew, met Mr Xhemaili on Wednesday to warn him not to support the gunmen. "All of these actions outside of Kosovo coming from Kosovo undermine the international community, and we're urging these leaders to be leaders, to express within the local community how much damage this is causing," Mr Pardew said. "We were very direct with Mr Xhemaili and the LPK that people should be focused internally on Kosovo."

fields.headline: Lowenbrau to adopt a hip new image
fields.trailText: 10.45am: The new owner of Lowenbrau lager is to relaunch it as a youth brand with a major marketing push, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The new owner of Lowenbrau lager is to relaunch it as a youth brand with a major marketing campaign.

An advertising campaign, scheduled to launch next month, will focus on the brand's German roots.

Poster sites and press slots have been booked but Refresh UK, the company that distributes Lowenbrau in the UK, is keeping the details of the campaign firmly under wraps.

The advertising will promote the fact Refresh UK is to stop brewing Lowenbrau Premium in the UK in favour of importing the stronger Lowenbrau Original from Munich.

Refresh UK has created the campaign in-house and has hired AMV Advance to handle PR for the relaunch.

webTitle: Oscar favourites line up for Renaissance romance

fields.headline: Oscar favourites line up for Renaissance romance
fields.trailText: Juliette Binoche and Benicio Del Toro will lead the cast of the film version of the controversial book, The Asumption of the Virgin
fields.body:
Two recent Oscar winners and two nominees are among the impressive cast lined up to star in a new romantic epic. Variety reports that Juliette Binoche and Geoffrey Rush (both Oscar winners who are nominated again this year), in addition to Benicio Del Toro and Chloe Sevigny are in final negotiations to star in the film, which is to be directed by Central Station helmer Walter Salles.

The movie, which is based on the Katie Campbell novel, The Assumption of the Virgin, is being scripted by Anthony Minghella and Leigh Jackson. Set in Florence during the Renaissance, the film will tell the story of the taboo romance between the painter, Fra Lippi, to be played by Del Toro, and the nun who posed for him (Binoche).

"Lippi is a hedonistic, extraordinarily physical guy who, even though he's a monk, is a notorious womaniser who fell in love with a deeply religious nun," Sydney Pollack, who is executive producing the film with Minghella, told Variety.

The film is set to start shooting in the autumn (as long as the strike by actors and writers in Hollywood is either settled or averted).

fields.headline: Publicis revenues soar
fields.trailText: 11am: Shares in French advertising giant Publicis rose this morning on the back of better-than-expected full-year results, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Shares in the French advertising giant Publicis rose this morning on the back of better-than-expected full-year results for 2000.

The company, which last year bought Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi, shrugged off the US economic slump to post a 72% rise in revenues to £1.12bn and said it was set for a bumper year in 2001.

Publicis bought Saatchi and Nelson Communications last year, boosting its presence in the European market.

"We have unique assets allowing us to continue our growth at a rate exceeding the overall market. The signs of deceleration seen in the American market have been taken into account," said Maurice Levy, chairman of Publicis.

The lack of serious damage from the US market will please investors who have watched revenues at media groups fall off the chart due to a drastic slowdown in advertising growth across the Atlantic.

"The year has started under good auspices, with some excellent campaign wins like the one for the euro launch, and some new budgets such as United Airlines, Informix and Renault in South Korea and Japan," the company said in its results statement.

Outside Europe, Publicis said it would spend the next 12 months building up its position in the Asian market.

Europe provides 50% of the group's revenues, with the US accounting for 39%.

webTitle: Debate rages over rights of way policy

fields.headline: Debate rages over rights of way policy
fields.standfirst: Ramblers Access rules differ across the country
fields.trailText: Huge discrepancies in reactions to the crisis by local authorities are emerging as the government's rural recovery taskforce urgently looks at which parts of the countryside need to be closed to the public.
fields.body:
Huge discrepancies in reactions to the crisis by local authorities are emerging as the government's rural recovery taskforce urgently looks at which parts of the countryside need to be closed to the public.

"There is a very big debate going on at the moment about rights of way," said Ewen Cameron, the chairman of the countryside agency and a member of the taskforce.

Many authorities have imposed blanket closures on footpaths in their areas, with devastating effects on rural life. Only 15 of 125 local authorities contacted by the countryside agency said they had taken care to close only rights of way in risk areas.

"People have been confused in the absence of clear advice about what they can and can't do," said a spokesman for the English tourism council.

About 50 local authorities have applied blanket closures to rights of way, many in areas where there are no confirmed outbreaks. Buckinghamshire, East Sussex and Lincolnshire have closed all rights of way, including those in urban areas, although they have no outbreaks."We have done it as a blanket ban, as a precaution," said an East Sussex county council spokesman.

Bedfordshire, Norfolk, and Suffolk, which are also free of foot and mouth so far, have closed rights of way in rural areas but kept urban routes open.

Yet in Northumberland, where the outbreak was first identified, and on Exmoor and Dartmoor in Devon, which has seen several outbreaks, rights of way were closed only where land was or had been grazed by livestock.

The risk of the disease being transmitted by walkers on footpaths is "low but not zero", said Professor Colin Blackstock, the director of the government's institute of animal health. "Is it appropriate to close all footpaths across all of the country? I think it is right to close them where they go over farm land where there might have been contact with susceptible animals."

The ministry of agriculture put in place statutory powers to enable local authorities to close rights of way at the end of February but decisions were delegated to local level.

"Veterinary advice is available to local councils. General guidance is that people should avoid contact with livestock. Maff's role is to manage the outbreak, not to dictate to councils what to do," said a ministry spokesman.

The National Trust and English Heritage, two of Britain's largest rural landlords, have adopted different policies.

The National Trust has closed all but 16 of its 630 properties (the exceptions being those in urban areas), and all its 240,000 hectares of land. But English Heritage, which has 409 properties, has only closed the 180 in or near areas with confirmed outbreaks.

Both organisations said yesterday they believed they were following government guidelines.

fields.headline: US isolationism increases under Bush
fields.standfirst: International pressure may demand further US involvement in the Balkans, but Bush's administration has other priorities, writes Martin Kettle
fields.trailText: 16 March: International pressure may demand further US involvement in the Balkans, but Bush's administration has other priorities, writes Martin Kettle.
fields.body:
There is little doubt that the Bush administration wants to get out of the Balkans, first from Bosnia and then from Kosovo. That is why this week's not very widely reported announcement that the administration is planning to pull out some tanks and around 750 troops from Bosnia has to be taken seriously.

It is the first step in fulfilling a wish that many Republicans have shared ever since Bill Clinton committed the US in the region as part of the Dayton accords. It will be followed by others, and together they will present a major challenge for Europe.

To understand why the US wants out, it is important to recognise the depth of contempt among Republicans for the Clinton administration's Balkans policy. The Republicans are sceptical about the existence of a clear US interest in the region and are downright angry about what they see as the absence of an obvious US aim in maintaining some 9,000 US troops there for peacekeeping duties that could continue for many years.

As modern Republicans tend to, they also believe their own rhetoric, which claims that the US is carrying the military weight of a policy that is rightfully Europe's responsibility. That 85% of the Nato forces in Kosovo are European is a fact not often mentioned, or even acknowledged, in the US.

During the election campaign, George Bush was careful not to say outright that he would bring the boys home from the Balkans. However, he repeatedly attacked the over-commitment of US troops in local conflicts, and he and his advisers regularly denounced the idea of using US troops for what they called "nation-building".

One adviser, Condoleezza Rice, now the White House national security adviser, actually went on the record during the campaign to say the troops should and would come out.

Some Europeans have convinced themselves that they have succeeded in dissuading the administration from such a pull out. But they are wrong. The views expressed by Rice on the campaign trail were not an aberration; they were an unguarded reflection of the Bush camp's true views.

They are widely shared, including by vice president Dick Cheney and defence secretary Donald Rumsfeld. The signs point overwhelmingly to a will to withdraw. Anyone who listened to Rumsfeld in his press conference in Washington last week with Lord Robertson, the Nato secretary general, would have heard a man who plainly sees the Balkans as nothing but trouble.

When he took over at the Pentagon two months ago, the new defence secretary circulated his subordinates with a document entitled Rumsfeld's Rules, a collection of aphorisms and commonplaces that Rumsfeld has collected over the years. And there, on page one of Rumsfeld's Rules is the observation that sums up post-Vietnam US defence thinking: "It is easier to get into something than to get out of it".

In the Balkans, the Bush administration believes that Clinton has dumped them in a situation that they want to get out of. As Rumsfeld's rule reminds us, however, that is easy to say and hard to do. But that in turn is why this week's latest Bosnia pullout move is significant and why further reports in the US yesterday, that the administration has decided to reduce its Bosnia troop commitment from the present 4,400 to under 1,000 within months, are also credible.

For the moment, these planned withdrawals do not affect Kosovo. But there are signs of a basic lack of US will there, too. Rumsfeld has conspicuously not used the sorts of words that the secretary of state Colin Powell has used - like "stay the course" - and he has prevented US troops from becoming too involved in the current problems on the Kosovo-Serbia-Macedonia borders. Every day of fierce fighting there increases Washington's resolve not to stick around.

Nowadays the official US position is that it will not make a precipitous withdrawal - hardly the most ringing declaration of solidarity that one has ever heard.

It is by no means the case that even Powell is as committed to the continuing US presence as he has been interpreted as being. Anyone who has read Powell's memoirs will remember the blistering indictments of "the pseudopolicy of establishing a US 'presence' without a defined mission in trouble spots", as he described the Clinton administration's Bosnia policy.

It was Powell's reluctance to get involved in Bosnia that sparked Madeleine Albright's angry comment to him: "What's the point of having this superb military that you're always talking about if we can't use it?"

If the situation on the Macedonian border continues to deteriorate, Washington will come under pressure to increase its involvement. The signs are that its response will be the exact opposite. This administration does not seek an extended role in Europe. Its concerns are in the Middle East and in Asia.

Not having wanted to be in the Balkans in the first place, the Bush administration may even welcome the latest crisis in Macedonia as a catalyst in the process of accelerated withdrawal that began this week.

As another of Rumsfeld's Rules puts it: "If in doubt - don't."

webTitle: Leader: A date for your diary

fields.headline: A date for your diary
fields.standfirst: May 3 is still feasible. But do not bet on it
fields.trailText: Enough of this nonsense, says number 10 with its usual robustness: elections will go ahead on May 3 as planned, despite foot and mouth. Some of the neighbours are not so sure. As we reported yesterday, Gordon Brown, Labour's chief election strategist, thinks the decision is on a knife edge.
fields.body:
Enough of this nonsense, says number 10 with its usual robustness: elections will go ahead on May 3 as planned, despite foot and mouth. Some of the neighbours are not so sure. As we reported yesterday, Gordon Brown, Labour's chief election strategist, thinks the decision is on a knife edge. It is right that this tension is there. There are solid arguments both for going ahead and for postponing - and time for the picture to change before the final decision day, 10 days from now.

The immediate issue is what to do about the local elections due to take place on the traditional date, the first Thursday in May. Few governments have departed from that, except in wartime; the most recent was the Conservatives in 1986, scrapping the elections to the doomed GLC. Only in very exceptional circumstances, when substantial numbers are likely to be effectively disenfranchised, should the usual rules be rescinded. There are parts of the countryside where that point is approaching, though the problems are much less formidable than they once would have been. Much canvassing is by telephone. The right to vote by post has been widely extended. Even in local contests, media coverage is more likely to sway the outcome than traditional doorstep canvassing. Yet some areas feel besieged. People are holding back from making all but the most necessary journeys - and resent those who make them. How much of the country is in this psychological state is hard to measure. But if the blight continues to spread in these next 10 days, the case for postponement will grow.

But May 3 is also the almost unchallenged date for the general election. Here the date is not fixed. It will happen when Tony Blair thinks it suits his party advantage. The Tories fear May 3. They now especially fear that Labour may go ahead on the basis that the Tories would lose more from having the election during the outbreak than Labour would. Mr Hague, who does not want to seem chicken, has held back from demanding postponement, but his cheerleader newspapers are doing it for him, asserting that to ask the nation to make its choice in conditions like these would be fundamentally indecent and undemocratic. The Telegraph is even trying to tag it "the carcass election". It is argued in terms of principle, but here too the case is all about party advantage.

One might have hoped that the new electoral commission would have some part in holding the ring. In fact it is given no right to dispute the prime minister's choice of date. The most it has done so far is to signal its likely concern should voters be effectively disenfranchised. Though powerless to stop that happening, it would have the right to declare in its post-election report that this had occurred and that the election, to this extent, had fallen below desirable levels of fairness. (What joy that judgment would bring to governments like Zimbabwe's!)

There is, too, a further judge of how the government handles this issue: the electorate. If the sense develops in rural Britain that this government has for party advantage cheated the rural voter and tilted the balance still further towards the urban majority, Labour's vote in its 180 rural or semi-rural seats is likely to suffer. Some of its MPs fear this already. So whatever the hardline rulings, these matters are not yet settled. As things stand today, it is probably right to press on with the local elections - which would clearly open the way for a May 3 general election too. But issues of taste and propriety will also come in to the final balance. Though harder to quantify, they are a central part of politics too.

fields.headline: Salmon unveils sports strategy
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The sports chief wants to restore viewer confidence in the BBC as a real player in the sports field, reports Dan Milmo.
Mar 13: BBC to swipe rugby rights from Sky
fields.body:
Tennis, snooker, golf and athletics are being hailed as the new crown jewels of sport on BBC2.

Sports chief Peter Salmon wants to make them as synonymous with the channel as racing and Italian football are with Channel 4.

After losing Premiership football highlights and a string of other top sports, the BBC is developing a strategy that involves picking other sports such as boxing and rugby and hyping the sports already in its portfolio.

"We want to be seen as the owner of certain sports, particularly on BBC2. Channel 4 has done this very successfully," said an insider.

Mr Salmon said he will give tennis a higher profile in the corporation's programming.

He plans to boost the BBC's tennis coverage beyond Wimbledon fortnight.

"We have a fantastic asset in Wimbledon and one of my jobs is to strengthen the impact of tennis.

"I want BBC2 to extend its coverage of the sport," he said.

"We need to provide real quality. I think we are looking for the BBC to dominate more high-profile sports.

"I am very keen BBC2 dominates sports such as snooker, tennis, golf and athletics," he added.

Mr Salmon said he wanted to add the US Open to the BBC's portfolio of tennis events, which includes the French and Australian Opens.

"We need to build a profile for the sport. But where is the next generation of UK tennis players coming from? We are actively working with the Lawn Tennis Association to encourage take-up of tennis and increase coverage of the sport," he explained.

The BBC is frantically playing catch-up with ITV, which has raced away with the broadcasting rights to Formula One and football Premiership highlights.

Mr Salmon is working on a wide-ranging strategy to reverse the corporation's fortunes and this will soon be submitted to the board of governors for approval.

The BBC believes it has already turned the corner but more needs to be done to restore confidence among viewers that the corporation is a real player in the sports field.

Related stories

Mar 13: BBC to swipe rugby rights from Sky

webTitle: Princess Diana considered role in Bodyguard sequel

fields.headline: Princess Diana considered role in Bodyguard sequel
fields.trailText: Kevin Costner has revealed that he had talked to the Princess of Wales about appearing in a follow-up to the 1992 blockbuster
fields.body:
Kevin Costner has revealed that Princess Diana was set to take a role in the sequel to The Bodyguard. According to Reuters, Costner, who starred in the original film with Whitney Houston, had talked to the late Princess of Wales about the role and she was "genuinely excited" by it.

"I had talked with Princess Di a couple of times," said Costner, who is in London promoting Thirteen Days. "I explained to her that I was going to try to make this movie for her and she was genuinely interested."

Costner, 46, told Michael Parkinson that the Princess had not committed to the movie, but he said the sequel would have broken new ground if Diana had agreed to appear. He added that he received the final draft of the script on the day Princess Diana was killed, August 31 1997.

"I was devastated by it," said Costner. "She was a very graceful woman and it is a great loss to all of us."

 For more on Kevin Costner.

webTitle: Hanif Kureishi on his musical tastes

fields.headline: 'Music was our common culture in the 60s and 70s'
fields.standfirst: Hanif Kureishi explains the influence of music on his work
fields.trailText: Hanif Kureishi
fields.body:
Pop music has always held sway over Hanif Kureishi's novels, from the summer of punk that dictated the mood of his debut, The Buddha of Suburbia, to the raves and ecstasy of The Black Album, right up to the returning 1970s rock star and the failed musician father of the title character of his latest, Gabriel's Gift. "Music was our common culture in the 1960s and 1970s," he says in explanation. "The only thing we talked about was pop and in those days it was exciting and new - there was Hendrix and the Rolling Stones and so on, and a whole culture went with it: the drugs, the parties, the clothes, the sexuality, even politics.

"I was reading Milan Kundera's The Joke this morning and remembered how Vaclav Havel was influenced by the Velvet Underground. So if you are to write about that time, you have to write about pop."

Kureishi's boy Kier, aged two and a half, whose favourite song is the Beatles' Yellow Submarine, is keen to show us his toy car while his father explains the role of music in his life, and you have to wonder whether pop music could ever mean as much to Kier's generation as it did to Kureishi's.

"Pop music has more power now, but only in terms of selling things. Back then, a lot of groups stood for what was then known as the alternative lifestyle, and the Rolling Stones were political just by being so rebellious. The period between Elvis and punk was a huge renaissance, and pop for us was like the cinema for previous generations - people like Stephen Frears [director of the Kureishi-scripted My Beautiful Laundrette], for whom US movies and film stars were the fantasy."

As much as anything, it was an escape route: "I was a suburban boy whose job it was to work in a bank or in customs and excise, but I didn't. Nor did John Lennon or Pete Townshend. Pop showed that there was another way to live your life. You get so fed up with getting up every day and going to school - the goal was that there would be a day when you get up and do what you want, as pop stars did. Unfortunately, I was a very bad musician, so I ended up writing about boys in bands rather than being one."

In the room where Kureishi writes, piles of CDs surround his desk, and there is a lot of classical and contemporary music alongside David Bowie, Arto Lindsay, Miles Davis, John Coltrane, Dylan and Radiohead. "I listen to music from the minute I sit down at seven in the morning, and I'll carry on working through to lunchtime with headphones on. I'll start with Bach or equally gentle classical music, then move on to Mahler, then some Miles Davis, then maybe Led Zeppelin. Recently I've been listening to a lot of American music, like John Adams, Terry Riley, Steve Reich - musicians known as the Serialists. It's good for listening to when writing, because it chugs along quite monotonously."

For Kureishi, music is an essential element of the working day: "I've been sitting in front of a computer for years and I will do it for another 30 years, and it bores the arse off me. Music cheers me up. Someone like Arvo Part, a modern composer I really love, although he's Polish and really miserable."

David Bowie, especially around the Berlin period of Station to Station and Low, is a continued favourite, and an influence on the writing. "I think it was very sophisticated, and knowing - it somehow encapsulated the history of music within it."

The rock star that Gabriel idolises in Gabriel's Gift is very Bowie-like. "I worked with him when he did the soundtrack to The Buddha of Suburbia TV series. He's really fantastic and very hard-working - he'd be in the studio all through the night. I remember he came round here once and asked me if I would pop out and buy him some fags. I said, 'Why don't we both go to the shops?' He explained that he couldn't go to the shops. We had lunch once and passed a building site, and all of the builders ran to the front of the site and stood there, screaming and shouting. A very strange life."

Kureishi is known best for his generational writing - fathers and sons figure heavily. Unsurprisingly, perhaps, it seems that his own identity, as something separate from that of his father's, was to an extent forged by musical choices. "I used to hate Dean Martin for the reason that my father liked him, although we both agreed on some black American music like Otis Redding and Sam Cooke.

"But I don't think the younger generation have the prejudices we had - my two seven-year-old boys like the Beatles, although their favourite group is SClub7. People with no clothes on as far as I can work out."

fields.headline: A bad prison gets worse
fields.standfirst: The shameful squalor of Winson Green
fields.trailText: Suppose you were a prisoner in the 'hell hole' - to use the prison director general's description - of Winson Green, Birmingham, in 1998. How would you feel about the system today?
fields.body:
Suppose you were a prisoner in the "hell hole" - to use the prison director general's description - of Winson Green, Birmingham, in 1998. How would you feel about the system today? In 1998 the chief inspector of prisons produced one of his most scathing reports. Similar reports in that year were filed on Wandsworth, Wormwood Scrubs and Feltham, which led to taskforces and action plans that earned the respect of the chief inspector. But at Winson Green, a bad prison has got even worse, as yesterday's report makes abundantly clear.

It is no longer just failing but "sick". The report documents a catalogue of appalling conditions: filth, overcrowding, the least amount of association of any prison (less than an hour a day) and low numbers in education and work, with half the prison idle every day. One mentally ill prisoner had not washed or changed his clothes for weeks. Now think of the 730 days spent by an inmate in the two years between the chief inspector's visits. Is it any wonder prisons generate such anger among their inmates?

Why is it the chief inspector uncovers conditions that area managers have failed to expose? Lord Laming was supposed to have answered this question, but failed lamentably. Who was it who sent in management consultants who proposed cuts - in already the cheapest prison - of almost £1m? And why have ministers failed to resolve the conflict between the chief inspector and director general? Both agree on the appalling conditions, but disagree about solutions. fields.trailText:
10am: The odds on Jack Dee winning Celebrity Big Brother have shortened after his emotional reunion with his wife, writes Claire Cozens.
Mar 14: 10.6m tune see Vanessa go
Mar 14: Julie Burchill on Big Brother

The story in pictures
Special report: Big Brother

fields.body:
The odds on Jack Dee winning Comic Relief's Celebrity Big Brother have shortened still further after his brief but emotional reunion with his wife was shown on Channel 4 last night.

Bookmaker William Hill slashed its odds on Dee winning to 10-11 this morning after being flooded with calls from people wanting to put their money on the deadpan comedian.

Dee is now the firm favourite to win, ahead of Brookside's Claire Sweeney on 7-4. Boyzone's Keith Duffy remains the outsider at 9-4.

The comedian has made repeated requests to the nation to set him free, but now believes the public will keep him in the house as a joke.

Dee won viewers' hearts when he yelled "I love you" at his wife in front of millions of TV viewers in last night's show.

He briefly escaped from the Big Brother house to run to hug his wife before being dragged back.

But his misery at still being in the house was showing last night as he told fellow contestants, "You learn so much about yourself when you're incarcerated".

Quite how much hardship the three remaining contestants are having to endure was today in doubt after press reports suggested they enjoyed £250-worth of fine food and wine.

Far from surviving on beans on toast, the reports claimed the celebrities had ordered in stilton cheese and mangoes and quaffed four bottles of Chablis, a chardonnay and some red wine.

One of the three remaining contestants will be evicted today. A winner will be declared tonight and released along with the remaining celebrity.

Bookies say they have been swamped with bets on Celebrity Big Brother because of restrictions on horse racing due to the outbreak of foot and mouth disease.

fields.headline: Nonconformist tough guys
fields.standfirst: Guardian editors and other stroppy radicals are profiled by the BBC in its history of the middle classes
fields.trailText: Guardian editors and other stroppy radicals are profiled by the BBC in its history of the middle classes, writes Martin Wainright.
fields.body:
The Guardian takes a bow tonight in the latest episode of the BBC's history of the middle classes, a link which will prompt a ghostly sneer from the grave of George Condy, long-forgotten editor of the Manchester and Salford Advertiser.

He described his rival, in May 1836, as the "foul prostitute and dirty parasite of the worst portion of the mill-owners" - not the first, and certainly not the last time that middle-class radicalism has been underestimated.

The jibe didn't trouble John Edward Taylor, the Guardian's first editor, whose chubby features (long overshadowed by his much more famous and handsome successor CP Scott) get a deserved airing in the programme. His may have been a face made for radio, but his obituary in 1844 is instructive and the sort we might all like to have.

"The reforms which Taylor considered absolutely essential to the good government and well-being of his fellow countrymen have all been effected," wrote the Manchester Guardian, "almost precisely in the form in which they have been advocated in the columns of this journal." He had gone into journalism to get certain things done, especially the extension of the franchise; and as thoroughly as any middle-class homeowner clipping the privet, he helped to make sure that they happened.

The absence of red banners and a downtrodden youth mean that his achievement will never rank as romantically revolutionary, but the motive and independence behind it are as deadly to unjust authority as orators and the mob. The Troublemakers, as this episode of the BBC series is called, considers the history of similar comfortably off, well educated but stroppy people, who have the confidence to twist any wrist which is turning the screw on the less powerful.

Perverted, this can lead to a new order as arrogant as the old - pace middle-class Robespierre or middle- class Lenin - but the Taylor tradition has a crucial regulator against that. John Edward didn't set up the Guardian out of anger, guilt, the desire for fame or to make money (he had plenty of that from his cotton trading), but because of his dissenting religious upbringing.

Helping to make life better for everyone was the one great point, a philosophy too simple to be the subject of tomes or much analysis, especially as expressed a couple of decades later by the young CP Scott, who wrote in 1869: "I believe in the Son of God because I see in His person a moral ideal shining with divine brightness in the midst of a dark age. To approach that ideal and help others approach it is the chief aim of my life."

This prospectus asks for teasing (and gets it) but there is nothing Mary Poppins-ish about the way it worked in the hands of Scott and his successors. Their view of the Guardian as a weapon for virtue and radical change is obvious in their work, but their leisure pursuits were just as telling.

Scott's chief leader-writer, CE Montague, dissected the complacency of Sunday morning church in his 1926 novel Rough Justice, through the eyes of a child who hears the New Testament story for the first time in a sermon and is incredulous that "instead of rushing out to help, the congregation sang another hymn, quite slowly".

WP Crozier, who succeeded Scott's drowned son Ted as editor in 1932, wrote a fictional volume of Letters of Pontius Pilate, the classic unjust authority who might have been saved had Jerusalem had the Guardian or a middle class.

The values involved are, tough, not sentimental (Scott threw books across the office when frustrated in his good works); and the sense of a battle and a wily enemy is as strong as Harold Wilson remembered from his nonconformist youth in Huddersfield in the 1920s. Any victory for a Liberal (another word for virtue) was greeted in the Wilson household on the piano with the hymn: "Sound the loud trumpet o'er land and o'er sea/Jeshuron has triumphed, his children are free."

Things are more secular for now, and as far as authority goes, the enemy is perhaps less pressing - but tonight's programme also features the doughty women who sledge-hammered Hawk jets and then persuaded a jury to acquit them. Like a Jesuit education, dissenting, middle-class radicalism is a gift for life. If you start to "Climb up Sunshine Mountain" at the age of five in Sunday school, it is very difficult to give up.

Martin Wainwright is northern editor of the Guardian and a minor member of the cast of The Troublemakers (BBC2, tonight, 9pm).

webTitle: Lib Dems promise 'serious' investment for public services

fields.headline: Lib Dems promise 'serious' investment for public services
fields.trailText: Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy has signalled that "serious" investment in better public services will be at the centre of his party's general election campaign.
fields.body:
Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy has signalled that "serious" investment in better public services will be at the centre of his party's general election campaign.

In the opening speech at the Lib Dem spring conference in Torquay this weekend, Mr Kennedy will argue that improvements to public services will not "come on the cheap".

Mr Kennedy will set out his party's plans for public services in a speech on Saturday. But he will tonight accuse both Labour and the Tories of breaking faith with public services and their staff.

"This government, and its predecessor even more, spent far too much time bashing teachers and doctors when it should be backing them," he will say.

He will also attack Labour's decision to stick to Tory spending limits for the first two years of government as producing "all too predictable results", claiming voters are disillusioned with them as they have only "fiddled" with public investment.

"Britain doesn't want that. It wants serious investment in our public services, paid for openly and honestly," he will say.

"We will appeal to people who wanted real change in 1997 but have been disappointed by lack of improvement in our NHS, in education, in public transport and a failure to help pensioners share in rising prosperity."

The Lib Dem leader will set out his party's plans to improve investment, which include adding 1p to the basic rate of income tax.

Mr Kennedy will also promise to cut bureaucracy in hospitals, by scrapping Labour's "phoney targets" to cut waiting times.

But he earlier denied that his party was primarily targeting Labour supporters, despite policies on issues such as taxation, asylum and public spending that appear to be to the left of the government.

He told the Today programme: "What we are saying is about the decent provision of public services and the honesty and fairness and transparency of tax required to provide them, that is a message that people who previously voted Conservative, as much as those who previously voted Labour, are interested in.

"They are worried about the long-term care of the elderly and they are worried about the fact that if their children go and become students they will be saddled with debt from the fees policy of this government."

The Liberal Democrats on Thursday set out how they would regenerate rural areas through more investment in public services.

Speaking at the launch of their rural policy for England, Don Foster MP, the party's spokesman on the environment, transport and the regions, said the Liberal Democrats would focus on regenerating rural areas.

"Social justice for rural people begins with affordable housing. More must be done to address the needs of the thousands of homeless people in rural areas. Regeneration of deprived rural areas must be encouraged through streamlined regeneration grants that cut excessive form-filling."

webTitle: Child health worker arrested over four deaths

fields.headline: Child health worker arrested over four deaths
fields.trailText: A hospital health care assistant has been arrested by police investigating the "unexpected" deaths of four children on a paediatric ward at a hospital in Berkshire.
fields.body:
A hospital health care assistant has been arrested by police investigating the "unexpected" deaths of four children on a paediatric ward at a hospital in Berkshire.

The unnamed woman, who worked on ward 24 at the Wexham Park hospital in Slough, was questioned by officers from Thames Valley police after consultant paediatricians became concerned about the number of deaths on the ward.

Four children, who were all being treated for non life-threatening illnesses, have died on the ward in the last eight months, compared with the usual average of two or three unexpected deaths a year.

The hospital yesterday refused to confirm if the health care assistant, who has been released on police bail pending further inquiries, was the last member of staff with the children before they died or whether they shared the same cause of death.

Margaret Edwards, chief executive of the Heatherwood and Wexham Park Hospitals Trust, said the deaths could all just be "coincidence".

"Taken in isolation all these deaths don't give us any reason for concern. Concern has been raised because we experienced more deaths than we expected.

"It may just be a statistical cluster, a coincidence. But we have taken it seriously and asked the police to investigate."

Ms Edwards said the circumstances surrounding the death of each child had been reviewed at the time as a matter of routine and nothing suspicious had been found. Postmortem examinations to determine the cause of death proved inconclusive.

The hospital and the police refused to reveal the identities of the children to protect their families. But the coroner, Peter Bedford, confirmed the last alleged victim, who is understood to have died very recently, was a baby.

Ms Edwards said she had first been alerted to the fact there might be a problem on Monday night when consultant paediatricians who work on the ward had gone to see her and expressed concern at the number of unexpected deaths. Thames Valley police were called in, and on Wednesday evening they arrested the nursing assistant. She has also been suspended.

Detective Superintendent Steve Morrison, of Thames Valley police murder squad, said the parents of the children, who were all aged under 16, were distressed by news of the arrest and investigation.

"Clearly, they are very concerned to see that the truth of what has happened is established. We can sympathise with how traumatic this must be for them."

A family liaison officer had been drafted in to to keep the families informed about the progress of the investigation.

Mr Morrison confirmed his officers would be working closely with other constabularies, including Essex, which investigated a nurse over similar allegations last year. He said there were no immediate plans to exhume bodies of any buried children.

"This is a very early stage in the inquiry. Clearly, a number of people will be interviewed immediately and we will interview anyone who can help us with our inquiry.

"It will take weeks and months to get a clear picture of what is happening."

Mr Morrison emphasised that all the deaths had occurred on ward 24, which is staffed by 40 nurses and cares for up to 30 children. He said none of the trust's other wards or children's services were under investigation.

An incident room has been set up at Maidenhead police station and 15 detectives have been assigned to investigate.

Staff at the hospital, which is in parkland on the outskirts of Slough, were said to be "very distressed" over the allegations about their colleague.

webTitle: ITV to screen life of Henry VIII

fields.headline: ITV to screen life of Henry VIII warts and all
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The violence, sex and corruption of the Tudor court is to be played out on TV in a dramatisation of the Henry VIII story, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The violence, sex and corruption of the Tudor court is to be played out on TV screens in a dramatisation of the Henry VIII story.

Granada Television has commissioned screenwriter Alan Bleasdale to paint a warts-and-all picture of the period, omitting none of the seamier elements of Henry's reign.

Ray Winstone, best known for his East End gangster roles, has been cast to play the king; and leading TV actors such as Anna Friel and Kathy Burke are being mentioned as possible candidates to play his wives. The production is intended to be one of ITV's highlights next year.

Granada said that the series would show the "ruthless ambitions, power struggles and the magnificence" of the period. The resulting drama would be a "sexy mix of power, intrigue, glamour and danger". Henry's six wives will feature strongly but the show will also explore his whole 40-year reign. "It's a fantastic part for an actor to get his teeth into," said Winstone, who was last seen on screen in the ITV series Tough Love.

Andy Harries, the controller of drama and comedy at Granada, said the project should prove popular with modern viewers. "Henry VIII's reputation as a womaniser and tyrant lives on 500 years after his death," he said. Bleasdale, creator of Boys from the Black Stuff, was the obvious choice: "He's the perfect writer to portray fully the cut and thrust of the Tudor court."

The commission comes as BBC1 is having trouble with its drama output. The last four Sunday night series have been ratings disasters. Ballykissangel, which until recently was a ratings banker, will not return after the end of the current series.

Nick Elliott, controller of drama at the ITV network, taunted the corporation over its troubles, claiming that ITV was the "benchmark" for quality drama. He told MediaGuardian that the BBC was running scared. "What they ought to do is have the courage of their convictions and go ahead with good Sunday night stuff like Clocking Off. The pieces they've had at 9pm on Sunday recently have been very skewed away from the mainstream audience. Love in a Cold Climate was so upper class and Take a Girl Like You was not very mainstream. But they seem to have panicked."

One option for the BBC would be to schedule the planned fourth episode of EastEnders on a Sunday.

Alan Yentob, the BBC's director of drama and entertainment, denied this week that the Sunday night battleground was a problem for the BBC, saying dramas like Monarch of the Glen and the Warren Clarke vehicle Down to Earth were providing "green shoots".

Five faces of bluff Hal

Private Life of Henry VIII
Bawdy version in black and white directed by Alexander Korda in 1933. Fine performance by Charles Laughton earned him a best actor Oscar

A Man for All Seasons
Unforgettable multiple Oscar- winning film of 1966, with Robert Shaw as Henry VIII and co-starring Paul Scofield and Orson Welles

Anne of the Thousand Days
1969 costume drama for Universal Pictures nominated for 10 Oscars. Richard Burton as smouldering Henry with Genevieve Bujold as Anne Boleyn

The Six Wives of Henry VIII
1970 BBC production in six parts starring Keith Michell as Henry opposite leading ladies including Angela Pleasence and Annette Crosbie

Carry on Henry
Lighthearted 1971 version starring Sid James as amorous Henry VIII. Publicity slogan was: "A great guy with his chopper"
