fields.headline: Crisis prevention on the cards
fields.trailText: "There cannot be a crisis next week. My schedule is already full." Those words were once uttered by Henry Kissinger, past US secretary of state.
fields.body:
"There cannot be a crisis next week. My schedule is already full." Those words were once uttered by Henry Kissinger, past US secretary of state.

Are adult mental health services as inflexible to crises? Can advance directives support people with mental health problems to prevent them suffering further in times of crisis? Birth plans have become established as an option for mothers-to-be who want to direct, in advance, what happens during birth. Can the same idea help people with severe mental health problems? Pioneering work at the Maudsley hospital in south London suggests it can.

In 1989, two users groups, Survivors Speak Out and the International Self-Advocacy Alliance developed the first "crisis card" in the UK. Originally meant as a form of advocacy, it allowed a service user to nominate a friend or relative to be contacted in a crisis. The card proved so popular that, by 1993, Survivors Speak Out recommended the initiative to the Commons health select committee in its evidence about community treatment orders. It described the cards as "an alternative to compulsory treatment orders when they are not the best judge of their own interests."

The groundswell of support for the crisis cards has inspired Maudsley hospital researchers Dr Kim Sutherby and Dr George Szmukler to carry out the first study to see if the cards really work. They saw the cards as statements of service users' preferences made in anticipation of a later crisis when the users might be too ill to express their views directly.

The cards contained details setting out what practical measures the holder wanted to be put into practice should a crisis occur. These might include the preferred place of treatment, who should be informed of a hospital admission - and who should not - and domestic details such as the care of pets.

The research team soon discovered that although it had intended the cards to be agreed between the service user and the clinical staff, it didn't always work out that way. In response, it identified two types of advance directive: the "crisis card", which was a statement by the service user of their requirements for crisis treatment - where staff did not agree on some of the details, and the "joint crisis plan", in which all the details were agreed between both sides.

The results were remarkable. The cards proved hugely successful with service users, some of whom still use them three years after the end of the study. Admissions to hospital, for people using the cards, fell by about a third during the first year. What made the difference? Dr Sutherby is in no doubt: "The cards allow users more responsibility and more control of the illness and its management."

Compared with the usual paternalism of staff, service users found that discussing the crisis card required more time and dialogue than was usual in their appointments. Professionals were asked to take part in a discussion that was a negotiation and not a lecture. The result was a plan tailor-made for each person. Many users liked the fact that they had the final say about the content of the plan, something they had never experienced before.

These encouraging findings from the pilot study have allowed the Medical Research Council to fund a larger study of crisis cards, which is under way at the Institute of Psychiatry, London. Service users receive their own specific joint crisis plan or a general information pack about local services. Lead researcher Dr Claire Henderson is already finding the same immediate welcome for the cards from many service users. "The cards clearly value the previous experiences of service users and what can be learned from them, rather than just seeing hospital admissions as wasted periods of illness."

Users say carrying crisis cards leaves them feeling more in control of the mental illness. In this way the cards are a type of a contingency plan, which has been related in the new care programme approach arrangements. These arrangements allocate staff, such as community psychiatric nurses or social workers, to provide and coordinate care to those disabled by mental health problems. But the cards do not solve all disagreements. They are not legally binding and staff often keep open the option to override aspects of the crisis plan if their judgment suggests another course of action, for example compulsory admission to hospital. Also, the cards could result in using up more precious time if the whole treatment team needs consulting on the detailed plans.

However, the future of crisis cards looks promising. There is accumulating evidence that they work and most service users welcome them. Moreover, the government has recently introduced the idea of crisis plans into the national service framework for mental health. Two of the seven standards in the framework refer to the service for people with severe mental health problems. The standards ensure those with mental health problems will receive a written care plan that "includes the action to be taken in a crisis by the service user, their carer, and their care coordinator".

These ideas could lead mental health staff towards a broader view of shared care, one that interests staff in keeping users well, rather than reacting in response to a crisis.

Graham Thornicroft is a consultant psychiatrist at the South London and Maudsley NHS trust and is head of the health services research department at the Institute of Psychiatry, at Kings College London.

Amanda Reynolds is head of community and mental health service development at Norfolk health authority.

 For more information about joint crisis plans contact Chris Flood or Dr Claire Henderson, Institute of Psychiatry, at spjurch@iop.kcl.ac.uk or 020 7848 0732.

fields.headline: NHS 'must act to reduce suicides'
fields.standfirst: 17% of suicides by people with mental health could have been prevented
fields.trailText: About 1,300 suicides by psychiatric patients over the last five years could have been prevented by better NHS care, the government's mental health tsar said yesterday.
fields.body:
About 1,300 suicides by psychiatric patients over the last five years could have been prevented by better NHS care, the government's mental health tsar said yesterday.

A confidential inquiry into suicides by people with mental illness found 17% of the deaths since 1996 were preventable. The risk could have been reduced in most other cases by closer supervision, said Louis Appleby, professor of psychiatry at Manchester university.

About six homicides by psychiatric patients could be prevented each year, but most perpetrators did not have the kind of illnesses that were easily treated, he said.

The report added weight to criticism from mental health campaigners that "care in the community" services do not offer the mentally ill the help they need outside hospital.

Prof Appleby said: "These findings emphasise the challenge facing mental health services. Around 40% of patient suicides happen during or soon after in-patient care and we should make the prevention of these deaths a priority."

His recommendations included reforming in-patient wards to make it less easy for people to hang themselves - the most common method of suicide by psychiatric patients.

The report also called for a follow-up assessment for all high risk patients within a week of being discharged from hospital and limiting their supplies of medication to reduce the risk of an overdose.

The study found 15% of suicides were in-patients and 23% committed suicide within three months of hospital discharge. The highest risk was in the first two weeks of leaving hospital.

John Hutton, the health minister, said the report would be used by officials preparing a national suicide prevention strategy. "We are making mental health services safer - for patients, those who work in mental health services, patients' families and the public," he said.

Hospitals were being asked to remove non-collapsible bed frames and shower rails in psychiatric wards within 12 months to reduce the suicide risk. Care orders in the community would ensure people continued to comply with treat- ment and cut reduce suicides by 32% a year.

Cliff Prior, chief executive of the National Schizophrenia Fellowship, said: "Deaths in railway crashes are rightly recognised as preventable, but too often suicides involving people with mental illness are seen as inevitable."

fields.headline: Ale to become a trendy tipple
fields.trailText: 8.30am Stouts and ales are to undergo a renaissance with the help of Belgium brewing giant Interbrew, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
The real ale drinker, so long maligned for his woolly jumper and beard, is set to get his revenge: ale and stout are about to become the trendiest drinks at the bar.

Premium lager and pre-mixed spirit drinks have dominated the £16.8bn drinks industry over the past five years at the expense of traditional stout and ale.

But a new report by Datamonitor says stouts and ales are to benefit from a renaissance driven by Belgium brewing giant Interbrew.

"If Interbrew supports and develops real ale brands within its portfolio, such as Flowers and Trophy, it could provide the figurehead brands that renew interest in the ale sector," said Neil Broome, Datamonitor consumer markets analyst.

Mr Broome said the popularity in the UK of Belgian speciality beers - such as Hoegaarden and Leffe - will open up a market for drinks that require a more discerning palate.

The volume of speciality beer sold in the UK between 1995 and 2000 has increased by 1.8m litres.

However, the volume of ales and stouts has fallen by 1.1% to just over 3,000m litres over the same period.

British consumers drank 6.7bn litres of beer last year, the lowest volume for the past five years.

The focus of pub estate owners on branded bars and pubs, family pubs and pub restaurants is paying off.

Interbrew is contesting the British competition authorities' ruling that requires it to sell off the Bass business it acquired last year.

Even if it retains the Scottish and Irish Bass businesses, there will be room in for a new global player to enter the UK market.

Heineken, Carlsberg, SAB and Anheuser-Busch are all likely contenders.

fields.headline: Dot.com buys the sound of history
fields.standfirst:
A new website has saved British movie sound tracks from US rivals

More net news
fields.trailText: The sounds of some of Britain's finest hours - or at least the soundtracks to the film versions - have been saved for the nation by a dot.com in a victory over Hollywood rivals.
fields.body:
The sounds of some of Britain's finest hours - or at least the soundtracks to the film versions - have been saved for the nation by a dot.com in a victory over Hollywood rivals.

Sound-effects-library.com has bought, for an undisclosed sum, a collection of 4m sound recordings from Cinesound, said its managing director, Lloyd Billing.

The library spans decades of film and real-life history. From the movies come the sound effects from every James Bond film, Zulu and the Battle of Britain.

Original sounds include recordings of the second world war bombing of Portsmouth harbour, Sir Winston Churchill's state funeral and a rare recording from the Bismark.

The archive has been kept on record and tape in Cinesound's vaults. It will now catalogue and transfer the entire library online.

This will be available to filmmakers, musicians, web designers, theatres, schools, museums and production companies, who can listen before buying.

Mr Billing, of the Tape Gallery in London, said he would honoured to digitise the archive. "This collection is truly unique. It has been recorded by the world's greatest sound recordists, it contains sounds that no other library could possibly achieve, like huge crowd scenes from the movie Cromwell and multiple Spitfires passing dangerously close overhead."

fields.headline: Drugs baron cleared of reporter's murder
fields.standfirst:
Dublin drugs baron, John Gilligan, cleared of murdering crime reporter

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: A Dublin drugs baron was yesterday cleared of masterminding the murder of the crime reporter Veronica Guerin after a 43 day, multi-million pound trial which has gripped Ireland.
fields.body:
A Dublin drugs baron was yesterday cleared of masterminding the murder of the crime reporter Veronica Guerin after a 43 day, multi-million pound trial which has gripped Ireland.

Judge Diarmuid O'Donovan said he had "grave suspicions", that John Gilligan, 48, was involved in the killing.

He condemned Gilligan at the special criminal court for causing a "haemorrhage of harm", saying he had shown insatiable greed and no remorse, as he jailed him for an unprecedented 28 years for importing 20,000 kilos of cannabis resin worth £32m.

"Never in the history of the state has one person been responsible for so much wretchedness to so many," said the judge.

However, he told the no-jury court he had no choice but to acquit him of murder because the main prosecution evidence, from one of Gilligan's former accomplices, Russell Warren, a state-protected witness, was unreliable and uncorroborated.

Gilligan was also found not guilty of four charges of possessing weapons and ammunition.

Warren had claimed that Gilligan ordered and directed Ms Guerin's killing, keeping in touch by mobile phone from Amsterdam in the minutes before and after the murder.

A ripple of shock ran around the packed courtroom when the verdict was announced at the end of the one hour 40 minute judgment. Gilligan, a small, stocky, grey-haired man in a casual, short-sleeved shirt, stared nonchalantly at the ceiling.

Later, he put his feet up in the dock as he was sentenced to 28 years, of which he will probably spend around 15 in prison.

Afterwards, the dead woman's brother, Jimmy Guerin, expressed bitter disappointment and said he would never forgive the killers.

"We were hoping this would be the end of it. I don't see anybody else being brought before the court," he said.

The murder of Ms Guerin, a 37-year-old investigative journalist with the Dublin-based Sunday Independent, on June 26, 1996, sparked deep public outrage and triggered the biggest police investigation in Irish history.

She had gained a formidable reputation for her hard-hitting exposes of Dublin's most feared gangsters in the six years she had been in journalism. Her unorthodox and sometimes reckless methods of working alone, doorstepping and then confronting dangerous criminals paid off with exclusives but made her many enemies.

She had shots fired at her house in October 1994 and the following January she opened her front door to a gunman wearing a motorbike helmet, who shot her in the thigh.

On September 14, 1995, Gilligan allegedly hit her and ripped her blouse when she inveigled her way into his £5m equestrian centre in County Kildare to interrogate him on how he made his money.

Ms Guerin filed charges for assault and Judge O'Donvovan accepted that Gilligan had made a chilling telephone threat on September 15, 1995 to kill her and kidnap and rape her boy, Cahal, who was six when she died.

Felix McEnroy, a barrister, who overheard the threat, told the court of Gilligan's controlled fury in that phone call.

Mr McEnroy heard Gilligan shout: "If you do one thing to me or if you write about me I will kidnap your fucking son and ride him. I will shoot you."

Ms Guerin was killed on a sunny afternoon, just before lunchtime as she waited in her car at traffic lights on a busy road on the outskirts of Dublin, characteristically talking on one of the two mobile phones she carried everywhere.

She was leaving a light-hearted message for a police contact to tell him she had just got off with a £120 speeding fine.

She barely noticed the motorbike pillion passenger leaning toward her window.

But seconds later she was dead, her body slumped over the passenger seat, shot by six bullets from a Magnum .357 revolver.

The murder led to a crackdown on organised crime, six new pieces of legislation rushed through the Irish parliament including new grounds for restricting bail and seizing criminal assets.

Assistant Commissioner Tony Hickey headed the huge police investigation during which more than 3,000 people were questioned and hundreds of premises searched.

Two of Gilligan's associates, Charles Bowden and Warren, were arrested in Dublin in October 1996 and Gilligan himself was lifted by police at Heathrow airport.

Two others, Brian Meehan, who drove the motorbike on the day of the killing, and Paul Ward, who disposed of the bike in the River Liffey afterwards, have already been jailed for life for murder.

In 1997 Bowden and Warren agreed to give evidence against Gilligan, in return for immunity from prosecution in relation to Ms Guerin's murder, new identities and relocation for themselves and their families when they leave prison, the first ever protected witnesses in the history of the Irish state.

Bowden led detectives to the lock-up garage where he claimed Gilligan stored his cannabis and also to a Jewish cemetery where officers dug up guns alleged to belong to the accused.

Gilligan was remanded in prison in England and fought extradition for three and a half years but was returned to Ireland in February last year and his trial finally got under way in December.

But Judge O'Donovan said yesterday that both Bowden and Warren had been shown to be self-seeking liars and while he did not totally discount their testimony, he could not convict Gilligan on the murder and arms charges without corroborating evidence.

fields.headline: The White House effect
fields.standfirst:
Where money talks, green values crumble

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Even by US standards, George Bush's politically inspired decision to renege on his election pledge to "establish mandatory reduction targets" for carbon emissions is breathtakingly irresponsible.
fields.body:
Even by US standards, George Bush's politically inspired decision to renege on his election pledge to "establish mandatory reduction targets" for carbon emissions is breathtakingly irresponsible. The Clinton-Gore record on the 1997 Kyoto accord to combat global warming was pretty feeble. But Mr Bush has now outdone them for spinelessness, caving in to lobbying from the energy companies that bankroll his party (the coal industry alone slipped $1.4m into Republican coffers in 1999-2000) and from senior members of his divided administration, like oil-man vice president, Dick Cheney. Mr Bush has broken a commitment he cynically used to trump the green-ish Al Gore; he has undermined his environment chief, Christine Whitman and treasury secretary, Paul O'Neill; he has again embarrassed the hapless Colin Powell, who recently gave assurances that the US was serious about climate change; and he has enraged EU countries and Japan, while simultaneously making a fool of UN boss Kofi Annan, who urged tougher action on carbon emissions in Dhaka only this week.

Mr Bush's stated reasons can only be described as pathetic. One was the "incomplete state of scientific knowledge", that old canard utilised by smokestack utilities but not responsible leaders. His assertion ignores all the evidence compiled by the intergovernmental panel on climate change and, for example, the latest study by British scientists, published in Nature, that employed satellite measurements to plot "a significant increase in the earth's greenhouse effect". Mr Bush's second reason, that the cost of carbon curbs could "harm consumers" by raising prices and that the US was facing an "energy crisis" is as selfish as it is short-sighted. fields.headline: Arts Council axes regional bodies
fields.standfirst: Every job is under review, says Arts Council chairman
fields.trailText: Every job is under review, says Arts Council chairman.
fields.body:
The Arts Council last night abolished the 10 regional arts boards as the first step in a radical plan to clear away the bureaucracy that has choked funding.

The boards, which were set up under the Tories 11 years ago, will begin to be amalgamated into the Arts Council next month, and will cease to exist by the end of the year.

The move was immediately attacked by the Liberal Democrats, who accused the Arts Council chairman, Gerry Robinson, of trying to "bounce this outrageous retrograde proposal" through before the general election.

Lib Dem MP Robert Maclennan compared the regional officials who will replace the boards to Nazi provincial "gauleiters" who would enforce the Arts Council's "autocratic whims" on the regions.

He said these "commercially driven" changes went against the spirit of the government's drive towards devolution.

Mr Robinson, who with the culture secretary, Chris Smith, is credited with last week's £70m rescue package for theatre, used the announcement to reveal he would be staying on for a further three years to push the reforms through. He said: "I now have two ambitions: to lever yet more funding for the arts from the government and other sources and radically to simplify the arts funding system."

Mr Robinson warned that "every job is now under review" both in the old autonomous RABs, each of which had their own boards and bureaucracy, and at the Arts Council headquarters in London, which he said would continue to be slimmed down. He said that because each board was independent, there were "large inconsistencies" across the country as to what kind of work was supported and what was not.

But he denied the centre was now riding roughshod over the regions. "Each of the executives running offices in the regions will be advised by the sort of experts who now sit on their boards. For the first time we have created a system where the voice of the regions will be heard at the top table in London."

Mr Robinson said the present system was untenable and had failed the artistic community. "No commercial organisation would run for 10 minutes in the way the present system has been set up. Everyone agrees, even the regions themselves, that it is crazy for us to be duplicating all this activity. The bureaucracy is awful."

He said there would be "significant savings" through the new system which would be passed on directly to artists.

All but one of the existing 10 regions will have new, small Arts Council regional offices . The south east board, regarded as the worst of the boards, will be absorbed into the southern region.

Mr Maclennan admitted that the system was a "total mess" but argued that to "bounce this out now, and implement it in April, is wholly unacceptable". He said he would be lobbying Mr Smith to put the plans on hold.

Yesterday Mr Smith unveiled the first £5m stage of Culture Online, the internet database he hopes to build in which the nation's cultural treasures will be available to all children and families.

Live theatre performances, concerts and images of works of art from national collections will be able to be downloaded by schools and children. Children will also be able to tap into the expertise of museums and other institutions for their classroom projects.

The pilot project will be expanded if it proves successful.

webTitle: Briton feared hurt after bomb in Saudi capital

fields.headline: Briton feared hurt after bomb in Saudi capital
fields.standfirst: Two injured in latest blast involving foreign workers
fields.trailText: Two men, one of them believed to be a Briton, were injured in an explosion outside a bookshop in the centre of the Saudi capital, Riyadh, last night, raising fears of a concerted bombing campaign targeting foreign workers in the Gulf kingdom.
fields.body:
Two men, one of them believed to be a Briton, were injured in an explosion outside a bookshop in the centre of the Saudi capital, Riyadh, last night, raising fears of a concerted bombing campaign targeting foreign workers in the Gulf kingdom.

Saudi police said one victim was a 47-year-old Scotsman; the Foreign Office agreed it was possible he was British. Earlier reports had suggested the injured European came from the Netherlands. The other victim was described as either Egyptian or Sudanese; neither was seriously hurt.

The two men were taken to the private al-Hammadi hospital but later released. The blast, caused by a device hidden in a bin outside the al- Jareer bookshop, was the fourth involving overseas workers in Saudi Arabia since November. The explosion smashed windows but did not cause widespread damage.

The building also houses the newspaper al-Hayat. Struc tural damage was minor. Saudi security forces briefly sealed off the area of the blast, diverting traffic to side streets.

Two bombings in Riyadh between November 17 and December 15 killed a Briton and injured four others. A third blast, in Khobar in eastern Saudi Arabia, injured one person.

Abdullah al-Shahrani, the city's police chief, last night said his officers were investigating the latest bombing but did not immediately link it to the other explosions.

Shortly before Christmas, three foreigners working in Saudi Arabia - a Briton, a Belgian and a Canadian - were arrested. They remain in custody. The three appeared on Saudi state television last month and confessed to carrying out the bombings.

Alexander Mitchell, chief anaesthetics technician at a hospital in Riyadh admitted planting the car-bomb which killed another Briton, Christopher Rodway. Five other Britons are being held for alleged alcohol offences. If convicted, Mr Mitchell could face the death sentence.

The latest bombing may cast fresh doubts on official Saudi claims that the bombings are the work of foreigners. Saudi newspapers have linked the Riyadh bombings to turf wars between westerners fighting over the profits of multi-mil lion pound illicit drinking clubs. Selling or trading in alcohol is banned in the conservative muslim kingdom.

Amnesty International urged Prince Charles to raise the issue of whether the detained men can expect a fair trial when he visited Saudi Arabia last month. "We hope he will use his influence and raise with his Saudi hosts issues such as torture and unfair and secretive trials, particularly in the light of the current detention of a British national," an Amnesty spokesman said.

Last month the Foreign Office said it was worried about the situation of the detained Britons but insisted: "Through our ambassador Britain is taking every opportunity to raise these cases at the highest level."

The Saudi interior minister, Prince Nayef bin Abdel Aziz, has revealed that another Briton with links to Mitchell, Gary Dixon, 55, had been arrested in the United Arab Emirates. Dixon fled to Dubai after being arrested last April on suspicion of illegal manufacturing and distribution of alcohol. Prince Nayef said he expected that Mr Dixon would be handed to the Saudi authorities soon.

The prince added that the investigation was continuing and that it was premature for Mr Mitchell to hire a lawyer.

webTitle: Business: Patientline to press ahead with floatation

fields.headline: Float goes ahead, says Patientline
fields.standfirst:
Hospital entertainment service provider is to press ahead with plans for floatation

More net news
fields.trailText: Patientline, which provides entertainment terminals and telephones for patients in hospitals, is pressing ahead with its £104m flotation despite current market turbulence.
fields.body:
Patientline, which provides entertainment terminals and telephones for patients in hospitals, is pressing ahead with its £104m flotation despite current market turbulence.

It yesterday gave details of its plans to float on the Alternative Investment Market next week, raising £44.4m to fund expansion in Europe through a placing of 25.4m shares at 175p each.

Derek Lewis, the company's chairman and chief executive and a former director general of the prison service, said: "I am delighted with the strong investor response to our AIM listing, in spite of the difficult market conditions."

Patientline, which has contracts with 36 NHS hospitals and provides services to 30 hospitals in the Netherlands, said the money would be used to finance growth, which will include expanding in Britain and continental Europe.

The group plans to concentrate on Britain and the Netherlands this year but might move into other west European countries towards the end of the year.

The company installs terminals that allow patients to have their own TV and radio, as well as access to games, audio books and a telephone. It will use some of the money raised to offer internet and e-mail facilities to patients, as well as providing electronic patient records at the bedside.

The cost of putting terminals into each hospital is about £1m and the company offers services to patients for £3.50 a day, although the price is lower if the person is staying in hospital for a longer time. The group provides a television-only rental service to more than 70 hospitals in Britain.

The government wants these bedside services to be available in all NHS hospitals by 2004.

 Elateral, the software company that hoped to become the first IT firm this year to float on London's main market, has been forced to postpone indefinitely its listing because of difficult market conditions.

"As a result of current adverse stock market conditions Elateral Holdings announces the postponement of its flotation", the company said.

Elateral, which claims its software improves communication and marketing, said in February it would brave the market to try to raise £30m.

The company said yesterday that it viewed the future with confidence, had agreements with venture capitalists and looked forward to returning to the market when conditions were right.

fields.headline: Sir Michael Woodruff
fields.standfirst: Pioneering surgeon who performed Britain's first successful kidney transplant operation
fields.trailText: Sir Michael Woodruff, who has died aged 89, was Britain's great pioneer of organ transplant surgery. From 1957 to 1976, he was professor of surgery at Edinburgh University and consultant surgeon to the city's Royal Infirmary. There, on October 30 1960, he performed the first successful organ transplant operation in this country.
fields.body:
Sir Michael Woodruff, who has died aged 89, was Britain's great pioneer of organ transplant surgery. From 1957 to 1976, he was professor of surgery at Edinburgh University and consultant surgeon to the city's Royal Infirmary. There, on October 30 1960, he performed the first successful organ transplant operation in this country.

He had discovered that one of his patients, a miner named Lewis Abbot, had an identical twin brother, and realised that a kidney transplant between twins would minimise the risk of rejection. The operation was hazardous, and post-operative care was problematic, but it eventually proved successful. Woodruff later developed a drug that helped prevent the rejection of transplanted organs by the body's immune system.

He was born in London, but two years later, following his father's appointment to the chair of veterinary pathology at the University of Melbourne, the family emigrated to Australia, where Woodruff was brought up. After schooling at Wesley College, Melbourne, he read electrical engineering at the university, where he distinguished himself both as an oarsman and an organist before graduating with first-class honours in 1932.

Then he decided to embark on a career in medicine, and graduated in surgery, again with first-class honours, in 1937. During the next four years, he not only began his surgical training at the Royal Melbourne Hospital, but also obtained the higher degrees of doctor of medicine and master of surgery.

In 1941, Woodruff volunteered for military service with the Australian Army Medical Corps and joined the 10th general hospital in Malaya, where, the following year, he was taken prisoner by the Japanese. He spent the remainder of the war incarcerated in the notorious prisoner-of-war camp at Changi, Singapore, where he distinguished himself by his efforts to reduce vitamin deficiency diseases among the inadequately fed prisoners - work that formed the basis of the report Deficiency Diseases in Japanese Prison Camps (1951), of which he was co-author.

Woodruff came to Britain in 1946 and, while working as tutor in surgery at Sheffield University, was elected a fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons of England. Two years later, he was appointed senior lecturer in surgery at the University of Aberdeen, and consultant surgeon to both Aberdeen Royal Infirmary and the Aberdeen Hospital for Sick Children. In 1952, he moved to New Zealand to become professor of surgery at the University of Otago. Five years later, he succeeded Sir James Learmonth at Edinburgh.

Woodruff already had an international reputation as an expert in transplant immunology, and his move to Edinburgh opportunely coincided with the commencement of clinical organ transplantation. Under his direction, the university's Wilkie surgical research laboratory became a department dedicated to the study of the immunological aspects of transplant surgery, and was chosen by the Medical Research Council to be the MRC research group on transplantation.

Woodruff's book Transplantation Of Tissues and Organs (1960), a monumental text that received international acclaim, was the standard work on the subject for many years. His other publications included The Interaction Of Cancer And Host (1980) and an autobiography, Nothing Venture Nothing Win (1997).

In 1968, the clinical renal transplant service, which until then had been based at the Edinburgh Royal Infirmary, was transferred to the newly-opened Nuffield transplant surgery unit, which had been built to Woodruff's personal specification at the Western General Hospital, although he continued to perform the rest of his surgical work -including responsibility for most of the peripheral vascular surgery carried out in south-east Scotland - at the Royal Infirmary.

The University of Melbourne awarded him the degree of doctor of science in 1962. He was elected a fellow of the Royal Society in 1968, and became its vice-president in 1979. A knighthood in 1969 was followed by his election to the presidency of the International Transplantation Society and the council of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh, and many other British and international honours.

Michael Woodruff earned the respect of all who worked with him, both in the research and clinical fields. He possessed a unique capacity for instilling enthusiasm in those who did research work under his direction, and often brought visiting academics to see the laboratory work in action. He was quite unperturbed when a visiting European professor once unwisely disposed of his cigar in a laboratory container holding discarded ether-soaked swabs. The resulting column of fire, quickly contained, simply produced the often-used comment, "How bizarre".

Woodruff expected his own high standards to be reflected in those who worked under him. His clinical ward rounds were famous as a source of stress for those who unwisely came inadequately prepared, but, if the required high standards had been achieved, he was unstinting in his praise.

For nearly 15 years after retirement in 1976, he continued to carry out his studies on cancer immunology, in addition to participating in his lifelong interests of music, sailing and tennis. He was a member of the Royal Forth Yacht Club, and his yachts, Therapist and Therapist II, were familiar sights both in the Firth of Forth and in the Mediterranean.

In 1946, he married Hazel Ashby, a botanical scientist from Adelaide. He is survived by her, their two sons (one of whom is a surgeon), and a daughter.

fields.headline: Charly Baumann
fields.standfirst: Animal trainer whose love affair with tigers changed circus life
fields.trailText: For 20 years, Charly Baumann, who has died aged 72, starred with the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey's three-ring circus in America, with a group of 15 Bengal tigers, and was one of the world's most stylish tiger trainers. He changed the way trainer and animal worked together in a circus setting.
fields.body:
For 20 years, Charly Baumann, who has died aged 72, starred with the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey's three-ring circus in America, with a group of 15 Bengal tigers, and was one of the world's most stylish tiger trainers. He changed the way trainer and animal worked together in a circus setting.

Baumann loved the big cats he worked with, and his displays quietly celebrated their natural abilities and characters, in contrast with the "fighting" style previously popular with American audiences. Although a few of his 1950s tigers had come from the wild, he was proud to have bred and raised more than 30 of the species himself; when necessary, he and his wife, Araceli, bottle-fed young cubs.

Baumann was born in Berlin and, as a child, appeared in a dozen German films. During the second world war, his parents were thrown into concentration camps after his father had helped a wealthy Jewish family flee to Spain. His father died in a gas chamber, but his mother was allowed back to Berlin, while their son was held in an orphanage and later worked on an eastern German farm. He escaped this brutal regime, only to be drafted into the navy and captured by the Americans weeks before the end of the war.

In postwar Berlin, Baumann's mother took him to an old friend, Paula Busch, who was reviving her once-prosperous circus at Berlin Zoo. He was employed as a groom, and made his first appearances in the ring trying to ride the unrideable mule - in a long dress and bonnet.

In 1946, Baumann joined Circus Williams, in Cologne, as an assistant horse-trainer. There he learnt the secret of infinite patience in animal training from the proprietor, Harry Williams, as well as the unremitting toil of hard work on a travelling circus.

Circus Williams included a chariot-racing scene, in which Baumann played one of the charioteers, and this was brought to London's Harringay Arena in 1950 for Tom Arnold's Circus. The building was so big that Baumann wrote that "the famous London fogs seeped into the vast, cavernous interior".

Tragedy struck during a rehearsal when Williams took over Baumann's chariot to show them how to get up more speed. As they circled the arena, the chariot overturned and Williams received injuries from which he died.

Back in Germany, Williams's widow, Carola, temporarily closed the circus, and Baumann embarked on his career with wild animals. Earlier, he had gone to the rescue of the Dutch trainer Jean Michon when he was attacked and badly injured by three lions, and the lions' owner, Eric Klant, was convinced Baumann had the courage to make a good trainer. So it proved, as Baumann began presenting lions, ultimately in Germany's Circus Roland, where he worked in a Tarzan costume - initially a great embarrassment.

He also began a long affair with the director, Ada Aureden, who had founded the circus with her late husband. She bought him a group of tigers, and Baumann described the change from lions to tigers as being like playing the violin after the drums, tigers requiring more sensitive handling. He achieved top bookings, including performances in the Bertram Mills Circus at Olympia and the Blackpool Tower Circus.

fields.headline: Pastor Richard Wurmbrand
fields.standfirst: Cleric driven by missionary zeal despite years of persecution in communist Romania
fields.trailText: Pastor Richard Wurmbrand, who has died aged 91, was a Lutheran Romanian minister who was imprisoned and tortured for more than 14 years by that country's communist regime between 1948 and 1964.
fields.body:
Pastor Richard Wurmbrand, who has died aged 91, was a Lutheran Romanian minister who was imprisoned and tortured for more than 14 years by that country's communist regime between 1948 and 1964. After being ransomed by a group of Norwegian Christians, who paid the Romanian government $10,000, he founded the Christian Mission to the Communist World, now a charity called Release International, which supports those persecuted for their faith.

Wurmbrand and his wife Sabina (Obituary, August 31 2000) were both Jewish-born, but converted to Christianity in 1936, apparently after meeting an uneducated German carpenter who gave them a Bible and urged them to read one of the gospels.

The couple, many of whose relatives perished in the Holocaust, subsequently worked for the Anglican mission to the Jews in Bucharest and, following the communist takeover in 1945, set up an underground church for Romanians and Soviet troops from the army of occupation.

Once memorably described in the Times as "an enormous Romanian", Wurmbrand was first arrested in 1948, released in 1956 and then imprisoned again between 1959 and 1964. He spent nearly three years in solitary confinement in an underground cell, and was repeatedly tortured, brain-washed and forced to watch the humiliation of other Christian prisoners. Sabina was also imprisoned and subjected to three years' slave labour.

In 1966, he gave evidence to a US senate internal security subcommittee, at one point stripping to the waist to reveal 18 deep torture wounds. "If I showed you my body, I wonder if you could bear to look at it," he told journalists.

Unsurprisingly, his experiences made him virulently anti-communist. He called the philosophy the greatest crime in humanity, and launched fierce attacks on the Soviet and Chinese regimes and organisations he perceived to be soft on them - such as the World Council of Churches. He claimed that he had once been offered the chance to become a bishop by his captors, so long as he would promise to influence the council in Romania's favour.

His efforts at resistance were not always appreciated. The Hungarian doctor and lay preacher Dr Mihaly Tapolyai claimed in 1967 that Wurmbrand had done little to help religious freedom, telling him: "Your doctrines will strengthen the conviction of communist leaders that Christianity is the ancient enemy of the people." Such attacks, though, came at the height of the cold war, long before the peoples of eastern Europe took their chance to show what they really thought of their regimes.

In fairness, Wurmbrand was not entirely rigid in his views, speaking out, for example, against the treatment of Indonesian communists rounded up in the 1960s by their country's government.

In the west, the Wurmbrands' mission, founded in 1965, smuggled Bibles, supported underground pastors and offered financial aid to the relatives of those imprisoned or killed for their religious beliefs. The pastor was the author of two books about his experiences: Tortured For Christ and In God's Underground, both of which have become bestsellers, translated into more than 50 languages.

Michael Bourdeaux writes: In December 1964, the Rev Stuart Harris, head of the European Christian Mission, held a clandestine meeting with a tall, gaunt figure in a Bucharest park. It was an encounter which would change the western Christian perception of communism for ever. Accepting a ransom of $10,000 was one of the worst financial temptations to which a communist regime ever succumbed. A thousand times the price could not have compensated for the explosion which Wurmbrand's arrival in the west ignited.

The prevalent myth at the time was that the lot of Christians under communist regimes had improved. With a passion that sometimes verged on hysteria, Wurmbrand set out to disprove this; his own body bore the marks of recent torture, and there were millions of others like him. If he sometimes exaggerated the statistics, his essential claim - that persecution was continuing - was correct.

By that time, communist propaganda was exerting a hold on the international Christian agenda through the World Council of Churches and other agencies. Wurmbrand's message, delivered with some of the most powerful oratory the postwar world had seen, awoke the conscience of millions.

He confronted Christian leaders round the world, pouring open scorn on the diplomatic niceties which they claimed should govern any dialogue with the communist authorities or church representatives from eastern Europe.

Wurmbrand's message was a factor in the eventual collapse of the Ceausescu regime in Romania and, in the 1990s, he and his wife appeared on Romanian television and were able to visit the very prison where he had been held, to find there a repository of his books.

fields.headline: George Simon
fields.standfirst: Critic and chronicler of the years when big band jazz was king
fields.trailText: George Simon, who has died aged 88, was one of the pioneer jazz critics. He stood out as champion of the decade or so during which large jazz and dance orchestras, and their singers, were accorded the kind of coverage now devoted to rappers and rockers.
fields.body:
George Simon, who has died aged 88, was one of the pioneer jazz critics. He stood out as champion of the decade or so during which large jazz and dance orchestras, and their singers, were accorded the kind of coverage now devoted to rappers and rockers. For Simon's Glenn Miller And His Orchestra (1974), Bing Crosby wrote the introduction; for his The Big Bands (1974) - he covered more than 400 and gives 72 their own chapters - Frank Sinatra did the honours.

In 1935, Simon left Harvard University to become an associate editor on the music magazine Metronome. While lacking the power to make or break, he did wield influence, and the reputation of some tyro bandleaders could rise after a few favourable mentions. He recommended pianist Mel Powell to Benny Goodman, and Woody Herman's bands were known as herds following a Simon review.

Ironically, perhaps, his most-quoted critique was the slating he gave the Count Basie band in 1937; though he recognised the swing, he continued on the lines of, "If you think that the sax section is out of tune, catch the brass." Commenting on this in later years, he pointed out that musicians in many black bands could not afford to buy the best instruments.

Simon described himself as the lowbrow member of an upper middle-class Jewish family. While his eldest brother, who founded the publishers Simon & Schuster, practised piano concertos, and another brother reviewed classical music, George would be in the basement with his jazz records and his drum kit.

His job with Metronome put him in touch with several musicians, including Glenn Miller, then playing trombone for Ray Noble. Simon helped organise the personnel of the original Miller band, and played drums on their first recording. During the second world war, he once more helped to organise, and occasionally drummed in, early versions of Miller's army air force band. He was eventually put in charge of V Discs, 12-inch vinyl 78rpm records sent to the troops - and, not surprisingly, recorded many stars of the swing era.

The postwar shift to small, bebop-influenced groups was not entirely to Simon's tastes. After 20 years with Metronome, the last 15 as editor-in-chief, he worked mainly in and around the record industry, though he had spells covering jazz for the New York Herald Tribune and the New York Post.

In between writing books, he produced albums for different companies, and acted as a consultant on TV programmes, including the acclaimed Timex jazz series. For several years, he was executive director of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, which runs the Grammy awards.

Instead of attempting to keep pace with every musical development, Simon's books reflect his unique and invaluable role as eyewitness to, and chronicler of, the 1935-45 decade. He won an ASCAP award for The Big Bands and, some years later, won a Grammy award himself for his sleeve note to a Bing Crosby album, written at Crosby's request.

He is survived by his wife, two children and three grandchildren.

 George Thomas Simon, journalist, born May 9 1912; died February 13 2001

webTitle: Wrapped in plastic, the rejected wait to die

fields.headline: Wrapped in plastic, the rejected wait to die
fields.standfirst:
The Guardian gains access to the Afghans' grim refugee camp which the Pakistani authorities kept from the eyes of the UN secretary general

Special report: Pakistan
fields.trailText: For the past five days the year-old child has been lying on an earth floor under a thin sheet of plastic, unconscious and with acute diarrhoea. As the sun sinks again into the thick cloud of dust on the horizon, Abdullah knows his son Waseem's death is only hours away.
fields.body:
For the past five days the year-old child has been lying on an earth floor under a thin sheet of plastic, unconscious and with acute diarrhoea. As the sun sinks again into the thick cloud of dust on the horizon, Abdullah knows his son Waseem's death is only hours away.

"I took him to the doctor here at the camp. He gave him medicine but it did not help," he said.

"Then I went to a private doctor and he charged 200 rupees (£2.30) for more medicine. That was all the money I had left, but I paid. Still he has not recovered. Now I know it is too late. Tell me, what can I do?"

Waseem's last hours are being spent in the refugee camp that Pakistan does not want the world to see. On Monday the authorities prevented the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, from entering Jalozai camp. Improbably for a country with the eighth largest armed forces in the world, the military government said it did not have enough soldiers and police to protect him.

Pakistan has also barred aid agencies from helping the 80,000 Afghans here. It says the refugees must return home.

To the few who do see the camp the reality is overwhelming: Jalozai is filled with the dying. Attached to the blue canvas wall of one of its three overworked medical clinics hangs a sign in neat Pashtu and Persian script : "Equipment for digging graves and making coffins is available in this hospital."

Strewn across a wide expanse of dusty, red-brown earth, thousands of squalid shelters are set up almost on top of each other. Small strips of meat, known as landi , hang on strings running from one tent to the next. In the cold of an Afghan spring the meat, donated during the Eid ul-Adha Islamic holiday last week, would keep. Under Pakistan's unforgiving sun it rots.

These are not the sturdy tarpaulin tents provided by the UN and other aid agencies in the official refugee camps elsewhere in the North West Frontier province. Aid workers call Jalozai "Plastic City." Newly arrived refugees must buy their own shelters: a square metre of dirty plastic costs 15 rupees (18p), the same price as 2kg of rice.

Toilets have been dug in the ground but not deep enough. A brief fall of rain and they overflow, running in broad, disease-ridden streams through the camp.

It is not the reception that Amir Gul expected to find when drought and fighting forced his family to leave their village in central Afghanistan, eight weeks ago.

"Somebody told me if I had no job, no home and no money I should go to Jalozai," the said. "We stay here in the hope that today aid may arrive, or if not then perhaps tomorrow. I have spent two months like this."

When he first arrived in Pakistan Mr Gul, 68, a farm labourer, borrowed 400 rupees (£4.70) from a friend. Now the money has been spent and he begs in the local market to support his eight children.

"The money went in two or three days. I cannot go back to my home and I cannot live here." Afghans are usually too proud to show their tears, but Amir Gul held a fist to his chest and sobbed.

In the past six months more than 230,000 refugees have poured across the border from Afghanistan's worst drought in 30 years and renewed fighting between the Islamic Taliban militia and the remnants of the former government. In November, in breach of international humanitarian law, Pakistan closed the border. But still the refugees come, bribing border guards or sneaking through mountain passes between the checkpoints.

The first to arrive were the lucky ones. They live in Shamshatoo, a more orderly site with mud huts, tents, food distribution and a water supply.

But since January the UN has not been allowed to register the thousands of new arrivals at Jalozai as refugees. Pakistan, which already has 2m Afghan refugees, insists they are either economic migrants or refugees who arrived years ago.

The UN disagrees, but aid workers are not allowed to move these people to other camps or issue the "verification" cards which would entitle them to free food, blankets and tents.

"We need shelter as soon as possible," said Amir Gul. "Either start the verification or shoot us."

The UN says it has the money to act if Pakistan gives permission. Another 10,000 people could be moved to Shamshatoo and the remainder at Jalozai could be moved to a better site nearby which has a proper water supply.

"The tragedy with Jalozai is that we are not able to do anything to help these people and that is why the conditions have deteriorated," said Yusuf Hassan, a spokesman for the UN High Commissioner for Refugees. "This is eroding all the good Pakistan has done in the past."

In the camp a thin veneer of ordinary life remains. Shortly before sunset men kneel in the brick ruins of an old mosque and bow in prayer. A handful of children fly tatty, paper kites low over the tents and an ice-cream seller pushes his cart home.

A crowd gathers as Khan Kochai, one of the camp's elders, describes how families are starving, forced to buy stale bread from the local market, which they soak into a barely edible mush.

"They have built us toilets, but when the stomach is hungry who needs toilets? They built a helicopter pad here for Kofi Annan. We wanted him to see the problem but the Pakistanis would not let him come."

He pulls from his inside waistcoat pocket a typewritten letter which he had hoped to pass to the UN secretary general.

"Please give us a chance in the world," it reads. "And suffice of free living to breathe from good and free air."

fields.headline: Unions angered by Corus figures
fields.standfirst: Corus chairman stands by decision to cut 9,000 jobs
fields.trailText: Corus, the country's biggest steelmaker, yesterday re-lit the row over a massive restructuring programme by revealing that it had set aside £250m for redundancies.
fields.body:
Corus, the country's biggest steelmaker, yesterday re-lit the row over a massive restructuring programme by revealing that it had set aside £250m for redundancies.

Most of that - £202m - was taken in last year accounts and helped the former British Steel run up a £1.1bn operating loss in the 15 months to December 31. Labour leaders last night claimed Corus would have a deficit of only £130m if the cost of closures and redundancies had been stripped out.

"Steel is a cyclical business, and in good years you make very large profits indeed. These comparatively small operating losses are no reason to panic and certainly no reason to swing the axe," insisted Michael Leahy, general secretary of the ISTC steel union.

He said he hoped to persuade Corus to adopt an alternative strategy when the two sides met later this month.

Analysts who asked not to be named said it was too early to say whether Corus had turned the corner. The stock has been heavily sold in the last week, and yesterday closed up 8p at 68p.

webTitle: Berlusconi in trouble on and off pitch

fields.headline: Berlusconi in trouble on and off pitch
fields.trailText: Worried that AC Milan's recent failures on the football field may tarnish his image as a winner just two months before a general election, Silvio Berlusconi has stepped in to sack the team's coach.
fields.body:
Worried that AC Milan's recent failures on the football field may tarnish his image as a winner just two months before a general election, Silvio Berlusconi has stepped in to sack the team's coach.

As honorary chairman, Mr Berlusconi has watched the club's increasingly dismal performances with alarm.

On Tuesday it crashed out of the Champions League. On Wednesday, Mr Berlusconi watched as the conflict of interest between his politics and business was the subject of a satirical show on state-run RAI television.

The comedy show, Satyricon, provided the unusual setting for the presentation of a book detailing the alleged links between Mr Berlusconi's entourage and the Mafia, culled from court papers, Bank of Italy investigations and an interview with a magistrate.

Among the claims in The Odour of Money is that Mr Berlusconi's 1994 government made tax changes under which his Mediaset broadcasting group gained £65m.

Mr Berlusconi's success in the 1994 general election coincided with trophies for AC Milan both in Italy's Serie A and in Europe. But the team is now languishing in mid-table.

Mr Berlusconi decided that enough was enough: coach Alberto Zaccheroni, who is also suspected of harbouring leftwing sympathies, had to go.

His trusted pollsters say the team's bad results have been eroding his advantage over the centre-left candidate, the former mayor of Rome, Francesco Rutelli.

The media magnate distanced himself from the club management, insisting that he was just the honorary chairman and that he could not take time off from politics to pay closer attention to the team's flagging fortunes.

This was the first time that the coach of a major Italian club had been sacked by a passer-by, scoffed the Left Democrat MP Giuseppe Giulietti.

Mr Berlusconi's political rivals have been quick to exploit his sporting discomfiture and are fielding the former AC Milan star Gianni Rivera to run against him in his Milan seat.

"When Milan was top of the league he was the architect of the victories. Now that the results are lacking he has nothing to do with it," said the Rome daily, La Repubblica.

Mr Rivera, who is now undersecretary of defence, said he intended to emphasise Mr Berlusconi's intolerable conflict of interests.

"It's to be hoped that Berlusconi decides to take a real interest in the fortunes of Milan," Mr Rivera told the Turin daily, La Stampa. "In that way we would resolve two problems in one go: his conflict of interests in politics would end and Milan would return to its ancient splendour. Perhaps."

webTitle: Child health worker arrested over four deaths

fields.headline: Child health worker arrested over four deaths
fields.trailText: A hospital health care assistant has been arrested by police investigating the "unexpected" deaths of four children on a paediatric ward at a hospital in Berkshire.
fields.body:
A hospital health care assistant has been arrested by police investigating the "unexpected" deaths of four children on a paediatric ward at a hospital in Berkshire.

The unnamed woman, who worked on ward 24 at the Wexham Park hospital in Slough, was questioned by officers from Thames Valley police after consultant paediatricians became concerned about the number of deaths on the ward.

Four children, who were all being treated for non life-threatening illnesses, have died on the ward in the last eight months, compared with the usual average of two or three unexpected deaths a year.

The hospital yesterday refused to confirm if the health care assistant, who has been released on police bail pending further inquiries, was the last member of staff with the children before they died or whether they shared the same cause of death.

Margaret Edwards, chief executive of the Heatherwood and Wexham Park Hospitals Trust, said the deaths could all just be "coincidence".

"Taken in isolation all these deaths don't give us any reason for concern. Concern has been raised because we experienced more deaths than we expected.

"It may just be a statistical cluster, a coincidence. But we have taken it seriously and asked the police to investigate."

Ms Edwards said the circumstances surrounding the death of each child had been reviewed at the time as a matter of routine and nothing suspicious had been found. Postmortem examinations to determine the cause of death proved inconclusive.

The hospital and the police refused to reveal the identities of the children to protect their families. But the coroner, Peter Bedford, confirmed the last alleged victim, who is understood to have died very recently, was a baby.

Ms Edwards said she had first been alerted to the fact there might be a problem on Monday night when consultant paediatricians who work on the ward had gone to see her and expressed concern at the number of unexpected deaths. Thames Valley police were called in, and on Wednesday evening they arrested the nursing assistant. She has also been suspended.

Detective Superintendent Steve Morrison, of Thames Valley police murder squad, said the parents of the children, who were all aged under 16, were distressed by news of the arrest and investigation.

"Clearly, they are very concerned to see that the truth of what has happened is established. We can sympathise with how traumatic this must be for them."

A family liaison officer had been drafted in to to keep the families informed about the progress of the investigation.

Mr Morrison confirmed his officers would be working closely with other constabularies, including Essex, which investigated a nurse over similar allegations last year. He said there were no immediate plans to exhume bodies of any buried children.

"This is a very early stage in the inquiry. Clearly, a number of people will be interviewed immediately and we will interview anyone who can help us with our inquiry.

"It will take weeks and months to get a clear picture of what is happening."

Mr Morrison emphasised that all the deaths had occurred on ward 24, which is staffed by 40 nurses and cares for up to 30 children. He said none of the trust's other wards or children's services were under investigation.

An incident room has been set up at Maidenhead police station and 15 detectives have been assigned to investigate.

Staff at the hospital, which is in parkland on the outskirts of Slough, were said to be "very distressed" over the allegations about their colleague.

fields.headline: Crisis? What crisis? asks P&O chief
fields.standfirst: P&O ferries
fields.trailText: Lord Sterling, one of the country's top industrialists, yesterday accused the City of panicking over the state of the US economy and driving down the price of shares in London unnecessarily.
fields.body:
Lord Sterling, one of the country's top industrialists, yesterday accused the City of panicking over the state of the US economy and driving down the price of shares in London unnecessarily.

The P&O chairman said his global ferries, container shipping and ports business saw little sign of the doom and gloom being peddled by stock market pundits.

"People are talking themselves into a panic and the fur ther you are away from the stock market the less you are affected. It [bad news] is just not apparent in my business."

P&O, which shed its cruise line division last November, announced pre-tax profits before exceptionals of £269m, 12% up on the same period last year and ahead of forecasts.

The figures were boosted by a strong performance from P & O Nedlloyd, the Anglo-Dutch joint shipping venture where operating profits rose from £1m to £66m.

This was even more surpris ing given a £102m rise in the bill for fuel costs which had to be shared by the two companies.

The rising price of oil did seriously dent ferry profits. That side of the business, which mainly comprises cross-Channel services, recorded a £20m profit compared with £60m last time. It was also damaged also by the ending of duty-free sales.

Lord Sterling said it was ironic that technology stocks were at the forefront of the stock market disarray, given improved communication systems were one of the drivers behind his company's success.

"All our companies are making every conceivable use of new information technology and it is driving down our cost structures in a manner that would have been unbelievable five years ago," he explained.

He said the P & O Nedlloyd website was recording 4,000 users a day, six times the level last year.

The share price ended the day up 15p at 275p.

fields.headline: Euro falls to new dollar low
fields.standfirst:
Euro currency pushed back to less than 90 cents to the dollar

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Impatient investors pushed the euro back below 90 cents to the dollar last night, as they grew weary of the single currency's failure to take advantage of the savage fall in US stock in recent weeks.
fields.body:
Impatient investors pushed the euro back below 90 cents to the dollar last night, as they grew weary of the single currency's failure to take advantage of the savage fall in US stock in recent weeks.

Despite the decision by the European Central Bank to keep Euroland interest rates on hold at 4.75%, the single currency fell as low as 89.85c, sinking to levels not seen since December 20.

Share prices around the world paused for breath yesterday after Wednesday's panic selling, providing the impetus for the dollar's rally.

"People are cutting out of long positions in the euro, disappointed that the price action hasn't been more encouraging," said one trader at a European bank in New York.

Economists had expected the ECB's governing council to leave borrowing costs at 4.75% after it issued an upbeat forecast for euro zone growth last week, but many say it will cut rates when inflation tapers off.

"They will adopt a wait and see stance until more precise figures are available," said Michael Schubert, chief euro economist at Commerzbank in Frankfurt. "If there is a decline in inflation we could see a rate cut in May or June - unless the situation in the United States worsens."

The Frankfurt-based institution is the only central bank not to have cut borrowing costs since concerns were first raised last December about the weakness of the US economy.

The Federal Reserve is expected to cut US rates for the third time this year when it meets on Tuesday.

After the turbulence of the last few days there was some late good news for traders. A last-minute spurt saw the FTSE 100 index close up 103.3 points or 1.8% at 5,729.2 yesterday, although moments before the close of the market it had only managed a gain of about 43 points.

By noon in New York, the Nasdaq composite index had risen 39.84 points to 2,011.93, while Dow Jones industrials gained 70.41 to 10,043.87.

European investors seeking bargains on Wall Street helped spur the recovery and added to the euro's woes.

"Foreigners are playing 'double or quits' in US stocks and direct investment, not yet ready to give up the equity game and knowing that Euroland growth prospects are mediocre," said Charles Dumas from Lombard Street.

Support for those members of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee seeking to follow the ECB's cautious lead was provided by robust spending figures from Britain's high streets.

The office for national statistics said sales surged 0.6% in February, against expectations for a 0.1% rise, to stand a hefty 5.8% higher than a year earlier. The annual figure was the strongest for more than a year.

"Bouyant retail sales data suggests the domestic economy is accelerating, not slowing," said Richard Iley from ABN AMRO. "Overall, these data underline the case for another month of inertia by the MPC."

But other economists said robust consumer spending was insulating the UK from the US slowdown. "The key question is how consumers will react to the flow of bad news from the US and to headlines of tumbling stock prices," said Daniel Kaye, of Capital Economics.

Engineering firms remain sceptical about the benefits of the single currency, according to a survey today. Two-thirds of those questioned by the Engineering Employers Federation were opposed to setting a date for joining the euro.

webTitle: Business: Light at end of Nokia's tunnel

fields.headline: Nokia finds a way through the telecoms gloom
fields.standfirst:
Nokia successfully coping with difficult trading conditions

Nokia
Vodafone
Motorola
Ericsson
Deutsche Bank
fields.trailText: Nokia, the mobile phone manufacturer, yesterday provided some welcome relief for investors in the telecoms sector with a statement suggesting it was managing to weather the difficult trading conditions.
fields.body:
Nokia, the mobile phone manufacturer, yesterday provided some welcome relief for investors in the telecoms sector with a statement suggesting it was managing to weather the difficult trading conditions.

Despite admitting that sales have been dented by slowing demand, Nokia said in a trading statement that earnings during the first quarter would meet expectations.

In the present climate, that was enough to inspire a 13% rise in the Helsinki-based firm's share price to €28.

The statement followed profit warnings from its chief rivals, Motorola and Ericsson, and investors had been expecting Nokia to follow suit. "Markets had expected something much worse," said one analyst.

Other stocks in the European and US telecoms sector were carried in Nokia's wake - including Alcatel, which rose 3%, Vodafone, which climbed 2.8% to 207p and Orange, 3% higher at 556p. Deutsche Telekom bounced back by 5%.

"We feel confident about our strengths and performance during the early months of the year," said Nokia's chairman and chief executive, Jorma Ollila. "Despite the more difficult market conditions, we have been able to show good progress. We expect to see solid growth for the first quarter as a whole, with better than anticipated margins".

Nokia said sales for the first quarter would probably show 20% growth compared to previous estimates of 25%-30%. It has also lowered its forecast for the market by the end of 2001 to 450m-500m handsets in circulation from an earlier estimate of 500m-550m.

"More challenging times like these test your mettle as a company. We believe that truly great companies emerge much stronger," Mr Ollila added.

The number of Nokia handsets held in inventory was also lower than at the year's end, the company said, which should mean a continued healthy flow of deliveries.

Mr Ollila said the company had maintained margins and earnings growth by quickening the pace of its continuing programmes to wring further efficiencies and cost savings from the business.

The statement also said Nokia had managed to increase its market share during the downturn.

Ericsson said on Monday that it would post a loss in the first quarter, while last month Motorola warned of a dramatic slowdown in sales and announced its intention to cut some 7,000 jobs.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Fund rules 'hit venture capital'
fields.body:
Fund rules 'hit venture capital'

Britain could lose its leading position in venture capital and private equity investment in Europe unless the government revamps rules covering the industry, the British Venture Capital Association said yesterday.

Speaking at the National Association of Pension Funds conference in Eastbourne, Edmund Truell, vice-chairman of the BVCA, said regulations covering pension fund investment in private equity and new financial services and market action rules could drive the industry offshore.

BMW falls short of expectations

BMW said profit rose 50% in 2000 to €1.663bn (£1.05bn), short of expectations. Analysts had expected BMW, freed of Rover, to post a profit from ordinary activities of about €1.97bn, against €1.11bn in 1999.

Helped by strong car sales, BMW said net profit before extraordinary items rose to €1.026bn from €664m in 1999. With exceptionals, including charges for Rover, it made a net loss of €2.49bn in 1999. It will increase its dividend for ordinary shares to €0.46 from €0.40. BMW said it made provisions of €240m for a European Union directive for car makers to recycle vehicles.

Virgin Atlantic suffers drop

Virgin Atlantic, owned by Singapore Airlines and Richard Branson's Virgin Group, hit turbulence last year because of rising oil prices and strong competition on its Atlantic routes.

Profits for the year to April 2000 fell 60% to £40m. The company said it expected an increase in profits and revenues in the current year.

Gillette boss gets £6m to go

US razor and batteries group Gillette, is to pay former chairman Michael Hawley $8.7m (£6m) after his resignation amid the company's declining fortunes. It also gave his successor, James Kilts, a lucrative option package to restore profits that suffered under Mr Hawley's 18-month stint. He will receive a salary and bonus of$2m in his first year.

Pernod toasts acquisitions

French drinks group Pernod Ricard announced an 8.4% increase in annual pre-tax profits to €369m (£230m), helped by purchase of spirits brands such as Chivas Regal and Martell from Seagram. Acquisitions have made Pernod one of the largest producers of Scotch. It is selling Orangina, Oddbins and grocery business BWG.

Helped by strong car sales, BMW said net profit before extraordinary items rose to €1.026bn from €664m in 1999. With exceptionals, including charges for Rover, it made a net loss of €2.49bn in 1999. It will increase its dividend for ordinary shares to €0.46 from €0.40. BMW said it made provisions of €240m for a European Union directive for car makers to recycle vehicles. Virgin Atlantic suffers drop Virgin Atlantic, owned by Singapore Airlines and Richard Branson's Virgin Group, hit turbulence last year because of rising oil prices and strong competition on its Atlantic routes. Profits for the year to April 2000 fell 60% to £40m. The company said it expected an increase in profits and revenues in the current year. Gillette boss gets £6m to go US razor and batteries group Gillette, is to pay former chairman Michael Hawley $8.7m (£6m) after his resignation amid the company's declining fortunes. It also gave his successor, James Kilts, a lucrative option package to restore profits that suffered under Mr Hawley's 18-month stint. He will receive a salary and bonus of$2m in his first year. Pernod toasts acquisitions French drinks group Pernod Ricard announced an 8.4% increase in annual pre-tax profits to €369m (£230m), helped by purchase of spirits brands such as Chivas Regal and Martell from Seagram. Acquisitions have made Pernod one of the largest producers of Scotch. It is selling Orangina, Oddbins and grocery business BWG.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Lorry hijacks more violent
fields.body:
Lorry hijacks more violent

The number of armed hijacks on lorry drivers rose from 51 in 1999 to 79 last year, with thieves targeting trailers with mobile phones and computer game machines, the National Stolen Lorry Load Desk said yesterday.

Thaw reveals Morse code

Actor John Thaw revealed yesterday how he resisted a part as an English baddie alongside Arnold Schwarzenegger. "I would sooner do leading parts on television than have 10 minutes in a Hollywood so-called blockbuster," said the Inspector Morse star.

£5,000 award for black PC

The Police Federation and the National Black Police Association urged the Liverpool force to eradicate discrimination after a black officer won a £5,000 claim yesterday. PC Dawn Devanna, 31, was left "bewildered, bullied, intimidated and angry" when colleagues made jokes about the Toxteth riots.

Pigeons face hawk assault

A team of harris hawks has been called in to rid a housing estate in Liverpool's Childwall Valley of its pigeon problem. Residents were plagued after a high rise block of flats was demolished in January.

£100 boost for childminders

Childminders in poor areas who lose earnings when parents move their children elsewhere will get up to £100 a week if they have a vacancy that cannot be filled within two weeks under measures announced yesterday by Margaret Hodge, the employment minister.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Clinton shortfall
fields.body:
Clinton shortfall

The legal defence fund for Bill and Hillary Clinton has raised only $750,000 (£520,000) in the past eight months, leaving the former president and his wife nearly $4m short of their legal bills. In three years it has raised $8.7m from more than 116,400 contributors, paying an average of $75. Los Angeles Times, Washington

Hostages freed

Four German tourists taken hostage by an Egyptian trying to get his German-born wife to return their two sons to his custody were freed unharmed near Luxor yesterday. The four men were flown to Cairo and were expected to fly home later in the day. AP. Luxor

Children burned

At least six Palestinian children, aged about 10-13, received light to moderate burns when a stun grenade thrown by Israeli border police landed in the courtyard of their school in Hebron, in the West Bank, yesterday. Reuters, Hebron

Editor shot

The editor of the Russian edition of Playboy, Maxim Maslakov, was recovering yesterday after being shot in the back in the car park of his Moscow office. Amelia Gentleman, Moscow
