fields.headline: On the farm
fields.standfirst: As the size of the cull increases, our diarist anxiously checks the temperature of suspect sheep
fields.trailText: As the size of the cull increases, our diarist anxiously checks the temperature of suspect sheep
fields.body:
Today I am really very upset. This is because of a number of things, including tiredness, pre-lambing jitters (an annual and very common affliction), and immense sadness over learning about the loss of a 200-year-old herd of Belted Galloways at Twynholm. When the children were small, we spent almost all our summer holidays in Dumfries and Galloway, and we loved to see the black-and-white striped "Belties" in their fields; they are absolutely irreplaceable. But mainly I am upset because of a report on Channel 4's seven o'clock news, which caused us to hardly sleep a wink.

Was there any truth in the report, or was it sensationalism? I really don't know (although I am trying to find out), but it frightened me. Let's hope it is only a "worst-case scenario".

The news story concerned the government's supposed Plan B. We saw an example of a slaughter and vaccination programme: Cumbria, Dumfries and Galloway, and Northumberland were "ring-fenced", and Jon Snow defined how the animals would be slaughtered or vaccinated inside the infected area. He calmly described how vets would watch carefully for the all-clear, and then once the disease had died out, all the vaccinated stock would be killed too - in order to return to our clean status.

I was absolutely speechless to start with, and then the phone started to ring: others had seen it too, and were equally horrified. We know the disease has been spreading faster than Maff can run, and we know that a conscious effort must be made to get in front of it. So all sheep classed as dangerous contacts from two livestock markets - Welshpool on February 19, and Northampton on February 15 and 22 - if found, will be culled. But where will it all end? And is it all part of Tony Blair's grand plan to hold the election at any price?

Nearer to home, the effects on so many other people's lives continues. The gates of Newcastle's Town Moor have been locked in an effort to keep it clear of infection, and the Northumberland county show has been cancelled.

Meanwhile, a farmer I know, Tom Warde-Aldham, is outraged because the insurance broker his family has used for 30 years has decided that, from this year's renewal on March 1, it will not be able to provide cover for foot and mouth. Tom, whose holding is about five miles from a confirmed case at Carterway Heads, County Durham, urges everyone to check their policies.

On the farm front we have one ewe suffering from twin lamb disease (pregnancy toxaemia). She was stuck on her back yesterday, and the strain on her system was too much. We are giving her calcium and a special energy-boosting tonic to try to get her eating again.

Our vet, Iain Carrington, has sent us more information about the notoriously hard-to-spot symptoms of foot and mouth. We now take the temperatures of any suspect lame or unwell animal. Normal sheep lameness should not lead to fever.

The outside thermometer is broken, so we have to use the one from the bathroom. Let's hope none of us runs a fever: we won't want the article back in the house after inserting it in a sheep's rectum.

I have just watched the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, on television. It appears that a great many animals are to be killed in our northern region and across into southern Scotland - possibly all livestock residing within a 3km radius of a confirmed case. I am not surprised, but very, very sad. Yet I cannot help wondering what took them so long to make this decision? After all, if they had been more ruthless at the start, as many farmers wanted them to be, so many more animals would still be alive.

But how will this bloodbath (because that is what it will be) be accomplished by Maff? We know that the current diagnosis and slaughter has so far proved too big a task. Perhaps they will be able to use abattoirs, and take the animals away, which is what happened to Peter's cows in 1980.

Waitrose has now lost one of its main pork suppliers. Around 4,000 pigs were killed as dangerous contacts, and the upland livestock industry is about to lose some of its finest breeding stock. Spring has clearly been cancelled, and I know the tears will be flowing in many a farm kitchen today. I feel sick and very cold, in need of a hot bath and a cup of tea, or perhaps something stronger.

webTitle: Martin Woollacott: The mishandling of Kosovo

fields.headline: Taking the easy way out has led to suffering in Kosovo
fields.standfirst:
All Albanians need help in combating the dangers around them

Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: The Balkan wars have, over the past 10 years, constituted one long series of lessons in the foolishness of taking the easy way out. Hardly ever have western governments asked themselves what was the most effective way of dealing with the crises in that region with which they were confronted. Their question was always different: what was the least risky and least costly way of responding?
fields.body:
The Balkan wars have, over the past 10 years, constituted one long series of lessons in the foolishness of taking the easy way out. Hardly ever have western governments asked themselves what was the most effective way of dealing with the crises in that region with which they were confronted. Their question was always different: what was the least risky and least costly way of responding?

And, almost invariably, this approach, at once timorous and unrealistic, has led on to new emergencies, as it has in Kosovo and now in Macedonia. Yesterday's decision by the US to wind down its Bosnian forces will not help. While it will probably not make Bosnia itself a more dangerous place, it sends signals that could further weaken international efforts to keep the peace elsewhere in former Yugoslavia.

It would be too much to say that the victory in Kosovo has been thrown away. As an indirect result of that operation, Serbia is back on the road toward normal national life. Croatia was already following that route and continues to do so. Bosnia remains a fragmented place, but violence has ended and nationalist madness is in check. In Kosovo, the lives of ordinary Albanians, although not of Serbs, are better than they would have been in other circumstances, and many useful and worthwhile things have been done. But the way in which Kosovo has been administered by its international protectors over the past 20 months has been deeply flawed. A lack of political courage and a failure of military will means that those who are supposedly in charge of Kosovo are temporising with the forces of political extremism and organised crime.

It is truly a shameful thing that the Kosovo Force should be watching as Serbian soldiers return to the buffer zone to do the job of keeping guerrillas out of Serbian territory which the international forces were unwilling to do. It is equally shameful that K-For should have permitted guerrillas to cross into Macedonia and cause increasingly serious trouble there. This is not to expect perfect control in remote border areas but rather to ask where is the evidence, not just of effective surveillance, but of effective interdiction? Where were the ambushes, the arrests, and the detentions? With a few exceptions they never happened, because K-For, and particularly its American contingent, did not want to fight or, more accurately, were under instructions from their home capitals to avoid fighting. The fear of taking a few casualties in such encounters was part of a larger anxiety about ending up as an occupation force holding down a disappointed population and suffering routine attacks by guerrilla forces.

That fear, exaggerated as it may be, cannot be wholly dismissed. But the problem of the border troublemakers did not have to be dealt with by military means alone. In a small society like that of Kosovo, there are few real secrets and few genuine renegades. There are Kosovo political leaders, some of them yesterday's Kosovo Liberation Army commanders, who are either responsible for spreading violence in southern Serbia and northern Macedonia or well know those who are responsible. And they have, it needs scarcely be added, the means of stopping these activities. What is true of the cross- border situation is equally true of the attacks on Serbs, and of proliferating criminal activity in Kosovo. That these leaders have not used their power to curb these evils suggests that the international administration has not employed the leverage it possesses to the extent it should have done.

The political history of the international occupation of Kosovo began with the failure to prevent attacks on Serbs and continued with the failure to prevent the takeover of local government, public property, and public enterprises by KLA people. Their arrogance and corruption in the positions they seized was one of the reasons that more moderate parties than those they led did so well in the October local elections, the results of which can be counted as a success for the international administration and the people of Kosovo alike.

Yet this check to the expectation that they were just going to walk off with all the prizes has probably made it more difficult to deal with some of the former fighters, because, in their struggle to survive as big men, it makes them more dependent on violent and criminal activities.

Should one at least consider whether claims on southern Serbia or on Macedonia are justified? The answer must be in the negative, for, if there has been one principle which morally governed a decade of intervention in the Balkans, it has been that of the sanctity of the borders of the constituent states of the Yugoslav federation. Whether Kosovo itself should benefit from that principle, on the grounds that its position was virtually the same as that of a state, is an important question. The answer to it depends on Kosovo's hopes of independence. There is certainly an argument that if independence was firmly on the horizon, it would be very hard indeed for anyone with any sort of power in Kosovo to justify cross-border meddling. How could you hope that the international community would allow you to benefit from a principle which you then intended to violate?

The unsettled state of Kosovo has certainly helped to unsettle Macedonia, perhaps mainly by feeding the competition between Albanian leaders in that country. Arben Xhaferi, the "moderate" leader whose party is in the coalition government, was in the past much more extreme himself. The movement of individual leaders between moderate and extreme positions may be less propelled by ideology than by the search for tactical advantage. The newly emerged National Liberation Army in Macedonia, insofar as its line can be understood, advocates a reform of Macedonia's constitutional arrangements rather than the incorporation of Albanian areas in Kosovo. The uprising in Macedonia could be the result of an alliance of convenience between Macedonian Albanians who are for the moment political losers and Kosovan Albanians who did not get their share of the spoils in Kosovo. The trouble in Tetovo followed a rally called by organisations connected to the Albanian party which is in opposition.

On both sides of the border the picture is of political entrepreneurs contending for power and control, often using illegal or violent means, and usually heedless of the larger damage they are causing. Funding coming from the Albanian diaspora in Europe may be channelled by criminal groups who have an interest in instability, in keeping political leaders beholden to them, and in keeping the states through which their illicit business moves as weak as possible. Albanians, whether in Kosovo, Macedonia, or Albania proper, need help in combating these dangerous processes in their societies.

A Bulgarian sociologist has called Albanians "the teenagers of the Balkans", noting their impulsiveness, lack of objectivity, and limited concern for the welfare of others. These are traits explained to some extent by their difficult historical experience. It was part of the task which western countries had to take on in the Balkans to rescue Kosovans not only from their oppressors but from their own worst tendencies, but it is not clear that it has been taken up with the seriousness it deserves.

webTitle: Farmers' union to vote on new Mugabe-friendly leadership

fields.headline: Farmers' union to vote on new Mugabe-friendly leadership
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: After softening up the Zimbabwean judiciary and press, President Robert Mugabe's government has set its sights on further weakening white farmers by dividing the Commercial Farmers Union.
fields.body:
After softening up the Zimbabwean judiciary and press, President Robert Mugabe's government has set its sights on further weakening white farmers by dividing the Commercial Farmers Union.

A campaign to sack its the white leaders and replace them with blacks close to the government has already split the organisation and forced it to call an extraordinary general meeting next Wednesday. It will consider whether to maintain the policy of opposing Mr Mugabe's farm seizures through the courts or back down and accept the seizure of nearly half its members' land.

More than 2,000 farms are illegally occupied by Mr Mugabe's supporters and the police force refuses to evict them. Many of the occupiers are armed and have threatened farmers.

Seven white farmers and 12 black farm workers have been killed in the past year by pro-government militants.The disruptions have cut agricultural production 30%.

Against this background, Nick Swanepoel, a former president of the union who boasts of close relations with the Mugabe regime, is calling on the white farmers to sack their leaders and replace them with people more friendly to the government. In return, he says, the farmers will get a better deal from Mr Mugabe.

"I believe getting a new leadership and making some compromises will improve our dialogue with the government and, at the end of the day, that will help to solve our problems," he said.

He has crossed the country in recent weeks to trying to persuade the union's 4,000 members to support his plan at the meeting. He is backed by one of the country's wealthiest businessmen, John Bredenkamp, who has strong links with the government.

They say the change of leadership will not only end the violence but also bring funds from the US and other western donors to pay for the seized land. US officials say Mr Bredenkamp's claim that the US supports the plans is "entirely unfounded and far fetched".

Jim Sinclair, a former union president, said: "If we fall for this we're digging our own grave. It is another attempt to strike at this country's civil society."

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 As you may have read elsewhere, Spectator owner Conrad Black hits prolific form again on the mag's letters page, writing at length about anti-semitism following the recent anti-Israel rant by Taki-George that so upset him. Although stopping short of sacking the Cypriot, Mr Black does issue a warning. "Fair comment and non-venomous ethnic reflections that might offend the politically correct" - all that is Canadian, by the way, for baiting humourless Guardian gits - "are perfectly acceptable," writes Conrad. "However our publications will not be used for the propagation of incitements to racial or religious bigotry against Jews or anyone else." Indeed so? Let us take the proprietor on a trip down memory lane to the Spectator of January 9 1998. Here Taki considered Deborah Bosely, Richard Ingrams's girlfriend who'd just had a baby by a black neighbour. "The natural father is keen to be involved with the upbringing of the child," wrote T-G. "Good for Sambo ... Go for it, Sambo , you'd be doing the kid a favour." If Mr Black requires any more archive material, it would be a pleasure to supply it.

Scholars of the Jewish Passover will be more than ever reminded of the 10 plagues visited on Egypt by news that (following rodent infestations, floods, a spate of burst pipes forcing total lavatorial closure and the restaurant failing a health check) the "water features" in the foyer are clogged up by an infestation of algae caused, apparently, by the sun coming through acres of glass. We are trying to get some idea of the cost of cleaning them out. Although not terribly hard.

 The saving grace of any disaster is that smart business cookies will find a way to profiteer, and with foot and mouth it's hats off to the Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions. There a sign is posted in the canteen declaring that, due to the outbreak, bacon is now available only by request, and at the bargain price of £1 per rasher. Rumours that newly appointed F&M task force supremo Michael Meacher plans to undercut the canteen by setting up a bacon butty stall outside the DETR in a bid to deal with his 29 council tax demands appear, prima facie, to be mischievous.

 Yesterday's cock up concerned The Servant. In the revival of the play at the Lyric, Hammersmith, Jack Davenport is playing Mr Tony, the part played in the movie by James Fox and not Dirk Bogarde who played the creepy butler. Exactly where today's howler is hidden I'm not sure, but thanks in anticipation to all of you who will be in touch with the readers' editor later today to point it out.

 We end as we began with the Spectator, and editors past and present. Johnson boys Mad Frankie and Boris the Jackal have both referred lately to Gordon Brown dyeing his hair, after apparently learning this from March 7's Financial Times. I ring the Jackal to complain only to hear "the guv'nor's gawn up west", from the Arthur Mullard soundalike. But Gordon's hair dye, I say, surely the guv'nor first read it here last year? "Read your Diary?" says the voice. "My gaffer wouldn't wipe his ..." All right, it's not for nothing that we carry the strapline The Column You Know You Can Safely Ignore, we know that. But would a little tact really hurt?

Mr Wolff had to chase the pigs some way, so some huffing and puffing must have ensued. There is no word yet, however, if Mr Wolff is big or bad, or both; nor of collateral damage to any domestic premises. Still, early days.

webTitle: Comment: no freedom of speech for Conrad Black's commentators

fields.headline: Bullied into silence on Israel
fields.standfirst:
There is no freedom of speech for Conrad Black's commentators

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: There are few more uncomfortable places for a foreign correspondent to be posted than Israel. Opinions are so polarised that it is almost impossible to write a line on the conflict without outraging someone.
fields.body:
There are few more uncomfortable places for a foreign correspondent to be posted than Israel. Opinions are so polarised that it is almost impossible to write a line on the conflict without outraging someone.

Since the second intifada exploded last October, as criticism of Israel has escalated and casualties mounted towards the 400 mark, this fact has been brought home especially to those who deal sympathetically with the plight of the Palestinians. All have found themselves deluged with complaints, which not infrequently include innuendoes - or outright accusations - of anti-semitism.

No one has been more ready to use this weapon than Conrad Black. Black is the proprietor of the Hollinger Group, whose British publications include the Daily and Sunday Telegraphs and the Spectator, and who also owns the Jerusalem Post. The different papers all reflect Black's notably rightwing brand of Zionism which tends to regard the Palestinians, like their leader Yasser Arafat (to quote from an article he wrote in the Post in 1993,) as "vile and primitive".

As a result, uniquely among British papers, the foreign pages of the Daily and Sunday Telegraphs have contained a notable absence of clear, critical reporting of Israel's deadly methods of suppressing Palestinian dissent. Their comment pages have been even more extreme.

Recent highlights have included Edward Luttwack, a former Israeli tank commander and friend of Black, writing to celebrate the election of Sharon whom he praised as "a master of outwitting his opponents", and a "raging bull who is really a matador" - as if he were some sort of jolly sporting hero rather than the man who failed to stop the single most gruesome massacre in the entire Arab-Israeli conflict. Then there are the regular appearances of Black's wife, Barbara Amiel, who recently concluded a two-page spread in the Telegraph by comparing the Palestinians to "animals".

It was against this background that a major row erupted three weeks ago when the Spectator columnist Taki (familiar to Guardian readers from his frequent appearances as a runaway waiter in Matthew Norman's diary) broke the unspoken ban on criticising Israel in a Black paper by writing a piece which Black described, in an emotional 3,000-word retort, as "almost worthy of Goebbels".

Since then the Spectator letters page has been like a war zone, with Black flinging increasingly hysterical accusations at anyone who dissents from his views. Lord Gilmour, who had written to defend Taki, was accused of "seeming like a common or garden Jew baiter". In a second letter in the same letters page, more than half of which was filled by Black himself, Piers Paul Read, AN Wilson, Charles Glass and I - all Spectator writers who had written to protest at the skewed coverage of Israel-Palestine in Black's papers - were denounced by Black as representative of "the depths of the problem of anti-semitism in the British media".

In fact, while anti-Jewish writing is today more or less confined to a few neo-Nazi hate rags, straightforwardly racist depictions of the Arabs are still widespread and relatively acceptable: in the past few months we have had Congressional candidates calling the Palestinians "lower than pond scum" and a senior Israeli rabbi denouncing them as "snakes and scorpions", quite apart from the epithets Black and his wife have thrown at them.

Yet for all its elements of farce, the tussle in the Spectator letters page has highlighted a serious issue. A press baron is an immensely powerful figure. With that power, however, comes responsibilities, and those responsibilities are abused when he makes it clear that certain areas are off-limits to legitimate enquiry, and that careers will suffer if those limits are crossed.

Black's propensity for bullying was starkly demonstrated when nearly half the journalists on the Jerusalem Post were sacked when they showed what he judged to be an unhealthy enthusiasm for Palestinian rights. Now, after Black has made the strength of his prejudices clear, is it really likely that any Telegraph journalist will ever again put his neck and career on the line and write frankly of the sufferings of the Palestinians under Israeli occupation? Or that his editors will have the courage to publish such articles?

By insinuating that those who criticise Israel are actually closet neo-Nazis, Black is effectively trying to suppress and muzzle justified criticism of a thoroughly brutal occupation, and to bully into submission any of his writers who disagree with him. In doing so he makes himself complicit in the continued enslavement of the Palestinian people, the on-going seizure of their land, and the systematic abuse of their human rights. To put himself in this position, while appearing to be speaking up against racism, seem to me to be beneath contempt.

fields.headline: Private Lives
fields.standfirst: Should I put up with my unloving mother's visits for the sake of my son?
fields.trailText: Should I put up with my unloving mother's visits for the sake of my son?
fields.body:
My relationship with my mother is abysmal and I'm considering severing links. I do not believe she loves me at all. For as long as I can recall she has periodically stopped speaking to me, without provocation. Eventually she comes around, without apology. She presented herself as attentive at my wedding four years ago, having shown no interest in the preparations. Then I decided to withdraw, as I realised that the more I hope for love, the more she disappoints me. However, I contacted her after my son's birth last year and during her three subsequent visits her interest has focused upon him. My husband believes we should not deny her a relationship with our son. Should I put up with such treatment for the sake of my mother's relationship with her grandchild?

Put your happiness first

Speaking as someone who has been the grandchild in a similar situation, I think your happiness as your son's mother should come before your son's relationship with his grandmother. My mother had a dreadful relationship with her own mother, but endured years of family visits to me and my two siblings so we could have a relationship with our grandmother. As we got older, we became increasingly aware of the tension in the house every time these visits took place, which was unpleasant and upsetting for us all.

Eventually, when I was about 10, the visits stopped and my mum cut off all contact with my grandmother. The relationship was never re-established, and my grandmother has since died. I didn't miss the contact with her at all, and it was obvious that our mother was relieved not to have to endure her presence any longer.

Do not feel guilty for depriving your son of his grandmother - she is responsible for her behaviour and the loss of her relationship with you, and he will not thank you for having to play piggy in the middle between his mother and grandmother. Tell her what you intend to do (ie sever links) and why. It is up to her to make amends.

Name and address withheld

Tell her how you feel

Don't even consider severing links with your mother. She will probably become your best friend. My mother died nearly 30 years ago, so she never knew my three daughters and didn't have the opportunity to tell me how they should be brought up or whether I should return to work when the youngest started school etc. In spite of that, I miss her dreadfully and now that my daughters are leaving home after university, I wish I could ask her how she felt when I left home.

It seems, from speaking to friends whose mothers are still alive, that they become increasingly close the older they become and the more experiences they share. I sometimes feel I am being fitted in to my daughters' busy lives and that there is no time to talk. It would be easy for me to just slip out of their lives. Make time to talk to your mother and tell her how you feel.

Name and address withheld

Don't waste your time

Trust your instincts and feelings - if you believe that your mother does not love you, you are probably right. It happens, despite what many will tell you. If you can come to accept this while you are a young woman with much to look forward to, you have a good chance of being happy.

Don't spend the rest of your mother's life in an almost certainly hopeless attempt to persuade her to love you through your son or by whatever other means, as I did to my cost. Your mother's lack of love for you is not your fault; it is her loss. You may well find in the future that other family members and close friends will confirm what you already suspect - that your mother is incapable of loving anyone. Given this, what does she have to offer your son in a relationship with him? It will lead only to grief and rifts within your potentially happy home. Your son will understand later on when you explain things to him honestly. Be brave - cut your ties!

Helen Young, Halifax

Let your son stay in touch

My relationship with my mother was abysmal too, and for years I fantasised about severing connections with her, until I found the courage two years ago, in my late 30s. My mother was manipulative and critical, and did not really love me. Despite this I continued a relationship with her in the hope that one day I would get the love and praise I craved from her.

Eventually I realised this would never happen and brought matters to a close. My sister chose the same path for the same reasons. She kept lines of communication open so that her two children could have contact with their grandmother, but sadly she has shown little interest in them. We both feel relieved and liberated by ending the farce that was our relationship with the woman who gave birth to us.

By all means break off contact with her for your own sake, but leave the possibility for her to have contact with your child. Make sure you manage this relationship on your terms. You know in your heart the right course of action, so don't be afraid of following your instincts.

Name and address withheld

Next weeK

My partner of five years, with whom I have a two-year-old child, is addicted to telephone sex lines. After I found this out from his mobile phone bill, he admitted that he has used them since he was a teenager. He also said that it is a gender thing - men need cheap thrills. We're in our late 20s and I'm an attractive woman who loves sex. Why aren't I enough? I made him understand how I felt about him calling these lines by describing myself getting off on what a man might say to me on a sex line. He was disgusted by the image and said that, in reality, he wouldn't be able to cope with it at all. It seems that it is acceptable for men to do this, but not women. I need some honest answers from both men and women. Is this a universal fact of life that I must get used to?

Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words.
Write to Private Lives, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, fax 020-7239 9935, email private.lives@theguardian.com (please do not send attachments).

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Zelig | The Mummy | The Wings Of The Dove | The Deer Hunter | Fatal Attraction
fields.body:
Films

Zelig (Woody Allen, 1983) 6pm, FilmFour Brilliant Woody comedy in which he plays Leonard Zelig, a nebulous figure who, like Forrest Gump only funnier, crops up on the periphery of historical events: with the pope on the balcony; in the garden with F Scott Fitzgerald; behind a Hitler giving it the sturm-und-drang. A superbly crafted treatise on conformity.

The Mummy (Stephen Sommers, 1999) 8pm, Sky Premier Indiana Jones meets the Evil Dead in this boisterous remake of the classic horror, with gruesome make-up and extra-special effects allowing a monstrous Arnold Vosloo to lumber about in the title role. Brendan Fraser is the gung-ho soldier of fortune providing the muscle for a 1920s expedition to Egypt. Rachel Weisz is the obligatory brainy beauty leading the show. Formulaic, but highly entertaining.

The Wings Of The Dove (Iain Softley, 1997) 8pm, FilmFour Softley and scriptwriter Hossein Amini create a surprisingly modern romantic drama out of the Henry James novel. Set in Edwardian London and Venice, it has Helena Bonham Carter remaking her prim Merchant-Ivory image: as well-to-do Kate, she is involved in a heated affair with lowly Merton (Linus Roache), and is prepared to act disgracefully to keep both him and her position in society. Alison Elliott plays her unfortunate friend; Elizabeth McGovern, Charlotte Rampling and Michael Gambon are high-class support.

The Deer Hunter (Michael Cimino, 1978) 10pm, FilmFour Deeply moving account of the Vietnam war as experienced by three Pennsylvanian steelworkers. Initially dwelling poignantly on a wedding celebration, it plunges into hellish battle, and grows even darker in an obliterating conclusion. The performances are excellent, from Robert De Niro, whose Michael is a survivor through force of will, to Christopher Walken's living-dead Nick and the dignified suffering of Meryl Streep's Linda, waiting back home. Shockingly violent but a residual human warmth lingers.

Fatal Attraction (Adrian Lyne, 1987) 10pm, Sky MovieMax A crude but effective thriller which set the benchmark for a new wave of demonic women (Basic, Instinct, The Hand That Rocks The Cradle and all). Michael Douglas stars as a middle-aged husband who has an affair with a provocative Glenn Close: when she realises he is not going to leave his wife (Anne Archer) for her, all hell breaks loose. The sexual politics don't bear examination, but Lyne builds the tension.
Paul Howlet

Sports

European cup draws 11am, British Eurosport Draws used to be such simple affairs: a few balls and a velvet bag. Now they're all glitz and glamour. The big early-season draws, like the one for the first group stage of the Champions League, are among the highlights of the season once you work out what's going on. Fewer teams means less fun but, with so much English involvement, it's still a must-see.
Simon Burnton

fields.headline: Widdecombe's stunt with whips
fields.trailText: What on earth led Ann Widdecombe, under instructions from William Hague, to march into a committee with three whips and conduct a silent sit-down strike (My sit-in against the dictators, March 14)? This is a narrow, parliamentary dispute that has no resonance outside the Westminster village. The great "issue" was whether the criminal justice and police bill standing committee should have 15 or 16 sessions.
fields.body:
What on earth led Ann Widdecombe, under instructions from William Hague, to march into a committee with three whips and conduct a silent sit-down strike (My sit-in against the dictators, March 14)? This is a narrow, parliamentary dispute that has no resonance outside the Westminster village. The great "issue" was whether the criminal justice and police bill standing committee should have 15 or 16 sessions.

Unlike Ms Widdecombe, I was on the committee. We sat for 15 sessions and, with extended sittings, debated the bill for over 40 hours. Sixteen sittings would have given 36 hours, so the objections about time are nonsense. The committee went through the bill, clause by clause. However, in between debates on important issues like DNA, the committee was treated to lengthy unfocused speeches on a variety of subjects, all designed to use up time. The Dangerfield series may have been very entertaining on the TV, but when details were relayed at length by Tory MP Nick Hawkins, the entertainment lost its edge.

Numerous pressure groups had things to say, but reading out the entire Criminal Bar Association brief (not so brief) added little to parliamentary scrutiny.

Conservative members insisted on extensive procedural debates, mainly over complaints about lack of time, instead of getting on with examining the bill. How could this justify a deliberate sabotage of the committee and a serious breach of the rules of the House? It could only happen in the mind of MPs who have become fixated with the internal processes of parliament.

If the Tories really justify their contempt of parliament over such a petty issue, what right have they to tell animal rights protestors or any other conscientious objectors they must obey the law? This ill-judged stunt was the end of the Tories as a party of law and order.
David Lock MP
Parliamentary secretary to the lord chancellor

webTitle: Letter: The just fight for my family's land

fields.headline: The just fight for my family's land given to a white man
fields.trailText: Mhepo Mavakire, my maternal great grandfather, used to have land in Zimbabwe stretching into an area now owned by a commercial farmer (Softly, softly, March 12; Letters, March 13). It was forcibly taken from the family after the second world war and handed to a white man, because he had fought for king and country
fields.body:
Mhepo Mavakire, my maternal great grandfather, used to have land in Zimbabwe stretching into an area now owned by a commercial farmer (Softly, softly, March 12; Letters, March 13). It was forcibly taken from the family after the second world war and handed to a white man, because he had fought for king and country. Many of my relatives died during the Zimbabwean war, trying to reclaim this land. I joined Zanu in the late 60s as part of that struggle. There was no doubt in my mind, then as now, that it was both a duty and an honour to fight for that land.

What is now happening in Zimbabwe is a result of the long delay to finding a consensual way of transferring some of the land of white landowners, whose property rights flow from disposs- ession. It is not - as Peter Hain and Robin Cook would like us to think- an issue that has suddenly emerged as the result of a despot trying to stay in power.

The crisis is all the more significant in that the situation in Zimbabwe has many parallels with South Africa: it highlights the question of restoring to the people of formerly colonised countries, particularly those with a high level of white settlement, not only the right to self-government but also the right to land which was taken from them. Although there other causes for discontent in Zimbabwe, which find a limited expression within the Movement for Democratic Change, the "movement" has at its heart the aim of preserving white land-owning rights.

Since the MDC is very well-funded and their spin on current events - which is aimed at diverting attention away from the land question - has been widely accepted in Britain, there is a serious danger that British interventions in Zimbabwe will serve to exacerbate the conflict.

To most Zimbabweans, the land issue is seen as the beginning of the second major stage of their struggle. Mugabe's re-election or otherwise will not substantially affect their approach, but they do know that he offers them the best hope.
George Shire
London G.Shire@open.ac.uk

 Liz McGregor claims that the MDC "is in tatters". That could not be further from the truth. The state-instigated terror is a direct and panicky reaction against the growing strength of the MDC. Every beating acts as a recruiting sergeant for the MDC. Zanu-PF threw everything it had at the Bikita West by-election, and did win, but it cannot repeat that exercise countrywide in a presidential election. The vast majority of the population has had enough.

What we ask is for selective action against Mugabe and those who immediately surround him - including travel bans, the identification of assets held abroad contrary to Zimbabwean law, and the preparation of indictments in terms of the conventions against torture to which Zimbabwe itself is a signatory.
David Coltart MP
Shadow minister of legal affairs

fields.headline: Hard to swallow
fields.trailText: Livelihoods at risk this week include those of farmers and steelworkers. I note calls on the government to compensate farmers, plus donations to alleviate hardship by Prince Charles and the Duke of Westminster (Prince gives farmers £500,000). As for the steelworkers, it's just tough luck. Could the difference in attitude towards these occupations be a class thing?

I note calls on the government to compensate farmers, plus donations to alleviate hardship by Prince Charles and the Duke of Westminster (Prince gives farmers £500,000). As for the steelworkers, it's just tough luck. Could the difference in attitude towards these occupations be a class thing?

Newnham, Glos

Matthew Oglethorpe
Bedford

James Tomlinson
London

 Julie Burchill thinks Anthea Turner's name is a 19th-century literary invention (So bad it's good, G2, March 14). My mother named me after the poem by Robert Herrick (1591-1674) entitled To Anthea who may command him any thing.
Anthea Beaumont
Highworth, Wilts

 Some people may consider pictures of naked children distasteful (Letters, March 15), but ask my children what they think of naked adults, in particular their 54-year-old father, and they will tell you it is positively disgusting. I am awaiting my arrest.

Burton in Lonsdale, Lancs

Stephen Lane
Clonee, Co Meath

 As a mark of respect to spy novelist Robert Ludlum, I read your obituary of him (March 14), then swallowed it.
Garry Chambers
London

fields.headline: Parental controls
fields.trailText: Your leader on our report on the effects of parents' employment on children's lives (March 15) is, to return the accusation, a rum affair. While rightly criticising the way some newspapers have distorted our findings to suit their own polemical purposes, we are disappointed that you apply the same techniques of partial reporting.
fields.body:
Your leader on our report on the effects of parents' employment on children's lives (March 15) is, to return the accusation, a rum affair. While rightly criticising the way some newspapers have distorted our findings to suit their own polemical purposes, we are disappointed that you apply the same techniques of partial reporting.

Unlike the balanced news report of the previous day, you unfairly charge us with turning correlations into causes. Yet you make no mention of the controls we applied to minimise other possible explanations for the results, including income differences. In particular, we used unique features of the British Household Panel Study data set to compare differences between siblings whose parents worked for different periods when they were pre-schoolers. This enabled us to control factors within families that other studies - comparing differences between children from different families - have had no means of eliminating.

Our study is evidence of a trade-off between the benefits of increased income from mother's working full-time before their children start school, and a reduced probability of children gaining A-level qualifications later on. If the positive effect of long-term increases in family income were enough to offset this adverse effect, then we agree a policy of encouraging mothers to work full-time in the pre-school years could still produce gains for children. But unless this can be demonstrated, it might be better for policy-makers to encourage part-time employment by one parent, since we found that this was associated with fewer negative, long-term effects.
John Ermisch and Marco Francesconi
University of Essex

fields.headline: Radio review
fields.standfirst: It's the way you tell 'em, Des
fields.trailText: In Conversation With Des O'Connor | The Mark Steel Lectures | Access All Areas
fields.body:
There are some situations you never expect to find yourself in. In Conversation With Des O'Connor (Radio 4) is one of them, but that's where Paul Jackson found himself last night. Last week it was Steve Coogan, a very different prospect - a chewy, reluctant interviewee - and it's a credit to Jackson that he varies the pace of these programmes to let everyone shine.

With Des that means letting him tell anecdotes that you couldn't make up. When he told his mother he wanted to be a comedian she said, "You can't do that, they'll just laugh at you." But now life is good. "I live in a world of no strangers. People come up and say "Ello Des' and 'please don't sing.'"

This affection was famously absent the night that he died (that's dying in the comic sense) before an audience at the Glasgow Empire in his sixth week of doing variety. He went down so badly that he pretended to faint. O'Connor had been used to clowning around to much acclaim in the RAF, where, he said, "they'd laugh at egg and chips".

A conversation with Mark Steel would, I imagine, be a one-sided affair, and so The Mark Steel Lectures (Radio 4) suit him perfectly. Taking People With Passion as his subject for the next six shows, Steel began with Byron and Shelley. His act is intense in the way that Billy Bragg songs are intense, but there's some fine observational detail and Steel's own passion.

Celebrating Byron, Steel suggested that if the poet were alive today, he'd be penning football songs at tacking spin-doctors, talentless stars and hypocrites: for example, to the tune of Go West, "You're Shit And You Know You Are." Repeat.

Nathalie Wheen is just as brimful of passion. The charms of Classic FM largely evade me, for all its success (I think it's all those shows called things like Easier Classics and Even More Soporific Tunes), but I can't do without Wheen. On Access All Areas (Classic FM) she interviewed Libby McNamara of the Association of British Orchestras about National Orchestra Week, which is currently in full swing.

Wheen was unimpressed by some of the week's offerings. "That wouldn't even ask me to bend down and tie a shoelace", she said of one pre-concert event. McNamara bravely suggested Wheen was hard to please. Wheen was having none of this. Too many concerts these days, she said, have no energy to them. Stuck in the stalls, she thinks, "I might have a coddled egg by tomorrow."

"But suck it and see", McNamara countered, trying to keep National Orchestra Week and the egg metaphor alive. You could hear what Wheen was thinking (clue: it rhymes), but class act that she is, she didn't need to say it.

webTitle: Letters: Bad deal for the jobless

fields.headline: Bad deal for the jobless
fields.trailText: In my teens, I went to school and then worked full-time. In my twenties, I worked and then began to raise a child alone. I also returned to education. In my thirties, I continued my education, under the punishing circumstances created by Tory policies on lone parents and students.
fields.body:
In my teens, I went to school and then worked full-time. In my twenties, I worked and then began to raise a child alone. I also returned to education. In my thirties, I continued my education, under the punishing circumstances created by Tory policies on lone parents and students. Now, in my forties, I have added IT skills to my academic qualifications. But I remain unemployed and this is likely to be the first decade of my life in which I have absolutely no hope for the future.

The New Deal (Labour imposes tough new rules on jobseekers, March 14) assumes the unemployed are unwilling to work, or lacking in ability, or both. Consequently, the real difficulties encountered by those who don't conform to the stereotype are never addressed. Long gaps in employment history, with the inevitable lack of recent references, place many capable job applicants at an insurmountable disadvantage against people who are already in work, or unemployed for a short time.

Throw in a little age discrimination, use words like "workshy" and imply we're all on the fiddle and it's no wonder the Tories think employers have to be bribed into taking us on. Any chance of some dignity?
Gail Robinson
Bolton

 I read your article with a mixture of despondency and wry amusement. Twelve months ago I became redundant from my job as a management consultant, since when I have made over 300 (yes, 300) applications for employment. The vast majority did not even do me the courtesy of a reply. I have applied for jobs at a third of my previous salary without success. I am a graduate, I am IT literate and can build fairly sophisticated web sites, I have years of management experience. So what's wrong with me? I'm 54 years of age.

Skills shortage? Don't make me laugh Mr Blair.
Nigel Davies
Stockport, Cheshire nigel@localuniverse.co.uk

 Gordon Brown's figures inform him there is no reason for any jobless claimant not to find work? His calculations are way off. The situations vacant are low-paid, demoralising, mind-numbing and soul-destroying, unrewarding graft in fast food joints, with security firms and, of course, the new "sweat shops", call centres.

Modern politics ought to promote happiness and self-belief for all, thus producing a society of more tolerance, less guilt, and all the associated benefits. Putting aside books and babies for part-time slavery will not do this.
Martin James McDonald
Edinburgh

 You argue the sanctions New Deal can impose (withholding benefits) are justified through the health benefits of being employed. Tell me how a person over 50, long-term unemployed, will live longer by accepting a £4 per hour roadsweeping job, or by having their benefit stopped?

New Deal is not the only stick used to beat the unemployed. In my area, long-term unemployment has been privatised into the employment zone run by Reed. No four options available here. We are not allowed to do voluntary work or any training not organised by Reed.
Geoff Chapman
London
lizageoff@hotmail.com

 Is the government still a signatory to the UN's universal declaration of human rights? Article 23 states: "Everyone has the right to work, to free choice of employment, to just and favourable conditions of work and to protection against unemployment." Work or lose your benefits, in reality, is forced labour, no matter how you dress it up as rights and responsibilities.
Colin Hampton
Chesterfield

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Readers were invited yesterday, page 12, G2, to bid for Peter Blake's original artwork for an Ian Dury tribute album, with proceeds to Comic Relief. What is on offer is a single ink-jet print of that artwork, surrounded by original signed Polaroids of the album's contributors.
fields.body:
Readers were invited yesterday, page 12, G2, to bid for Peter Blake's original artwork for an Ian Dury tribute album, with proceeds to Comic Relief. What is on offer is a single ink-jet print of that artwork, surrounded by original signed Polaroids of the album's contributors.

This column transposed two digits yesterday, page 19, in an item about crowding on London Underground. A Hammersmith and City line carriage with 32 people seated is allowed to hold up to 180 standing - maximum crowding of 563% (not 536%).

Royal Holloway, University of London, was wrongly put in a list accompanying an article about concerns over high student drop-out rates on university mathematics courses (Unsolved equation, page 9, March 13, Education). The college's maths degree results were the concern.

The wrong Professor David Williams was pictured yesterday on page 2 of G2 as a member of the Near Earth Objects taskforce. The photo showed an atomic scientist of the same name. Prof Williams of the taskforce is past (not current) president of the Royal Astronomical Society.

A photo caption on page 7, March 14 (with the story, Arts industry worth £100bn) said Saving Grace was a BBC film. It was by Sky Pictures.

There is reason to withdraw a correction we published on page 15, December 23, about a story on discord at Westminster Abbey's choir school (page 3, December 19). The story indicated that a 1999 inquiry into management at the abbey was prompted by a controversy there about the sacking in 1998 of organist Martin Neary. Our correction accepted there was no such link. This month the inquiry report has been published by the review group on the Royal Peculiars. It shows that part of the impetus for the inquiry was the Neary episode.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number.

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Red sky at night
fields.trailText: Red sky at night
fields.body:
Northumberland

We stay at home and walk only on our own land, but the red glow and billowing smoke on the southern horizon reflects the aftermath of a local farm which suffered an outbreak of foot and mouth. Hundreds of walks and trails on our moors and hills, still dusted by snow, are a desolate scene, unsullied now by the footprint of a single walker. Our Northumberland Wildlife Trust is one of the largest wildlife organisations, but has closed all its 66 nature reserves for the foreseeable future. I had been looking forward to meeting the new goatherd for the Whitelee reserve near the Scottish border, who is to look after the 75-strong herd of wild goats there, but interviews are now on hold for the 80 applicants for the job. So the goats will have to continue looking after themselves for a while. The area is popular for walking, as well as being a Site of Special Scientific Interest. Local hotels and pubs are suffering, and sadly, the hikers, birdwatchers and geologists who normally visit one of Britain's last unspoilt open spaces have evaporated faster than the snow in this week's spring sunshine.

Our Christmas roses have been stalwart, growing sturdily through the recent bitter cold spell, and in wintry sunshine I picked a dozen blooms which are now in our hall. Reduced to local activities, there is plenty going on in the village to keep me busy - it takes more than snow and power cuts to stop whist drives in village halls, and our's is warmed by a proper fire. Every Tuesday evening in the village hall we also play carpet bowls, a game derived from outdoor bowling. It is rather like snooker played on a big table.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Check Up | Jazz Legends | The Friday Play: Ecce Homo - Behold The Man
fields.body:
Barbara Myers brings in the experts to conduct a teach-in on lupus for Check Up (3.0pm, Radio 4). Though there's an international conference about the disease this year, few people have heard of it. It's an immune system disorder suffered by some thousands of people in Britain. It may result in fewer deaths than previously, but it can still cause significant damage to the kidneys and other organs. Not least of the associated problems is that treatment can trigger diabetes.

In Jazz Legends (4.0pm, Radio 3) Julian Joseph recalls the meteoric career of the guitarist Charlie Christian, who died aged 25 in 1942. Little is known of his early life except that, unable to afford a proper instrument, Christian fashioned one from cigar boxes. By his early teens he was playing professionally, and then began tinkering with electrical amplification. In 1939 a reluctant Benny Goodman included him in a Beverly Hills concert. It was a sensational success.

No preview tape was on offer, but The Friday Play: Ecce Homo - Behold The Man (9.0pm, Radio 4) sounds worth a try. The unremitting efforts of Councillor Naomi Tonks have resulted in Birmingham becoming this year's European City of Thought. This naturally requires a philosopher -in-residence, and a local lad, Diogenes Walker, is given the job. Since he doesn't fit into any existing department he is privately sponsored by a local scrap yard, not a happy omen.

fields.headline: No 1840 Mike Batt
fields.trailText: Looks like a decent sort of chap. I'll wager he's a celebrity gardener with a new primetime BBC2 show called something like Potted History. Actually, he's not a gardening supremo at all. He's a composer.
fields.body:
Looks like a decent sort of chap. I'll wager he's a celebrity gardener with a new primetime BBC2 show called something like Potted History. Actually, he's not a gardening supremo at all. He's a composer.

I see. Has he composed anything I might have heard of? Dum-de-dum, dum-de-dum, dum-de-dum-dum . . .

The Archers? No, The Wombles.

Damn. That would have been my next guess. And what has Mike been composing lately? A rousing symphony to spur the Conservative party on to victory.

Blimey! That's going to have to be pretty darn rousing. Does Mike realise what he has taken on? Well, I'm not going to be the one to tell him.

No, sirree. The Tories are a far cry from the Wombles and all that pom-tiddly-om-pompomming. Where was it they used to live? Wenlock Edge? No, you dullard, Wimbledon Common.

Oh, of course, yes. The Wombles of Wimbledon. I didn't think the Tories had an awful lot to do with commoners. Easy, tiger.

And what was it the Wombles used to pick up? Things that the everyday folks leave behind.

Such as the Conservative party? Actually I meant rubbish.

Such as the Conservative party? Don't be rude.

But there is a certain similarity between the Wombles and the Conservative party. In that they're both quaintly English and lovable?

In that they're both strange, woolly-headed, snouty creatures who live underground. I think you'll find that's not factually correct.

Well, maybe I lied about the underground bit. But you can't deny that Ann Widdecombe bears a startling resemblance to Madame Cholet. Well now that you come to mention it . . .

Do sing: "I wanna live like common people."

Don't sing: "Things can only get better."

webTitle: Business: Charles Schwab considers job cuts

fields.headline: Safety-first strategy on Wall St looks as risky as dot.bombs
fields.standfirst: Charles Schwab
fields.trailText: After a year of congratulating themselves for choosing the safety of their investment banking jobs over a risky dot.com, Wall Street bankers and brokers are no longer feeling quite so secure.
fields.body:
After a year of congratulating themselves for choosing the safety of their investment banking jobs over a risky dot.com, Wall Street bankers and brokers are no longer feeling quite so secure.

Yesterday Charles Schwab, the leading US discount brokerage, became the latest firm to consider job cuts in an attempt to survive the market downturn. Schwab has already cut about 850 of its 25,500-strong workforce over the past two months as a result of a hiring freeze. In a statement yesterday, the bro ker, which expanded exponentially over the past five years, admitted that the freeze might not be enough.

Since September, about 10,000 banking and brokerage jobs have been cut in New York as the equity capital markets dried up and mergers and acquisitions business stalled. Most investment banks spend nearly half their revenues on compensation. With revenues down about 20% and profits down even more over the past year, few banks can continue to support hefty payroll bills.

Last week, Morgan Stanley reversed its previous position and said that job cuts would form part of a cost-cutting plan. Bear Stearns, which managed to hire more staff during the stock market crash in 1987, also announced 400 job cuts last week, almost 4% of its total headcount.

Other leading banks to an nounce cuts in the past few weeks include Bank of America, Citigroup, which owns Salomon Smith Barney, and Goldman Sachs.

The cuts have been fairly tentative so far and Wall Street headhunters see little evidence of a bloodbath yet. Robert Winter, a headhunter at recruiting firm Baines Gwinner, says that banks may be keener to retain staff after the tight labour conditions of the past two years. "They are haunted by the memory of 1998," he says, referring to the markets crisis. "One or two firms cut back far too hard and had to go on a recruitment binge to get back into the market."

Banks have cut the perks laid on during the good times such as first-class flights. But other firms are looking to expand, headhunters say.

Looking forward, the only consolation for some bankers is that those they once envied in Silicon Valley are suffering even more.

webTitle: Business: Prudential's merger with American General

fields.headline: The deals dry up
fields.trailText: Prudential's £30bn merger with American General this week was a much-needed sign that there is still lucrative business around for the bankers who advise companies on such deals.
fields.body:
Prudential's £30bn merger with American General this week was a much-needed sign that there is still lucrative business around for the bankers who advise companies on such deals.

Mergers and acquisitions specialists have thrived on the record volume of deals in recent years. They insist they are busy behind the scenes working on new takeovers, but according to Thomson Financial the first few months of 2001 witnessed barely a third of the deals completed in the same period last year.

Anecdotal evidence suggests it is the executives who help companies raise money in the equity markets who have had least to do. The Orange flotation earlier this year showed how difficult it was persuade investors to pay premium prices for shares and, it is said, put paid to attempts by other leading companies to raisecapital.

According to Thomson Financial, $19bn was raised on the world's stock markets in the first two months of 2001, down from $32bn a year earlier.

Companies increasingly are turning to the debt markets, perhaps encouraged by falling interest rates, to raise money. According to Capital Data, business outside the US is up by $80bn on the same period last year.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: • When singer Courtney Love (one-time partner of Kurt Cobain, the lead singer of Nirvana who killed himself in 1994) started her court case to break out of her recording contract with Vivendi Universal, she claimed that being "sold" to Vivendi by her original record company meant she had "slid down into the sewers of Paris". Perhaps she was thinking of the 1998 report in Le Monde, detailing "an agreed system for misappropriation of funds" where Vivendi executives met rival firms Bouygues and Suez-Lyonnais, both of whom own water companies in Britain, and divided up contracts instead of competing against each other.
fields.body:
 When singer Courtney Love (one-time partner of Kurt Cobain, the lead singer of Nirvana who killed himself in 1994) started her court case to break out of her recording contract with Vivendi Universal, she claimed that being "sold" to Vivendi by her original record company meant she had "slid down into the sewers of Paris". Perhaps she was thinking of the 1998 report in Le Monde, detailing "an agreed system for misappropriation of funds" where Vivendi executives met rival firms Bouygues and Suez-Lyonnais, both of whom own water companies in Britain, and divided up contracts instead of competing against each other.

The cartel ran from 1989 to 1996 and involved billions of pounds. A levy of 2% on all the contracts was divided between the four main political parties. (Just one of the many illegal party funding scandals that have rocked the French establishment.)

Or perhaps Courtney was thinking of the two executives of the firm (when named Générale des Eaux) who pleaded guilty to bribing the mayor of St-Denis to win the town's water concession. Or perhaps she just meant that Vivendi, originally a water utility, actually does run the sewers of Paris.

 The mind boggles as to why King Arthur's Castle Hotel in Tintagel, Cornwall, should have put out a press release this week headlined "Harry Potter's magic beats foot and mouth", given the serious plight of the tourism and farming industries. But it did.

 A cracking survey arrives from the combined forces of the British board of film classification, the broadcasting standards commission and the independent television commission (phew!), entitled: Wrestling - how do audiences perceive TV and video wrestling? And the report's extraordinary conclusions is that most viewers "believe that the violence in wrestling is fake and that the narrative is pre-scripted." Well, that's another victory for common sense. But the report's most entertaining part is its excerpts from pro-wrestling fans interviewed. "Now, if this was real wrestling, and they could choose weapons, they would not be choosing ironing boards as weapons," commented one perceptive dedicated male viewer from Newcastle.

 It's a sad state of affairs if - as the financial services authority is threatening to do - the finely honed City practice of the "Friday night drop" is made illegal. True, "the drop" is nowhere near as exciting these days as it was in its heyday during the takeover frenzy of the 1980s, when favoured Sunday newspapers would be given dirt on a company's rivals. But there's plenty of life left in the technique, as a glance at any Sunday paper's business section will show. It will be fascinating to see how they cope.

 In the meantime, one Sunday newspaper journalist is spreading his wings: there arrives a press release flogging a new subscription investment newsletter. "Written by Neil Bennett, City Editor of the Sunday Telegraph," gushes the blurb, "[it] will give you the inside track to the most attractive new investment opportunities on the market." Not so good for Sunday Telegraph readers, who will presumably have to stump up the £10 a month to subscribe (along with everyone else) if they want to read about these "most attractive" investment opportunities.

 A Beginner's Guide to Speaking Citytalk. Lesson 46: At the preliminary results of Trinity Mirror newspaper group. "Refocusing digital strategy - icShowbiz and icSport content will enhance national newspaper sites". Translation: Trinity Mirror has closed both websites and sacked the 50 staff working on them. (Thanks to The Register website for that particular gem.)

fields.headline: It's not over until it's over
fields.standfirst:
Market forces

vodafone
Goldmansachs
fields.trailText: The FTSE 100 entered the official closing period last night 43 points higher; 10 minutes later it was 103.3 points better at 5,729.2. The London Stock Exchange insists nothing untoward went on but traders were bemused.
fields.body:
The FTSE 100 entered the official closing period last night 43 points higher; 10 minutes later it was 103.3 points better at 5,729.2. The London Stock Exchange insists nothing untoward went on but traders were bemused.

The exchange introduced the controversial system, which calculates the end-of-day prices for all stocks traded in the electronic order book, Sets, last year to afford investors the opportunity to deal at the closing price.

When the order book closes at 4.30pm, all Sets stocks go into the "auction", where buyers and sellers can enter a price at which they are prepared to deal. Using a complex formula, the auction then comes up with one price that satisfies greatest numbers of orders. This becomes the closing price.

According the exchange, yesterday's spike reflected the strong buying demand in the market at the end of the session. This seemed at odds with events elsewhere. With indices in New York coming off their earlier highs, there seemed to little reason for institutions to buy heavily at the close.

Some traders said the move might be related the expiry of options and futures in London and New York today, a suggestion played down in some parts. "To push the index up 60 points across the board and do to it with no single stock going up more than 4%, is a nigh on impossible task," one market watcher commented.

Others pointed to a string of late trades in AstraZeneca , up 148p to £31.99, which has recently been buying back its shares.

Whatever the truth, it could not detract from what had been a mildly comforting day for the London market. All major indices closed in positive territory with the FTSE Techmark 100 rising 35.67 points to 2,172.25.

With Wednesday's rumours amounting to little, a few buyers returned. Fears of a crisis in the Japanese banking system eased after finance minister Kiichi Miyazawa said he might consider funding measures to shore up sagging bank balance sheets, while the Nokia profits warning turned out to be a forecast of lower sales.

Underpinned by the news from Nokia, Vodafone rose 5.35p to 208p, while biotech group Celltech added 90p to £12.20 after analysts at Dresdner Kleinwort Wassertein upgraded the stock. Barclays gained 96p to £20.50.

If nothing else, Wednesday's sharp falls provided analysts with a reason to start pushing their favoured stocks again.

Goldman Sachs championed Colt Telecom , up 58p to 996p, and Energis , 35p higher at 360p, arguing that the sell-off, which followed the profit warning from Cable & Wireless , up 4p to 482p, was unjustified as neither company has a comparable exposure to Japan or North America -C&W's problem areas.

That said, Energis's performance probably had more to do with the completion of a seriously large sell order in the previous session.

Deutsche Bank came out in support of Standard Chartered , which was 16.5p better at 900p. The German broker believes concerns about its exposure to Japan are overdone, given that it has only about $1bn (£694m) of interbank loans to Japanese banks.

On the second line, Trafficmaster extended Wednesday's gain with a rise of 29.5p to 308.25p as investors started taking seriously the idea that it will make an extra £47m in sales this year. Lifting its rating to "buy", Deutsche Bank said recent figures provided far more visibility over where the revenue will come from.

Among smaller companies Ovoca , the dual-listed Irish mining company, advanced 2.5p to 15.5p amid speculation of a stake-building exercise being carried out in Dublin. According to the gossips, the mystery buyer is looking to build a 7% holding.

Elsewhere, European Telecom dropped 14.75p to 24.25p after warning that it will makes a substantial loss this fiscal year.

"To push the index up 60 points across the board and do to it with no single stock going up more than 4%, is a nigh on impossible task," one market watcher commented. Others pointed to a string of late trades in AstraZeneca , up 148p to £31.99, which has recently been buying back its shares. Whatever the truth, it could not detract from what had been a mildly comforting day for the London market. All major indices closed in positive territory with the FTSE Techmark 100 rising 35.67 points to 2,172.25. With Wednesday's rumours amounting to little, a few buyers returned. Fears of a crisis in the Japanese banking system eased after finance minister Kiichi Miyazawa said he might consider funding measures to shore up sagging bank balance sheets, while the Nokia profits warning turned out to be a forecast of lower sales. Underpinned by the news from Nokia, Vodafone rose 5.35p to 208p, while biotech group Celltech added 90p to £12.20 after analysts at Dresdner Kleinwort Wassertein upgraded the stock. Barclays gained 96p to £20.50. If nothing else, Wednesday's sharp falls provided analysts with a reason to start pushing their favoured stocks again. Goldman Sachs championed Colt Telecom , up 58p to 996p, and Energis , 35p higher at 360p, arguing that the sell-off, which followed the profit warning from Cable & Wireless , up 4p to 482p, was unjustified as neither company has a comparable exposure to Japan or North America -C&W's problem areas. That said, Energis's performance probably had more to do with the completion of a seriously large sell order in the previous session. Deutsche Bank came out in support of Standard Chartered , which was 16.5p better at 900p. The German broker believes concerns about its exposure to Japan are overdone, given that it has only about $1bn (£694m) of interbank loans to Japanese banks. On the second line, Trafficmaster extended Wednesday's gain with a rise of 29.5p to 308.25p as investors started taking seriously the idea that it will make an extra £47m in sales this year. Lifting its rating to "buy", Deutsche Bank said recent figures provided far more visibility over where the revenue will come from. Among smaller companies Ovoca , the dual-listed Irish mining company, advanced 2.5p to 15.5p amid speculation of a stake-building exercise being carried out in Dublin. According to the gossips, the mystery buyer is looking to build a 7% holding. Elsewhere, European Telecom dropped 14.75p to 24.25p after warning that it will makes a substantial loss this fiscal year.

fields.headline: Dick-ery could soon be docked
fields.standfirst: Whisper it in the banking halls and bars: shares turmoil could cost 20,000 Square Mile jobs
fields.trailText: They were immortalised in Liars' Poker, Michael Lewis's account of life as an investment banker in 1980s London. The Big Swinging Dicks - the deal-makers and master traders of Wall Street and the City, who worked hard, played hard and spent even harder.
fields.body:
They were immortalised in Liars' Poker, Michael Lewis's account of life as an investment banker in 1980s London. The Big Swinging Dicks - the deal-makers and master traders of Wall Street and the City, who worked hard, played hard and spent even harder.

The image softened during the 1990s, partly because women broke through the glass ceiling but mostly because the high-rollers of esoteric finance threw less at life's consumables and thought more about building an agreeable home life, typically in Chiswick or Richmond, with children at the right schools and the pension fund fully invested.

Now, the whole concept of Big Swinging Dick-ery is up for review. In short, it may be about to get the ice cold water treatment. The future could be shrivelled.

At least 20,000 City jobs and 28,000 related positions nationwide will disappear if the gloom descending over the world's financial markets persists, according to new estimates by a leading economic research body. Under this dismal scenario, from the Centre for Economics and Business Research, £4bn - 0.4% of gross domestic product - will be knocked off the country's prospective growth in the coming two years.

Yet the threat is only starting to be appreciated in a London where house prices are rising quickly again after last year's pause and tables at the best restaurants are more difficult to come by than ever.

To the squadrons of bankers earning a handsome living in the City, where some 300,000 people arrive each day for work, it is a case of entering the unknown. "We seem to be in a bear economy," one young analyst said, "and none of us knows anything about it." Watching the stock exchange screens turn red, the colour of active selling, in such a prolonged fashion is something many City traders have not seen before on a serious scale.

'Such a tricky call'

The City has not forgotten 1998, when the big investment banks took the axe to 5% of their workforce as cold reality swept through the fragile economies of south-east Asia and the Pacific rim. Nor the tech market rout of almost a year ago when "new economy" stocks first contracted the jitters.

But this time, City veterans say, the omens are worse. No one is prepared to predict when the market might stop falling. "What am I supposed to tell my clients?" one stockbroker at a major retail firm asked this week. "It's just such a tricky call."

Despite perceptions in some quarters that the markets are in free-fall, the terror is not yet evenly spread across the Square Mile. "It is pretty gloomy," one banker confided. "But not everywhere. The boys in mergers and acquisitions are saying there is work to be done. It's in the equity and debt world where it's all much tougher."

Because share prices are under pressure, private companies are no longer scrambling to acquire publicly quoted status and work is drying up for the bankers who make a pile out these flotations. The heartache suffered when Orange, the mobile phone company, had to slash the offer price of its shares is deterring other companies which not long ago were itching to go public.

Few of the major investment banks admit yet that the jobs axe is being sharpened. Merrill Lynch, the US bank which three years ago admitted it was sacking 5% of its workforce,is keeping quiet. It employs some 6,500 people in the City and is building a hi-tech office in the heart of the financial district.

Jobs are going elsewhere, in large part as a result of huge mergers in the banking sector. Credit Suisse First Boston, for instance, is trimming its 7,000-strong City workforce by 10% after taking over Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette, a US bank, last year.

Jobs have gone at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, a 10,000-strong banking operation formed by slamming together Salomon (the original US exponent of the Big Swinging Dick movement) and its more staid British rival, Schroder & Co. Yet recruitment continues and the bank's 42-storey tower at Canary Wharf has just had its "toppping out" ceremony.

Publicly, bankers insist that the current job cuts are not motivated by fears of global recession. Privately, one senior banker at a large firm admitted: "I suspect we're looking at the size of our business. But, hopefully, we'll avoid any major knee-jerk reaction and just wait to see how things look at the end of June."

Sympathy for these anxious bankers is in short supply. Their image of brash, fast, lavish living and rapidly accumulated personal fortunes does not help.

Douglas McWilliams, head of the CEBR, yesterday produced some worrying news for workers outside the City enclave. According to his calculations, 28,000 jobs are at risk outside the financial district if the jitters persist - a statistic that could eclipse government celebrations of the jobless total falling below 1m.

His calculations are based on the FTSE 100 falling some 15% from its December peak of just below 7,000, a slide it has already endured. The impact may not be felt immediately. "We are starting from a reasonably strong background. Last year was still pretty bullish," Mr McWilliams said.

So this year the cull in the City may be restricted to 7,000 people. The real pain will be felt by the end of next year, when some 25,000 jobs will have gone - 20,000 in the City and another 5,000 as a result of "knock-on" effects. While Mr McWilliams estimates that every City job creates 0.7 support roles in close proximity - estate agents, newsagents, hairdressers - on the downside the impact is not quite as great.

Next bonus round

Yet even under this scenario a drop in bonuses -the traditional impetus for London house prices - could lop 3.9% off the annual growth of house prices in the City commuter belt.

Mr McWilliams forecast at the start of this year that a slowdown would come. While he predicts the next two years are "not going to be pleasant" for the City, the alarm bells are not ringing as loudly as 10 years ago when 50,000 jobs were shed during the height of what was largely an unforeseen recession.

One reason for the reticence is that the infamous bonuses have just been paid to many bankers. This week's crises seem a long way from the next bonus round. "The impact hasn't really yet sunk in that it might be the last year for a while that[the bonuses] will be generally good," one investment banker said.

The City has grown used to some areas of banking faring better than others. Last year was a good one for mergers and acquisitions specialists, and some brokers specialising in small, hi-tech stocks. Mainstream stockbrokers noted that the main markets gained little ground.

It is the United States economy that matters to most in the City, not only because of the country's global economic clout but also because many City bankers are now employed by American firms: employers not known for sentimentality when business conditions deteriorate.

fields.headline: Team tucker
fields.standfirst: When England are away for an evening match the Narbett menu looks like this
fields.trailText: When England are away for an evening match the Narbett menu looks like this
fields.body:
Breakfast: cereals; fruit; eggs, poached or scrambled; and maybe some lean, cold ham. No bacon.

Lunch: the main meal, taken around 12.30pm. A typical Narbett buffet lunch will include: tomato soup; salad Nicoise; Waldorf salad; shepherd's pie; lasagne; chicken poached in chicken stock with mushroom sauce; salmon with courgette and tomato sauce; spaghetti Bolognese; and of course, tomato ketchup; rice pudding made with skimmed milk; apricot crumble and skimmed-milk custard.

Tea: Poached or scrambled eggs are available again at around 4.30pm to 5pm, although some players opt for yoghurt and fruit or even breakfast cereals. Narbett prepares sandwiches and cakes for after the match, washed down with much water. More pasta is served up for refuelling on the plane home.
