fields.headline: Iceland deep in the red
fields.standfirst: £20m cost of pulling out of organic food debacle
fields.trailText: Beleaguered frozen food group Iceland yesterday delivered its third profits alert this year and said that higher one-off costs will push the group deep into the red.
fields.body:
Beleaguered frozen food group Iceland yesterday delivered its third profits alert this year and said that higher one-off costs will push the group deep into the red.

Only four months ago analysts believed the company was on track to make a £130m profit this year. Six weeks ago, new chief executive Bill Grimsey said they would be no more than £62m, and yesterday he said the true figure for the 15 months to the end of March would be no more than £40m - and that would be wiped out by £66m of exceptional costs.

The group, which was a City favourite last year, has been battered by the departure of executives including founder and chairman Malcolm Walker, who resigned after selling 4m shares, netting £13m, just before the first signs of any problems emerged.

The chain has been stung by its high profile switch into organic food - which customers did not buy.

Yesterday Mr Grimsey, who was hired in December to run what he thought was a booming business, revealed that the move into organics, which had been championed by Mr Walker, would wipe £8m off the bottom line this year, £4m next year and £2m in 2003.

Mr Grimsey, who previously ran the Wickes DIY business, has ditched organics to return to the firm's old strength of cheap deals and "bogof" - buy one, get one free - promotions.

Sales are still on the slide. In the three months to the end of March, they are expected to be down 3.7%. Six weeks ago Mr Grimsey estimated a 2.5% downturn.

Iceland has £530m of debt, which it took on last year when it merged with the Booker cash and carry and catering supplies business.

Rumours had been circulating that the group was in danger of breaching its banking covenants and was considering a rescue rights issue.

Yesterday, Mr Grimsey denied the rumours, and insisted Iceland had no problems with servicing its debt.

"We have now had enough time to go over the books and I'm confident as I can be that we have now uncovered everything and am comfortable that we have a base on which to build an outlook for the group," he said.

"My most immediate concern is current trading. I'll be working very hard to restore sales growth and am confident I can do it."

Mr Grimsey has hired several ex-Wickes executives and 21 senior managers are to benefit from an incentive scheme, though the details have yet to be finalised.

A strategic plan is to be announced in June which will detail " a lengthy process of rehabilitation".

The £66m of one-off costs include a hefty £20m to pull out of organic food supply deals. Another £7m relates to banking fees relating to the Booker deal.

He refused to blame his predecessors for the company's appalling figures.

A source close to the company said: "He is not going to point the finger, but clearly the internal controls were completely inadequate and the financial reporting system was grossly inadequate if the board thought the business was going to make £130m and the real figure is £40m".

Iceland's shares - which have fallen by more than 50% since Christmas - rose 10p to 162.5p, despite the grim news. Many analysts believe Mr Grimsey has the talent to restore the company's fortunes - he resuscitated Wickes after an accounting scandal - though some suggested he might be planning to take the ailing group private.

A spokesman for the company described the suggestion as "absolute rubbish". He added: "How the hell would he do it with half a billion pounds of debt. It's ludicrous".

fields.headline: Glycosciences makes 'land grab' for proteins
fields.trailText: Biotechnology company Oxford Glycosciences is hoping to apply for patents over 4,000 proteins by the end of the year, as part of a "land grab" to corner the rights to promising areas of research.
fields.body:
Biotechnology company Oxford Glycosciences is hoping to apply for patents over 4,000 proteins by the end of the year, as part of a "land grab" to corner the rights to promising areas of research.

The firm, which yesterday announced a 62% jump in full-year losses to £16.8m, sells information about proteins to other drugs companies.

It has already made applications covering 1,500 proteins which it believes to be associated with disease. Chief executive Michael Kranda said: "We're focusing on land grab proteomics. We're really in a very good position to attack this technology."

Proteins are governed by genes in the body, and their activity is central to the maintenance of good health. Some biotechnology companies are targeting genes in the race to create new medicines but the completion of the Human Genome Project revealed that there are only about 30,000 genes in the body, rather than the expected 150,000.

As a result, Mr Kranda said proteins are becoming the new battleground: "There are 300,000 to 500,000 proteins out there. The value is really going to be in understanding the protein world."

Oxford Glycosciences recently changed its strategy to pump more cash into developing drugs in-house, rather than selling its research to other pharmaceuticals firms.

By the middle of the year, it expects to apply for US approval for its lead product, Vevesca. This treats Gaucher's disease - an illness prevalent among Ashkenaze Jews which inhibits the body's ability to store sugar, causing swelling in the liver and spleen. The existing treatment for Gaucher's disease is one of the most expensive drugs in the world, costing $150,000 (£105,000) a year. Oxford Glycosciences hopes to undercut this, charging $50,000-$150,000.

Some analysts are sceptical - one said that Vevesca might not be acceptable to US health insurers. The firm's shares, which reached £32 last year, were unchanged at £10.65.

webTitle: Notebook:  Bush sends out mixed messages

fields.headline: President wobbles on state of the economy
fields.standfirst:
Bush sends out mixed messages

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: It would be quite funny if the subject were more frivolous: George Bush does not seem to know whether the American economy is going up or down. More to the point, he does not appear sure whether he should be saying that prospects are improving or deteriorating on the other side of the Atlantic.
fields.body:
It would be quite funny if the subject were more frivolous: George Bush does not seem to know whether the American economy is going up or down. More to the point, he does not appear sure whether he should be saying that prospects are improving or deteriorating on the other side of the Atlantic.

Yesterday in Washington the new president was telling those who would listen that he "has great faith in our economy". A couple of hours later he declared in a speech: "Our economy is beginning to splutter."

Of course, no politician (of any political colour) has ever been able to hold to the common sense rule that those in government should listen to the markets rather than try to set their path.

But Mr Bush and his lightweight economic team have found themselves in a tight spot. The new administration wants to push through tax cuts worth $1.6 trillion. Because this is an inflationary move, it makes sense to promote the package to a sceptical Congress as a way of refuelling a sluggish economy. With all the leading indicators over there heading south, Mr Bush is promising a "second wind for economic growth", as he put it earlier this week.

Yet when an American president takes to his feet and says the economy is headed off the rails there is one big, worrying side-effect: a good portion of the population takes him at his word, rows back on its confidence and stops spending.

As currently structured, the 10-year tax package is heavily skewed towards later years, with the net injection (in the form of tax credits) over the next 12 months amounting to just a few billion dollars - nowhere near enough to reflate an economy the size of the US.

In short, Mr Bush is now being accused in both Washington and New York of exacerbating the downturn without a realistic plan to mend the damage caused.

Steel pain

Meanwhile, as British steel maker Corus was putting some real numbers on the misery of shedding 9,000 jobs over here, there was a reminder from over there about how much more pain might be in store for this industry if (as seems likely) faltering economic growth is met with protectionist policy measures.

Bush officials are reported to be negotiating with the US steel industry to impose a three-year package of restrictions on steel imports, involving prohibitive tariffs on imports above a yet-to-be-defined level. The talks are said to stem from a deal the administration is trying to strike whereby so-called "fast track" trade agreements (with the likes of Jordan and Vietnam) can move through Congress without being amended.

But how this fits with the free global trade rules which the US has spent so much political firepower promoting over the past 10 years or so remains a mystery.

Trade off

Clara Furse has had a glitch-free six-week honeymoon as the new chief executive of the London Stock Exchange.

We can put this down to her tough persona and the fact that many in the Square Mile are probably still coming to terms with the fact that a woman is leading such an important City institution. Uncharitable types would add that since everything associated with the internet or high technology went into a spin the external pressure on the exchange to go global through an alliance or merger, allowing investors around the world a common technological trading platform, has eased somewhat.

"New economy" business plans are out of favour this month, whatever the logic.

But Ms Furse should not take this as a signal that the present systems employed in trading stocks in London are anywhere near up to the job.

Take the close of the main equity market yesterday evening. In its typically erratic fashion, the FTSE 100 index meandered its way through most of the day locked between 5,680 and 5,660 points. Then, during the last 10 minutes of business, this supposed barometer of British corporate health surged 60 points to close at 5,729.2.

Sadly, this had nothing to do with a sudden improvement in investor sentiment. It simply reflected the mechanics of the closing auction now held in Footsie stocks, which sets closing prices. The system was introduced to cut volatility and reduce the incidence of so-called rogue prices. But the way it is used by London's major investment banks just exacerbates the problem.

The exchange response was true to form: nothing untoward happened, the move was driven by genuine buying.

So everyone sat around all day and then decided to trade all at once during the last few minutes of the day? Nonsense. Ms Furse should remember that if market participants of all shapes and sizes cannot trust the prices then she does not have a business.
fields.bodyText: It would be quite funny if the subject were more frivolous: George Bush does not seem to know whether the American economy is going up or down. More to the point, he does not appear sure whether he should be saying that prospects are improving or deteriorating on the other side of the Atlantic. Yesterday in Washington the new president was telling those who would listen that he "has great faith in our economy". A couple of hours later he declared in a speech: "Our economy is beginning to splutter." Of course, no politician (of any political colour) has ever been able to hold to the common sense rule that those in government should listen to the markets rather than try to set their path. But Mr Bush and his lightweight economic team have found themselves in a tight spot. The new administration wants to push through tax cuts worth $1.6 trillion. Because this is an inflationary move, it makes sense to promote the package to a sceptical Congress as a way of refuelling a sluggish economy. With all the leading indicators over there heading south, Mr Bush is promising a "second wind for economic growth", as he put it earlier this week. Yet when an American president takes to his feet and says the economy is headed off the rails there is one big, worrying side-effect: a good portion of the population takes him at his word, rows back on its confidence and stops spending. As currently structured, the 10-year tax package is heavily skewed towards later years, with the net injection (in the form of tax credits) over the next 12 months amounting to just a few billion dollars - nowhere near enough to reflate an economy the size of the US. In short, Mr Bush is now being accused in both Washington and New York of exacerbating the downturn without a realistic plan to mend the damage caused. Steel pain Meanwhile, as British steel maker Corus was putting some real numbers on the misery of shedding 9,000 jobs over here, there was a reminder from over there about how much more pain might be in store for this industry if (as seems likely) faltering economic growth is met with protectionist policy measures. Bush officials are reported to be negotiating with the US steel industry to impose a three-year package of restrictions on steel imports, involving prohibitive tariffs on imports above a yet-to-be-defined level. The talks are said to stem from a deal the administration is trying to strike whereby so-called "fast track" trade agreements (with the likes of Jordan and Vietnam) can move through Congress without being amended. But how this fits with the free global trade rules which the US has spent so much political firepower promoting over the past 10 years or so remains a mystery. Trade off Clara Furse has had a glitch-free six-week honeymoon as the new chief executive of the London Stock Exchange. We can put this down to her tough persona and the fact that many in the Square Mile are probably still coming to terms with the fact that a woman is leading such an important City institution. Uncharitable types would add that since everything associated with the internet or high technology went into a spin the external pressure on the exchange to go global through an alliance or merger, allowing investors around the world a common technological trading platform, has eased somewhat. "New economy" business plans are out of favour this month, whatever the logic. But Ms Furse should not take this as a signal that the present systems employed in trading stocks in London are anywhere near up to the job. Take the close of the main equity market yesterday evening. In its typically erratic fashion, the FTSE 100 index meandered its way through most of the day locked between 5,680 and 5,660 points. Then, during the last 10 minutes of business, this supposed barometer of British corporate health surged 60 points to close at 5,729.2. Sadly, this had nothing to do with a sudden improvement in investor sentiment. It simply reflected the mechanics of the closing auction now held in Footsie stocks, which sets closing prices. The system was introduced to cut volatility and reduce the incidence of so-called rogue prices. But the way it is used by London's major investment banks just exacerbates the problem. The exchange response was true to form: nothing untoward happened, the move was driven by genuine buying. So everyone sat around all day and then decided to trade all at once during the last few minutes of the day? Nonsense. Ms Furse should remember that if market participants of all shapes and sizes cannot trust the prices then she does not have a business.

fields.headline: No charges over Saatchi photos
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: The photographer Tierney Gearon and the Saatchi Gallery were told last night they would not face prosecution for exhibiting pictures of nude children because there was insufficient evidence to secure a conviction.
fields.body:
The photographer Tierney Gearon and the Saatchi Gallery were told last night they would not face prosecution for exhibiting pictures of nude children because there was insufficient evidence to secure a conviction.

The decision by the crown prosecution service ends a week-long furore. Embarrassed senior officers at Scotland Yard believe the matter should have been handled with more sensitivity.

It is also a humiliating defeat for the News of the World newspaper, which demanded the closure of the display at the north London gallery and condemned it as "a revolting exhibition of perversion under the guise of art".

Jenny Blyth, the curator, said the gallery was delighted by the decision. "We are absolutely thrilled. It has been a very worrying time ... There has been fantastic support from the press and the public."

Gearon, whose pictures of her nude children feature in the exhibition, said she was relieved. "It's such great news. It has been an overwhelming week. These are my children. I am a mother first and then I am an artist. It is not something I intended to happen.

"They have polluted my pictures. There are now a lot of people who are disturbed by my photos, which is unfortunate because they were just images that people enjoyed in an art gallery.

"When people ask whether they are pornographic and when they appear with censoring squares over them they look dirty."

She had faced up to 10 years in jail under the Protection of Children Act, which deems the making, possession, distribution and display of indecent pictures of children an offence.

The Metropolitan police also said they would take no further action against the publisher Edward Booth-Clibborn, who had been told to remove from British bookshops thousands of copies of I Am a Camera, which contains pictures from Charles Saatchi's collection and on which the exhibition is based.

A CPS lawyer visited the exhibition, which has been running for eight weeks and continues to April 15, before telling Scotland Yard the case should be dropped.

"After carefully reviewing the evidence submitted by the Metropolitan police, the CPS has advised that there is insufficient evidence to provide a realistic prospect of conviction under the Protection of Children Act 1978. In reaching this decision, the CPS considered whether the photographs in question were indecent and the likely defence of the gallery, ie whether they had a legitimate reason for showing them."

webTitle: Shane Watson: Britain's  freedom to fail

fields.headline: The freedom to be a disaster
fields.standfirst:
Britain is going to the dogs, and the rest of the world is damning us. But they're just envious of our freedom to fail

Special report: what is Britain?
fields.trailText: Britain is going to the dogs, and the rest of the world is damning us. But they're just envious of our freedom to fail
fields.body:
These are bad days for Britain. Octogenarians heaped on trolleys in hospital corridors, farm animals stacked on funeral pyres - anxiety levels couldn't get much higher. It's at times like these that our neighbours and allies really come into their own, the veneer of symbiosis peeled away to reveal the simmering contempt. Boy, have we had this coming, is the general consensus.

Depending on where you are from, Britain is either a union of foul-mouthed thugs (that is everyone), or a dirty, dangerous backwater (America) populated by retards with neither taste buds nor education (France, Germany etc). In recent weeks, the Wall Street Journal has had a go, Le Monde has blamed our lack of moral debate for the state we're in - "falling apart" - and the Irish have named us the "leper of Europe". Bloody nerve.

But if you are British, you are used to being on the wrong side of everyone's expectations - either too wild and pissed, or too snooty and superior - to the point where you could almost forget we know something they don't. Which is that only we, and particularly our women, can have the best of both worlds.

As a child on holiday in Italy in the early 70s, I got my first taste of how English women are perceived when the hotel receptionist explained that the men hanging around the gates were there to pick up the daily influx of English girls, because they were guaranteed to be singing Just One Cornetto, on their backs, in three hours. Slags! Horror! But, of course, I now know that our girls were simply ahead of the game, doing exactly what boys like to do on holiday, unlike their European counterparts who are afraid to be seen outdoors without tights in summer. It may not be pretty to watch, but who's having more fun?

Living in New York in the 80s, I took advantage of that other stereotype: the English lady. Back then you could be shocking, but you were also celebrated. To have a British person at your table - any British person - was like having a faux library, consisting of yards of leather spines: it suggested you were classy and educated, whatever they were like. To be drunk and welded to a cigarette was considered kind of old-country quaint; if you were monosyllabic and ill-informed, you got the Shy Di vote. For my nationality alone (no shorthand, no typing, no hairdryer), I was hired as a secretary in a factory in the Bronx, told to play up the posh on the end of the phone, and act very Joan Collins superior. Easy!

Later, I was paid a tidy wage by an Upper East Side "couturier" to wear a navy suit and make like the princess (this proved tougher and I was stripped of the suit and sent packing, wearing only bra, knickers and a mac). The point is that when people think your genes are special, you can do anything, and though the Americans have got wise, to an extent, they still want to believe it. Only we can be both Madonnas and whores in the eyes of our friends across the water.

Come the 90s, we were suddenly Cool Britannia and - crucially for our relationship with the French - the British were taking the top jobs at the most revered fashion houses. As someone who made the round of the fashion shows then, I can confirm that there was a delicious frisson the first time the French were forced to hold on to their coiffures as the British teams shuffled past them looking diabolique (Ha!), heading for the best seats in the house. Yet again the fou anglais , the scruffs with the hangovers and the bleeding lipstick, win the day, without even having to compromise on grooming.

The proof that we are still having it all in 2001 is Bridget Jones's Diary, the movie, out next month. The underachieving, self-deprecating pisshead Bridget is everything that everyone despises about the British. She is a mess, yet this character has gone global. She has barely anything going for her but people like her because she is what she is, and she isn't up herself. And in the end, would you rather have an uptight, macrobiotic New Yorker, a Frenchwoman who is bound by her marriage contract to wear exquisite underwear, or a Bridget who is prepared to push the car so long as you give her a glass of chardonnay afterwards? We may be going down the tubes fast, but we've still got something they want: the freedom to be a disaster.

fields.headline: Gerbeau drops dome bid to seek new role as fixer
fields.standfirst:
Buyer may not be selected before end of the year

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Pierre-Yves Gerbeau yesterday said goodbye to the Millennium Dome. Or was it au revoir?
fields.body:
Pierre-Yves Gerbeau yesterday said goodbye to the Millennium Dome. Or was it au revoir?

The Frenchman brought in by the government to run the Greenwich project announced that he was withdrawing a bid to take over the giant tent.

He pulled out of the race as ministers admitted that a buyer is unlikely to be selected before the end of the year; Mr Gerbeau claimed it could take as long as 18 months.

Mr Gerbeau's "very sad" decision risks triggering further embarrassment for Tony Blair over a dome fiasco that has already seen negotiations fail with two previous bidders.

"I want to get on with my life and I want to stay in Britain," said Mr Gerbeau.

"I want to go and find a business to run, anything that's got a strong brand and is pretty much in trouble. I'm a pretty good brand promoter and a fixer."

The favourite to take the dome off the government's hands is a consortium that in cludes the BBC, Madame Tussaud's and the Duke of Westminster's Grosvenor Estates property company.

But Mr Gerbeau, the former chief executive, could yet return as a member of another consortium as he seeks to retain the structure as an entertainment venture.

Mr Gerbeau's New Dome Partners group was backed by Ministry of Sound nightclub owner James Palumbo, a friend of ex-dome minister Peter Mandelson, but his bid was dogged by doubts over his ability to finance and operate the complex.

David James, the troubleshooter brought in after Mr Gerbeau to prevent it collapsing in a financial crisis, dismissed the Frenchman's bid as "puff" and suggested the dome would never be a success as an entertainment venue.

The Japanese bank Nomura pulled out of the race before Christmas, while in February ministers rejected an offer from the Legacy consortium now threatening to sue over its costs.

Mr Gerbeau, a former French ice hockey international, was arguably one of the few people involved with the dome to come out of it reasonably well, his bonhomie helping save the project after initial criticism that he had overplayed his previous position in Disneyland Paris.

He is still waiting to learn whether an estimated £45,000 bonus is to be paid, despite being promised that he would receive the money in February.

Mr Blair had promised the dome would be the "envy of the world" though Prince Charles, who never visited the site, dismissed it as a "monstrous blancmange".

It was budgeted to get 12m visitors in its year of operation. In the end it got 6.5m and Mr Gerbeau was to say later that the original figure should never have been pitched so high.

A spokesman for Lord Falconer, the minister handling the sale, said: "There is a lot of interest in the dome and English Partnerships has had around 100 expressions of interest.

"At the moment, bidding competition rules are being drawn up and they will be published in due course.

"Mr Gerbeau spoke about the bidding process taking as long as 18 months, but we hope that a winner will emerge during 2001."

The Tory culture spokesman, Peter Ainsworth, said: "Millions of pounds of national lottery money are being wasted every month but the government remains deathly silent."

fields.headline: Slaughter policy brings fresh problems
fields.standfirst:
Extended cull: disposal of up to a million carcasses puts pressure on system

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The slaughter of up to a million animals and, worse, the disposal of their carcasses without risk of further spreading foot and mouth infection is both a terrible task and a daunting logistical problem.
fields.body:
The slaughter of up to a million animals and, worse, the disposal of their carcasses without risk of further spreading foot and mouth infection is both a terrible task and a daunting logistical problem.

Jim Scudamore, the chief veterinary surgeon, estimated it would take three weeks to a month to clear the infected areas of Dumfries and Galloway in southern Scotland and Cumbria of all farm animals. Every animal inside each 3km exclusion zone will be destroyed, and where zones overlap and thousands of sheep and cattle roam, the landscape will be emptied of livestock.

Trained slaughtermen will today start killing healthy animals and will work their way through herds of cattle most susceptible to the disease. Priority will be given to killing and disposing of animals closest to existing outbreaks.

To cope with the vast numbers involved, the ministry is having to set up new ways to kill and dispose of animals. The army has been asked to help plan the logistics but not provide people to kill the animals; disposal of the carcasses is the main problem.

Up to now, the ministry has been burning most animals but this is proving time-consuming and thousands of tonnes of straw and coal have to be shifted to infected farms. A flock of sheep 1,000 strong requires a fire a kilometre long, 2,000 bales of straw and 300 tonnes of coal.

A second method, favoured during the 1967 epidemic, is to bury the carcasses. This is a relatively quick and easy operation which prevents the virus spreading. But it is not possible in many areas of the country where the ground water is pumped from wells. Water companies and the environment agency are consulted each time burying is suggested. Most schemes have been rejected.

Criticism of carcasses left lying in fields has already led the ministry to step up its efforts at quicker disposal of decomposing bodies. Rather than burn carcasses, lorries capable of being sealed are being hired to take them to rendering plants.

Boiled down

Vets are so nervous of spreading the disease that lorries are filled with water and tipped up to make sure there are no leaks. Last week, despite objection from farmers, a rendering plant was opened in Widnes, Cheshire. Its sole purpose is to boil down carcasses 24 hours a day, seven days a week.

The dead animals are chopped up and boiled down, leaving bonemeal and tallow - a form of hard fat. Though heat kills the virus, leaving the residue harmless, it is still being fed into incinerators to be certain.

But the Widnes incinerator cannot cope alone and yesterday a second plant began operation in Exeter to try to catch up with the backlog of dead animals in Devon. Yesterday, the ministry said it was negotiating with two more rendering plants, which it also hoped would work continuously.

Even so, after yesterday's announcement, these measures will be inadequate.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, acting on veterinary advice, wants all animals disposed of as quickly as possible. Priority will still be given to disposing of animals in new outbreaks but slaughtermen will systematically work their way through the rest.

Using lessons learned in the BSE crisis when thousands of apparently healthy animals had to be slaughtered and removed from the food chain, the ministry is to open a number of abattoirs to kill and freeze animals.

All abattoirs in the existing infected areas have been shut since the restrictions were imposed on movement of animals on February 23. Now they will be busy again killing healthy animals which will never reach the food chain.

Many abattoirs have large cold stores which will freeze the meat until there is capacity in rendering plants to dispose of them. If they become full, as they rapidly will, the ministry will hire further cold stores.

In Dumfries and Galloway alone, 200,000 animals are expected to be slaughtered under the clearance scheme - at least as many again will be killed in Cumbria.

Elsewhere, similar schemes will also be needed. In Devon, the slaughter of entire infected areas is not planned at present but to prevent the continued spread of the disease, inspections of all farm animals will take place every two days. If there is any sign of infection, all animals will be killed.

The entire stock that went through three markets, 21,000 at Longtown, near Carlisle, 8,000 in Welshpool and 3,300 in Northampton will be killed, although some have already been destroyed because they have been infected.

Any animals from anywhere in the country which have been moved into west Wales, mid and northern Scotland and East Anglia will be traced and slaughtered. This is not thought to be very many, otherwise these areas would have already developed some cases.

Healthy animals, mostly sheep, stranded away from home farms and unable to return to lamb, present another distressing problem. Estimates of numbers vary from 250,000 to 500,000. Yesterday, Mr Brown proposed a new licence scheme, to be carefully policed, which would enable some sheep to be moved to home farms provided they were not in infected areas or being moved from infected areas to disease free areas. Farmers will be able to apply to licences to move them over the weekend.

Farmers in parts of the country subject to movement bans, and faced with seeing many of their lambs die because sheep are left to give birth in exposed areas, can apply to the ministry to kill flocks on welfare grounds. They will be paid around 70% of the market value of the stock.

But the Widnes incinerator cannot cope alone and yesterday a second plant began operation in Exeter to try to catch up with the backlog of dead animals in Devon. Yesterday, the ministry said it was negotiating with two more rendering plants, which it also hoped would work continuously. Even so, after yesterday's announcement, these measures will be inadequate. Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, acting on veterinary advice, wants all animals disposed of as quickly as possible. Priority will still be given to disposing of animals in new outbreaks but slaughtermen will systematically work their way through the rest. Using lessons learned in the BSE crisis when thousands of apparently healthy animals had to be slaughtered and removed from the food chain, the ministry is to open a number of abattoirs to kill and freeze animals. All abattoirs in the existing infected areas have been shut since the restrictions were imposed on movement of animals on February 23. Now they will be busy again killing healthy animals which will never reach the food chain. Many abattoirs have large cold stores which will freeze the meat until there is capacity in rendering plants to dispose of them. If they become full, as they rapidly will, the ministry will hire further cold stores. In Dumfries and Galloway alone, 200,000 animals are expected to be slaughtered under the clearance scheme - at least as many again will be killed in Cumbria. Elsewhere, similar schemes will also be needed. In Devon, the slaughter of entire infected areas is not planned at present but to prevent the continued spread of the disease, inspections of all farm animals will take place every two days. If there is any sign of infection, all animals will be killed. The entire stock that went through three markets, 21,000 at Longtown, near Carlisle, 8,000 in Welshpool and 3,300 in Northampton will be killed, although some have already been destroyed because they have been infected. Any animals from anywhere in the country which have been moved into west Wales, mid and northern Scotland and East Anglia will be traced and slaughtered. This is not thought to be very many, otherwise these areas would have already developed some cases. Healthy animals, mostly sheep, stranded away from home farms and unable to return to lamb, present another distressing problem. Estimates of numbers vary from 250,000 to 500,000. Yesterday, Mr Brown proposed a new licence scheme, to be carefully policed, which would enable some sheep to be moved to home farms provided they were not in infected areas or being moved from infected areas to disease free areas. Farmers will be able to apply to licences to move them over the weekend. Farmers in parts of the country subject to movement bans, and faced with seeing many of their lambs die because sheep are left to give birth in exposed areas, can apply to the ministry to kill flocks on welfare grounds. They will be paid around 70% of the market value of the stock. What's going on? fields.headline: NHS 'must act to reduce suicides'
fields.standfirst:
17% of suicides by people with mental health could have been prevented


Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: About 1,300 suicides by psychiatric patients over the last five years could have been prevented by better NHS care, the government's mental health tsar said yesterday.
fields.body:
About 1,300 suicides by psychiatric patients over the last five years could have been prevented by better NHS care, the government's mental health tsar said yesterday.

A confidential inquiry into suicides by people with mental illness found 17% of the deaths since 1996 were preventable. The risk could have been reduced in most other cases by closer supervision, said Louis Appleby, professor of psychiatry at Manchester university.

About six homicides by psychiatric patients could be prevented each year, but most perpetrators did not have the kind of illnesses that were easily treated, he said.

The report added weight to criticism from mental health campaigners that "care in the community" services do not offer the mentally ill the help they need outside hospital.

Prof Appleby said: "These findings emphasise the challenge facing mental health services. Around 40% of patient suicides happen during or soon after in-patient care and we should make the prevention of these deaths a priority."

His recommendations included reforming in-patient wards to make it less easy for people to hang themselves - the most common method of suicide by psychiatric patients.

The report also called for a follow-up assessment for all high risk patients within a week of being discharged from hospital and limiting their supplies of medication to reduce the risk of an overdose.

The study found 15% of suicides were in-patients and 23% committed suicide within three months of hospital discharge. The highest risk was in the first two weeks of leaving hospital.

John Hutton, the health minister, said the report would be used by officials preparing a national suicide prevention strategy. "We are making mental health services safer - for patients, those who work in mental health services, patients' families and the public," he said.

Hospitals were being asked to remove non-collapsible bed frames and shower rails in psychiatric wards within 12 months to reduce the suicide risk. Care orders in the community would ensure people continued to comply with treat- ment and cut reduce suicides by 32% a year.

Cliff Prior, chief executive of the National Schizophrenia Fellowship, said: "Deaths in railway crashes are rightly recognised as preventable, but too often suicides involving people with mental illness are seen as inevitable."

webTitle: New battle for a family under siege

fields.headline: New battle for a family under siege
fields.standfirst:
Isolation: Farm turned fortress waits and hopes

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The Wells family started rearing sheep in Milton Lilbourne not long after William Cobbett spurred his pony across the Wiltshire Downs and approvingly noted the rich grassland in his great political tract, the Rural Rides.
fields.body:
The Wells family started rearing sheep in Milton Lilbourne not long after William Cobbett spurred his pony across the Wiltshire Downs and approvingly noted the rich grassland in his great political tract, the Rural Rides.

But a telephone call at any time could end the four generations of patient lambing and over-wintering at Totteridge farm, where precautions on the scale of a fortress could collapse in the face of the government's draconian new precautions.

"It's like the wartime - which I remember well," said David Wells, 67, whose 265 acres form the centre of an island surrounded by three big dairy farms, with foot and mouth's front line less than 10 miles away as the crow flies.

"I sit here looking out of the window and hoping for a great clap of thunder which'll sweep the wretched thing away."

If ministry vets decide that their 'firebreak barriers' against the infection have got to be widened the phone call might come, and 120 healthy lambs which have lived for less than half a year will be shot. So will their ewes, whose calls - all the same to the human ear but distinctive to the lambs - are now muffled inside Totteridge's barns.

Remembering his experiences in the 1967 outbreak - "It came very close that time," he says - Mr Wells is looking after the 150 adult flock in one shed, the lambs in another and the rams out in the fields. On this, and on a pastoral regime as strict as in an ebola ward, depend his hopes of the fifth generation - his son Anthony - taking over the Totteridge sheep when he retires.

"We've done all that we can," said Mr Wells, taking a break in the kitchen with his wife Pat and a helper, Clare Giles, who has joined the besieged, mellow stone buildings to help the isolation system work. She looks after the horses while Mr Wells feeds seven cows on an outstation of the farm and his wife takes care of the sheep.

Dividing the tasks by animal is the family's best hope of keeping the work of more than a century going, reinforced by strict precautions for anyone approaching the little dip beneath the downs. Post is left in a barrel and the very few visitors not only drive across two belts of disinfectant-soused straw but stand in a bath of the chemical and change into new clothes at the farmhouse.

"If it's all for nothing, and they have to cull animals which are healthy but at 'too high risk', we'll accept it," said Mr Wells wearily, hoping that the flock and his little dairy herd will be spared, but acknowledging the wider good.

"We know it's essential that animals are culled to deal with foot and mouth. It is the only way. Vaccination would just be covering up the fact that we'd accepted the disease is here to stay. It has to be wiped out."

Anthony Wells still wants to inherit Totteridge, a land-holding which was there when King Alfred manoeuvred around Salisbury Plain against the Danes (and had his own disaster nearby, involving cakes). Slaughter or not, his father still hopes for the best, partly thanks to diversification into horse-stabling and carriage-riding - another part of the business which is temporarily paralysed.

"Other farmers are talking of abandoning animals and going back to cereal," he said, "and that'll mean lower quality imported meat in the shops and the end of a lot of high standards which we've maybe come to take for granted."

If Cobbett rode down again from the high land, with his notebook and power of invective against bad practice, he would find even more to absorb him than he did in 1830.

webTitle: MI5 chief speaks of crime fighting role

fields.headline: MI5 chief speaks of crime fighting role
fields.trailText: Intelligence supplied by MI5 is being used increasingly in criminal trials, Sir Stephen Lander, the head of the agency, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Intelligence supplied by MI5 is being used increasingly in criminal trials, Sir Stephen Lander, the head of the agency, said yesterday.

Speaking publicly for the first time since taking over from Dame Stella Rimington in 1996, he told a London conference: "Every week crown counsel are reading our files."

MI5 intelligence had been used in 12 court cases this year, compared to no more than four annually less than 10 years ago, and MI5 now employed seven lawyers instead of one.

The agency has a growing role in targeting serious and organised crime, described by Charles Clarke, the Home Office minister, yesterday as "multinational organisations" making "billions of pounds worth of profits". However, MI5 officers would remain anonymous when giving evidence, insisted Sir Stephen.

He and Mr Clarke were addressing a conference sponsored by the Royal United Services Institute and the Security and Intelligence Studies Group, a body consisting mainly of academics.

David Shayler, the renegade former MI5 officer, was barred from the conference. "The whole thing is cowardly, they can't take the rough and tumble of debate," he said outside in Whitehall.

Security sources at the conference later made it clear they were strongly opposed to Dame Stella's decision to publish he r memoirs but acknowledged they could not stop her.

fields.headline: £7.5m appeal to buy 'noble' Michelangelo'
fields.standfirst:
£500,000 starts drive by Scottish galleries to keep Renaissance master's drawing in Britain


Special report: artist in residence
fields.trailText: The biggest appeal since the Three Graces was launched yesterday to stop a Michelangelo drawing, potentially the most expensive piece of paper in the world, going abroad.
fields.body:
The biggest appeal since the Three Graces was launched yesterday to stop a Michelangelo drawing, potentially the most expensive piece of paper in the world, going abroad.

The drawing, one of three by the Renaissance master in private hands, was found in a scrapbook that Simon Howard kept next to his extensive collection of Eric Clapton CDs in the private wing of Castle Howard, the vast family pile in North Yorkshire used for the TV adaptation of Brideshead Revisited.

Unless £7.5m can be raised in a few months, the 10in by 6in three-quarter length drawing of a woman in mourning garb will almost certainly go abroad - where it might even break the world record of £8.1m set by Michelangelo's Study for the Risen Christ.

Yesterday the National Art Collections Fund pledged £500,000 towards a campaign led by the National Galleries of Scotland to keep the drawing in Britain - its biggest grant ever for acquiring a drawing. It believes it is important that it goes to a Scottish gallery because there is no Michelangelo in any gallery north of Cambridge.

Sir Nicholas Goodison, the fund's chairman, took the highly unusual step of going public with the gift, in order to prompt other possible donors.

"A campaign such as this requires a rapid response," he said. "The fund's £500,000 gift, one of the largest in our 98-year history, reflects our desire to see this noble and exquisite drawing saved for Scotland."

A large portion of the asking price needs to be raised in the next five weeks for the bid to succeed.

The next step would be to ask the government to place a bar on the export of the drawing to give more time, though that could not happen until it was formally sold.

The fund contributed a similar amount to start the £7.6m appeal to keep Canova's Three Graces, the most expensive statue in the world, seven years ago.

The drawing's discovery in October was described by the auctioneers Sotheby's as "the most significant Michelangelo find in living memory; like finding part of the Holy Grail".

One of its specialists, Julien Stock, chanced on it while flicking through the scrapbook of Old Master drawings for a routine insurance evaluation.

"What I thought when I first saw the drawing is unprintable," he said. "I immediately realised this was a major drawing by Michelangelo - and no one had any idea it was here."

The drawing is thought to have been bought by Henry Howard, 4th Earl of Carlisle, at a London auction in 1747. However, neither he nor anyone else who saw it during the next 250 years realised that it was by Michelangelo.

When Mr Stock went through the album into which it had been pasted, he was struck by its superb quality. Tests on the ink and paper were carried out before it was confirmed as a Michelangelo, although its precise dating is unclear.

Mr Howard, 44, decided to sell partly because it would be prohibitively expensive to insure the drawing.

"Clearly this is a drawing of importance which has been accepted by all the experts as being by Michelangelo, and as such it should be on display in a national gallery or museum where everyone can enjoy it," he said.

The money raised by the sale will also help maintain Castle Howard and its 10,000 acre estate. Four years ago the family sold a painting by the Italian artist Il Guercino for £2m.

Strictly speaking the drawing belongs not to Mr Howard but to the trustees of his late father, Lord Howard of Henderskelfe, who died in 1983 aged 64.

webTitle: Milosevic allies linked to drug trafficking

fields.headline: Milosevic ally linked to heroin stash
fields.standfirst:
Serbian police suspect Milosevic allies of drug trafficking

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Key figures in the regime of former Yugoslav president Slobadan Milosevic kept heroin worth tens of millions of pounds in banks in Belgrade
fields.body:
Key figures in the regime of the former Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic kept high-grade heroin worth tens of millions of pounds in bank vaults in Belgrade for several years, according to the Serbian police, who suspect that they were engaged in trafficking.

Following a tip-off from an unnamed source, a team of police officers raided a city centre bank last week and found more than 600kg of 93% pure heroin in the safe deposit boxes.

The drugs have a street value of about £40m in western Europe.

The Serbian interior minister, Dusan Mihailovic, who exhibited the sealed bricks of heroin before overseeing their burning in furnaces outside Belgrade, said they had been seized from smugglers by Mr Milosevic's customs officers.

He said the contract for the bank safe had been taken out by the old regime's state security service.

Rade Markovic, a key Milosevic henchman and former state security chief, is in custody awaiting murder charges. Mihalj Kertes, another senior aide to Mr Milosevic throughout his 13-year rule, was the head of the customs service until Serbia's street revolution last October toppled Mr Milosevic.

Police sources told a Belgrade newspaper yesterday that a small amount of heroin identical to that discovered last week was found in Mr Kertes's office after Mr Milosevic was overthrown.

While the heavily criminal character of the Milosevic regime has long been common knowledge, the drugs disclosure provides evidence of the interaction between Belgrade politics and the underworld in the past 10 years.

While Mr Milosevic, in his final year in power, sought to make propaganda out of the fact that Kosovan and Albanian mafias were playing an increasing role in the European drugs rackets, Serbian investigators examining the activities of the old regime are concluding that senior government figures were implicated in organised crime.

In a separate case, a former Yugoslav diplomat went on trial in Belgrade on Wednesday on charges of smuggling 33kg of cocaine from Latin America.

On Sunday evening a prominent underworld figure, Milan Djordjevic, died in Belgrade in a hail of automatic gunfire. Nicknamed Sweetie, he was a close associate of the late warlord and gangster Arkan.

Both men had close connections with the Milosevic regime and could have provided damaging evidence to the new authorities of the corruption and criminality rampant under Mr Milosevic.

The heroin saga goes back to 1997 when Yugoslav customs officers impounded 625kg of heroin crossing the Bulgarian border in two lorries, one Slovene, the other Bulgarian.

Legally, the drugs haul should have been publicised, the public prosecutor's office given control of the shipment and the drugs burned.

But Mr Kertes's customs office gave the heroin to Mr Markovic's state security department, which lodged it in the bank vault.

Milos Vasic, an investigative reporter at the weekly magazine Vreme, described the heroin disclosure as the biggest scandal to emerge in Belgrade since last October, and demanded to know whether the Milosevic regime was supplying heroin to Serbian youth or the drug addicts of western Europe.

Mr Kertes's relationship with Mr Milosevic goes back to the 1980s, when he organised mass demonstrations in his support as Serbia's new strongman.

As a senior police official he later played a central role in supplying arms and funds to Serb rebels in Croatia and Bosnia in the run-up to the wars of 1991-95.

And as the head of the customs service, he orchestrated the smuggling and arms-trade rackets devised to beat the United Nations sanc tions imposed on Belgrade in 1992.

When Serbia's democratic rulers evicted Mr Kertes from his office last October, they found automatic weapons, explosives and 3m German marks in cash.

webTitle: EU take drug war into Balkans

fields.headline: Taskforce tries to stop traffickers trucking 200,000 Chinese into EU
fields.standfirst:
Jack Straw pledge to send police and immigration officers to help Croatia and Bosnia

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: The European Union yesterday took its war against people-traffickers into the Balkans from where thousands of illegal immigrants are smuggled into western Europe.
fields.body:
The European Union yesterday took its war against people-traffickers into the Balkans from where thousands of illegal immigrants are smuggled into western Europe.

Justice and interior ministers, including Britain's home secretary, Jack Straw, pledged in Brussels to send 30 police and immigration officers to help Croatia and Bosnia control their own porous borders and stop the racketeering.

According to an internal EU report, up to 200,000 Chinese could be in the former Yugoslavia waiting to be smuggled into the EU - using similar routes to the one used by the 58 Chinese who suffocated to death in a truck bound for Dover last summer.

Britain pledged 10 officers, the largest contribution of any member state, and a reflection of the priority that the Blair government now attaches to immigration and asylum.

"The Balkans are the single most important source of illegal immigration into western Europe," Mr Straw told fellow ministers. "If we can close it off or restrict it we are on the way to winning the battle."

But having responded to an Anglo-Italian initiative to send EU personnel to the front line, ministers found it harder to agree upon common penalties for trafficking.

Britain has the toughest maximum sentence of 10 years, while other countries impose terms of up to four years.

Mr Straw was criticised for leading an effort to reach agreement with the EU's bigger states, but excluding Sweden, the current holder of the rotating presidency.

Mr Straw met colleagues from Germany, France, Italy and Spain in London last week, angering those who want to see EU-wide action, not individual initiatives by some member states.

"This kind of carve-up is an insult to the Swedish presidency and will damage rela tions between the big and smaller EU players," protested the Liberal Democrat MEP Graham Watson. "Why is Jack Straw looking for a back road for policy coordination when the Treaty of Amsterdam has given him a motorway?"

Ministers also agreed that a Swedish-led team should go to Belgrade and Sarajevo, the Serbian and Bosnian capitals respectively, later this month to press for more cooperation from governments there.

The 30 police and immigration officers from Britain, Italy, Germany, Denmark, the Netherlands and Austria will advise and train their counterparts in checking visa validity and finding forged passports.

In a related move, Britain also proposed that convicted drug traffickers in Europe should have their passports confiscated and be banned from travelling.

Britain's minister for immigration, Barbara Roche, outlined a package which includes tough penalties for drug traffickers - a minimum of seven years in jail for a third conviction. It also involves working to improve the anti-drug campaigns of states wanting to join the EU and a "scoreboard" approach to make sure that the EU Drugs Action Plan stays on track.

Immigration, asylum and criminal and judicial matters - once national concerns - are now a high priority.

Last month more than 900 Iraqi Kurds were shipwrecked on the French Riviera, fuelling demands for tighter controls.

Dozens of aspiring immigrants drown off Italy and Spain each year crossing from Albania or Morocco. Immigrants are often forced into prostitution or sweated labour to pay debts to traffickers.

Today the EU ministers will discuss how to coordinate the fight against trafficking with ministers from the 12 candidate countries in eastern and southern Europe, which also suffer from weak external border controls.

webTitle: Julia Roberts: Hollywood's most successful actress

fields.headline: So, Julia, what will you say if you win?
fields.standfirst: At $20m a movie, Julia Roberts has long been Hollywood's most successful actress. But could this be the year she finally wins the recognition of the Academy?  Bob Longino  reports
fields.trailText: At $20m a movie, Julia Roberts has long been Hollywood's most successful actress. But could this be the year she finally wins the recognition of the Academy? Bob Longino reports
fields.body:
Julia Roberts, dressed for comfort in jeans and a suede and leather jacket, strides into a hotel room five weeks before Oscar night, taking her seat at the head of a banquet table lined with nearly a dozen waiting reporters. Her cheeks give off a soft reddish glow. Her demeanour is the opposite of Erin Brockovich, the headstrong, foul-mouthed upstart role that made Roberts the clear favourite to win the best actress award on March 25. She seems more like Mary Reilly, the mousy, English waif she played in 1996 who found herself face to face with Dr Jekyll's Mr Hyde.

Somewhere in this room, high up in LA's Regent Beverly Wilshire, some unsuspecting journalist is going to ask the inevitable question. Roberts is Hollywood's premier actress and, at 33, she has weathered more than a dozen years of prying and dumb press questions.

She's here promoting The Mexican, her new $35m DreamWorks action comedy with Brad Pitt and James Gandolfini, and she explains how she tries to avoid repeating herself in back-to-back movies. Then one of those questions comes. It always does. Can she explain the differences, a Latino reporter wants to know, between The Mexican and the movie she's filming now, America's Sweethearts? "Well, you know," Roberts replies quickly, lowering her head and then looking up with focused brown eyes. "The Mexican. Mexican. America's Sweethearts. American. So right there I'm going down the right path."

Roberts has never exactly enjoyed a great relationship with the media. In an episode of The Simpsons, Homer finds himself trapped in a cinema showing a fake Julia Roberts movie entitled Love is Nice, and loathing every minute of it. And there are heaps of magazines sporting glorious, glossy photos of her in glorious, glossy fashions and replete with words like "hugely famous" and wondering "ain't her life grand?" But here, long before Roberts enters, some of the reporters are labelling her "catty". Even mean. No one asks what her responses might be if she was asked more thought-provoking questions.

That messy private life has fuelled a lot of the past press attention she clearly despises. Breaking her engagement to Kiefer Sutherland. Anxiety in the park with Jason Patric. Marrying and then divorcing Lyle Lovett. Living with Liam Neeson. Dating Daniel Day-Lewis. That friendship with Matthew Perry.

A German interviewer at the Brockovich press junket asked: "Did that [performance as Brockovich, a mother of three] make you think of children, imagine yourself as a single mother?" Roberts replied: "Doing Pretty Woman didn't make me want to hit the streets! It's as if people are wanting me to procreate . . . This is something I ponder when I go home at night all weary. Why do people keep checking if I'm ovulating?"

Ask a Julia Roberts fan which of her nearly 30 film performances is her best work and, quite often, you'll hear Pretty Woman or My Best Friend's Wedding. Ask Roberts and she'll name neither. "I guess specifically I could find the good and bad in all the movies," she has said. "But I suppose Erin Brockovich, just in the most general sense, I'm the best in. It was the most challenging, the most well-rounded, had the widest scope of a person to play."

Brockovich herself says that the film's opening-scene car wreck in LA, a startling, grab-the-moviegoer's-gut crash, actually happened in Las Vegas. It set in motion an odd turn of events that ultimately led to the filming of her story and five Oscar nominations, including Roberts's high-profile race for an award after 10 years without an Academy nomination.

Following the wreck, Brockovich went to Los Angeles chiropractor Pamela DuMond. DuMond related the story to another client, Carla Santos Shamberg. She happens to be married to Michael Shamberg. He happens to be a producing partner with Danny DeVito. "I was pitching Michael something every day of my life," Shamberg says. "On that day I told him I found something." Shamberg, who eventually became Brockovich's executive producer, knew that she wanted Roberts to play Brockovich. Her husband's thoughts were, she says: "I don't get [the story] and you won't get Julia Roberts." Roberts not only "got" the story but, after reading the script, asked for the part. She also asked for $20m, a salary that only top male actors had commanded. "I was so happy to give this girl $20m," Shamberg says. "Why shouldn't she make what the boys make?"

In The Mexican, Roberts plays the high-strung, in-your-face girlfriend of Brad Pitt, sent by thugs south of the border to recover a legendary handmade pistol. Roberts's performance often crackles with the same ferocity as the movie's frequent gunfire.

With gun in hand, and a willingness to pull the trigger, Roberts is shedding her perceived Melanie Wilkes image for a fully-fledged Scarlett O'Hara. "It was really original," she says of the script. "Introduce two people in a relationship and then half a minute later separate them - put them in two different countries, in fact." Roberts's co-stars praise her and her work ethic. "She's such a laugh, a charm, a wit," Pitt says. "I liked putting us into a run-and-gun movie."

Exactly 24 hours after her west coast press interviews, Roberts is striding across the New York stage of David Letterman's chat show. It's one more interview, and Roberts knows that the Late Show host is going to try to rattle her, as she says, "in the name of fun". He starts with the Oscars. "Uh, well, yeah, yeah," Roberts says, shifting uncomfortably. "You know what it is? I'm a grown-up person now. So on that level, it has a different kind of effect on me."

Letterman keeps on. "This is what I find myself thinking - and I'm so pleased you asked about the Oscars," she says. "It doesn't rattle my nerves at all. Everybody talks about, you know, uh, 'Do you want to win?' 'What will you say if you win?' And really that bypasses to me a huge step - the excitement and 12-year-old giddiness of, 'I got nominated for an Oscar!' So that's what I'm doing for the next five weeks."

Letterman keeps on, wondering if, "as a professional", she shouldn't be ready with an Oscar speech? Finally, Roberts musters up her most revelatory statement. Words from a woman who's risen to the top of her field, matured in front of our eyes. Words that, perhaps better than most, reflect what she is like now on-screen and off. "Yes," she says. "However, I think one must be hopeful but expect to remain seated."

And - who knows - if she does win an Oscar, perhaps even Homer Simpson will become a Julia Roberts fan.

© New York Times. Erin Brockovich is re-released next Friday. The Mexican is released on April 27.

webTitle: Takeshi Kitano on his new LA-based film

fields.headline: Blood Brother
fields.standfirst: Takeshi Kitano went to America with one objective - to take revenge on Hollywood for all those 'inscrutable' Japanese bit parts.  Duncan Campbell  meets the master of elegant ultra-violence on the set of his first LA-based film
fields.trailText: Takeshi Kitano went to America with one objective - to take revenge on Hollywood for all those 'inscrutable' Japanese bit parts. Duncan Campbell meets the master of elegant ultra-violence on the set of his first LA-based film
fields.body:
On the coast between Santa Monica and Malibu is Pacific Palisades, where a Methodist group formed a colony in the 1920s "for moral and cultural betterment", and where artists and writers lived bohemian-style in the 1940s. Now it's a wealthy white suburb of Los Angeles. Most of the well-tended lawns carry an "armed response" sign, a genial death threat to warn off any potential intruders. Little do the residents realise on this sunny Saturday morning that the stocky, debonair man pacing their streets is the embodiment of armed response at its most spectacular.

But Yamamoto is just a character in a film. Brother, which tells the story of a yakuza (a gangster) transported to the United States, is the first foreign venture for one of Japan's most celebrated film-makers - Takeshi Kitano, who has also cast himself in the main role. Kitano is rehearsing a brief scene with American actor Omar Epps. Recently seen on screen in Spike Lee's Love and Basketball, The Wood and Breakfast of Champions, Epps is riding a bicycle. This is significant: neither black people nor cyclists are a common sight around these parts. But then, neither are Japanese film-makers - although film production in general is nothing to get excited about. The scene in question is taking place outside a villa which represents the mobster's home. A knife flashes, someone lies dead - it's all over with the minimum of fuss. Kitano works with the speed and efficiency of a contract killer.

That was a year ago. After seven weeks of shooting and a few more of editing, Brother is now complete and Kitano is back in LA to talk about this, his ninth film. His first, Violent Cop, was made in 1989, although it was not released in the UK until 1993. At that point, he was best known in Europe for playing a PoW camp guard in Merry Christmas, Mr Lawrence, but since then has garnered a fanatical western following for elegantly violent films such as Hana-Bi (Fireworks), which won the Golden Lion at the Venice film festival in 1997, and the earlier Sonatine.

On the other hand, the 53-year-old Kitano remains hugely famous in Japan as Beat Takeshi, a stand-up comedian and television personality with seven shows a week. Did he find that humour translated well between cultures? "I used to think that because of the language I might not be able to understand, but I checked out first of all the ancient comic actors like Charlie Chaplin, Buster Keaton and the Marx brothers, and then your Mr Bean, and I get the joke. In the 1980s, I used to watch Eddie Murphy [doing stand-up on film] and I found that the subject matter was the same as I used to do in the 1970s in my routine."

Today he is wearing a black crew-neck jersey and smoking Frontier cigarettes in impressive defiance of the ubiquitous LA nicotine police. Speaking through an interpreter, he tells me: "When I went to film festivals in Europe and elsewhere, many journalists asked me about the yakuza. I was impressed by how intrigued they were, so I thought, why not make a film about an old-fashioned yakuza and show it to them? Then I thought it would make a greater contrast to set the story outside Japan. His behaviour would have a greater impact, so I had the idea of the yakuza guy going to a foreign country. I happened to write down Los Angeles in the script but without any real significance."

Then five years ago, at the Toronto film festival, Kitano was having dinner with the British producer Jeremy Thomas (The Last Emperor, The Sheltering Sky, The Hit, Crash, Bad Timing), who produced Merry Christmas, Mr Lawrence in 1983. By chance, Thomas asked Kitano if he was interested in making a film outside Japan.

The resulting script involves a yakuza gangster, Yamamoto, who is forced to leave Tokyo and travels to LA to meet up with his half-brother Ken (Claude Maki), who is involved in the LA drug world along with Denny (Omar Epps). Yamamoto soon finds himself back in the violent world of gang warfare, taking on LA gangsters of varying ethnic backgrounds. What follows is strictly not for the squeamish: with everything from auto-disembowelment to graphic yakuza-style finger amputation to rat-tat-tat desert massacres, there is enough gore to make Reservoir Dogs look like chihuahuas. Not for nothing does Quentin Tarantino's Rolling Thunder Pictures distribute Kitano's work on video in America, and Tarantino lists Sonatine as one of his five favourite films.

Kitano says that he thinks the yakuza do operate in LA but more surreptitiously than in Japan. He says he was wary of making a crime film in a different culture. "I did not want to make the same mistake as American films which have a yakuza character in them. They are so untrue compared to the reality and as a Japanese person I just have to laugh at the way they are depicted. I was careful because I did not have much knowledge of American gangsters so I decided to treat them as symbolic, not as individual characters. What I did was depersonalise them."

When Yamamoto and his half- brother collide with American characters, they sometimes provoke predictable responses. One character tells Yamamoto: "You Japanese are so inscrutable," and another talks about "fucking Jap assholes". The Japanese, he says, are still often portrayed in the west as stereotypes. "When people include Japanese characters in films, they are usually the sidekicks of the main character and they use kung fu - which is Chinese - and are depicted in an inaccurate fashion. So I thought, 'If we are going to be treated like that anyway, why not make one film in which the Japanese character was more brutal - and more cool - than any of the American characters?' That was part of my motivation."

Taiwanese director Ang Lee had just had his film, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, nominated for 10 Oscars when we spoke - a record for a foreign-language film. That has a good side to it because it creates a professionalism amongst the crew. They are not sentimental - they don't look on the crew as a family. The violence was not a major problem, he says. "The initial promise from Jeremy Thomas was that I could make the film however I wanted and I was not given any pressure. I'm thinking of taking a break from violence for a while."

Brother is released on March 23.
fields.bodyText: On the coast between Santa Monica and Malibu is Pacific Palisades, where a Methodist group formed a colony in the 1920s "for moral and cultural betterment", and where artists and writers lived bohemian-style in the 1940s. Now it's a wealthy white suburb of Los Angeles. Most of the well-tended lawns carry an "armed response" sign, a genial death threat to warn off any potential intruders. Little do the residents realise on this sunny Saturday morning that the stocky, debonair man pacing their streets is the embodiment of armed response at its most spectacular. But Yamamoto is just a character in a film. Brother, which tells the story of a yakuza (a gangster) transported to the United States, is the first foreign venture for one of Japan's most celebrated film-makers - Takeshi Kitano, who has also cast himself in the main role. Kitano is rehearsing a brief scene with American actor Omar Epps. Recently seen on screen in Spike Lee's Love and Basketball, The Wood and Breakfast of Champions, Epps is riding a bicycle. This is significant: neither black people nor cyclists are a common sight around these parts. But then, neither are Japanese film-makers - although film production in general is nothing to get excited about. The scene in question is taking place outside a villa which represents the mobster's home. A knife flashes, someone lies dead - it's all over with the minimum of fuss. Kitano works with the speed and efficiency of a contract killer. That was a year ago. After seven weeks of shooting and a few more of editing, Brother is now complete and Kitano is back in LA to talk about this, his ninth film. His first, Violent Cop, was made in 1989, although it was not released in the UK until 1993. At that point, he was best known in Europe for playing a PoW camp guard in Merry Christmas, Mr Lawrence, but since then has garnered a fanatical western following for elegantly violent films such as Hana-Bi (Fireworks), which won the Golden Lion at the Venice film festival in 1997, and the earlier Sonatine. On the other hand, the 53-year-old Kitano remains hugely famous in Japan as Beat Takeshi, a stand-up comedian and television personality with seven shows a week. Did he find that humour translated well between cultures? "I used to think that because of the language I might not be able to understand, but I checked out first of all the ancient comic actors like Charlie Chaplin, Buster Keaton and the Marx brothers, and then your Mr Bean, and I get the joke. In the 1980s, I used to watch Eddie Murphy [doing stand-up on film] and I found that the subject matter was the same as I used to do in the 1970s in my routine." Today he is wearing a black crew-neck jersey and smoking Frontier cigarettes in impressive defiance of the ubiquitous LA nicotine police. Speaking through an interpreter, he tells me: "When I went to film festivals in Europe and elsewhere, many journalists asked me about the yakuza. I was impressed by how intrigued they were, so I thought, why not make a film about an old-fashioned yakuza and show it to them? Then I thought it would make a greater contrast to set the story outside Japan. His behaviour would have a greater impact, so I had the idea of the yakuza guy going to a foreign country. I happened to write down Los Angeles in the script but without any real significance." Then five years ago, at the Toronto film festival, Kitano was having dinner with the British producer Jeremy Thomas (The Last Emperor, The Sheltering Sky, The Hit, Crash, Bad Timing), who produced Merry Christmas, Mr Lawrence in 1983. By chance, Thomas asked Kitano if he was interested in making a film outside Japan. The resulting script involves a yakuza gangster, Yamamoto, who is forced to leave Tokyo and travels to LA to meet up with his half-brother Ken (Claude Maki), who is involved in the LA drug world along with Denny (Omar Epps). Yamamoto soon finds himself back in the violent world of gang warfare, taking on LA gangsters of varying ethnic backgrounds. What follows is strictly not for the squeamish: with everything from auto-disembowelment to graphic yakuza-style finger amputation to rat-tat-tat desert massacres, there is enough gore to make Reservoir Dogs look like chihuahuas. Not for nothing does Quentin Tarantino's Rolling Thunder Pictures distribute Kitano's work on video in America, and Tarantino lists Sonatine as one of his five favourite films. Kitano says that he thinks the yakuza do operate in LA but more surreptitiously than in Japan. He says he was wary of making a crime film in a different culture. "I did not want to make the same mistake as American films which have a yakuza character in them. They are so untrue compared to the reality and as a Japanese person I just have to laugh at the way they are depicted. I was careful because I did not have much knowledge of American gangsters so I decided to treat them as symbolic, not as individual characters. What I did was depersonalise them." When Yamamoto and his half- brother collide with American characters, they sometimes provoke predictable responses. One character tells Yamamoto: "You Japanese are so inscrutable," and another talks about "fucking Jap assholes". The Japanese, he says, are still often portrayed in the west as stereotypes. "When people include Japanese characters in films, they are usually the sidekicks of the main character and they use kung fu - which is Chinese - and are depicted in an inaccurate fashion.
